DOC.HEAD: Americans, Other Evacuees Speak of Waning Kuwaiti Resistance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with interviews, ADD higher estimate of Canadians, other details, byline; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jetliner landed at Gatwick airport late Friday with more than 350 evacuees, mostly American women and children, who told of dwindling opposition by Kuwaiti resistance fighters. Galina Suliman, a passenger from San Francisco, said Kuwaiti groups were being systematically put down by the Iraqis. American Andrea Hanson, who arrived on the U.S.-chartered Boeing 747 with her 5-year-old son Zach, said Kuwaiti resistance groups did not have enough weapons to fight the Iraqis. A British woman on the flight relayed one report of a group of 16 Kuwaitis being gunned down in the street by an Iraqi soldier as they sat around chatting. The British domestic news agency Press Association said there were believed to be 275 Americans on board, 43 Canadians, 26 Britons, six Japanese, six Australians, two West Germans and an unspecified number of Indians, Syrians and Filipinos. However, there was confusion about precise numbers. Press Association initially reported 39 Canadians were aboard. An official at the U.S. Embassy in London said of the Americans on the fight: ``We haven't got a final head count. We are still processing.'' An airport official speaking on condition of anonymity said the passengers included some men. The plane left Baghdad on Friday afternoon and landed at Gatwick 25 miles south of London about 11:30 p.m. The airport official said 30 people due to fly to Gatwick had instead been detained in Baghdad because they could not clear Iraqi exit formalities in time. She did not give their nationalities. Sky News television said the women and children on the plane are believed to have been among the last who expressed a wish to leave behind their husbands and fathers in Kuwait. The Iraqis have said they are keeping men as hostages to deter any foreign attack on Iraq. The Americans who arrived Friday were booked into hotels in and around Gatwick for the night. They were due to leave for Baltimore-Washington International airport on Saturday afternoon. The 26-year-old British woman, who declined to gave her name for fear it might jeopardize her husband left behind in Kuwait, said the 16 Kuwaitis had been shot on a road near Kuwait City. ``They were just sitting around chatting. We didn't talk about it too much. It had a very bad effect (on morale).'' She added: ``The Iraqis are starting to seal areas. They are looking for weapons. They are looking for foreigners.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the tiny, oil-rich neighbor. The British woman said people living in Kuwait were being restricted in what they could buy but Iraqi soldiers were going into stores and taking all they wanted. Iraqis were also seizing jeeps and trucks, she said. Ms. Hanson said that in recent days, Iraqi authorities had succeeded in partly quelling Kuwaiti resistance. ``Resistance is very haphazard. The Iraqis are very successful at putting them down. They haven't got enough people. They haven't got enough weapons,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: State Lawmaker's Son Convicted in Bow-and-Arrow Slaying of Mother
DOC.TEXT: A state lawmaker's 20-year-old son was convicted Friday of intentionally killing his mother with a bow and arrow as jurors rejected his claim the death was accidental. Chad Goetsch, who testified that the hunting arrow slipped when his mother's voice startled him, showed no emotion when the verdict was read. He is the adopted son of state Rep. Robert Goetsch, who testified against him. The jury deliberated 4{ hours before finding Goetsch guilty of first-degree intentional homicide. He was also found guilty of endangering safety for injuries suffered by his father in a struggle. Circuit Judge Daniel Klossner scheduled sentencing for Oct. 29. Goetsch faces a mandatory life term for the intentional homicide conviction. The second charge arose from allegations he aimed another arrow at his father and fought with him after shooting his 51-year-old mother, Carolyn. The arrow pierced his mother's heart. The killing took place after Goetsch arrived at the family home in Oak Grove early Nov. 8 from his college residence. The elder Goetsch had testified that his son had threatened the mother. ``We talked about buying a gun,'' he said. ``She started insisting on locking the doors. She said she was afraid of him. She was afraid he was going to kill her.'' The younger Goetsch testified Thursday that he never meant to release the arrow, but his mother startled him. ``My whole body jerked and contracted and I lost control of the bow string,'' he said. He denied that he aimed another arrow at his father. Defense attorney Henry Conti said previous family conflicts described during the trial ``perhaps had an effect in the incident that morning. I'm afraid it poured over'' to the jury's decision. He said the verdict would be appealed. The elder Goetsch, who was present when the verdict was read, said the trial ended as it should, but the outcome brought no relief. ``Justice has triumphed in this case, but I feel bad, terrible,'' said Goetsch, who adopted Chad at age 4 after marrying the boy's mother.

DOC.HEAD: `Space Taxi' Model Unveiled
LaserPhoto RA4
DOC.TEXT: A model of a small NASA ``space taxi'' to shuttle crew and cargo between Earth and an orbiting station was unveiled Friday. Fifty-five students from two universities designed the mock-up of the spacecraft that would be launched by a Titan 4 rocket and would land on a runway similar to space shuttle landings. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has said it will use the model of the HL-20, which has a 23{-foot wingspan and is 29{ feet long. Space shuttles are more than four times as long and three times as wide. The nose of the HL-20 resembles space shuttles, with a sleek, swept-wing tail section. The ``space taxi'' is being considered as a means of moving small loads of cargo and people to and from the planned space station Freedom. It was unveiled on the North Carolina State University campus. Students from both N.C. State and North Carolina A&T State University worked on the vehicle. ``The agreement with NASA was that we would do the structural design and construct the working model,'' said N.C. State aerospace engineering professor Fred DeJarnette. ``They provided the external shape, the computer geometry of the vehicle.'' The university is home to the Mars Mission Research Center. NASA's goal is to reach Mars by 2019 and scientists say a working space station would be needed to accomplish such a trip. To aid in Mars mission research, the center has a budget of $8.4 million from NASA over five years. DeJarnette is the center's director.

DOC.HEAD: Golfer Survives 150-Foot Fall
DOC.TEXT: A golfer reaching for a ball toppled 150 feet off the edge of a cliff and survived with a broken rib and cuts. Bill Sadler, 45, a novice golfer, had not played Pebble Beach before Thursday, when he took the plunge into sand near the eighth hole on one of the country's most difficult courses. ``I'm extremely lucky. Thursday the 13th wasn't an unlucky day after all,'' Sadler said Friday from a hospital in nearby Monterey. ``The ball was just over the edge of the cliff. I reached down trying to get it and the ground gave way,'' he said. Sadler, a lieutenant commander in the British Royal Navy, has lived in nearby Pacific Grove for three years. He is an oceanographer assigned to an annex of the Navel Postgraduate School in Monterey. An Army helicopter airlifted him off the sand and onto the golf course. He suffered only a broken rib and minor cuts. ``He was lucky,'' said sheriff's deputy Ray George. ``This should have been a coroner's case.'' Asked if he'd try golf again, Sadler replied, ``Well, we'll see. I know I'm not doing any more cliff walking.''

DOC.HEAD: Dear Mom: American Troops Write Home from Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Mom, do you remember when you and I used to ... stop at the park and play on the teeter-totter?'' Sgt. Christopher Austin writes in his first letter home from Saudi Arabia. ``We used to balance ourselves on the teeter-totter.'' His mother, Pam Huffman, has read and reread the words, scrunched close on sheets from a memo pad. Her sisters, friends and teen-age daughters all heard excerpts before she tucked the letter away in a plastic sandwich bag. ``It's the most precious thing I've ever received,'' said Mrs. Huffman, whose only son is in the Army's 82nd Airborne. Like thousands of others, Austin is prepared to battle Iraq's Saddam Hussein. And yet, all he really wants is to come home. He's 22, tall, slim and blond. His blue eyes dance when he smiles, which he does a lot. He loves New Castle, Ind., fresh laundry, football and Kim, his high school sweetheart and bride of three months. ``I remember when I was in the first grade, Mom, and I used to walk to school. I saw this bird every morning and it seemed to follow me all the way, every morning,'' writes Austin. ``I remember Uncle Terry and how he used to play his guitar and sing to me. I remember I used to ride my Big Wheel around the block and try to jump the humps and cracks in the sidewalk.'' Memories of home have helped sustain the more than 100,000 U.S. servicemen and women in Saudia Arabia since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. They make the 120-degree desert days and September sandstorms easier to bear. ``Hello sweetheart,'' writes Army Pfc. Sean Walters to his wife in Crossville, Tenn. ``It's not all that bad yet. (But) it's hot and boring ... and the only thing you see are tents for as long as you can see.'' Mai Walters, who left Vietnam after Saigon fell in 1975, is lonely but stoic in her young husband's absence. She waits and writes to him, then waits some more before finally receiving his first letters. ``Two in one day!'' she yelped after swinging shut her curbside mailbox. ``It's 5 o'clock in the evening here. That would make it 9 o'clock in the morning there. I miss you very much...,'' writes Walters, a 25-year-old Minnesota native. ``I hate being away from you, but it's out of my control.'' Soldiers stationed in the Middle East don't have much, if any, access to telephones. So they, and relatives back home, revert to that wonderful old dinosaur: the letter. Even if written in chicken scratch on dog-eared paper, through the mail come bits and pieces of life sometimes lost in telephone calls. There is time for reflection; time to scribble things in the margin. ``Mike, Tony and I have been spending as much time together as we can,'' Sgt. Gary Bruce Goodwin assured his mom. He and his two brothers are also deployed with the Fort Bragg, N.C.-based 82nd Airborne. ``Currently, Mike is suffering from a severe case of diarrhea. Everybody here is getting it. I had mine last week for five days and, believe me, it was awful,'' writes Goodwin, 27, the middle son. ``Hello from Saudi Arabia,'' writes Jim Bell, a sober 23-year-old who works in Marine intelligence. ``(It) is really desolate. Nothing but miles and miles of sand dunes.'' His father, architect Robert Bell, pauses after reading the letter again. ``I've been thinking over the last few weeks about what my position is on this,'' said the Oak Park, Ill., father of six. ``My position is we should get out. I remember the Vietnam thing.'' His son, who was 8 years old when Saigon fell, is grave about his commitment to the military. But clearly, too, he is anxious about the risks of war. ``It is difficult to say when I'll get back to the states,'' writes Jim, who'd planned to take accounting courses this fall at the University of Southern California. ``I wish it were tomorrow ... (but) it looks pretty bleak.'' Even Army Pfc. Wade Merritt, the Tennessee soldier whose letter President Bush held up before the nation as an emblem of patriotism, has his fears. ``As much as I love my job, I don't believe in war or the unnecessary acts of violence against fellow human beings, but it is my job,'' he wrote in a passage the president did not include in his televised address. ``When I made a decision to make the Army my career, I knew that this day would come,'' he wrote. ``But I was hoping it wouldn't.'' ``Yes, I'm a little scared,'' writes Mrs. Huffman's son, Christopher. ``Check up on Kim for me. I hated leaving her in the night like that. It was 2 a.m. and she was real shaky, you know? ``Just help he out and tell her that I love her, because I really miss her, Mom.''

DOC.HEAD: Speculator's Violation Earns Him TV Appearance to Educate Viewers''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report; also on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Convicted felons don't usually appear on their own television specials. But a 56-year-old Tucson real estate speculator had the dubious distinction, starring in ``Niles Thim: Conditions of Probation.'' A star, sad to say, was not born. ``This is boring,'' one of the investor-victims in the studio audience complained. The judge who ordered the half-hour program said it was intended to educate and warn viewers ``about the consequences of what a proper or prudent investment would be.'' The show, substituting locally for ``New Attitude'' in the ABC affiliate KGUN's 8:30 p.m. slot Friday, was part of a creative sentence imposed by Pima County Superior Court Judge Lawrence Fleischman as a condition of Thim's probation. During the Sept. 6 taping, Thim's attorney, Robert Hirsh, objected frequently to questions that he insisted amounted to ``an inquisition ... a pillory.'' Under a negotiated agreement, Thim pleaded guilty in January to three felony counts of selling unregistered securities. The securities were mortgages on raw land. ``I'm hopeful that people at the very least can be forewarned about looking before leaping into investments,'' Fleischman said Friday. ``I think it fulfilled part of the function. I don't think it was perfect. It's never been done before and we were all treading on new grounds.'' Thim also must repay $9.2 million to 112 investors and serve four years' probation and one year in jail. He has served part of the term and faces four more jail stays annually during the Thanksgiving-through-New Year's holiday season. Authorities have estimated that more than 600 investors in 18 states lost at least $25 million in real estate investments with Thim, who failed to register the transactions with the Arizona Corporation Commission and did not prepare offering memoranda, as state law required. The half-hour program was taped before a studio audience that included some of the investor victims. It made for less-than-gripping television; some of the audience walked out before the end. During the taping, Hirsh, Thim, Atchley and Jerry Goddard, a former county attorney's investigator, sat before the cameras in a talk-show setting. The agreed-to format limited the questions Thim could be asked, principally by KGUN anchor Guy Atchley, to dealing with the three counts to which Thim had pleaded. Only one investor, Ina Bartenslager, was allowed to ask a question on-camera. Fleischman and Howard Fell, a Pima County deputy prosecutor who handled Thim's case, also attended the taping, which was interrupted frequently by objections from Hirsh to questions pitched toward Thim. ``I thought it was probably worthless from the perspective of fulfilling any of the real functions of probation,'' Hirsh said. He contended that most of the questioning was accusatory, directed to ``whether Thim was a good guy or a bad guy. I think they totally missed what I perceived was the whole point of all of this.'' Fell was out of town Friday and could not be reached for comment. Hirsh had succeeded through a court appeal in getting Fleischman to change the name of the show from ``Niles Thim: How I Stole $9.2 Million.'' He objected that Thim didnot steal $9 million and did not plead to such a charge. Mrs. Bartenslager, representing investors who lost money with Thim, said she and her deceased husband had lost more than $30,000 invested with Thim, proceeds from an automobile accident, and that she had been forced to put her house up for sale. Thim said he sympathized with her but that she had made money through his investments over the years. He also said several times that payments to the investors have simply been delayed, and that he hopes to repay all within two years. Thim has filed for bankruptcy and his properties are being sold off. Thim blamed his problems on the savings and loan debacle, which depreciated Arizona land values, on the 1986 tax changes. He also said he relied too much on real estate investments and recommended that investors own their own property. Said Fleischman: ``It will be worthwhile if one person who was about to make an investment stops and thinks. Then it will have achieved what it was set out to achieve.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in the Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the breakdown of the opposing forces in the Persian Gulf: ---
DOC.HEAD: UNITED STATES: Officials say more than 150,000 troops,
DOC.TEXT: including those aboard ships, are in the Persian Gulf region or on the way. Deployments could go as high as 250,000. The troops include elements of the 82nd and 101st Airborne Divisions, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment, and other units. They also include a contingent of 45,000 Marines. The American fleet in the gulf and Arabian Sea waters immediately outside it totals about 30 ships, including three aircraft carriers, a battleship armed with Tomahawk cruise missiles, more than a dozen missile cruisers, destroyers, supply ships and an undisclosed number of submarines. Two hospital ships are sailing for the gulf. Another seven ships are expected in the Mediterranean. The Pentagon has also sent 22 Stealth fighter-bombers and dozens of other aircraft. ---
DOC.HEAD: BRITAIN: Has a flotilla permanently in the gulf and has
DOC.TEXT: contributed three warships: a destroyer armed with Sea Dart missiles and two Frigates armed with Exocet and Seawolf missiles. They are accompanied in the gulf by a Royal Fleet auxiliary vessel. Soon to join them will be three Royal Fleet auxiliary ships: one supply vessel, one fleet tanker and one forward supply vessel. Three minesweepers and one support vessel are en route, but the minesweepers are expected to stay in the eastern Mediterranean. Also dispatched were two squadrons of Tornadoes and one squadron of Jaguar fighter-bombers. A squadron totals 12-16 planes. The F3 class Tornado fighter-interceptors is based in Saudi Arabia. The Jaguars are at Thumrait airbase in neighboring Oman. The second squadron of Tornadoes, which are IDS-type interdictor strike planes, are expected to arrive within the week from a base in West Germany. There are also three Nimrod maritime reconnaisance aircraft stationed in Oman. Britain has also committed an armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops to the Persian Gulf, along with another squadron of Tornado ground attack aircraft and additional air defense aircraft. ---
DOC.HEAD: FRANCE: Nine ships are either in the gulf or enroute, including
DOC.TEXT: the aircraft carrier Clemenceau with anti-tank helicopters, a guided-missile cruiser and two destroyers equipped with anti-ship Exocet missiles, two frigates and one corvette. The helicopters will be sent to Saudi Arabia. One company of 180 paratroopers has been sent to the United Arab Emirates. They are equipped for chemical warfare. ---
DOC.HEAD: GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United
DOC.TEXT: Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait): A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops based in northeast Saudi Arabia. They would be supported by Saudi Arabian forces. ---
DOC.HEAD: GREECE: Greece is sending its top frigate, the Limnos, to join
DOC.TEXT: multinational operations in the gulf. The frigate has a 180-member crew and is equipped with a Phalanx anti-missile system, ground-to-air missiles and ground-to-ground missiles. It can also carry two anti-submarine helicopters. ---
DOC.HEAD: ITALY: Two frigates and a support ship are on the way to the
DOC.TEXT: gulf, having sailed through the Suez Canal. Two corvettes are in the eastern Mediterranean off Turkey. Italy said it would send an additional warship and eight Tornado fighter-planes to the gulf region. ---
DOC.HEAD: NETHERLANDS: Has sent one air defense frigate and one standard
DOC.TEXT: frigate are expected to arrive in the Gulf of Oman or Gulf of Aqaba next week. The Dutch navy has sent six Stinger short-range missiles. ---
DOC.HEAD: SPAIN: Sending one frigate and two corvettes. The frigate will
DOC.TEXT: be based in the Gulf of Oman. The corvettes are en route to Bab El Mandeb Strait at the entrance to the Red Sea. --- Also:
DOC.HEAD: EGYPT: 4,000 ground troops sent.
MOROCCO: 1,200 ground troops sent.
SYRIA: 4,000 ground troops sent, and is planning to send 15,000
DOC.TEXT: more.
DOC.HEAD: AUSTRALIA: Two-guided missile frigates and a supply ship are en
DOC.TEXT: route.
DOC.HEAD: BELGIUM: Two minehunters and a supply ship are en route to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: of Oman.
DOC.HEAD: CANADA: Two destroyers and a supply ship are heading for the
DOC.TEXT: gulf. Sending a dozen fighter jets and a total of 450 fliers and ground crew. ---
DOC.HEAD: IRAQ FORCES:
DOC.TEXT: Army: regular 555,000, reserves 480,000. Claims militia called Popular Army, originally formed in Iran-Iraq war and partially demobilized after cease-fire, of 5 million. Tanks: 5,500, including some 500 T-72s. Heavy artillery: 3,500 Multiple Rocket Launchers: 200 Surface-to-Surface Missiles: estimated 500 Surface-to-Air Missiles: 330 launchers Combat Aircraft: 500-plus, reportedly including Soviet-supplied Su-24 long-range fighter-bombers. Navy: 1 training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, estimated eight missile attack craft, six torpedo boats.

DOC.HEAD: Dellosa, One of the Faceless Thousands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM3 sent Sept. 14.
DOC.TEXT: Justo Enrique Dellosa's trip from Kuwait to Queen Alia Airport took 22 days. Along the road, his fiancee died of the heat. Then he was one of the faceless thousands stranded in the Jordan desert. ``It was terrible,'' Dellosa said, shaking his head at the inadequacy of the word but not finding a better one. ``Terrible.'' He sat on the curb Friday with 50 Filipino friends awaiting an evacuation flight to Manila. Nearby, a young man hugged his girlfriend, who wept silently. A group of others joked and laughed. Chased out of Kuwait by hunger and fear after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion, they did not know what to expect back home. Dellosa said his friends had gone to the gulf for work they could not find in the Philippines. Nearly a million foreigners - many of them citizens of impoverished Asian countries - had come for the same reason. Hundreds of thousands have begun tortuous trips home in the last six weeks. ``I'll find something, maybe,'' Dellosa said, looking dubious. His last possessions were within reach, stuffed into a cheap suitcase. His pockets held a few dollars worth of Iraqi dinars. As an office boy in Kuwait, he earned $450 a month. For four years, he fed a bank account to pay for a trip to the United States for a shot at the American dream. ``I have an auntie and two uncles in California,'' he said. ``Also, an auntie in New Mexico. You know where that is?'' But Iraqi authorities froze all Kuait bank accounts. They searched Dellosa at the border and shook him down for a few electronics items he might have sold for a small stake. Dellosa's parents live in Manila, but with four daughters and three other sons, they have scant means to provide for a destitute 27-year-old son. The Filipinos' plight was shared by the 12,000 to 15,000 Asians who mob the airport each day to get onto the dozens of special flights home. On Friday, ragged lines of Indians, Bangladeshis and Sri Lankans snaked out of Terminal 2. Each slight movement touched off a mad scramble among people terrified of being left behind. Dellosa and his financee, Thelma Cajayon, left Kuwait early Aug. 23 in a taxi with two others. The driver left off the air conditioning, afraid of overheating the car in the blasting sun. After 11 hours on the road, only 60 miles from Baghdad, Thelma collapsed from the heat. Revived, she went into convulsions from nervous anxiety. ``We got her to a doctor, but it was a small provincial hospital,'' Dellosa said. ``They could not do anything.'' After her death, he pressed on with his friends. A day later, they crossed out of Iraq. Besieged by refugees, Jordanian authorities held the newcomers in a no man's land without admitting them to Jordan. Fate landed Dellosa in Shaalan II, a tent camp with water tanks and a clinic. It was a luxury next to the filthy squalor of Shaalan I, where refugees with no shelter battled for food and water. But the same heat and dust beat down on both camps, with bone-chilling cold at night. Refugees tried to sleep on sharp rocks infested by scorpions and snakes. Day and night, they were tormented with fear and confusion. None knew when their consulates might find enough airplanes to get them home. For 22 days, Dellosa and his friends paced in the sun and tried to keep up their health. ``We ate sardines, some tomatoes, Arabic bread,'' he said. ``At the end, they gave us only some kind of corned beef with hair from the cow still in it.'' Eventually, buses took the refugees to another camp outside of Amman. From there, three days later, they were at the airport. Prodded by questions, Dellosa reflected on his ordeal. ``I suppose I am happy to be going,'' he said. ``But I left my girlfriend behind. And my whole life in Kuwait. They destroyed our futures. All of our dreams, they are nightmares.''

DOC.HEAD: As Berlin Wall Goes Down, Rabies Goes Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The snarling guard dogs that patrolled the Berlin Wall held back East Germans yearning to breathe free in the West, but they also kept an unwelcome visitor at bay - the rabid fox. When the wall came down, dozens of the disease-ridden creatures began scampering into West Berlin, reintroducing a dreaded ailment that had been virtual eradicated. Since the wall crumbled last November, 37 rabid foxes have been found in West Berlin, including one at a crowded swimming pool. About 10 people have been bitten, according to West Berlin health department spokesman Thomas-Peter Gallon. ``The fall of the borders with East Germany not only led to people moving freely, but also foxes,'' Gallon said. ``Before, rabies had been virtually wiped out.'' Surrounding East Germany has been slow in combating rabies, health officials said, although no statistics on rabies cases in the east were available. West Berliners have been thrown into a minor panic by the rabies outbreak. Police have even issued warnings over radio and by loudspeakers from a van. Doctors have cautioned against alarm but warn bite victims to seek shots to stop the disease, which can be fatal if untreated. The savage guard dogs once posted along border crossings scared away foxes as well as people, said Gallon. In the case of the foxes, just the scent of the dogs was enough to keep them way. When the wall and other border barriers came down, the dogs were retired and the foxes found they could dash over the crumbling wall and into the West. In addition to the 37 rabid foxes, West Berlin officials have found six other rabid animals since Nov. 9. During the preceding 10 months, there were only three rabid animals found in West Berlin, none of them foxes. No one was bitten, Gallon said. He estimated it could take up to a year to bring rabies back under control, adding the real fear is that it could spread to dogs and cats. West Berlin officials have issued a public appeal for pet owners to be sure their beloved dogs and cats are immunized. Local veterinarians have offered special prices to help with the program. ``Rabies Getting Worse!'' screamed the headline of the daily Berliner Morgenpost on Friday. ``Now a Dog is the Victim of the Disease.'' The newspaper said the dog, presumably bitten by a rabid fox, had become the first pet with the disease in West Berlin in five years. Another recent article said a 70-year-woman was attacked by a fox in a city park. ``With the Berlin Wall opening, it really went up,'' said Dr. Christian Schoenfeld, a leading immunologist involved in rabies treatment. ``The wall was definitely a barrier.'' Gallon calls the rabies outbreak ``one of the small, unavoidable disadvantages'' of the wall's opening. West Berlin officials are already working with the East Germans to curb the threat, he said. West Germany, like many Western countries, has had great success over the years by using bait laden with an immunizing substance to eliminate the rabies virus in the wild animal population. Schoenfeld, who at one point interrupted an interview to answer a co-worker's anxious query about rabies, cautioned against overreaction. He noted that anti-rabies injections are given in the arm now, rather than the painful stomach injections administered in the past.

DOC.HEAD: South African Violence Threatens To Derail Peace Efforts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The violence claiming scores of lives every week in South Africa threatens efforts to end apartheid and is pushing the country into what some fear will be civil war. Optimism generated earlier this year by President F.W. de Klerk's steps to end white rule is fading. Rival black factions are feuding for power, white extremists vow to fight any effort to end apartheid, and the violence is creating mistrust on all sides. Growing numbers of whites and blacks fear the country is hurtling out of control. White and black leaders warn they won't be able to end apartheid if there is no peace or trust between ethnic groups. De Klerk warned Friday that growing violence was undermining the government's efforts to share power between whites and blacks and find a way for the two groups live together peacefully. ``The new South Africa, which is the goal of all sincere South Africans, is being threatened by present events,'' he said. Chris Hani, leader of the African National Congress' military wing, said South Africa is already in a state of ``undeclared war.'' Almost 800 people have been killed since August in the black townships that ring Johannesburg. People have been butchered on trains, burned to death in their homes and hacked to death in the streets. ``More than everything in my life I want this fighting to stop. I haven't slept for days - every night I hear gunfire and shouting and whistles. Sometimes I get messages that they are coming,'' said Boxer Ngwenga, a township resident. Despite calls from white and black leaders for peace, the violence shows no sign of ending. The reasons for the fighting are numerous and complex. Much of the fighting pits Zulus aligned to the conservative Inkatha party against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC. Rivalry between Inkatha and the ANC has cost more than 5,000 lives in Natal Province in recent years, and the power struggle has intensified and broadened with the government promise to end white rule, political analysts say. The ANC and Inkatha disagree over plans for a future South Africa, with the nationalistic Zulu group favoring conservative policies, including a capitalist economy. The non-tribal ANC talks about compulsory redistribution of wealth and left-leaning programs to end poverty. But the violence in the townships has become increasingly chaotic, with armed men attacking strangers for no discernible reason. Fear appears to be fueling the violence, prompting people to kill before they are killed. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi has repeatedly offered to meet Nelson Mandela, the ANC's deputy chief, to negotiate an end to the violence. The ANC has refused, accusing Buthelezi of using the fighting to get a meeting with Mandela and enhance his stature as a national leader. In any case, the ANC and Inkatha acknowledge they have many young followers they cannot control, and it's unclear whether a meeting would stop the fighting. The ANC contends the police are provoking the violence in an attempt to wreck peace talks and preserve apartheid. Townships are filled with stories of mysterious white men leading attacks. The government and the police have denied the charges. But many analysts believe some of the violence is organized, possibly by rogue elements in the security services determined to preserve white rule at any price. White extremists fear the end of apartheid would mean their destruction. Whites, they claim, would be submerged by the black masses and violence and anarchy would sweep the country. The violence so far has had little impact on white South Africans. It has been confined to black townships and the only white casualties have been a few police officers. Government officials and others worry about what could happen if whites are dragged into the fighting. Most whites have guns and even a minor incident could spark a confrontation with blacks. Chances of peace seem to be getting slimmer as the violence spreads. How, political leaders ask privately, can people at each other's throats hope to live in peace and racial equality? --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Barry Renfrew is The Associated Press bureau chief in Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: VOA Criticism of Saddam Squelched Just Before Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: One week before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the State Department refused to allow the Voice of America to broadcast an editorial critical of President Saddam Hussein's threats. The department cited concerns that the editorial would anger Saddam, sources say. The case is the latest indication that some administration officials and congressional leaders either misread Saddam's intentions in the months preceding the invasion or believed he could be talked out of them. A week before the Aug. 2 invasion, U.S. Ambassador April Glaspie was quoted as telling Saddam that the United States understood his need for money to rebuild Iraq after its eight-year war with Iran. ``We understand that, and our opinion is you should have the opportunity to rebuild your country. But we have no opinion on the Arab-Arab conflicts, like your border disagreement with Kuwait,'' Ms. Glaspie is quoted as telling Saddam. Her comments were echoed in subsequent days by officials in Washington. Three months earlier, four Senate leaders met with Saddam and assured him the United States wanted to improve relations with his country. In response to questioning by the group, led by Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas, Saddam acknowledged he had chemical weapons and was working on a nuclear bomb. Dole assured Saddam that President Bush would reject attempts in Congress to impose sanctions on Iraq, and might even veto them, according to a transcript of the meeting, which was taped by Iraq without the senators' knowledge. ``The meeting was supposed to be private. We were prevented from taping it but the room was bugged,'' said Dole's spokesman, Walt Riker, who attended the April 12 meeting. Riker said the Iraqi transcript was doctored to excise comments by Saddam that agreed with U.S. positions. Iraq also provided a transcript of the meeting with Ambassador Glaspie. The State Department declined to say whether it accurately reflected her remarks. Analysts say Iraq has circulated the transcripts in an attempt to show that Saddam did not have any indication the United States would object so strongly to his invasion of Kuwait. Dole rejected Saddam's claim that the administration was leading a campaign against Iraq. On the contrary, Dole said, a VOA commentator who had written a critical editorial about Saddam two months earlier was fired. In fact, the commentator was not fired. Riker said Friday that Dole had been misinformed by the State Department. Sources say VOA was sharply reprimanded for the Feb. 15 editorial, which said democracy requires the dismantling of secret police services in such countries as North Korea, Iran, Libya, Cuba and Iraq. The sources also say the same editorialialist wrote the July 25 editorial the State Department refused to clear. All VOA editorials have to be cleared by the radio's parent agency, the U.S. Information Agency, and, in the case of sensitive topics, by the State Department. ``We were asked to refrain from muddying the waters as long as diplomatic efforts were underway in the Arab world to resolve the crisis,'' said a State Department official of the decision to stop the editorial. In the days before the invasion, Egypt, Jordan and other Arab countries were trying through diplomacy to prevent Saddam from fulfilling his threats. ``This is all Monday-morning quarterbacking,'' Riker said of those who say the United States should have known better than to try and pacify Saddam. He said the Senate group went to Iraq in an attempt to find out Saddam's intentions and to warn him that he would have to improve his behavior if he wanted better ties with Washington. But the Iraqi transcript of the meeting paints a somewhat different picture. ``After listening to you for about an hour, I realize you are a strong and an intelligent man and that you want peace,'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, is quoted as saying. And Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyoming, told Saddam his problem was with the Western media, not with the U.S. government. ``The press is spoiled and conceited,'' he is quoted as saying. ``My advice is that you allow these bastards to come here and see things for themselves.'' Simpson's spokesman, Stan Cannon, said the senator was a well-known advocate of press freedom and that his comments were taken out of context. ``Saddam is just trying to embarrass him,'' Cannon said.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacists Convicted
DOC.TEXT: Three senior members of a white-supremacist group have been convicted of more than 100 offenses committed in an 18-month terrorism campaign against Asians. A Perth District Court jury on Friday found the men guilty of conspiring to drive Asians out of Western Australia state with a series of tactics, including arson attacks on Perth Chinese restaurants. They also carried out a string of thefts to fund the movement, which reportedly has offshoots in other states. Two defendants argued they were patriotic Australians fighting for their country. A former member of the group who had testified against the defendants received plastic surgery and was given a new identity overseas. Judge Kevin Hammond planned sentencing hearings on separate days next week.

DOC.HEAD: Washington to World Body: Give Us Diplomacy, Not Army
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is relying on U.N. diplomatic backing in the Persian Gulf but ignoring the world body's military potential. Instead, U.S. officials are trying to resurrect a Middle East military alliance. Washington wants Moscow to help blunt Iraqi aggression. Ironically, the earlier Middle East alliance was the 1955 Baghdad Pact, later called CENTO, in which America allied with Iraq against the Soviet Union. CENTO unraveled in 1959 when Iraq dropped out after revolutionaries overthrew the country's monarchy. In his effort to forge a new alliance, President Bush has urged Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to send ships or troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf. But Gorbachev has refused. The Soviets say they will only send troops as part of a U.N. command under the direction of the Security Council's Military Staff Committee. That committee consists of officers from the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China - the five permanent council members. The Military Staff Committee has never been activated to coordinate or monitor any U.N. military operation, however. Even the Korean War U.N. command was primarily under U.S. control, with some allied troops pitching in. On Sept. 4, Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Congress the United States needs ``a new regional security structure'' in the Middle East to deter Iraqi aggression the way NATO checked the Soviets in Europe. Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates are the likely partners in the alliance, which has yet to take shape. In the process, Baker bypassed the United Nations. The world body already has more than 10,000 military observers and peacekeepers in various global hot spots, though the United States and Soviet Union have not contributed troops to those forces. Why has Washington ignored the U.N.'s military potential? An official at the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday that activating the Military Staff Committee is being explored, but it will be ``a very long and slow process.'' The U.N. ambassadors of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France, and China held two private meetings with top military officers from their countries, flown in from Washington for the talks. The U.S. Mission official said the Military Staff Committee could begin receiving reports on the naval enforcement of the U.N.-ordered embargo on Iraq from the United States and other nations involved. ``This skeletal structure can now begin to grow,'' he said. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said he has no objection ``in principle'' to U.S. participation in an international military operation. However, Cheney said he could not imagine breaking the ``constitutional chain of command'' that leads up to Bush as commander-in-chief. ``The Pentagon, of course, would object vehemently to the notion of putting U.S. personnel under international authority,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said Sept. 7 at a gulf policy seminar. Aspin, however, said Bush should consider the idea of a U.N. command structure. Ed Luck, president of the U.N. Association of the U.S.A., said, ``One could easily meld the idea of a regional security system with the U.N. Charter and with the Military Staff Committee.'' His group is a private organization that studies U.S. policy toward the world body. It generally advocates more active American involvement in the United Nations. With more U.N. peacekeeping operations looming in the Western Sahara in Africa and Cambodia, it is time to revive the U.N. committee as a coordinating group, Luck added.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Approves Food Aid, Int'l Charities Must Handle It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 13-2 passage to allow shipments, Cuba, Yemen oppose the resolution, details, quotes, minor editing to trim and conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council overwhelmingly voted late Thursday to allow food shipments to Iraq and occupied Kuwait only ``to relieve human suffering'' and said relief agencies must distribute the aid. The wording of the resolution, which passed 13-2, sought to maintain the narrow restrictions under which aid could be sent, in line with a resolution passed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The council rejected an alternative Cuban-sponsored resolution that would have opened the door to unlimited food shipments to the estimated 19 million people in Iraq and Kuwait, including hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped by the invasion. Cuba and Yemen voted against the resolution. The United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France, Finland and Canada sponsored the resolution. Also voting in favor were China, Colombia, Ethiopia, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania and Zaire. Under Security Council Resolution 661, passed four days after Iraq's invasion, only medical supplies may be sent to Iraq or Kuwait, or, ``in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs.'' India and the Philippines, however, have appealed to the Security Council's sanctions committee for permission to send food to their people still stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq has said it will not feed the 140,000 Indians, 93,000 Sri Lankans and 60,000 Filipinos it holds, but that they must rely on their governments. The resolution passed Thursday said the International Committee of the Red Cross or ``other appropriate humanitarian agencies'' should distribute the food or supervise its distribution. That left open the possibility that the Iraqi Red Crescent, one of the Moslem national charities that are members of the ICRC, might be allowed to handle food distribution. The five permanent Security Council members had said earlier Thursday that food shipments should be allowed into Iraq and occupied Kuwait ``to relieve human suffering.'' The permanent council members are the United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France and China. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Al-Anbari said Wednesday that only ``Iraqi authorities'' could distribute food in his country. The full 15-member council was ready to adopt it Thursday night when the ambassador from Yemen, the only Arab nation on the council, suddenly left the closed-door meeting. Cuba and Yemen had been pushing a separate resolution with a very board definition of humanitarian circumstances that would have allowed unlimited shipments of basic foodstuffs to feed the Iraqi civilian population. If the Security Council's committee on sanctions decides ``there is an urgent humanitarian need to supply foodstuffs to Iraq or Kuwait in order to relieve human suffering,'' it can recommend the council allow such aid to be sent, the resolution said. Al-Anbari also has rejected the idea of U.N. experts investigating the food situation in his country. Also Thursday night, the council's committee on sanctions was expected to approve India's request to send a ship loaded with 22 million pounds of food to Kuwait to feed 140,000 Indians stranded in that country and Iraq. In addition to Finland, the other members of the council are Algeria, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Ethiopia, Malaysia, Nepal, Senegal and Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Seeming Neophyte Actually Is Savvy, Experienced Political Veteran
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Pratt Dixon is a political unknown, but the woman who is favored to become the next mayor of the nation's capital is hardly a political novice. The probable successor to Marion Barry, Dixon scored a stunning victory Tuesday in the city's Democratic primary, her first bid for public office. ``She didn't have the kind of money in the primary to put out those television commercials, `This is Sharon Pratt Dixon, and this is who I am,''' said Julius Hobson, a longtime observer of city politics. ``But it would be a mistake to call her a political newcomer - she doesn't have a real day-to-day record, but she does have a long involvement in local and national politics,'' said Hobson. She was short on cash, staff and supplies, but Dixon's theme throughout the primary campaign was that the time had come to get rid of the bloated bureaucracy and inefficiency associated with Barry's administration. While her message had become familiar on Election Day, voters in this city of 620,000 still know little about the 46-year-old divorced mother of two - or the depth of her political experience. A former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, Dixon learned how to run a city-wide campaign when she managed former Carter aide Patricia Roberts Harris' unsuccessful effort to defeat Barry in the district's 1982 primary. And when she made her victory speech Tuesday, DNC Chairman Ron Brown chose to stand by her side. Dixon is also an old friend of Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder, who fashioned his own underdog campaign last year in becoming the Old Dominion's first black governor. If elected in November, she would break new ground herself, becoming the first black woman to serve as mayor of a major American city. She's no stranger to Congress, which reviews the annual city budget and frequently takes a more critical look when things aren't going well for the local government. Within hours of her victory, she had set up a meeting with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. The city's image on Capitol Hill, badly tarnished by Barry's drug conviction and the local government's $93 million deficit, already seems to be regaining some of its luster. ``I'm a very optimistic person and a very determined person,'' Dixon said wen asked to describe herself. ``I don't take no for an answer very easily.'' Those who know the slight, bespectacled woman agree. ``She's always been a very aggressive person, eager to prove herself,'' said her aunt, Aimee Pratt. ``I remember when she was a little girl and she would be climbing on a chair or something. I would tell her not to, and she would say, `But I can, I can!''' Her business resume is lengthy, too. An attorney, she rose through the ranks at the Potomac Electric Power Co. to become director of the utility's consumer affairs department before launching her long-shot mayoral campaign. ``She's a very warm, dynamic, intelligent person,'' said W. Reid Thompson, Pepco board chairman. ``She is very relaxed with people, and she shows a lot of poise and charm.'' ``She's really succeeded in the mainstream of politics, and in the business world,'' said Eddie Williams, director of the Joint Center for Political Studies, a black-oriented think tank. ``She's a technician, very good with numbers. Her background is more ... corporate than civil rights.'' Dixon has taught at the University of the District of Columbia's law school; worked on a commission that took authority over the city's criminal code from Congress and gave it to the city council; and served in a variety of legal posts at Pepco. And while voters responded to Dixon's repeated, sometimes strident calls for cuts in the city work force and elimination of other forms of cronyism, those familiar with her believe there is another side to her. ``Something people don't see is that she is very gentle, not aloof at all,'' her aunt said. ``You have to get to know her, but once you do, she's very approachable and warm.'' It wasn't until after Barry was convicted of a cocaine possession charge - less than a month before the primary - that city residents started paying attention to Dixon. She scored a major coup two weeks later, when The Washington Post endorsed her over four rivals with longtime ties to city government. Democrats outnumber Republicans here by a 9-to-1 margin, so Dixon appears headed for victory Nov. 6 against GOP candidate Maurice Turner, a former city police chief.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Agreeable to Phaseout of U.S. Bases, Congressman Says
DOC.TEXT: U.S. negotiators in the Philippines are likely to propose a 10-year phaseout of U.S. bases with a possible commercial agreement for limited use of the facilities afterward, a congressman said late Thursday. If the position is taken, it will be the first time the U.S. government has been willing to discuss a withdrawal from Clark Air Base and Subic Navy Base, two of its largest overseas facilities. Rep. Stephen Solarz, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs, said he has talked with administration officials involved in the talks to open next week in Manila. The Washington Post, citing congressional and administration sources, reported in its Friday editions that the United States was considering the phaseout. State Department spokesman Martin Judge said he could not comment on the Post report or comments by Solarz, D-N.Y. Richard Armitage, head of the U.S. negotiating team, was en route to Manila. The U.S. government has given no details of exactly where or when the talks will be taking place in Manila, citing security concerns. A series of bombings blamed on either right- or left-wing rebel opponents of President Corazon Aquino have shaken the city in recent weeks, and there have been threats against Americans. The agreement under which the bases are used by U.S. armed forces expires next year. Solarz, in a telephone interview, said he has had discussions with U.S. negotiators about the possibility of a 10-year phaseout and other positions the team might take. ``I have the impression that this is a timetable they are comfortable with and likely to propose,'' Solarz said. The congressman, who is well known in the Philippines for his interest in the country, said the position recognizes the fact that ``we cannot persuade the Filipinos to let us stay indefinitely but could conceivable persuade them to allow use of the bases for another decade.'' He said the idea would be that if U.S. and Philippine authorities feel a U.S. military presence is needed beyond that, the U.S. government could have access to the bases, which already are technically owned by the Philippines, on a commercial basis, paying for their use. Current agreements call for unlimited U.S. use of the facilities based on an aid package that Congress has trimmed below levels agreed upon between the two countries' negotiators.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Warns of Terror Attacks Against U.S.; U.N. Passes Food Measure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with U.N. Security Council passage of food aid resolution, Cuba and Yemen oppose it. Picks up 3rd pvs, `Meanwhile in...' Edits thereafter to delete dated U.N. material.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TEH1,PAR1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq warned Thursday of possible terrorist attacks against U.S. forces, sounding the theme of Arab feelings wounded by the presence of non-Moslem soldiers massed in the holy lands of Saudi Arabia. But a convocation of Moslem clergy in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, condemned the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait and said the U.S.-led multinational force's presence was justified by Iraq's invasion. Late Thursday, the U.N. Security Council voted 13-2 to allow food shipments to Iraq and occupied Kuwait only ``to relieve human suffering'' and said relief agencies must distribute the aid. Cuba and Yemen, the only Arab nation on the council, voted against the resolution, which was sponsored by the United States, the Soviet Union and four other countries. Meanwhile in Tokyo, the Japanese government announced Friday that it will provide an additional $3 billion in aid to more than $1 billion already promised to assist peacekeeping forces in the Persian Gulf region and nations suffering from the U.N.-sponsored embargo against Iraq. Members of the U.S. Congress had complained Japan was not doing more in the crisis, and had not contributed enough in light of its high dependence on Middle East oil. Iraq and Kuwait possess 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, second only to Saudi Arabia. Chief government spokesman Misoji Sakamoto said Japan's increased contribution was not in response to U.S. demands but was his country's ``contribution to the world based on the United Nations resolutions. ... We are not only listening to what the United States says.'' Sakamoto said the expanded contribution was the maximum Japan could provide at this point. In another development, the U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia said the flow of equipment for American forces into Saudi Arabia was eight days behind schedule. The commander, though, said the troops and military hardware already there were sufficient enough to stop any Iraqi attack. Iraq's warning came in a memorandum to the U.S. charge d'affaires in Baghdad, according to the Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. It said Iraq was responding to a U.S. claim that Iraq-based terrorists were preparing to attack U.S. targets. The United States is creating a ``pretext'' for aggression, the memorandum was quoted as saying, and ``Iraq reserves its legitimate right to self-defense, to reciprocate and to retaliate firmly against these parties if it becomes a target.'' ``President Bush should expect that the crimes the United States of America is committing against the Arab nation and the insult it is directing to the Islamic shrines by occupying holy lands will undoubtedly produce a natural reaction from the Arab and Islamic masses,'' said the memorandum. INA said the U.S. claims were contained in a note delivered Wednesday to the Foreign Ministry in Baghdad. In Washington, State Department officials said U.S. diplomats in Baghdad told Iraqi authorities Wednesday night that the United States would hold them accountable for any terrorist attacks on Americans. A U.S. official said American intelligence has indications terrorist groups based in Iraq have begun planning for possible actions against various targets - not only American, but also of allied Arab countries. All U.S. intelligence gathering posts are ``on a high state of alert,'' the official said. All the U.S. officials spoke on condition of anonymity. In the past, U.S. officials have noted that two Palestinian leaders linked to terrorist acts - George Habash and Mohammed Abbas - have their headquarters in Baghdad. Secretary of State James A. Baker III flew to Damascus on Thursday to try to reinforce U.S. cooperation with Syria against Iraq, its longtime enemy. Meanwhile, more than 300 Moslem religious scholars and preachers from the Saudi-funded Moslem World League issued a declaration after a meeting that ended Wednesday. They condemned Saddam's annexation of Kuweit as ``un-Islamic.'' The ``Mecca Declaration'' said the invasion of Kuwait and the massing of Iraqi troops on Saudi borders ``are enough Islamic reason'' to justify the presence of non-Moslem forces for Saudi Arabia's defense. ``Moslems should not attack or commit any felonies against each other,'' the declaration said. ``Within these rulings, Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait is against the principles of Islam.'' Saddam last month attacked the Saudi monarchs for inviting in the Americans, saying their presence sullied the holy sites of Mecca and Medina. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's spiritual leader, echoed Saddam's statement on Wednesday in a further sign Iran and Iraq may be entering an alliance of convenience following their eight-year war, which ended in 1988. Oil experts said Thursday that Iran's reported food-for-oil deal with Iraq could allow Tehran to earn nearly $2 billion more a year by eliminating its other oil imports and boosting exports. Sources have said Iran agreed to send food and medicine to Baghdad in exchange for 200,000 barrels of oil per day. Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies, said Iran ``probably could supply enough food to the right people and places to keep the Iraqi economy going'' for awhile. Iran's oil refineries were damaged during the war, so the Iranians have been importing 150,000 barrels a day, paid for in scarce foreign currency. Kayhan International, a Tehran newspaper, said Thursday that recently improved ties would allow the two countries to ``safeguard the area's tranquility, and also prevent the influence and domination of foreign forces in the Persian Gulf.'' The Tehran Times, which reflects government thinking, on Wednesday denied Tehran had agreed to provide food and medicine to Iran. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States believes Iran will uphold the U.N.-imposed embargo of Iraq. Ambassador Marjatta Rasi of Finland, head of the U.N. Security Council sanctions committee, said Iraq already was feeling the pinch from the trade embargo. She said Iraq had ``plenty of foodstuffs'' stockpiled but was withholding food from foreigners. The U.N. Security Council vote sought to maintain the narrow circumstances under which aid could be sent, in line with a resolution passed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. But Cuba, Yemen and some non-aligned nations insist food should be allowed in under much broader circumstances. Differences also have surfaced between the United States and its allies over how to pay for the troop deployments in the region and related costs - such as feeding refugees and reimbursing countries whose economies suffer as a result of the embargo of Iraq. Earlier Thursday, Japan's government rejected plans by the U.S. House of Representatives to link support for U.S. troops in Japan to Tokyo's contribution to the Mideast peace effort. The House voted Wednesday to demand Japan pay for the 50,000 U.S. troops stationed on its soil under a security treaty. The United States currently pays three-fifths of the $7.4 billion annual bill. ``We have been doing our best for the effective implementation of the Japan-U.S. security treaty, and we will continue to do so in the future,'' Sakamoto said in a Tokyo news conference. ``But quite logically, they are two separate matters.'' West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who also has been criticized in Congress for not helping the U.S. effort enough, promised Thursday to lend ``a helping hand,'' though he did not whether the Germans would provide money. In an interview at U.S. forces headquarters in Riyadh, commander General H. Norman Schwarzkopf said the infusion of armored units the next two months will provide a ``100 percent chance'' of winning any battle with Iraqi forces. However, he said he was confident his forces would stop an Iraqi attack now, despite logistical problems that have put the deployment eight days behind.

DOC.HEAD: Nominee Distances Himself From Bork in Style, Substance
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter, in style and substance early in his Senate confirmation hearings, is proving what he had to: he's no Robert H. Bork. Souter, who spent many hours watching videotapes of Bork's 1987 performance, is using his appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee to distance himself from the lingering memory of Bork's defeated high court nomination. To many, Bork the Senate witness seemed a bloodless academic who talked about the ``intellectual feast'' Supreme Court service would provide. He sometimes bristled at pointed questions and ignored some softballs pitched by sympathetic senators. In contrast, many of Souter's responses Thursday were embellished with personal anecdotes. And he has won praise from two committee members for being ``a listener.'' ``The Bork thing was extraordinary in its intensity, in what occurred,'' Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., said at one point. ``I don't see any portent of that here.'' Because too little is known about Souter's views on key constitutional issues, he has not had to face the charges of extremism that dogged Bork. But Souter, a 50-year-old New Hampshire bachelor with an ascetic lifestyle, is working hard to dispel any notion that he leads a life of disengaged isolation. At one point, he playfully complained about a senator's cutting short one of his questions. ``You're going to turn me into a laconic Yankee if you keep doing that,'' Souter said. After Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., pointed to several positions Souter took as a state official and suggested that he was less than sensitive to minorities' struggle for civil rights, Simpson put it to the nominee bluntly. ``David Souter, are you a racist?'' It was the type of question Bork might have dismissed with a simple ``No.'' But after responding, ``The answer is no,'' Souter went on to deliver a moving soliloquy that left the usually loquacious Simpson at a temporary loss for words. Souter recalled that he never heard his parents refer to any human being in racial or ethnic terms. ``I am glad I am conditioned by my beginnings,'' he said, ``and I am glad I do not have to overcome them.'' As the large hearing room grew increasingly silent, Souter talked about the discrimination is longtime friend Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., knew as a young Jewish boy and the biases that stung the Irish grandparents of Thomas Rath, a Concord lawyer and another longtime friend. There was no such similar moment during the record five days that Bork testified before the committee three years ago. Bork never let his Senate questioners make him embrace the notion that the Constitution, although it doesn't say so specifically, provides a general right of privacy. Souter, although no doubt a conservative, endorsed such a constitutional right - the one on which the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion is based. He distanced himself from the doctrine of ``original intent'' - in which judges seek to discover what the framers of a constitutional provision wanted it to mean when it was written. Instead, Souter said constitutional provisions must be interpreted in today's world - a position more identified with retired Justice William J. Brennan, the liberal Souter seeks to replace. As an example, Souter praised the Supreme Court's 1954 ruling that outlawed racially segregated public schools. It was based on a constitutional amendment adopted in 1868, when separation of the races was strictly enforced by numerous laws. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., cited the nominee's comments on that 1954 ruling to ``highlight the difference'' between Souter and certain unnamed past nominees. The senator clearly had concluded that no clone of Robert H. Bork sat before him. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Richard Carelli covers the Supreme Court for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Finalists Chosen By APME for Public Service Awards
DOC.TEXT: Twenty newspapers have been chosen as finalists in the Associated Press Managing Editors association's 20th annual Public Service Awards competition. The finalists, announced Thursday, were picked from 122 entries - 79 from newspapers with more than 50,000 circulation and 43 from newspapers with less than 50,000 circulation. One winner from each category will be announced at the APME convention in Dallas next month. ``The entries showed a remarkable commitment to report the news in depth and expose corruption and incompetence in our institutions,'' said Paul Janensch, immediate past president of APME and chair of the judging committee. ``The smaller newspapers, with their limited staffs and budgets, are especially deserving of praise,'' added Janensch, who is editor and general manager of The Journal-News in Rockland County. Finalists in the less than 50,000 category, listed alphabetically by city, are: The Albuquerque Tribune for its series, ``A Price on Their Heads,'' exposing the threat to elk, eagles, bear and other wildlife posed by animal traders, trophy hunters and poachers. The Bismarck (N.D.) Tribune for its investigation into the abuse of children placed in foster homes on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation. The Casper (Wyo.) Star-Tribune for its articles about the state's lax regulation of insurance companies. The reporting prompted the withdrawal of a gubernatorial candidate and the resignation of the state insurance commissioner. The Columbia Missourian for a special report that concluded the public housing authority was not only the city's largest landlord but also the worst. This and other coverage led to the resignation of the authority's executive director and its chairman. The Livingston (Mont.) Enterprise for comprehensive coverage by its five-member news staff of the large and secretive Church Universal and Triumphant and its damaging impact on an area adjacent to Yellowstone National Park. The Sun News of Myrtle Beach, S.C., for providing detailed, helpful, responsible coverage of Hurricane Hugo even though its plant was disabled. The newspaper organized a print and broadcast pool to report from the battered oceanfront. The West County Times of Richmond, Calif., for its series exposing safety and environmental violations at the San Francisco Bay area's six oil refineries. As a result, the state increased minimum fines for pollution from $1,000 to $10,000. The Salina (Kan.) Journal for articles about use of excessive force by city police officers. The report led to a state investigation and the retirement of the police chief. The Valley News Dispatch of Tarentum, Pa., for a series that painstakingly documented the failure of local officials to collect more than $10 million in taxes owed to the area's 13 school districts. The Washington (N.C.) Daily News for revealing that for eight years city officials had known cancer-causing chemicals were in the tap water. The disclosure resulted in a two-month water ban, an improved treatment system and state and federal reviews of water regulations. Finalists among newspapers with more than 50,000 circulation, listed alphabetically by city, are: The Albuquerque Journal for discovering a link between the dietary supplement L-tryptophan and a rare and sometimes deadly blood disorder. Ten days after the first story was published, the federal government banned the sale of the supplement. The Chicago Tribune for its series, ``A Dream in Jeopardy,'' a comprehensive examination of cutbacks in corporate pensions and health benefits and threats to the Social Security trust funds. The Des Moines Register for a series about the rape of an Iowa woman and how she coped with the emotional trauma and legal ordeal that followed. The woman's decision to be identified in the account touched off a national debate over whether to keep secret the names of rape victims. The Detroit News for uncovering the financial ties of the mayor and police chief to a former deputy chief at the center of a federal investigation into a secret police fund. Questionable practices by the officials were documented in spite of the city government's ``no comment'' policy when questioned by reporters. The Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader for its series, ``Cheating Our Children,'' on political interference in the state's public schools and the failure of local officials to collect property taxes owed to financially-strapped school districts. The Courier-Journal of Louisville for a broad examination of Kentucky's public-school crisis. Articles published over six months included four in-depth series on flaws in the tax system, the special problems in Appalachia, the need for preschool programs and ways to improve teaching. The Philadelphia Inquirer for its series, ``The Blood Brokers,'' which lifted the veil from the unregulated, multi-billion dollar business of buying and selling blood. Dog kennels in Pennsylvania were inspected more often than blood banks, the series revealed. The San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News for its comprehensive coverage of the Oct. 17 earthquake that devastated parts of Northern California. The day after the disaster and during the months that followed, readers received exhaustive reporting, vivid writing, compelling photos and graphics, and public service information. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer for its report, ``Chemicals Ride the Food Chain,'' which revealed that truckers haul orange juice, baby food and other cargo destined for human consumption after carrying toxic chemicals in the same tanks. The disclosure resulted in a new state law prohibiting such a practice and support for similar legislation in the U.S. Congress. The Blade of Toledo, Ohio, for its series, ``The Secret Files of Internal Affairs,'' based on a review of 200,000 city police disciplinary documents never before made public. The seven-month project revealed that the department failed to prosecute officers for assault, drunken driving and other crimes and that 98 percent of citizens' complaints of police brutality were dismissed. The judges of the APME Public Service Awards competition are past presidents of APME. The 1990 judges, in addition to Janensch, were: Larry Allison, senior vice president and editor of the Long Beach (Calif.) Press-Telegram; James F. Daubel, editor and publisher of the News-Messenger of Fremont, Ohio; Robert H. Giles, editor and publisher of The Detroit News; Robert J. Haiman, president of the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, St. Petersburg, Fla.; Ted M. Natt, editor and publisher of The Daily News of Longview, Wash.; and Robert E. Rhodes, Atwood Professor of Journalism at the University of Alaska at Anchorage.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Gives Sweden Second Thoughts on Nuclear Power
With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil prices from the tensions in the Persian Gulf have opened a rift in the governing party over Sweden's plan to abolish nuclear power in 20 years. At least half the delegates to the Social Democratic Party congress, which begins Saturday, want to postpone the nuclear shutdown, recent polls show. About 25 percent of Sweden's total energy - and 50 percent of its electricity - come from nuclear power. ``The opinion over when to abolish nuclear power is divided within the party,'' Sweden's Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said to the news agency TT last week. In 1980, a year after the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in Pennsylvania, Swedes voted to start shutting down their nuclear energy plants in 1995. Oil has been viewed as the most likely alternative to nuclear power, but the surge in price after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 has reminded Swedes of how much their plan could cost. The price of gasoline in Sweden is already among the highest in the world, mostly because of taxes. A gallon costs about $5. ``To cut the nuclear power at a fast pace, we would be forced to use oil as an energy source in the meantime. Nuclear power is relatively inexpensive compared to the high oil prices,'' acknowledged Bertil Karlberg, a party official. He said the Social Democrats want to replace nuclear energy with power sources such as wind and sun. But Sven Bengtsson, an energy expert at the Ministry of Industry, said, ``With not a lot of sunshine in Sweden, solar energy is out of the question. Also, even if wind power is implemented on a large scale, it can only replace a small part of the total energy output.'' A poll published early this week by Eureka Research said 52 percent of the 80 party delegates it interviewed wanted to delay the nuclear shutdown. A party paper said Thursday that nearly 50 percent of the 350 delegates wanted to reconsider the schedule for closing plants, which was established by Parliament in 1988. The issue promises to produce the most controversial debates of the six-day congress. The meeting, held every three years, is the highest decision-making body of the Social Democratic Party. Influential Social Democrats, such as union leader Stig Malm and Minister of Energy Rune Molin, have said the deadline for abolishing nuclear power should be reconsidered - at the least. Molin went further: ``There is a lot speaking in favor of changing everything,'' he said. Minister of Environment Birgitta Dahl opposes any delay in the shutdown and says the most important consideration is the damage a nuclear accident can cause. Radiation from the Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union four years ago reinforced Swedish public opinion against nuclear power. Radioactive particles brought by the wind and rain contaminated the plants that reindeer eat, forcing the Lapps in northern Sweden to slaughter hundreds of the animals they depend on for food.

DOC.HEAD: Finalists Chosen for APME Freedom of Information Award
DOC.TEXT: Four newspapers are finalists in the annual Freedom of Information Award competition sponsored by the Associated Press Managing Editors association. The finalists were announced Thursday by David Hawpe, editor of The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., chairman of the APME Freedom of Information Committee. The newspapers chosen are: The Detroit News, for an investigation tracing payments from a secret Detroit police fund, through which more than $1 million in taxpayer money was said to be laundered. The complex story touched on the activities of a deputy police chief, Mayor Coleman Young and others. The Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) Sun-Sentinel, for a series on the state of Florida's failure to impose adequate contros on care centers, leading to client deaths and injuries among such diverse groups as infants, retarded adults and teen-age criminals. The Daily Reflector of Greenville, N.C., for revelations concerning the background of a candidate for Superior Court judge, resulting in legislation changing state law to open the records of the North Carolina Judicial Standards Commission. The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, for an examination of the government's military recruiting system that suggested it promotes corruption, undermines quality of the armed forces, and costs taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars annually. The winning entry will be announced at the APME convention in October in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: If War Comes: Analysts Foresee U.S. Victory - but Big Losses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: If it comes to war, military analysts say, the United States and its allies could drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait, but only with a land assault against a dug-in Iraqi army that might result in thousands of American casualties. For comparisons, one expert calls up the bloody island-to-island Pacific warfare against the Japanese in World War II; another reaches further back to the British battle against the Germans along the Somme River in France during World War I. In the first 30 minutes of that fight, 19,240 British soldiers were killed or mortally wounded. ``If we have to fight them, the only thing that worries me is how many Americans get killed,'' said retired Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``No one knows the answer to that.'' The experts were asked a few simple but troubling questions as the massive buildup of American and allied forces continued apace on the Saudi Arabian peninsula: If war comes, would the American side win? At what cost? How long would it take? ``That's a ridiculous question; of course we can win,'' said an incredulous Moorer, 78, who was shot down over the Pacific in 1942 and rescued by a freighter, only to have it bombed out from under him. ``It just depends on will and determination,'' Moorer added. ``It doesn't have anything to do with capability. We are capable, and then some.'' In interviews, a variety of military analysts agreed with that assessment and made this addtional points: - The allies aren't ready to launch an offensive against Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait and won't be until the American contingent, now numbering 100,000, is twice as large, perhaps not until late October. ``If Iraq has 200,000 men in Kuwait, then you'd want a sizeable American advantage before you launch an attack,'' said James A. Blackwell Jr., analyst with the Center for Strategic and International Studies and former West Point instructor. He sees a need for 200,000 U.S. troops, augmented by 50,000 to 100,000 Arab soldiers as well as forces from other countries. - Iraq cannot be ejected from Kuwait militarily without a ground war. It can't be done from the air or with high-tech warfare alone. ``I don't think you can win it by bombing Iraq,'' said Jack N. Meritt, a retired four-star Army general who was the U.S. representative to NATO's military committee. ``We've been trying that since World War II and there has been no case in history where you've been able to defeat a force on the ground from the air.'' - Fighting the Iraqis in Kuwait would be difficult; fighting them on the ground in Iraq would be infinitely more difficult. Said Harry G. Summers Jr., a retired Army colonel, combat infantry veteran of Korea and Vietnam and fellow of the Army War College: ``If we set the goal as the expulsion of Iraq from Kuwait, then the cost will be high, but not nearly what it would be if we tried to conquer Iraq. I can't imagine anybody being that dumb as to take on that task.'' - It is important, militarily and politically, that Arab and other allied forces be in the midst of the fighting. ``You wouldn't want to lead with American forces, you'd want Arab forces to take the immediate action,'' said Blackwell. ``It's important to keep the coalition together.
