This can't become an American war.'' - While the United States has been building up, the Iraqis have been digging in, preparing to do what they did best in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Said Blackwell: ``If Saddam Hussein orders his Iraqi occupiers to fight to the death in Kuwait City and secure their place in heaven - Jiminy Christmas that's a long fight, months. Not to mention the tens of thousands of casualties in such a fight.'' Summers, to illustrate the difficulties of going against an entrenched enemy, drew a parallel with the battle on the Somme on July 1, 1916, when there was enormous British bloodshed in just minutes. ``That gives you the outside parameter of what kind of casualties can result from assaulting fortified positions head on,'' he said. ``You can go much lower, but still it is probably the most difficult'' kind of warfare. ``We need to remember that they Iraqis fought the Iran-Iraq war primarily on the defensive. That is by far the strongest form of war. It is not decisive, but it can certainly cause enormous casualties.'' Added Blackwell: ``If they're defending the city room by room to the death, we're back to island-clearing operations in the Pacific in World War II.'' On the other hand, the Americans have significant advantages. ``We own the night with our military force,'' said Merritt. ``All our tanks and aircraft are night fighters. We might be so effective so quickly that we can destroy their morale and keep our casualties down. ...In the main and on the average, we're technologically far superior and our training is far superior.'' He added that there's much talk about Saddam's ``battle-hardened'' army, ``but it is also a battle-weary army.'' And Moorer pointed out that while Saddam has 5,500 tanks ``many are obsolete.'' Because of the blockade, ``he's going to have spare parts problems to keep his machines going.'' He said Saddam ``could make a big noise for two or three days, but in my view he doesn't have sustainability.'' American commanders in the field exude confidence that they can prevail. The commander of American forces, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, said the American technological advantage should not be discounted. ``We would be using capabilities that are far more lethal, far more accurate and far more effective than anything we have ever used,'' he said. And Marine Maj. Gen. Royal N. Moore said the U.S. attack would pulverize Iraq's defenses in minutes. ``We want about three to five minutes, and we're going to give them the most violent three to five minutes they've ever seen,'' Moore said. ``That's all we want.'' But, he cautioned: ``I'm not going to ever predict that it's going to be a cakewalk. If we do it right, the casualties will be light, we hope.''

DOC.HEAD: El Salvador Rebel Commander Has Unique Perspective on War ^Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
LaserPhoto SJO1 of Sept. 10.
DOC.TEXT: When Capt. Francisco Mena deserted the army and joined El Salvador's guerrillas, they greeted him with tentative embraces, hard stares and skepticism. For a year, a veteran fighter known as Fredy never let Mena walk behind him. ``There was a ceremony that was a bit awkward,'' Mena, who changed sides in 1981, told an interviewer. ``I gave a talk and afterward the guerrillas began asking questions.'' Some of those questions, he said, were: ``Why did you stay so long in the army? How many operations did you take part in? How many of us have you killed? `` `Damn,' I thought. `What have I gotten myself into? Here I came to help these guys, and they're busting my chops','' Mena said. He smiled at the recollection and brushed one hand through his wavy black hair. The 47-year-old rebel commander was in the delegation that, on Aug. 22, ended a fruitless round of peace talks here with the government of Alfredo Cristiani, the Salvadoran president. A nearly 11-year-old civil war between the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and a succession of U.S.-backed governments has killed an estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians. The trip to Costa Rica was Mena's first involvement in the monthly negotiations and his first respite from the fighting in years. He was included because the exclusive subject of the talks this month was a rebel demand that the armed forces be purged of corrupt officers and reformed. That issue is the main sticking point in the negotations. Col. Mauricio Vargas, as a member of the government delegation, protects the military's interests at the talks. Officially, the Salvadoran military holds Mena in contempt. In the words of Col. Orlando Zepeda, vice minister of defense: ``That traitor and murderer has no moral right to make accusations or demands on us.'' Classmates at the military and some other officers, however, have demonstrated a camaraderie with Mena that could help promote eventual accord. Lt. Col. Mauricio Duke shook hands and chatted amiably with Mena, his former superior, when they met in the lobby of the hotel where the talks were held. Mena gave a copy of his book, ``From the National Army to the Guerrilla Army,'' to Duke, who responded with a sly smile: ``Gracias, my captain.'' The copy, like another sent to Vargas, was inscribed: ``Let's not forget the 15th of October.'' That is the date in 1979 when young officers - Vargas, Mena and Duke included - overthrew the rightist dictatorship of Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero. A broad-based government whose objective was national reconciliation resulted, but a purge of the military old guard faltered. Repression and death squads followed, and the result was civil war. Mena traces his change of heart to a year as an officer of the National Guard, a militarized police force. He described counterinsurgency tactics that included torture, rape and murder of alleged leftists, and told of an initiation rite during which he declined an invitation to drive a bayonet through the heart of a suspect. While he pondered such brutality later in his air-conditioned office, Mena said, the suspect and 11 others were killed in the gymnasium of the National Guard headquarters. ``That kind of thing consolidated my change of thinking by making me profoundly question the role we military men were playing,'' he said. ``It became denigrating for me to wear the National Guard insignia.'' The proclamation issued by those who carried out the 1979 coup promised respect for human rights, an end to corruption and modernization of a semifeudal economy that left most Salvadorans destitute. Peace is possible if military authorities honor those goals, Mena said, but added: ``The picture is this: We're getting nowhere in negotiations, so let's have at it with the irons.'' Fredy, the guerrilla fighter so wary of Mena, was killed in combat in 1985. Just before he died, Mena said, they had a conversation in which Fredy told him: ``In those early days I didn't trust you a bit, like you were still the enemy. Who ever would have believed that we'd come to be like brothers, that I'd gladly give my life for you?''

DOC.HEAD: Storm Warning: '90s May See More Hurricanes
DOC.TEXT: A weather expert is issuing a long-term storm warning for people living along the Atlantic and Florida coasts. This decade and the early years of the 21st century could see a return to more frequent and stronger hurricanes, such as those that battered the region before a recent period of relative calm. The reason: The drought-plagued Sahel region in West Africa seems to be moving into a moister period. Historically, when that happens, more hurricanes form in the Atlantic and they are stronger than the tropical cyclones of other years. The warning came from William M. Gray, a professor of atmospheric science at Colorado State University, writing in today's edition of Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Gray said the ``intense Caribbean hurricanes Gilbert, Joan and Hugo of 1988 and 1989 may be the forerunners of this change.'' Relatively few intense hurricanes affected the United States between 1970 and 1987, a period when the Sahel region suffered a severe drought, Gray noted. The principal beneficiaries, he said, were the East Coast, Caribbean Basin and the Florida peninsula. ``It is these coastal areas, not so much the Gulf Coast, that will likely see the largest upswing in landfall of intense hurricanes when a long period of heavier rainfall returns again to West Africa,'' Gray said. If past variations are an indication of the future, he wrote, ``we should expect an eventual recurrence of somewhat heavier Western Sahel precipitation, possibly during the 1990s and the early years of the 21st century.'' ``With such a rainfall increase, we should also expect a return of more frequent intense hurricane activity in the Caribbean basin and along the U.S. coastline,'' Gray added. During the years of relatively few hurricanes, coastal poplations have grown rapidly, and Gray said residents of these areas need to be wary in the coming years. The federal Climate Analysis Center, meanwhile, reported that while much of north and central Africa is dry, rainfall increased in July and early August in large areas of the western Sahel. The region also was relatively moist in 1988 and 1989. Gray rummaged through historical records and found that the Sahel seems to alternate with long periods of dry conditions followed by moister times. For example, it was wet from about 1870 to 1900, 1915 to 1935 and 1947 to 1969. Records are poor for the earliest period, but Gray found that the Atlantic and Caribbean region averaged 5.52 days per year of intense hurricanes from 1915 to 1935 and 8.53 days between 1947 and 1969. By contrast, the dry periods in between averaged between 2.1 and 2.5 days of intense hurricanes. Why should rain in Africa cause hurricanes to hit the United States? Atlantic hurricanes are powerful storms that tend to originate just north of the Equator, in a region where trade winds come together to create rising air currents. When the ocean is warm, 80 degrees Fahrenheit or more, it helps create hurricanes. This water warms the air along its surface, causing it to rise. As that air rises, the seawater it holds evaporates, a process that forms clouds and at the same time heats the air even more and causes it to continue rising. This gives strength to the storm. Weather disturbances move off the coast of Africa over the ocean 50 or more times a year. Some of them generate hurricanes by helping this moist rising air organize into a churning storm. It's not the number of African disturbances that matters, said Gray, but the fact that in moist years they are better organized into storms themselves, and move more slowly across the ocean, building strength as they go.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Enrollment Dips At Schools As Foreigners Flee Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Enrollment at international schools has plummeted as foreign workers and their families head home to escape tensions in the Persian Gulf. And the expatriates who remain say they cope with the standoff by holding discussions on Middle East events and staging ``duck and cover'' drills. The foreign community in Saudi Arabia has shrunk drastically since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Roughly 5,000 Americans left the country's eastern province. A few have trickled back. At the Saudi Aramco Schools, enrollment is about one-fifth of normal. When school opened Saturday, 410 students showed up, down from 2,010 projected before the crisis. The Aramco schools, kindergarten through ninth grade, are run by the oil-producing company Aramco for the children of foreigners. The Dhahran Academy, a private school for expatriates, will open Sept. 15, two weeks later than expected. Only 600 students, half the normal number, have signed up, said principal Don Kirkpatrick. There are few Americans in the classes, he said. The low enrollment is also apparent at Dhahran Hills Junior High School. Nancy Hicks' seventh-grade language class had two rows of empty seats. ``I thought more of my friends would be here,'' said 12-year-old Miriam France who returned from Denver, Colo., two days ago. Many people, including junior high vice principal Bill Vahey, have put their children in shools in the United States for this fall's term. Vahey's wife and family are in Hilton Head, S.C., but they expect to come back to Saudi Arabia in late October. A U.S. government advisory suggests dependents of foreigner workers stay out of Saudi Arabia's eastern province. John McClung, 12, of Oceanside, Calif., said his family planned to stay in the United States, but his father changed his mind after talking to Aramco officials. Teachers and students showed little concern for their security, although they wanted to talk about the crisis and the presence of U.S. troops in the province. ``We have discussed the apprehension,'' Vahey said. ``I went into one class and gave them some political backround.'' ``I don't feel they are tense but they want to talk about it,'' Ms. Hicks said. Ms. Hicks said she and her husband, a structural engineer, were determined not to let the invasion intimidate them. They are just months shy of retirement, she said. ``I resented that person causing all this disruption,'' Ms. Hicks said, referring to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Several teachers, however, have resigned because of the political uncertainty, she said. The school is taking measures in case of attack. The evacuation plan has been updated and the basement has been converted into a bomb shelter stocked with water, flashlights and canned goods, Vahey said. ``Duck and cover'' drills have been held, with children diving under desks and covering their heads with their arms, he said. For some students, the gulf crisis has not changed their feelings about heading to class. ``It's not as exciting as it used to be,'' said John McClung. ``School is boring.''

DOC.HEAD: Latest German Concern: What to Do About Socialist Statues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto sent Sept. 13.
DOC.TEXT: A towering Soviet soldier smashes a swastika with a giant sword. Marx stares at passing traffic. Cars roll down Ho Chi Minh. Lenin tugs on his lapel. Germany is less than three weeks away from becoming a single bastion of Western capitalism, but much of the new nation will be filled with totems to the old East Germany. While leaders argue over how to pay for unification and East Germans worry about their jobs, many towns are wondering what to do with all those old statues, streets, squares and schools dedicated to the stalwarts of socialism. It is a problem far more complex than merely changing street signs and carting away scowling icons of stone and bronze. In southern East Germany, Karl Marx City wasted little time reclaiming its historical name, Chemnitz. But it is taking much longer to decide what to do with Karl himself, a huge, glowering bust that dwarfs tourists who stare at his gargantuan noggin in the heart of town. No community has taken a greater interest in this issue than East Berlin, the showcase of the former Communist government and the historic heart of what will be the capital of a united nation. An estimated 800 postwar monuments dot the cityscape, some of them the centerpieces of squares. In Leninplatz, the Soviet revolutionary is affixed to a jagged panel, scowling in flowing overcoat, one hand on his lapel and the other clenched at his side. In Marx-Engels Platz, Engels stands erect while Marx sits at his side, his huge lap a favorite place for tourists to nestle for photo opportunities. A committee of artists and historians convened last week to begin an monument-by-monument appraisal of what to do with the memorials. A similiar committee has been charged with examining street names. Some Germans want to remove all remnants of the regime imposed by the Soviets after World War II. Others say they should, to some extent, be preserved. ``Monuments, even if they are horrible or an attack against good taste, are part of the postwar history here,'' said Klaus Hetzel, a spokesman for the East Berlin government. ``You can find other solutions for them.'' The East Berlin committee members believe many statues will be retained but altered, perhaps by adding plaques that put them in historical perspective. Others may have new gardens or green spaces around them to soften them. Still others may be carted away to a single location, becoming part of a museum that will in a sense be a graveyard of Communist artifacts. ``What we do not want to do is merely get rid of everything,'' said Richard Dahlheim, deputy chairman of the city's Cultural Affairs Department. ``Too many historical remnants are lost to the emotions of the moment.'' Few monuments trigger more emotions than the giant Soviet memorial in East Berlin's charming Treptow Park. Many people are stunned by the militaristic scope of this tribute to Soviet soldiers who died while conquering Germany from the east. To see it, a visitor follows a path lined with birch trees leading to a pedestal of stairs. Two red granite walls shaped like drooping flags form a gateway. Two giant Soviet soldiers kneel in front of each wall. On the other side is a lawn that stretches for more than 550 yards, the burial place for 5,000 Soviet soldiers. On each side are eight stone sacrcophagi depicting feats of heroism. At the end of the lawn is a mausoleum on which a 38-foot-high soldier stands. Broad-shouldered and handsome, the soldier smashes a swastika with a sword and clutches a child, creating an idealized image of a Soviet avenger slaying the Nazi oppressors and saving the innocent. Many Germans want it shipped back to the Soviets. ``Marx is okay, but get rid of that thing,'' said Werner Tischer, 72, a native Berliner. West Berlin also has monuments to its World War II occupiers, including a Soviet memorial and a street named after Karl Marx. Hetzel said it will be up to a future united Berlin government what should remain or be modified. An estimated 100 to 200 streets are being studied by the East Berlin streets committee, ranging from streets named after Salvador Allende, the former Marxist leader of Chile; to Konstantin Ziolkowski, a father of Soviet flight technology. They already have decided to change the name of Otto Grotewohl street, named after the first East German prime minister who was a hard-line Stalinist. One broad avenue Americans are always startled to see is named after Ho Chi Minh, the Communist leader who drove the Americans out of Vietnam. There is even a Wall Street. Its namesake nearby, however, has been reduced to rubble.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Miss Pennsylvania Marla Wynne, who finished in the top 10 during the Miss America Pageant, says talk show host Larry King's disparaging remarks about her still sting. ``If he knew the work and the hours and the blood, sweat and tears that went into it, he wouldn't have been so quick to be so insensitive,'' she said on the ``Joan Rivers Show,'' taped for broadcast today. King, the host of a Cable News Network talk show, was a judge for the pageant, which culminated Saturday with the finals. He was asked by Rivers earlier this week which contestant was ``the ugliest of the group.'' Without hesitating, he answered, ``Pennsylvania.'' ``She was one of the 10 finalists and she did a great ventriloquist bit,'' he said. ``The dummy was prettier.'' King later sent Wynne a telegram apologizing, saying, ``In this case, I'm the real dummy.'' --- LAS VEGAS (AP) - Rodney Dangerfield left 'em laughing after three days of testimony in his lawsuit against Ceasars Palace. The comedian's lawyers surprised a federal judge Thursday by resting their case after calling only Dangerfield and a hotel employee as witnesses. Dangerfield contends he suffered a serious eye injury in a steam bath at the resort in March 1988. He completed his combative and contradictive testimony with a flourish, getting jurors and spectators to laugh as he told a joke to demonstrate how he uses his eyes in his stage act. ``My dog found out we look alike. So he killed himself,'' Dangerfield said, his eyes bulging for effect. U.S. District Judge Roger Foley recessed the trial until Monday. Dangerfield, 68, is suing Caesars for $225,000 in lost wages and $5 million in punitive damages. Caesars countersued, seeking $100,000 and punitive damages. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version of Ditka story in today's sports report.
DOC.TEXT: Football coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears is trying to cut the mustard in a new business - Ditka Dogs. Ditka's signature frozen pork chops already grace some grocery freezers. Now, he's expanding to a $1.8 million fast-food restaurant to open next month in suburban Naperville. It will be a place ``where local people can go,'' he recently told Food Industry News. Ditka has a one-third stake in Ditka Dogs, which hopes to open 10 franchises over three years. Ditka already operates three regional restaurants that offer a somewhat more exotic cuisine than hot dogs, sandwiches and salads. --- BOSTON (AP) - Former tennis champion Arthur Ashe Jr. says he considers the concept of affirmative action laws insulting but important. Ashe, who is black, expressed the mixed sentiment Thursday before a commencement crowd of 1,300 at Northeastern University. ``Affirmative action has provided many opportunities for thousands of dispossessed minorities, precisely because many organizations and institutions would not have acted otherwise,'' he said. ``Yet the very concept is insulting to me. I don't want affirmative action, I want human parity,'' Ashe said. Ashe, who played during the 1960s and '70s, won every Grand Slam tournament except the French Open.

DOC.HEAD: Cereal Joining Croissants on French Breakfast Tables
DOC.TEXT: Buttery croissants are traditional at breakfast in France, but an Agriculture Department report says corn flakes and other cereals are gaining favor. Sales of breakfast cereals in France rose 25 percent in value last year, following a growth of more than 80 percent from 1985 to 1988. The report in the October issue of AgExporter magazine said 1989 imports of breakfast cereals into France were valued at $5.9 million and totaled 30,496 metric tons, or 92 percent of total sales. Most of the imports came from West Germany, where Kellogg's - the most popular brand on French store shelves - has a plant. Other major suppliers were Britain and Italy. Although imports from the United States were ``insignificant, and have been for several years,'' the report said there is room for competition. ``There is potential for U.S. cereal sales, particularly for new, innovative products targeted at a niche market and distributed through speciality stores,'' the report said. No one expects French-consumed breakfast cereals to drain the U.S. corn bin right away, however. The USDA's latest crop estimate issued this week pointed to a corn harvest of 8.12 billion bushels, up 8 percent from last year. The September estimate has helped push down prices at the farm, now protected by USDA economists at an average of $2.10 to $2.50 per bushel in the corn marketing year that began Sept. 1. That was down 25 cents a bushel from the projected season price a month ago. Although the biggest uses of corn are domestic livestock feeding and exports, the cereal market is not to be sneezed at. The USDA groups together a selection of uses for corn as ``food, seed and industrial'' purposes. Wet-milled products such as sweeteners, starch and alcohol are included, as well as dry-milled and cooked products, plus corn used for seed. Altogether, in the 1989-90 marketing year that just ended, 1.28 billion bushels of corn were required to fill those demands. This year, according to the latest projections, the use of corn for those purposes is expected to gain further to about 1.3 billion bushels. ``Most of the increase likely will be in the wet milling sector among the corn sweeteners and alcohol,'' said the department's Economic Research Service. ``Dry milling will likely use about the same amount.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department has been told to use ethanol or ETBE blends of gasoline in government vehicles as a way of confronting the Mideast oil crunch. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said the use of ethanol and ETBE, or ethyl tertiary butyl ether, in the department's cars and trucks is required if the fuels are available at prices competitive to regular unleaded gasoline. ``Ethanol is produced from American corn and other agricultural products, and that's good for American farmers,'' Yeutter said Thursday. It also helps reduce U.S. dependency on foreign oil, he said. President Bush in his speech Tuesday night to Congress said ``fuel switching'' would be one way to ease the nation's dependency on oil imports. ``This is a great way for each of us, as individuals and as members of USDA, to demonstrate our commitment to America's farmers, America's environment and America's future,'' Yeutter said in a statement. The USDA operates more than 33,000 cars and light trucks in all 50 states. If all were fueled with ethanol-blended gasoline, they would use about 1.7 million gallons of ethanol a year, which would require 680,000 bushels of corn. On Wednesday, the department estimated this fall's corn harvest at 8.12 billion bushels. Department analysts say about 220 million bushels of corn were used for fuel in 1989-90, up from 210 million the previous year. A further increase is expected in the corn marketing year that began Sept. 1. Yeutter noted that the availability of ethanol and ETBE blends of gasoline varies from state to state. He also urged the department's 100,000 employees to use the blends in their personal vehicles. Spokeswoman Kelly Shipp said Yeutter's staff was ``looking around'' for a local source of blended fuel to use in USDA cars carrying the secretary and other senior officials. So far, none had been found, she said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department says there is a record supply of tree nuts, except for walnuts. A USDA report said Thursday that the ``burdensome'' supply of nuts expected in 1990-91 probably will ``result in lower grower prices'' because consumption has not kept pace in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Tomato Plants on Posh Avenue Cause Tiff
LaserPhoto CX4
DOC.TEXT: Steven Balourdos was tired of the glitz along the city's Magnificent Mile, so he did what he used to do back home in Greece. He planted tomatoes. Some of his neighbors are less than enthusiastic, but Balourdos says he's standing by his fruit. ``I feel very strongly to do what I do back home,'' Balourdos said Thursday. He emigrated from a tomato-growing region in the 1950s and runs a business on Michigan Avenue. ``You see a lot of diamonds, you see a lot of mink coats, you see a lot of Rolls-Royces, but you don't see any tomatoes on Michigan Avenue,'' he said. Earlier this summer, Balourdos had a yearning for some earthiness to counterbalance the downtown shopping street's glitter and haute couture. He planted about 30 tomato plants in square granite containers on the sidewalk outside a high-rise where he runs his second-story real estate development company. Only four spindly plants remain. The rest have been ripped out by unknown foes. The building's association of condominium owners contends tomatoes may be fine in pasta primavera but a makeshift garden has no place on Michigan Avenue. ``I do not believe that those tomato plants are an asset to the front of our building, bearing in mind the beauty of all of the other buildings on the Avenue,'' said the association's president, Marilyn Lewis. Planters outside other buildings on the street contain exotic flowers, neatly pruned trees and shrubs. ``We just don't fit in,'' Mrs. Lewis said of the tomato plants. The majority of the association's nine board members agreed that the tomatoes are an affront the avenue's aesthetic standards, Mrs. Lewis said. ``I don't know whether he thinks he's a comedian or what,'' said resident, Eleanor Folta, 81. ``I guess he thinks he can do whatever he wants.'' ``We can pray for a quick frost and that'll take care of that,'' she said. Balourdos has refused to back down. The condo association is considering complaining to the Greater North Michigan Avenue Association, which has guidelines recommending plants on the street be ``beautiful and low-key,'' spokeswoman Jane Driscoll said. Ms. Driscoll said she didn't know if her organization would formally object to the tomato plants. The group can issue only recommendations and has no enforcement powers, she said. The owner of a nearby jewelry store can't understand the fuss. ``If they were ripe, I'd go pick the tomatoes instead of going to the store,'' said Henry Kaplan, owner of Henry Kay Jewelers. Balourdos says he's received more than two dozen letters of support. He pledged to go to court, if necessary, to keep his beloved plants in sight outside his office window. ``Hundreds of people have stopped their cars to see the tomatoes on Michigan Avenue,'' he said. ``People pass by and they touch it, it's a great feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: House Approves National Service Bill
DOC.TEXT: A $193 million bill encouraging young people to volunteer for community service projects won House passage despite a veto threat from the White House. The National Service Act, approved on a voice vote Thursday, now goes to a conference committee to resolve differences with a version passed by the Senate last spring. The Senate version is less costly and contains a key provision not included by the House - a $35 million demonstration program providing financial aid to college students and first-time homebuyers in exchange for community volunteer work. Democratic backers of that provision reluctantly supported the bill and said they would try to have it restored in conference. ``This is not national service,'' said Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., one of the sponsors of tying financial aid to youth service. ``... This is a very weak image of what we saw as national service.'' The idea was the outgrowth of a proposal by the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of moderate and conservative Democrats trying to push their party toward the political right. Without that provision, the House bill would provide money for federal grants to states to establish programs in the schools encouraging community service volunteer work and incorporating the service into school curricula. It would set up an American Conservation Corps to perform volunteer projects for conservation, historical and cultural projects. It would establish a Youth Service Corps, as part of the existing ACTION volunteer program, to perform volunteer service in social programs including nursing homes, day care centers and other non-profit organizations. The Senate's $35 million demonstration program would provide young people vouchers of up to $5,000 - good for higher education or first-home purchases - in return for a year's volunteer work. That provision was strongly opposed by Rep. Gus Hawkins, D-Calif., chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, which removed it before sending the bill to the floor. Hawkins told the House his bill ``rejects any linkage between service and student financial assistance.'' ``This bill is an attempt to make the concept of service more central to Americans' life and work,'' Hawkins said. Republicans opposed the measure as too costly and unnecessary, and some said government involvement would actually discourage people to do volunteer work. ``Here we are today, in the midst of deficit reduction, saying `Let's pass another program ... a centralized bureaucracy for volunteerism,''' said Rep. Steve Gunderson, R-Wis. ``It's unnecessary,'' added Rep. Thomas Petri, R-Wis. ``The volunteer service is alive and well and just doesn't need government messing around with it.'' The White House budget office said in a statement that Bush's advisers would recommend he veto the bill if enacted in the version approved by the House. The statement said the measure is too costly, provides unneeded financial incentives and is an ``attempt to direct community service efforts from the federal level rather than from the community.'' The bill provides for government student aid loans to be deferred and partially canceled for students who perform fulltime volunteer community service, are professionally employed in drug counseling or do fulltime volunteer work providing health care to American Indians. The House defeated, 212-200, a move by Republicans to eliminate the loan cancellation provision, which they said would cause untold cost to the government. Sponsors, however, said it would amount to only $500,000 a year.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Elections in Doubt Under Caretaker Government
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - After 186 years of authoritarian rule, mostly out of the barrel of a gun, democracy has again been deferred on this impoverished Caribbean island. The postponement of elections has threatened to unravel the caretaker civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot and raised new doubts about whether Haiti can succeed in its march toward democracy. ``She cannot make good on her pledge to hold genuine elections, so her administration has lost its reason to exist,'' said Gerard Pierre-Charles, one of Haiti's most respected political analysts. ``We are sliding inexorably towards the temptation of a military coup.'' The independent Electoral Council, charged by the constitution with organizing free and fair balloting, said last week it was postponing the Nov. 4 elections until sometime in December for lack of funds. But critics say the problem is more than money. They accuse Pascal-Trouillot's 6-month-old transitional government with corruption and ineptness. During her short term, Haiti has been beset by a crime wave, unpunished political murders and growing poverty in what is already one of the world's poorest countries. ``The problem of elections is not only technical; it is political. The government looks down its nose at the prerequisites of justice and security,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a member of the 12-party Unity Assembly politcal coalition. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a former Supreme Court judge, was appointed by the Unity Assembly on March 13 after the fall of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, who had taken power in September 1988 during a soldiers' rebellion that toppled the previous government. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was to govern jointly with a Council of State, a quasi-legislative body of 19 prominent Haitians. The government's main task was to lead Haiti to its first free elections since independence from France in 1804. It is the country's fifth government since Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in 1986, ending 29 years of dictatorial Duvalier-family rule. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has had the support of the United States. It has tied renewal of economic aid, cut after an Election Day massacre in 1987, to democratic elections. Five presidential candidates considered strong contenders disavow any efforts to unseat the president before elections. But seven political parties in the Unity Assembly have called for her resignation and say they will boycott the vote if she is president. They made the appeal after the Council of State broke relations with her on Aug. 14. Council members charged she was an obstacle to elections, and five Cabinet ministers later resigned. ``We can say she has continually acted in bad faith, in violation of the conditions of her appointment,'' said Dr. Louis Roy, president of the council. ``Her policy to avoid confrontation with the most retrograde and criminal elements ... has led us to this impasse.'' The council charges she has not abided by an accord signed with political leaders to institute urgent administrative, judicial and military reforms. The president has also alienated labor unions and businessmen who believe mismanagement of funds is behind a $30 million budget deficit - $20 million of which accrued since April. Misgivings perhaps could have been overlooked had the government investigated the murder of council member Serge Villard, who was shot and killed in broad daylight on June 21 by men linked to the army. Also killed in the attack was a union activist. There have been no arrests, even though more than a dozen people witnessed the shooting. A month after the assassinations, two figures linked to brutal previous regimes returned to the country from exile and remain at large, despite warrants for their arrest. Many fear year's vote could be disrupted by the return of Roger Lafontant, whose feared Tontons Macoute militia kept the Duvalier family in power, and retired Maj. Gen. Williams Regala. Regala was head of security during the November 1987 massacre of 34 voters at the polls by thugs working in collusion with the army. Voter registration is set for Oct. 5. But the Electoral Council said it will suspend election activities if voters do not sign up in sufficient numbers to give credibility to the next government. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has vowed to remain in office until elections. Despite the uncertainty, many Haitians still hold out hope that Haiti will not return to the tyranny of the past. ``The popular desire for democracy is too deeply rooted to be eradicated,'' said the analyst, Pierre-Charles.

DOC.HEAD: CBS and Japanese Network Announce Newsgathering Agreement
DOC.TEXT: CBS will join with Tokyo Broadcasting System to share the financial burden of gathering news overseas. Under the agreement announced Thursday, the two companies also will study the possibility of co-producing sports and entertainment programming, although no joint projects in those areas are imminent, said James A. Warner, president of CBS marketing arm, CBS Enterprises. The agreement is effective in April, he said. John Frazee, CBS News' vice president for news services, said the agreement isn't necessarily a prelude to a larger operation that might eventually try to compete globally with the 24-hour Cable News Network. CNN, started in 1980, is seen in 95 countries. ``I'll just say that anything is possible and we are looking at all kinds of possibilities'' with the Japanese network, Frazee said. ``We'll consider anything.'' CBS and Tokyo Broadcasting have cooperated with each other on news coverage for 30 years and share office space in New York, Tokyo and Johannesburg. The two will have access to each other's worldwide news reports and programs, with TBS getting exclusive rights to air in Japan all CBS News reports and such programs as ``60 Minutes.'' CBS News once provided news to the rival NHK network, but that arrangement ended two years ago, Frazee said. CBS still services several Japanese broadcast companies but will stop when the exclusive agreement with Tokyo Broadcasting begins, Warner said. Tokyo Broadcasting and CBS News plan to share office space in more overseas cities, possibly starting with a Berlin office that also would be shared with CNN, Frazee said. Save for ``tentative'' plans for Berlin, no decisions had been made on other cities for the sharing of news, Frazee said. CBS News had been the only one of the three major U.S. networks without an overseas partner in sharing newsgathering costs. NBC News bought a 37.5 percent interest in Visnews, a London-based video news service. ABC News has a 45 percent interest in a similar agency in London, Worldwide Television News, which CBS also subscribes to. CBS News will continue as a subscriber to Worldwide Television, Frazee said.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Women Marries Elephant Keeper After Ride
DOC.TEXT: A two-hour ride on the back of an elephant has changed the life of a Swiss tourist. That night she married the elephant keeper, official radio reported. Radio Thailand said Anouk Tschabold, 22, was smitten with the elephant keeper, or mahout, during a recent jungle ride in the northern province of Chiang Rai. Ms. Tschabold was initially impressed by the politeness of Su-rang Ner-pae, also 22. Love blossomed as the ride progressed against a backdrop of mountains, the radio said. That night they were married in a traditional Karen ceremony. Her husband is a member of this ethnic minority famed for its ability to catch, train and ride elephants. The broadcast, a transcript of which was made available today, said the Swiss bride from Lausanne planned to give up her job in the computer field and live in Thailand.

DOC.HEAD: Namibian Official Says Seal Harvest Has Begun
DOC.TEXT: The government has granted quotas for the harvesting of 19,400 seals this year and 256 seals were killed last week off the country's coast, an official says. Dr. Jan Jurgens, the director of sea fisheries, told the independent South African Press Association that permit holders at Cape Cross in the north and Luderitz in the south received the quotas last Friday. He said Wednesday that 256 seals were harvested last Friday and Saturday, the first two days of a season that lasts until November 15. A South African environmental group claimed 17,000 seals already had been culled at Cape Cross since last Friday, SAPA reported. SAPA said Cape Cross has a seal population of about 200,000, while Luderitz has about 250,000. In July, South Africa suspended plans to kill 30,000 seals after protests from environmentalists. The seals were to be used for dog food and aphrodisiacs.

DOC.HEAD: Experienced Storyteller, Barbara Bush, to Read on Radio
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, who has been reading stories to her own children and grandchildren for years, reaches out to a wider audience this weekend with a nationally broadcast radio series. Borrowing a page from former New York Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, the first lady will be reading children's stories over the ABC radio network in a weekly series called ``Mrs. Bush's Story Time.'' She'll also be offering tips in her 10 half-hour broadcasts to parents on reading aloud to children. It's all part of her family literacy campaign. Unlike New York's Depression-era mayor, who broadcast the comics during a newspaper strike, Mrs. Bush is eschewing the funny pages and sticking with children's literature. But she will get an assist from the cartoon world. Mrs. Bush will be reading her stories to such familiar characters as Winnie the Pooh, Garfield, Bugs Bunny, Roger Rabbit, Mickey and Minnie Mouse and Big Bird, done by their usual cartoon voices. ``I'm not a comic reader,'' snipped Mrs. Bush. ``What we're trying to do is encourage families to read to their children and take them to libraries,'' she explained in an interview. ``We're going to tell them how to stop and talk and how to explain words'' the kids don't understand, she said. ``Mrs. Bush's Story Time'' is a joint project of ABC's Project Literacy U.S. and the Philadelphia-based Children's Literacy Initiative. Jim Farley, executive producer of the series, calls it ``a radical departure'' for commercial radio. ``American commercial radio stations don't program to kids,'' he said. ``They don't let kids fill out (ratings) diaries, so they don't count in the ratings.'' For children listening to the first lady's broadcasts, ``radio won't be a jukebox, it will be a source of both entertainment and stimulation,'' the producer said. Mrs. Bush taped the broadcasts in two sittings at ABC's Washington studios earlier this summer. The cartoon voices were dubbed in later. ``This is an experienced storyteller,'' said Farley. ``She was terrific.'' The line up of stories include ``Ira Sleeps Over,'' ``Sylvester and the Magic Pebble,'' ``The Story of Ferdinand,'' ``The Three Billy Goats Gruff'' and ``Frog and Toad Together.'' Farley said the stories are intended to hold the interest of children from ages 3 to 10. Mrs. Bush interrupts her own storytelling to ask her listeners open-ended questions, and each week she offers a reading tip for parents. Each broadcast ends with such celebrities as Oprah Winfrey and Bette Midler talking about how reading affected their lives. More than 100 radio stations have signed up to air the weekly broadcasts at various times starting this Saturday and Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T to Offer Fax Service for U.S. Troops In Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is making it easier for families and friends to reach out and touch U.S. military personnel stationed in the Middle East. The company said Thursday that beginning Sept. 21 it will provide free facsimile service at its 400 phone sales centers in the United States for messages to the more than 100,000 troops taking part in Operation Desert Shield. MCI Communications Corp. also was considering a range of services to families, including facsimile and electronic mail, perhaps through personal computers, said Jerry Edgerton, MCI vice president for government systems. US Sprint spokesman Jim Crawford said his company was considering installing more phone lines, electronic mail service or videoconferencing to the Middle East. AT&T's ``Desert Fax'' service resulted from a request from Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., who also asked MCI and Sprint to provide similar services to the troops. ``If we're using 20th century weapons, we also should be using 20th century communications,'' Cranston said in a statement. He said a facsimile service would provide a big boost to morale for U.S. forces participating in Operation Desert Shield. AT&T said the duration of Desert Fax ``will depend on several factors, including cost, volume of messages and benefits to military personnel and their families.'' AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said it normally would cost someone $3.46 to use the same facsimile service to transmit a page to the Middle East. He added that AT&T had installed 25 facsimile machines at an undisclosed location in the Middle East to handle the messages. A facsimile or ``fax'' machine takes a printed page and translates it into electronic signals that are sent through the phone network and reprinted by a distant facsimile machine. AT&T said military postal service personnel will deliver the messages at regular mail calls in the Middle East, where U.S. troops were posted following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Senders must fill out forms with a message, the name of a person stationed in the Middle East and an APO or FPO address. AT&T said it cannot accept messages without proper APO or FPO addresses. The addresses of AT&T Phone Centers may be obtained by calling 1-800-555-8111.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Praises Upcoming `People-To-People' Diplomacy In Kansas
DOC.TEXT: For Soviet historian Robert Ivanov, no setting is more appropriate than Kansas for a summit next month of citizens of the world's two most powerful nations. Ivanov, an American history scholar in Moscow, said Thursday it's ``tremendously important'' that the gathering coincide with celebrations in Kansas of the centennial of President Dwight Eisenhower's birth. ``The first attempts to improve our relations was during Eisenhower's presidency,'' Ivanov said at a news conference at the Soviet embassy to announce details of the ``Meeting For Peace.'' More than 250 Soviets and an equal number of Americans will meet Oct. 12-18 in Lawrence, Kan. ``There's never been anything quite like this where several hundred people from the Soviet Union have descended upon one state, coming in peace as they are,'' said Bob Swan of Lawrence, the U.S. co-chairman of the event. The Soviets, from all 15 republics and a cross-section of society, will live with American families and participate in events in Lawrence and six other cities across the state. ``We have an opportunity to really celebrate this new era of peace and cooperation,'' said Swan. The gathering occurs during the commemoration of the 100th anniversary of Eisenhower's birthday, Oct. 14, 1890. A Soviet-U.S. group will attend a special ceremony on Oct. 13 in Abilene, Kan., Eisenhower's boyhood home. Ivanov, who has published a biography of Eisenhower, said the former president was ``tremendously popular'' in the Soviet Union because of his military leadership during World War II, when the U.S. and Soviets were allies. ``Eisenhower was ahead of his time'' in trying to improve U.S.-Soviet relations, said Ivanov, citing Eisenhower's ``open skies'' proposal to permit air inspection of each country's military bases. It was during Eisenhower's administration in 1959 that Nikita Khrushchev visited the United States and conferred with the president at Camp David, Md. Ivanov said Khrushchev's son, Sergei, will attend the conference and John Eisenhower had been invited. ``Two sons of two presidents, we hope, will meet in Kansas,'' said Ivanov. U.S. and Soviet specialists in a variety of fields will hold special workshops to exchange information on issues such as business, trade, agriculture, medical care, energy and the environment. Former President Ford is to speak at one event. Organizers said they hope the sessions produce ``concrete results,'' such as ways to increase business deals between the two countries. ``Our task is not only to meet, to talk about peace, friendship and mutual understanding,'' said Ivanov. ``Our relations today, after the end of the Cold War, they should not depend on President (Mikhail) Gorbachev and on President Bush. Presidents ... come, then go. But people stay and it's our task to put under these new Soviet-American relations, a people-to-people diplomacy system.''

DOC.HEAD: Mining Companies Fight Royalty on Gold, Other Minerals
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dale Bumpers says he can't fathom why the federal government would sell mineral-rich lands at terms enacted by Ulysses S. Grant. So the Arkansas Democrat is sponsoring legislation that would levy an 8 percent royalty and raise the fees charged on lands obtained from the federal government for mining ``hardrock'' minerals such as gold, silver, copper or iron. The 118-year-old law, signed into law when Grant was president, allows miners outright ownership of land for a fee of $2.50 to $5 an acre - the approximate price of land in 1872 - if they prove they've found a valuable deposit and performed $500 worth of work there. ``I don't understand why this particular industry ... ought to just have a bird nest on the ground,'' Bumpers said Thursday at a hearing of a Senate Energy and Commerce subcommittee. ``There isn't a state in the nation that would permit this.'' The government already gets royalties from oil, gas and coal leases, he noted. The Bush administration, however, joined representatives of mining companies in opposing Bumpers' proposal. Royalties could make it economically unfeasible to risk developing mineral deposits on public lands, said Cy Jamison, director of the Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management. Stephen Alfers, a Denver attorney who analyzed Bumpers' legislation at the Senate committee's request, said the proposal ``would have a devastating impact on the U.S. mining industry.'' Smaller miners will ``have no future, many mines will close, construction of new mines will decline precipitously, exploration and discovery of new deposits will decline, and mining activity will concentrate on private lands and in foreign countries,'' Alfers said. An 8 percent royalty on gross proceeds would consume nearly half the typical mining company's profit, said Alfers, who represents landowners and mining companies who develop minerals on public and private lands. The proposed royalty would raise $300 million a year for federal and state governments, Bumpers said. The Bureau of Land Management estimates that $3.9 billion in minerals are mined from public lands each year, he said. Since 1970, the federal government has sold land worth up to $47 million for just $4,500, according to a recent General Accounting Office study.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders Joint Custody of Frozen Embryos
LaserPhoto NY35 of Sept. 13
DOC.TEXT: A divorced couple must jointly decide what to do with seven frozen embryos, a Tennessee appeals court has ruled, overturning a landmark decision that granted custody to the woman. Charles Clifford, the lawyer for Junior Lewis Davis, declared the Thursday ruling ``a complete vindication'' and said it could lead to a settlement in the case. Kurt Erlenbach, who represents Davis' former wife, Mary Sue Davis Stowe, said the decision may be just another step in the legal battle over the embryos - the only disputed issue in the couple's divorce. ``I am very disappointed. Mary is quite upset,'' Erlenbach said. ``My guess is that we are going to appeal, that we are going to ask the (Tennessee) Supreme Court to hear it,'' he said. Erlenbach doubted that Davis and Mrs. Stowe can resolve the future of the embryos, which were produced in vitro in December 1988 using his sperm and her eggs. Neither Mrs. Stowe, who lives in Titusville, Fla., or Davis, from Maryville, would comment Thursday. Both have remarried. In February 1989, Davis sued his wife for divorce, asking a court to prevent any use of the embryos without his consent. Davis argued he should not be forced to become a parent against his wishes. Circuit Judge W. Dale Young called the embryos ``children in vitro'' and ruled in September 1989 that life begins at conception and the embryos deserved protection under the law. He awarded custody to Mrs. Stowe. The Tennessee Court of Appeals sent the case back to Young to enter a judgment giving Mrs. Stowe and Davis ``joint control of the fertilized ova (and) equal voice over their disposition.'' ``It would be repugnant and offensive to constitutional principals to order Mary Sue to implant these fertilized ova against her will,'' Judge Herschel P. Franks wrote for the three-member court. ``It would be equally repugnant to order Junior to bear the psychological, if not the legal, consequences of paternity against his will,'' the opinion said. Davis has said he wanted an equal role in deciding what to do with the embryos, but never stated what that role would be. Mrs. Stowe initially said she wanted the embryos because they were possibly her last chance to give birth. Later, she said she wanted to donate them anonymously to a childless couple, a move opposed by Davis. The appeals court did not consider the issue of whether the embryos are alive and deserving of legal protection.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Seek Extra Dollars for Persian Gulf Deployment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Timing of White House announcement uncertain
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants Congress to provide an additional $1.8 billion to cover the unexpected costs of Operation Desert Shield through the end of this month, administration and congressional sources say. Bush will formally ask Congress today for the money in an emergency spending package that also includes a request to forgive $7 billion in past military debt owed the United States by Egypt, said the sources, speaking only on condition of anonymity. The request also includes a proposal to transfer $900 million for the Persian Gulf deployment from unused accounts within the Pentagon to make up the rest of the $2.7 billion additional costs incurred in the operation, the sources said. The 1990 fiscal year ends Sept. 30, and the White House hopes that paying some of Operation Desert Shield's bills in the current year will ease pressure at least slightly as the administration and Congress draft a Defense Department budget for 1991, according to the sources. ``We want to get it up and done so there's not that budget impact,'' said an administration official. And the debt forgiveness for Egypt is included in hopes that pairing it with the military money will make it easier for lawmakers, always wary of foreign aid, to support, said one administration official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. ``There's a lot of head scratching over how we are gonna pull this off 30 days before an election,'' a source said. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, in visits to key members of the House and Senate on Wednesday, argued that the debt forgiveness for Egypt is necessary to reward an ally that has taken a leadership role in rallying the Arab world against Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In the private meetings, Eagleburger has made the case that aid to Egypt bolsters a moderate Arab state and helps to stem the rising tide of Moslem fundamentalism in the Middle East. Egypt has been the linchpin of U.S. efforts to mount a broad international response to the invasion, Eagleburger argued. But while many lawmakers agree Egypt is worthy of a reward, they wince at the size of the debt forgiveness and worry that other U.S. aid recipients will line up for similar largesse at a time when the budget can ill afford it. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said he has asked the administration for a better idea of how much the debt forgiveness will cost the United States in lost repayments each year. ``Egypt should be helped,'' said Leahy, chairman of the Senate Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee. ``They do have their neck out about as far as you can get. But there's going to be a need to help a lot of people.'' Leahy said he would like to handle it all at once instead of piecemeal, and with a full picture of the costs involved.

DOC.HEAD: Moo News Makes Bovimaniac's Newsletter
DOC.TEXT: Carol Peiffer is a ``bovimaniac'' with a mission. She collects cow figures, cow dolls, paintings of cows and other bovine memorabilia. And she writes a cow quarterly. The art teacher mailed the first issue of ``Moosletter'' a year ago to six fellow enthusiasts. Next month, she plans to send the 35-page fifth edition to about 100 subscribers. Peiffer, 45, said she has been collecting cow memorabilia for years, but isn't sure what started it all. ``It's just that one day some time ago - I don't even remember the date - I bought a knick-knack with a cow on it for the home,'' she said. ``When people came in, they loved it. And it dawned on me that cows were serene and kind, and then I started my hobby.'' When Peiffer met others who liked cow collectibles, she hit on the idea of a forum to exchange information. The newsletter includes the light-hearted and the serious. For the upcoming issue, Marcie Leitzke of Gresham, Wis., contributed a short story, ``Down the Lane,'' about growing up on a farm with a cow named Beulah. Ken Kephert, with Pennsylvania State's cooperative extension service, contributed an article about the animal rights movement. ``We don't take any side on any issue,'' Peiffer said. ``The Moosletter was started as a pleasant, good-humored newsletter and I want to keep it that way.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Even Pariah States Welcome in Anti-Saddam Front
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It was a historic moment the other day when representatives of the four victorious World War II powers, meeting in Moscow, took the steps that will permit Germany to become a sovereign reunified state. Too bad they couldn't savor the moment more than they did. The perils of the Persian Gulf crisis were perceived to be too great for more than a perfunctory celebration. Just hours before the ceremony, President Bush spoke to Congress and the American people in a formal setting for the first time about the crisis. The close timing of the two events symbolized the transition from the ideological conflict of the Cold War to the new and different type of struggle that the gulf conflict represents, at the heart of which is economics. In some ways, the East-West conflict was easier for Americans to swallow. After all, the survival of democracy was at stake in the U.S. commitment to the defense of European and other partners. In the gulf, the issue is somewhat less majestic: the survival of cheap oil. The administration, not without cause, has been saying that high principles are at stake in the gulf. Few dispute the contention of Bush and most other world leaders that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein violated international law when he devoured Kuwait six weeks ago. But the episode showed once again how selective governments can be in deciding when to be indignant. How many governments would have lifted a finger in Kuwait's defense if it were not sitting atop a huge pool of oil? Indonesia did much the same to East Timor in 1975 that Iraq did to Kuwait this summer. The Timorese found themselves invaded one day and annexed the next. International protests were limited largely to human rights groups. The fuss was contained because too many countries prized their relationship with Indonesia - an oil country, by the way. Americans feel more comfortable about defending democracy, but they don't have that luxury in the gulf crisis. The Kuwaiti leadership, by Western standards, was more benign than rulers elsewhere in the region, but no one has ever detected a Jeffersonian streak in them. But as Secretary of State James A. Baker III sees it, the stakes in the gulf are too high to allow moralistic concerns about multi-party democracy to transcend other interests. The issue, he said last week, is not just a narrow question of the flow of oil from Kuwait and Iraq. ``It is about a dictator who, acting alone and unchallenged, could strangle the global economic order, determining by fiat whether we all enter a recession, or even the darkness of a depression,'' Baker said. The administration's defense of Kuwait has taken it to some strange addresses. One example is Damascus, where Baker spent several hours Thursday conferring with Syrian officials. There may be three or four countries in the world that administration officials find more disreputable than Syria, which the United States accuses of engaging in state-sponsored terrorism. But on the narrow issue of the Persian Gulf crisis, the two nations happen to agree and to need each other. In times of world tension, the United States has often entered tactical alliances with dictators it would shun under ordinary circumstances. In the name of anti-communism, successive administrations cozied up to rightist strongmen from all continents. They did so because the perceived alternative - allowing a Marxist group to take power - was too perilous to contemplate. With the decline of communism, the United States can feel comfortable about loosening ties with countries whose only perceived virtue is opposition to Marxism. But with the rise of Saddam, the administration is ready to make common cause with just about anyone who shares the U.S. concern about leaving him unchecked. Saddam at this point is about as isolated as he can be, but the question lingers: Will the gulf crisis end as benignly as the Cold War did? --- EDITOR'S NOTE: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Tobacco Companies to Supply Cigarettes to Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. tobacco giants have leapt to the rescue of Soviet smokers fuming over their worst cigarette shortage in decades. Philip Morris and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco said Thursday they will supply billions of cigarettes to the Soviet Union, which has an estimated 70 million smokers out of a population of 285 million. The financial details were not disclosed. The shipments could help ease a domestic crisis that has caused unhappy smokers to protest in the streets of Moscow and Leningrad this summer. The companies have been emphasizing sales to foreign countries as the U.S. tobacco market gives ground to anti-smoking campaigns. Philip Morris said the order by the Russian republic, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, was the single biggest cigarette export order in the company's history. Marlboro and other well-known Philip Morris brands will be part of the order that will amount to more than 20 billion cigarettes by the end of next year. Shipments by Philip Morris International Inc., a division of New York-based Philip Morris Cos., will start at the end of this month. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc., a Winston-Salem, N.C.-based subsidiary of RJR Nabisco Inc., said it signed a separate agreement to ship 14 billion cigarettes to the Soviet Union. Delivery of Winston and other R.J. Reynolds brands is expected to begin next month and conclude by September 1991, the company said. Both companies said they will have continuing involvement with the Soviet tobacco industry. Philip Morris said it has an agreement to supply additional quantities of cigarettes to the Russian republic from 1992 to 1995. Under another agreement, it will help Soviet agencies develop their domestic cigarette industry. Similarly, R.J. Reynolds noted that it previously announced it would participate in a joint venture operation with the Uritsky cigarette factory in Leningrad. ``The Soviet Union is the third-largest cigarette market in the world, and we are pleased to help satisfy Russian consumer's pent-up demand,'' said Aleardo G. Buzzi, president and chief executive of Philip Morris International. John Dollisson, a vice president at Philip Morris, said the company will be paid in hard currency and in counter trade items, which he declined to specify. He said Philip Morris had been in negotiations for ``quite some time to get our products into the Soviet Union.'' The U.S. cigarettes sold in the Soviet Union are expected to be priced at a premium to the domestically made brands. Currently, American cigarettes are sold on a limited basis in that country, with sales restricted to duty-free outlets and stores that accept only hard currency. The shortage of cigarettes became so severe in the Soviet Union this summer that rationing was imposed in Moscow, where jars of used butts were being sold on street corners for as much as $16.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,897.46, down 177.62 points or 0.71 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Administration: Tougher Pollution Standards Will Cut Oil Consumption
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Tougher pollution controls will not only clean the air but help America ease its dependence on foreign oil, the administration says in trying to head off criticism of anti-pollution bills in Congress because of the oil crisis. The Environmental Protection Agency sought Thursday to highlight the oil-saving potential of the clean air bill by releasing a study that estimated as much as 1 million barrels of oil a day could be saved if the legislation becomes law. The study said the savings would come from utilities shifting from oil to natural gas to comply with acid rain pollution controls, and the use of cleaner gasoline blends that contain non-petroleum additives such as ethanol. Much of the savings would come toward the end of the decade. The EPA issued the report as some members of Congress began questioning the wisdom of new and expensive pollution controls at a time of vaulting energy costs. House and Senate negotiators for weeks have been engaged in intense discussions to try to work out a final clean air bill before Congress adjourns next month. The conference committee members were scheduled to meet today to give final approval to a section of the bill requiring new industrial smog controls and several other provisions. But broad sections of the legislation, including those covering new emission controls on automobiles, requirements for cleaner motor fuels in the most smog-ridden cities, and curbs on acid rain have yet to be agreed upon. The legislation is expected to cost industry as much as $25 billion a year by the end of the decade when all requirements become effective. Opponents of the bill and industry lobbyists trying to thwart various sections of it, have argued that such expensive controls are ill timed when energy prices are soaring with the potential of energy shortages in the months ahead. But EPA Administrator William Reilly said Thursday the legislation is even more needed now. ``I think the energy implications ... make it more urgently necessary than ever for Congress to pass the bill,'' said Reilly in a telephone interview. ``The total (savings) of 800,000 to 1 million barrels a day exceeds the total oil imports from Kuwait and Iraq.'' According to the EPA study, between 300,000 and 500,000 barrels of oil a day could be saved by the end of the decade if utilities switch from sulfur-containing oil to natural gas to comply with requirements for reducing sulfur dioxide emissions. The emissions cause acid rain. Another 500,000 barrels of oil a day could be saved because oil companies will have to sell cleaner fuels or gasoline blends that contain 15 percent or more of non-petroleum additives, the study said. Requirements for wider use of vehicles that use fuels other than gasoline also is expected to cut into oil demand, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Cartoon Woodpecker Gets Star on Walk of Fame
DOC.TEXT: Woody Woodpecker, the perky cartoon character known for his staccato laugh and shenanigans, was honored on his 50th birthday with a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame. About 150 schoolchildren sang ``Happy Birthday'' at a ceremony Thursday. ``Woody is 50 and I'm 90,'' said Walter Lantz, who created Woody in 1940 and has his own star on the Walk of Fame. ``Pretty good for a couple of old birds, isn't it?'' The meddlesome, red-and-blue bird has appeared in 200 cartoons in 35 languages and 17 million comic books. Lantz said he created Woody after a bird destroyed the roof of his mountain cabin. ``Every morning this woodpecker would be going at my roof. ... I finally had to replace the entire roof, but he's repaid me over the years,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Give Defense Department Control Over Exports
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has endorsed legislation through which the Defense Department would gain greater authority to block technology exports by U.S. companies to Iraq, Iran, Libya and Syria for national security reasons. Senate approval of the legislation came Thursday on a voice vote. Its adoption came as it was learned that the Commerce Department, despite Pentagon objections, last February approved the exporting to Iraq of digital image-enhancing equipment made by California company. ``Clearly, that device is going to be used against our forces; there's no denying it,'' said Stephen Bryen, a former deputy assistant defense secretary for trade policy. The Pentagon already has national security controls over exports to a group of primarily communist bloc countries but now can only advise the Commerce and State departments on export licenses for the four Arab nations targeted in the legislation. A provision expanding the Defense Department's authority was added by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., to a bill generally loosening restrictions on the sale of U.S. computers, telecommunications equipment and machine tools to newly democratizing countries in Eastern Europe. Helms cited the Commerce Department's approval in February 1989 of selling two furnaces to Iraq even though the manufacturer acknowledged they could be used to make nuclear fuel rods for an atomic weapons reactor. That sale was stopped just before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait when the Pentagon appealed to President Bush after Commerce officials had refused to allow the Defense Department to review the manufacturer's export license request. ``We have this situation where the Defense Department says `don't do that' but is overruled by the Commerce Department,'' Helms said. ``This has occurred over and over and over again.'' Also as part of the bill, the Senate approved a measure by Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., raising civil and criminal fines for violating President Bush's embargo against Iraq from $10,000 and $50,000, respectively, to $250,000 and $1 million. The bill now goes to a conference with negotiators from the House, which - at the behest of U.S. manufacturers losing out to Japan, South Korea and Europe on export sales - voted in June to ease the restrictions even more. ``In the United States it takes a business 114 days on average to get an export license,'' complained Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., whose state is home to several high technology manufacturers. ``In Germany, it takes just 14 days and in Japan only four days,'' Kerry said. ``Therein lies a great deal of the story why the United States is struggling in the world marketplace.'' The legislation reauthorizes the Export Administration Act giving the president authority to restrict exports and the U.S. participation in the 17-nation Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Security Controls (COCOM). COCOM is a Cold War-era multinational agency that jointly determines which high-tech goods are too militarily sensitive to be sold to potential enemies. In June, it agreed to greatly reduce restrictions on sales of computers and other technology to former Iron Curtain countries in Eastern Europe. Meanwhile, a company stuck with four multimillion-dollar furnaces that the Bush administration first approved and then disapproved for shipment to Iraq filed a $62 million suit Thursday against Saddam Hussein's government. The federal court suit by Consarc Corp. claims that Saddam's invasion of Kuwait and Iraqi deception over how the high-temperature furnaces would be used resulted in losses for the industrial furnace builder and its sister company in Scotland. Consarc, of Rancocas, N.J., cited U.S. assertions that the equipment could help give Iraq the ability to make nuclear weapons. Two of the furnaces were to be shipped from the United States and two others from Scotland.

DOC.HEAD: DiPrete Proposes Campaign Reforms - After November
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Edward D. DiPrete is proposing a wide-ranging campaign and ethics reforms. Diprete, a Republican, promised Thursday to ask the Democrat-dominated General Assembly to ban campaign contributions from state or municipal contractors and from corporations or labor unions. He would cut maximum donations from others to $1,000. DiPrete's campaign finance reports detail contributions similar to the ones he wants to outlaw. But he refused to return that money ``because I feel the candidates should be on a level playing field for 1990. We can't change the rules retroactively.'' He also proposed limiting campaign donations from political parties and barring candidates from keeping surplus funds. In addition, DiPrete wants to bar candidates from making loans to their campaigns. Democratic opponent Bruce G. Sundlun is a millionaire who has self-financed most of the three campaigns he has run against DiPrete in six years. DiPrete's voter approval ratings have dropped to around 20 percent as the state's economy has faltered. Surveys show likely voters choosing Sundlun more because they dislike DiPrete and want a change.
DOC.HEAD: Pressler, Muenster Release Tax Returns
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Larry Pressler and his Democratic opponent, Ted Muenster, both enjoyed six-figure incomes last year, according to their tax returns. Press, R-S.D., and his wife, Harriet, reported $154,020 in income last year and paid $29,906 in federal taxes. Muenster, a Sioux Falls businessman, and his wife, Karen, made $112,000 and paid $20,848 in federal taxes, according to their 1989 return. Pressler released his returns for the past 10 years late Thursday afternoon after Muenster gave his 1989 forms to the media. Pressler had challenged Muenster to release returns for the past decade. Democrats have tried to paint Pressler as a high-living incumbent who has lost touch with his constituents since going to Washington. The Presslers' 1989 income included the senator's $89,500 salary, $49,028 in speaking fees, and $15,180 that Mrs. Pressler made selling real estate.
DOC.HEAD: Wilson Takes Campaign to Hispanics, Feinstein Looks At Housing
DOC.TEXT: Pete Wilson courted Hispanic voters by promising to consider seriously Hispanics for appointments if he is elected governor, while Dianne Feinstein unveiled an affordable housing plan. Though Wilson made no promises of specific appointments Thursday, he pointed to his record as proof of his commitment to minority appointments. He noted that as a U.S. senator he had nominated women, blacks and Hispanics as federal judges. But Wilson remained firm in his opposition to hiring quotas, an idea the senator says his Democratic opponent once endorsed. Feinstein says she never wanted quotas, contending her views on hiring goals were misunderstood. In San Francisco, Feinstein outlined policies she said would ``make the dream of owning your own home possible for more Californians.'' The former San Francisco mayor said that as governor she would immediately tap $600 million in voter-approved bonds to build affordable housing, 90 percent of which she said remain unspent. That percentage was disputed by state officials. Actually, the state Department of Housing and Community Development has spent $151.9 million of the money after a delay caused by drafting regulations and hiring staff, said department spokeswoman Kathie Parrish. Another $200 million is expected to be spent by year's end and most of the money should be allocated by 1992, said Parrish.

DOC.HEAD: Family Says Woman Died Unattended in Waiting Area
DOC.TEXT: A 63-year-old woman collapsed and died in a waiting area at D.C. General Hospital after being all but ignored by hospital staff members, relatives say. ``No hospital personnel ever touched my mother, not until after she was dead,'' Carolyn Evans told The Washington Post. Patricia Jones of Washington waited about three hours for treatment after walking into the emergency room Monday night with several family members. She had complained of chest pains and shortness of breath, Evans said Thursday. Mark Chastang, D.C. General's executive director, said in a statement that officials are investigating the death. He also offered his sympathy to the family. The hospital declined further comment. Jones, who suffered from hypertension, walked into the hospital waiting room, got into a wheelchair and registered, Evans said. During the wait, Jones said she was feeling faint and asked to be taken to the bathroom, Evans said. Watson ran to the admissions desk to alert personnel about her mother's condition. ``My sister turned back and looked at my mother and saw that she was turning blue,'' Evans said. By this time, several other people in the waiting area, also noticing Jones' condition, began to yell for attention, Evans said. ``Finally someone came out,'' Evans said. ``But she just stood there looking at my mother.'' Jones was taken into the emergency room a short while later, after family members and others in the waiting room placed her on a gurney, Evans said. Evans said the family at first was told that Jones died from hypertension, but the death later was attributed to a blood clot in her lungs. D.C. General had more than 81,000 emergency room visits last year, an average of about 220 a day.

DOC.HEAD: Hometown Watches Hearings With Pride
LaserPhoto CR3 of Sept. 13
With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: High school teacher Tom Sutton wants to show tapes of David Souter's Supreme Court confirmation hearings to his personal-law class. He says Souter gives hometown flesh to the abstractions of justice. ``Here's the highest court in the land and we've got someone who is maybe going to be there,'' Sutton said. ``It's creating a lot of local interest in the man, but it's creating interest in the position as well.'' Souter, 50, answered questions Thursday during the first day of hearings by the Senate Judiciary Committee. He spoke about his life in this small New Hampshire town as neighbors watched with pride and affection. Janet Brown, a childhood friend, said she wasn't surprised that Souter brought up the town of 4,500 people during his opening remarks. ``He's a very caring person, warm to everyone,'' Brown said. ``He's what we were all brought up to believe in.''
