Souter said Weare bred a closeness among people ``unattainable anywhere else'' and added, ``We were aware of lives that were easy and we were aware of lives that were very hard.'' Marian Setterlund, who owns Cinder's Country Store, also praised Souter. ``He's apolitical, he's an honest man and he stays to himself,'' she said. Others in Weare agreed. ``I don't think he can do wrong in any way as far as the people in the town are concerned,'' Selectman Bill Herman said. Each of Weare's selectmen urged the Judiciary Committee to confirm Souter's nomination. Souter's mother, Helen, thought he looked exhausted on the hearing's opening day and noticed his 5 o'clock shadow. ``He has a very heavy beard. He's meticulous about shaving, but that he can't help,'' she said. Souter lived with his mother in their weatherbeaten Weare farmhouse until she moved into a retirement residence in Concord several years ago. Souter still lives in the farmhouse and visits his mother every Sunday. Brown said that the respectful way the senators treated Souter renewed her patriotism. She said watching the hearings was like watching America at work. ``I'm impressed with the whole system. America can sleep better knowing someone with his integrity has the opportunity to be there,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Iraq Tested Chemical Warheads on Missiles
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has successfully tested an intermediate-range ballistic missile loaded with chemical weapons, a newspaper reported today. During the test last year, Iraq fired a missile loaded with a chemical warfare agent, the Los Angeles Times said, quoting Arab and U.S. officials it did not identify by name. The test in northwestern Iraq shows that the government of Saddam Hussein can carry out a chemical weapons attack using missiles with a range of 175 to nearly 600 miles, the newspaper said. Such missiles could reach U.S. forces deployed in Saudi Arabia. No country has ever launched a missile attack with chemical weapons. Iraq combined the two after its war with Iran ended in 1988. Officials say such an attack would be far more difficult for Iraq than waging chemical war with conventional aircraft. ``It is an extremely complicated and difficult operation,'' said Geoffrey Kemp, a former National Security Council staff member. ``It requires that you have a mechanism that releases the gas at the right altitude as the missile is re-entering the atmosphere.'' Because missiles can travel farther and faster than aircraft and are more difficult to intercept, the test is seen as a serious threat. In response, the United States has deployed Patriot surface-to-air missiles to intercept Iraqi missiles, the newspaper said. The U.S. plan is to intercept the missiles at high altitude and disperse the gas before it reaches the ground, it said. Three types of Iraqi missiles are Soviet made and described by a U.S. Air Force official as inaccurate. ``They could be useful against an area target, but not against a high-value military target,'' he said. High-value military targets include radar installations and air fields. An area target is a population center. Iraq used chemical warfare extensively in the eight-year war with Iran and experts say that contributed to Iran's acceptance of a United Nations settlement in 1988. Officials say American troops are well trained in chemical warfare.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Romania Complying with Embargo After All
DOC.TEXT: Romania is complying with United Nations sanctions and has not imported oil from Iraq, the State Department says, contradicting its own internal study. An unclassified State Department report on compliance with the sanctions said that Romania ``expects to receive oil indirectly from Iraq.'' The report was completed last Friday and the Associated Press carried a story based on the study on Tusday. Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Thursday, ``There is no truth to reports that the State Department believes Romania is importing Iraqi oil, or otherwise violating the sanctions. ``In fact, Romania has been a strong supporter of the sanctions from the outset, and has played a very positive role on a number of issues relating to the Gulf crisis.'' Boucher did not mention it, but Romania has offered to refine oil for U.S. forces in the Middle East. Asked to elaborate on the discrepancy between the report and the public statement, a State Department official said, ``Information changes.'' He asked not to be identified and declined further elaboration. The Cuban government also has denied a State Department assertion in the report that Cuba had received oil from Iraq in circumvention of the sanctions. Boucher said that although there is no firm evidence that Cuba has violated the sanctions, Iraqi oil was delivered to the port of Matanzas on Aug. 25. He said Cuba claims that this is not a violation because the tanker was loaded and contracts signed prior to Aug. 6, when the U.N. Security Council voted to embargo Iraq. ``We've expressed our concern to the government of Cuba and said that as a Security Council member, Cuba should strictly abide by the embargo,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Emmy Awards to be Televised Sept. 16
With PM-Emmy List, 4 Takes
DOC.TEXT: Barring the weird or the unexpected, there is precious little in the yearly Emmy awards to titillate television viewers, except for the usual stargazing fest. On paper, the 42nd Annual Primetime Emmy Awards appear decidedly unweird. But in the tradition of live television, anything can happen during Sunday's 8 p.m. (EST-PST) telecast on the Fox Broadcasting Co. in which ``Twin Peaks'' and ``L.A. Law'' were expected to be the big winners. The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences still winces at past embarrassments: -The 1978 broadcast, which was pre-empted for more than an hour by a press conference announcing the signing of the Camp David accords between Israel and Egypt. The awards ceremony, which came to a halt while the historic peace treaty was announced, eventually resumed. Total elapsed time: 5 hours and 10 minutes, the longest Emmy program in history; -The 1980 Screen Actor's Guild strike, which left the awards show with no presenters, performers or trophy accepters. Although SAG promised to not picket the ceremony, the union barred its members from participating. Some ignored the order. Powers Boothe, who won in the miniseries category that year for his portrayal of People's Temple leader Jim Jones, was the only nominee who attended; -The 1983 program, hosted by Joan Rivers and Eddie Murphy lit up NBC switchboards across the country. First, Rivers called then-Secretary of the Interior James Watt an ``idiot.'' Next, the controversial comedian introduced ``Dynasty'' star Joan Collins, saying the character played by Collins ``has had more hands up her dress than the Muppets.'' Walter Miller, director of this year's ceremony, thrives on such unpredictable incidents. ``It's like life, you never know what's around the corner until you turn it,'' said Miller, who has directed three other Emmy programs, as well as 12 Grammy shows, four Tony Awards presentations and 18 Country Music Awards. ``It tests my mettle everytime,'' Miller said. ``Every show, something comes up.'' This year's program is hosted by ``Murphy Brown'' star and nominee Candice Bergen, NBC news personality Jane Pauley and comedian and ``Tonight Show'' guest host Jay Leno. Emmy trophies in the creative arts categories were to be given on Saturday night and broadcast Sept. 19 at 8 (EST-PST) in Los Angeles and New York. Sunday night's ceremony, broadcast live to the East Coast from the Pasadena Civic Auditorium and tape-delayed to Western states, is dominated by nominations for the most bizarre show on television. ABC's ``Twin Peaks'' captured a leading 14 nominations last month. The surreal, nighttime soap opera about sex, violence, murder and junk food in a Northwest lumber town captured selections including outstanding drama series, led actor, lead actress, and directing for eclectic film maker David Lynch. Kyle MacLachlan was nominated for his portrayal of coffee-slurping, pie-guzzling FBI agent Dale Cooper. Piper Laurie was selected for her performances as Catherine Martell, the ruthless director of the Twin Peaks sawmill. NBC's ``L.A. Law'' finished second in the nominations race, with 13 selections including best drama series (which it won last year), and three supporting dramatic actor recognitions for Richard Dysart, Larry Drake and Jimmy Smits. Drake's poignant portrayal of the law firm's mentally retarded messenger won him the trophy in the supporting actor category in 1988 and 1989. Sunday's three-hour telecast also will feature a montage tribute to late Muppets creator Jim Henson, compiled from film and television clips. The cast of ``In Living Color,'' Fox's risky comedy sketch show featuring an almost all black troupe, also will perform. The critically acclaimed half-hour program, created by Keenen Ivory Wayans, is nominated for outstanding variety, music or comedy series.

DOC.NOTE: EDITORS NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is with the 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

Has this ever happened to you? You get the family RV loaded for an outing. You manage to fit everything in just right. Then you discover a pesky radio bracket is somewhere you can't get to easily. What do you do? Well, if you're a member of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment, you laugh some, mutter some, then unpack and repack the pickup truck for what seems to be the 15th time. It's no big deal. The 14 men of the South Carolina National Guard unit have time to kill as they wait for a plane to take them to the Mideast. The latest word was that the water purification unit will leave this weekend. There had been prior false alarms, but this time the men treated the news seriously. Many of them stashed their families at post guest quarters or in off-post motels advertising discount rates for servicemen. Another indication that the men are short timers was a visit by Maj. Gen. T. Eston Marchant, South Carolina's adjutant general. Marchant gave the unit the state flag with orders to fly it in the Mideast and return it home safely. ``I'm counting on you,'' he said. Marchant also joked about the unit's reputation for card playing. ``I want to know how long it will be before you have that casino set up in the desert,'' he said. ``That would be Sgt. Cohen's job, sir,'' said Sgt. Ronnie Jackson, the unit's commander. Sgt. Hullie Cohen, who plays long games of cards in the barracks at night, smiled and nodded. Cohen, a former Air Force load handler, and the other men spent the rest of the hot dusty day carfully loading and rearranging four sand-colored Chevy Custom Deluxe four-wheel drives that will fly over to the Mideast aboard the same plane as the men. Cohen showed how to segregate potentially dangerous materials, like chemicals, flares, batteries and fire extinguishers into a separate pile. ``If something happens in the plane, you just drop the ramp and toss anything dangerous,'' he said. The slow-paced packing and repacking was supervised by Sgt. Robert Martin, regular Army, sent to help the 265th prepare for overseas. It was Martin who pointed out the misplaced radio bracket. ``You know what they do to messengers who bring bad news don't you, sergeant?'' asked Sgt. Earnest Deloach, a cigar clamped in his mouth. ``I look at it as constructive criticism,'' Martin said as he watched the work from his perch on a huge propane tank. ``I get my butt chewed if this isn't done right. This just makes it harder for me.'' ``Yeah,'' said Spc. Ulysses Calhoun. ``I can see that you're about to break into a sweat.''

DOC.HEAD: Refugees Into U.S. Hit Decade High
DOC.TEXT: The United States admitted 107,000 refugees in 1989, the highest influx in a decade, the Department of Health and Human Services says. Of the 107,000, 39,414 came from the Soviet Union, 37,066 from Southeast Asia, 4,826 from Iran, 3,808 from Cuba, 1,745 from Afghanistan and 1,724 from Ethiopia. Amerasians - children with a Vietnamese mother and American father - comprised 8,721 of the total, HHS said. Since 1975, the United States has admitted more than 1.3 million refugees, HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan said in an annual report to Congress. ``I am proud that we are able to welcome these refugees to our country and to assist them in their quest for self-sufficiency,'' Sullivan said in a statement. The 107,000 was an increase of 31,000 from 1988. It was the largest number of refugees since 1981. Through English language and vocational training programs, more than 24,000 refugees were placed in unsubsidized employment last year, said Jo Anne B. Barnhart, HHS assistant secretary for family support. ``These individuals and their families are now repaying this country through their work efforts and their tax dollars,'' Barnhart said. HHS reimburses states for costs of providing cash and medical assistance to refugees during their initial months in the United States. ---
DOC.HEAD: Panama Invasion Cost Nearly $164 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department estimates that the cost of the U.S. invasion of Panama last December was about $163.6 million, a congressional report says. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found in a report released Thursday that the incremental cost for Operation Just Cause was about $155 million for the Army, $5.7 million for the Air Force and $2.9 million for the Navy. The invasion that began in the early morning hours Dec. 20, 1989 and lasted until Jan. 31 involved 27,000 U.S. troops, including 13,000 who were stationed in Panama. The objective of Operation Just Cause was to remove Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega, who had been indicted in the United States on drug charges. The GAO based its report on estimates from the military services and did not independently verify the numbers. Among the costs associated with Operation Just Cause were expenses incurred prior to the invasion, including practice missions and the price of evacuating military dependents. Other expenses included replacing aircraft and vehicles lost during the operation, the price of ammunition and allowances paid to military personnel, including imminent danger pay and family separation pay. The release of the costs associated with the Panama invasion comes as the Bush administration is estimating that the U.S. military buildup to deter Iraqi aggression could cost as much as $15 billion in the next fiscal year. ---
DOC.HEAD: HHS to Recover Wrongly Charged Medicare Payments
DOC.TEXT: The federal government is trying to recover as much as $600 million in Medicare payments for claims that should have been paid by private insurance companies or other payers. Louis Sullivan, Health and Human Services secretary, announced the program Thursday. The funds are expected to be recovered in fiscal years 1991-1993. The program will identify cases in which Medicare was charged incorrectly for health care services to beneficiaries who work or to spouses whose claims should have been paid by employment-related plans. ---
DOC.HEAD: Pentagon-Postal Service Disagree Over Free Mail
DOC.TEXT: A day after the Postal Service offered to deliver mail free from American military personnel in the Middle East, the Pentagon said no. Military post offices collect the mail and then turn it over to postal officials for delivery in this country. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank had said Wednesday that his agency was prepared to accept and deliver mail, without stamps, from personnel serving in Operation Desert Shield. But, on Thursday, the Defense Department said letters without stamps cannot be accepted until Congress and President Bush approve the action. The plan has passed the Senate and is pending in the House. The House had appeared poised to approve the plan overwhelmingly until Rep. Thomas Ridge, R-Pa., offered an amendment stipulating that money to pay for the free mail would come from appropriations for free franked mail by members of Congress. Ridge's proposal was rejected on a voice vote. He then demanded a roll call vote, and because the House had already agreed to hold no more recorded votes this week, the members postponed action until next week. Pentagon spokesman Glen Flood said ``current law does not authorize free mail for deployed forces in situations short of hostilities. We hope the full Congress takes action soon, but as of right now free mail is not authorized. We hope that changes.'' Advised of the Pentagon decision, the Postal Service said that its announcement of free mail from troops in Saudi Arabia ``was made in the spirit and intent of proposed legislation.'' ``The Postal Service stands ready to accept and deliver service men and women's free mail when received,'' the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Allison Atlas Shows Progress Four Weeks After Bone-Marrow Transplant
DOC.TEXT: A leukemia victim whose search for a perfect bone marrow match swelled a registry of possible donors by 50,000 has been released from a hospital after receiving marrow from her mother. Allison Atlas, 20, of Bethesda, Md., was discharged from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center's bone marrow transplant floor Thursday after spending 35 days isolated in a sterile environment. It will be six months to a year before it is known if her immune system has returned to normal. ``The bone marrow graft is well established and functioning appropriately,'' said Dr. David Peace, one of Miss Atlas' physicians. ``At this time, there is no evidence of recurrent disease.'' The transplant was conducted after her diseased marrow was destroyed by chemotherapy and radiation. A nationwide search for a perfectly matched marrow donor inspired 50,000 would-be contributors, but none were suitable for her.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Japanese Stocks Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed lower. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average shed 177.62 points, or 0.71 percent, ending the day at 24,897.46 in moderate trading of 530 million shares in the first section. The index lost 141.06 points Thursday. Meanwhile, the dollar closed at 136.55 yen, down 1.10 yen from Thursday's close of 137.65 yen. It opened at 136.35 yen and ranged between 136.20 yen and 136.70 yen. ``Trading was mixed as many investors focused on cross tradings involving the dollar, the yen and the German mark,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank. She said the dollar's weakness has become a firm trend due to continuing pessimism over the U.S. economy. Other dealers said the dollar's weakness Friday followed its overnight decline in New York, where investors were discouraged by remarks by Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan about the possibility of relaxing monetary policy if the White House and Congress reach a U.S. budget deficit reduction accord. Lower U.S. interest rates tend to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average shed 192.34 points, or 0.77 percent, ending the morning session at 24,882.74. It lost 141.06 points Thursday. Traders attributed the index's decline to a weakness in the Japanese government bond market and a 43.07-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in New York. They said the Nikkei fell mainly due to a large-scale arbitrage selling to take profits between the spot and the futures market. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was higher at 8.400 percent from Thursday's close 8.385-percent close. The price slipped to 81.86 points from 81.93.

DOC.HEAD: Research Shows Ozone More Harmful Than Thought
DOC.TEXT: California air quality officials will tighten their standards for smog alerts because of new research that suggests ozone causes ill health effects at lower levels than previously thought. The state Air Resources Board decided Thursday to issue earlier and more frequent ozone health advisories, said board chairwoman Jananne Sharpless. Ozone, the most common element of smog, was thought hazardous at 0.20 parts per million. The new standard is 0.15 ppm. ``We strongly believe if the air isn't healthful, the public should be aware of it,'' said spokesman Tom Eichhorn of the Air Quality Management District in El Monte. The studies were made by the state Department of Health Services, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Warren Burger: Don't Ask Souter for Advance Commitment
DOC.TEXT: Warren Burger, former chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, says the confirmation process for David Souter should not involve asking him for commitments on how he would vote. ``Are the types of questions senators are posing to the latest nominee subjecting him, and the court, to dangerous pressures from elected officials, pressures which undermine the essential American idea of the separation of powers and an independent judiciary?'' Burger asked in an article he wrote for the Sept. 16 issue of Parade magazine. He continued: ``Now the question is whether the American people are witnessing a confirmation process in which special-interest groups have flooded senators with questions demanding advance commitment from the nominee as to what his or her vote will be on some pet subject.'' ``To expect a nominee to make commitments, or even to engage in substantive discussion of a case yet unseen, borders on the preposterous,'' Burger said. The Senate Judiciary Committee began confirmation hearings for Souter on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Singer Mary Wells Stricken With Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Singer Mary Wells, known for such 1960s hits as ``My Guy'' and ``You Beat Me to the Punch,'' is destitute and fighting throat cancer. Celebrity friends are helping her face the struggle. ``People say this is a cruel business - and it is. But a lot of people in the business do have hearts,'' said the 47-year-old singer, whose voice is barely audible because of a recent tracheotomy. The operation was performed last month after doctors found a cancerous tumor on the two-pack-a-day smoker's larynx. ``I'm fighting for my life,'' she said in a recent interview from a downtown hotel room where she lives. Miss Wells had been living comfortably with her 4-year-old daughter in a three-bedroom townhouse in the San Fernando Valley, but throat pain forced her to stop performing on the oldies circuit and her savings dried up. While she was in the hospital last month, her landlord evicted her for failing to pay her rent. Miss Wells has no health insurance to cover her mounting medical bills. ``I found out about Mary's illness while she was still in the hospital. I called everybody in the media I could think of to put the word out that Mary needed financial help,'' said Joyce McRae, co-trustee of an account set up by the philanthropic Rhythm and Blues Foundation in Washington, D.C. As a foundation grant recipient, donations have helped Miss Wells. Diana Ross gave $15,000, Rod Stewart and Bruce Springsteen came up with $10,000 each, and the Temptations gave $5,000. ``She's doing quite well,'' foundation managing director Susan Jenkins said Thursday from her Washington office. ``She is undergoing radiation treatment several times a week.'' The singer was under treatment at the Kenneth Norris Jr. Cancer Hospital at Los Angeles County-USC Medical Center. The radiation treatments, if successful, may allow her to avoid surgery to remove her larynx. The 2-year-old foundation has designated the Carter and Turner Management firm to administer the Mary Wells Fund. As of this week, the fund has grown to $54,000, Jenkins said. A portion of the proceeds from the five-album ``Motor City Dance Party,'' a medley of Motown hits, will be donated to help pay medical expenses for Miss Wells, Quality Records president Russ Regan said Thursday. As Motown's first successful individual singer, Miss Wells was among a group of rhythm and blues artists, including the Temptations, Supremes, Miracles and Marvelettes, who defined the Motown sound. Her other hits included ``Two Lovers,'' ``The One Who Really Loves You,'' ``Laughing Boy'' and ``What's the Matter With You Baby?'' --- Mary Wells Fund donations can be made through Carter and Turner Management, Attn: Willie Carter, 9229 Sunset Blvd., Los Angeles, Calif. 90069.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Keeps Tight Restrictions on Imports to Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. committee today allowed India to send food to its citizens trapped by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The vote came hours after the Security Council set strict guidelines for exceptions to the trade embargo. ``Let us be frank - there is food in Iraq and Kuwait, but the Iraqi authorities have chosen to deprive the most vulnerable elements of the civilian society, pushing them to the brink of starvation,'' U.S. Ambassdor Thomas Pickering said. The Security Council voted 13-2 late Thursday to allow food shipments to Iraq or occupied Kuwait only ``to relieve human suffering'' and said humanitarian organizations must distribute the aid. The council's committee on sanctions met later and gave India permission to send a shipload of food to its 140,000 citizens in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. ``In line with the resolution just adopted, the Sanctions Committee has approved the sailing of a ship'' from India to Kuwait to assist Indian and other nationals in Kuwait and Iraq, Pickering said. Under the U.N. embargo, passed four days after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, only medical supplies or ``in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs'' may be sent to Iraq or Kuwait. India and the Philippines had appealed to the Security Council's sanctions committee for permission to send food to their people still stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq has said it will not feed the 140,000 Indians, 93,000 Sri Lankans and 60,000 Filipinos it holds, but that they must rely on their governments. The resolution passed late Thursday night said the International Committee of the Red Cross or ``other appropriate humanitarian agencies'' should distribute food or supervise its distribution. That left open the possibility that the Iraqi Red Crescent, one of the Moslem national charities that are members of the International Red Cross, might be allowed to handle food distribution. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Al-Anbari said Wednesday that only ``Iraqi authorities'' could distribute food in his country. India has said it would like to distribute the shipment of 11,000 tons of food it is sending to Kuwait through its consulate. Pickering said U.N. officials ``will be watching closely'' this shipment and its distribution. The ship is expected to arrive in five to seven days. The United States, Soviet Union, Britain, France, Finland and Canada sponsored Thursday's resolution, which also attracted the votes of China, Colombia, Ethiopia, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania and Zaire. Cuba and Yemen voted against it. The resolution contains a narrow interpretation of humanitarian circumstances, requiring that ``human suffering'' be verified by independent experts. Under the resolution, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar woud seek information from U.N. agencies and other humanitarian agencies on whether a desperate need for food exists in Iraq or occupied Kuwait. While noting that the previous resolution permits the shipment of medical supplies and medicines, the new resolution urges countries sending medicines or supplies to closely supervise their distribution. Thursday's resolution also insists Baghdad is responsible for the safety and well-being of all foreigners it holds ``in accordance with international humanitarian law, including, where applicable, the Fourth Geneva Convention,'' which protects the rights of civilians in territories under military occupation. On Thursday, Dutch customs Thursday impounded a Bahamian-registered ship which was apparently carrying Iraqi-bound cargo in defiance of U.N.-imposed trade sanctions, a spokeswoman for the prosecutor's office said. Also Thursday, Canadian External Affairs Minister Joe Clark confirmed Canada has stopped shipment of a shipload of grain bound for Iraq. Iraq complained that Canada and Australia halted delivery of 120,000 tons of wheat purchased before the U.N. embargo. ``For it to have gone through to Iraq would have meant, in our judgment, a break of the U.N. policy,'' Clark said in Toronto.

DOC.HEAD: More Women Getting Mammograms, But Not Regularly Enough
DOC.TEXT: More American women over 40 are having mammograms to check for breast cancer, but most don't have them frequently enough, a new survey shows. The survey, conducted earlier this year and reported Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control, found that 64 percent of women 40 and older had undergone a mammogram - up sharply from 37 percent in a similar survey in 1987. But only 31 percent in the new survey followed the recommended mammography schedule: one every year or two for women in their 40s, and once a year thereafter. Researchers said problems appear to be doctors who don't tell their patients to have mammograms, and patients who don't think they need them. Forty-five percent of the women who had never had a mammogram said it was because no doctor ever told them to. ``Doctors are going to have to do a much better job of recommending that women get mammograms, and get them on a regular schedule,'' Dr. Douglas Marchant said in a statement from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. The college's Jacobs Institute of Women's Health commissioned the study, which was conducted with the National Cancer Institute. Forty percent of the women who had never had a mammogram said they weren't at risk because no one in their family had been a breast cancer patient. ``For years, we've been telling women, `Look, if you have a history of breast cancer in your family, you need a mammogram.' But women have translated that as, if you don't, you don't,'' said Dr. Sharyn Sutton of the cancer institute, a co-author of the study. Among the women who had received only one mammogram in their lives, 35 percent believed that because it was negative they didn't need another. ``Clearly, we need to help women understand the role of mammograms in routine preventive health care,'' Marchant said. ``And we need to emphasize that a single mammogram is of little benefit.'' Researchers also found that as age goes up, compliance with mammography recommendations goes down. While about 40 percent of the women in their 40s got mammograms every year or two, as recommended, fewer than 20 percent in their 70s got their yearly tests. ``It's directly opposite to their increased risk,'' Sutton said. ``People perceive cancer as a disease you get at 55 or 65, and once you're older than that, you got by, you escaped. I don't think older women understand that you don't escape; you need to keep going back every year.'' The survey also found that nearly 40 percent of the women questioned said ``mammograms cost too much'' and half said they wouldn't pay as much as $150 for an annual mammogram. Mammograms can cost from $50 to $250, although most are $100 to $125, said Dr. Marion Nadel, a CDC cancer specialist. The CDC noted that 29 states require insurance companies to provide some level of mammography coverage. Researchers estimate that 44,000 American women will die this year of breast cancer. Previous studies have estimated that breast cancer death rates could be lowered 30 percent if women received mammograms as recommended by the NCI, the American Cancer Society and other groups. The survey questioned 980 women in a national sampling, with a margin of error of about 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Saloon Ordered to Keep ``Spanky'' Out of Name
DOC.TEXT: George McFarland, the chubby child star Spanky of ``Our Gang'' and ``Little Rascals,'' wants about $100,000 from a saloon that he says used his name and face for 13 years without permission. Federal Judge James Rosenbaum on Thursday ordered the saloon not to use the ``visage or name'' of Spanky. It's not enough for McFarland. In March, seven months after McFarland filed a lawsuit, the owner of the bar changed its name from Spanky's Saloon to Checker's Nightclub. Drawings of a round-faced kid wearing a beanie came down from the front of the building and from interior walls. Patrons no longer could buy jackets, T-shirts and hats imprinted with the Spanky's Saloon logo. Other businesses pay the McFarland, 62, who lives in Fort Worth, Texas, for the right to use his name and childhood face. McFarland wants similar retroactive payments from the owner and former co-owner of the St. Paul bar. ``He's after 5 percent of their gross profits for 13 years and that's an exorbitant amount of money, even if they did something wrong,'' said Dennis Johnson, a lawyer for the bar's former owner, Michael Kalis. Kalis sold his interest in the bar to his partner, Walter Engelhardt, in 1982. Johnson and Engelhardt, who represented himself in court, contend that the bar's name had little to do with its business and that the connection with McFarland was unintentional. Marshall Tanick, a Minneapolis attorney representing McFarland, said they denied his client his legitimate livelihood. He said the Spanky name and image are McFarland's meal ticket. Tanick also accused the bar owners of tarnishing McFarland's name by associating it with heavy metal bands that perform at the bar. McFarland was shocked when he discovered his name had been linked to such bands as ``Raw Meat,'' ``Primal Scream'' and ``Blue Murder,'' Tanick said in court papers. ``Spanky's wholesome appeal, particularly to families and children, is debased by associating him with these morbid musicians,'' the lawsuit contended. In addition to 13 years of licensing fees and legal costs, McFarland also wants all the merchandise and bar equipment featuring the Spanky's logo. Rosenbaum urged attorneys to work out an agreement regarding the merchandise and took McFarland's other claims under advisement.

DOC.HEAD: Some 300,000 Mobilized for Flood Mop Up, Death Toll Rises to 106
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of soldiers, government workers and civilians were mobilized today to clean up the rain-soaked capital, and floodwaters from the worst rainstorm in 70 years began to recede. The Central Disaster Relief Center today said 106 people died, 40 were missing and 160,000 homeless in this week's flooding. Dozens of villages and large areas of farmland remained underwater after the Han River that runs through the capital broke through its embankment in outlying areas. While the water began receding, more rain was forecast this weekend. Thousands of people remained quartered in public shelters, and campaigns were launched for private funding and donations to help those without homes. Authorities said 300,000 soldiers, reserve forces, civilians and local officials were taking part in rescue and relief activities. President Roh Tae-woo visited flood-struck residential areas in eastern Seoul and pledged government support. Officials said damages to schools, homes, farmland, utilities, roads and railroads would top $240 million. The Trade and Industry Ministry said more than 500 factories in electronics, textiles and small manufacturing complexes outside Seoul in Inchon and Kyonggi have been severely damaged. Economists worried lost production time would further affect the country's already sagging exports. Three days of torrential rain that ended Wednesday brought the year's total rainfall to 90 inches, double the average annual rainfall. In one 24-hour period, parts of Seoul received 15 inches. Some areas in the capital were without drinking water and electricity today. Soldiers in jeeps and heavy trucks sloshed through muddy streets to help homeowners dump household goods destroyed by floodwaters. The piles of trash made some streets impassable. The stench of rotting food, upholstery and wet clothing filled the air. Prices of fresh fruit and vegetables jumped by as much as 50 percent. Military and civilian engineers struggled to rebuild a broken Han River embankment west of Seoul, where 83 townships and vast areas of farmland were flooded. Dozens of villages remain submerged, though the water was beginning to recede. Officials said 1,700 workers using army trucks and helicopters dumped rocks, sand and dirt in more than 100,000 sandbangs to try to restore the embankment, which was burst Wednesday by the rain-swollen river. A 53-year-old farm woman tried to poison herself in despair over flooding of her family's farm, news reports said. About 100 farmers continued to refuse to leave stranded livestock and remained isolated and surrounded by floodwaters, reports said.

DOC.HEAD: New Round of Salvadoran Peace Talks Starts Amid Heavy Fighting
With PM-Soldier-Insurgent
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran negotiators have begun their fifth attempt this year to end a nearly 11-year-old war. The army said new fighting between rebels and troops has killed or wounded 66 people. El Salvador's U.S.-backed administration and the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front began the latest round of talks Thursday and were to meet again today. They agreed earlier this year to try to reach a cease-fire by Saturday. But failure to agree on the issue of army reform, the main stumbling block in talks since then, has dashed hopes of meeting the goal. ``I take a bath of pessimism every day - we musn't expect any important agreement from this meeting,'' U.N. mediator Alvaro de Soto told reporters at the end of talks Thursday. Rebel negotiator Roberto Roca charged that government changes in military officers' positions in recent weeks do not meet the rebels' demands to purge the army of members accused of human rights abuses. Despite the standoff over military reform, Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria said his delegation hoped for progress in the round of talks scheduled to continue through Tuesday. The army reported 61 rebels and soldiers killed or injured and five civilians injured in stepped-up fighting outside of San Salvador on Wednesday night and Thursday morning. The civil war has claimed more than 73,000 lives, most of them civilians. An estimated 30,000 were believed killed by right-wing death squads linked to the military. The only accord the negotiators have reached this year is an agreement to form a commission verifying human rights protection in El Salvador. They have not agreed on when the commission will be established. The government has called on the rebels to disarm as a condition for cease-fire, a demand the rebels refuse to accept.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Lotto Jackpot Soars to $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: Jackpot fantasies are in full bloom in Florida, where Lottery players snapped up tickets at 500 a second in hopes of winning an estimated $100 million. ``I'm getting lost with all the zeroes,'' said Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul, who added a ninth digit Thursday to the projected jackpot. No more projections will be announced before Saturday night's televised drawing, she said. A $100 million jackpot would be the second largest in U.S. history. State lottery officials doubted the jackpot would break the $115 million record split among 14 winning tickets in Pennsylvania's Super 7 game in April 1989. The number of winners will be announced Sunday. The final size of the jackpot will not be determined until Monday, Mrs. Paul said. The heaviest ticket sales Thursday were reported along Florida's borders with Georgia and Alabama. Tickets are not sold outside the state. Joe Revolta and Robert Bache traveled from New Orleans to buy 10,000 tickets at $1 apiece at Groovin' Noovin's, a Pensacola convenience store near the Alabama-Florida state line. ``You might not have much of a chance, but you have even less if you don't play,'' Revolta said. Long-distance telephone calls poured into the state to friends and relatives asked to buy tickets for thousands of people attracted by the huge prize. Lotto mania even brought warnings from Lotto officials to spend prudently, and a gamblers' group questioned why the lottery is not providing money to treat compulsive gamblers. ``Half of the people in one Gamblers Anonymous meeting said they were tempted because of the lottery,'' said Paul Ashe, executive director of the Florida Council on Compulsive Gambling. To play the Florida Lotto game, players select six numbers from one to 49. The winning numbers are chosen at random during a weekly, televised drawing. The odds of one ticket containing all six winning numbers are about one-in-14 million. But for every dollar spent, there was a dream. ``I'd get a 200-foot yacht and staff it with chicks in bikinis from stem to stern and go to Europe,'' said 19-year-old Ricky Ford, a Tallahassee college student who spent $20 on tickets. ``First, I would help the church in any way I could, then I would by a ticket to fly to the moon,'' said Anne Straub, 66, of Gulf Breeze. ``I've just always wanted to go into space.'' Bahamians carrying thousands of dollars are flying to South Florida to buy lottery tickets to resell at a higher price back home, the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale reported. ``They come every Friday. This week they will bring $4,000 to $5,000,'' said George Prado, who sells lottery tickets at the Caribe Cafeteria, a Cuban restaurant near the Miami International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Ends `Doe Watch'
DOC.TEXT: Police eliminated the Doe Gang without firing a single shot. For 17 days, the Pekin Daily News blamed nearly every crime in this Illinois River city on John, Jane and assorted other Does to protest the police department's refusal to identify people arrested. Police agreed to reveal real names and the newspaper's Doe Watch has come to an end. ``The Doe family was a ficticious creation of the police as a way to shield the names of people arrested each day,'' said Kent R. Davy, the Times' managing editor. ``Apparently it was the historic practice of the Pekin police to shield the names of those arrested by listing them as John Doe or Jane Doe.'' Police Chief Jack Leuck scrapped the secrecy policy Sept. 4, allowing the Times to print the names of everyone arrested daily after city lawyers advised him the department may be violating state law Leuck, a retired FBI agent, said he took over a year ago and was told the policy had been in effect at least 15 years. He said the police changed suspects' names to Doe to protect anyone who was not formally charged. ``Sometimes we pick someone up and the victim decides not to press charges,'' he said. ``People change their story or make things up and we end up releasing the individual who was arrested. If that arrest is reported, it can cause an individual irreparable harm.'' Davy, a lawyer and former assistant prosecutor in Guam, sees it differently. He said abuses could occur if police arrest records are kept secret in the city of 34,000 people, near Peoria in central Illinois. ``People ought not be whisked away and jailed without the public knowing,'' Davy said in an editorial. ``People of position and influence ought not to be able to avoid prosecution after an arrest without everyone knowing.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Investigators Convene to Probe Rocket Segment Fire
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force team has begun an investigation into why a Titan 4 rocket fell off a crane and caught fire last week, killing one person and injuring eight. The team is headed by Brig. Gen. Ralph G. Tourino, commander of the Air Force System Command's Ballistic Missile Organization at Norton Air Force Base near San Bernardino, spokesman Ranney Adams said Thursday. Portions of a 400-foot-tall crane and a segment of a Titan 4 rocket's twin boosters toppled Sept. 7 at Edwards, the Air Force said. The rocket segment, 30 feet long and 10 feet wide, ignited when it hit the ground, sending a spectacular cloud of smoke 12,000 feet into the sky. An aide to U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., said ``the Pentagon seems to think there was a problem with the crane.'' The crane's builder denied that and questioned the soundness of the ground beneath the crane. The Air Force has refused to comment, saying no further information will be released pending completion of the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Pledges $3 Billion More To Gulf Effort
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan today earmarked an additional $3 billion for international forces in the Persian Gulf region and for nations suffering from the U.N. embargo on Iraq. The government, accused of being slow and miserly in providing such support, said the new funding will bring Japan's total aid toward meeting the gulf crisis to more than $4 billion. The United States has complained Japan was not contributing enough, especially considering its high dependence on Middle East oil. The House of Representatives made its displeasure known in a resolution Wednesday calling for Japan to pay all expenses of American troops based in Japan. ``If they had known the magnitude of the total package of contribution measures which we have announced today, they would know how serious Japan is in trying to cooperate with the United States and other countries in keeping the peace and security in that region, even at the sacrifice of our own fiances,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe told reporters. Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had phoned President Bush to notify him of the expanded contribution. ``President Bush expressed deep appreciation and told Kaifu that he will tell his people that Japan is playing an active role in the international effort in the Gulf,'' Sakamoto told reporters. Sakamoto said Japan would provide up to $1 billion to the U.S.-led forces deployed in the gulf region after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Japan on Aug. 29 had pledged $1 billion. Another $2 billion would go to such countries as Egypt, Jordan and Turkey facing difficulties from joining in the U.N. economic embargo imposed against Iraq, he added. Sakamoto said Japan would give $600 million immediately to those three nations as an ``exceptional measure,'' in the form of a loan at 1 percent annual interest, repayable in 30 years. Japan would decide how to provide the additional $1.4 billion depending on how the situation develops, he added. The $4 billion total figure matched the contribution that Japanese media reports said the United States was demanding from Japan. Watanabe said, however, it was ``our own decision.'' Sakamoto said the expanded contribution was the maximum Japan could provide at this point. Responding to criticism that Japan had acted slowly, Watanabe said Japan had constitutional and legal restraints against sending military forces overseas. He said Tokyo had not been consulted on operational details for the multinational peacekeeping forces in the gulf, although it was willing to cooperate with them. ``Therefore, when we are asked to pay the bill, we have to check the contents of the invoice, and we have to examine what is the real thinking behind it. That is something quite natural,'' he said. On Wednesday, the U.S. House approved, 370 to 53, a resolution stating that the United States would withdraw 5,000 U.S. troops each year from Japan until Tokyo agrees to pay the full cost of all 50,000 troops now stationed in Japan. The resolution has not been passed by the Senate. The United States spends $4.5 billion annually for the U.S. forces in Japan, while Japan currently contributes about $2.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Author Claims Moses was Egyptian Pharaoh
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th pvs, `Sydney Leperer...' to UPDATE with Canadian authority doubtful of theory. Pickup 9th pvs, `Naim Dangoor...' Author uses spelling Akhenaten, but Ikhnaton conforms to style.
DOC.TEXT: The author of a new book claims the Jewish prophet Moses was known to ancient Egyptians as Ikhnaton, the ruler and religious reformer. ``I am convinced that I have identified Moses as Ikhnaton, the prophet, poet and king in the 14th century B.C., who shut the temples of the ancient gods, sent the priests home and declared there was only one god,'' said Ahmed Osman. His book, ``Moses: Pharaoh of Egypt,'' was published in Britain on Thursday by Grafton Books. The U.S. rights are under negotiation. Osman's first book in 1987, ``Stranger in the Valley of Kings,'' theorized that the mummy of a royal official named Yuya was Joseph, the biblical figure with the coat of many colors who led the tribe of Israel into Egypt. Osman, 55, an Egyptian who has pursued research in Egyptology and the Bible in London for 25 years, is regarded by academics as a controversial but respected outsider. Younes Ahmed el-Batrik, cultural counselor at the Egyptian Embassy, held a reception Thursday night to launch Osman's book. ``It's a very interesting subject and a very controversial book and I will be interested to hear what the experts say about it,'' he said. In identifying Moses with Ikhnaton, Osman builds on Sigmund Freud's last book, ``Moses and Monotheism,'' in which the father of psychoanalysis commented on the similarity of the teachings of the two ancients. Sydney Leperer, a senior history lecturer at Jews' College, University of London, said of Osman's Ikhnaton-Moses theory: ``There is a faint possibility that it is true, although I have my doubts.'' Donald B. Redford, professor of Near Eastern studies at Toronto University and an expert on Ikhnaton, scoffed at the theory. ``There is no evidence that Ikhnaton was a man called Moses and the religious teachings of Ikhnaton have nothing to do with Moses, who appears to have lived five centuries after him or longer,'' Redford said in a telephone interview. Naim Dangoor, editor of The Scribe, a journal on Babylonian Jewry, said he had read and reviewed both of Osman's books. Osman ``knows a great deal about the period,'' and his theories ``invite further investigation,'' Dangoor said. Osman said in an interview that scholars had always had difficulty establishing links between any of the important figures in the Old Testament and Egyptian history. ``I believe that Moses had an Israelite mother and an Egyptian father,'' he said. ``He was the son of Pharaoh Amenhotep III and Queen Tiye, daughter of Joseph the Patriarch. Tiye's first son had mysteriously disappeared so when Moses was born, Tiye sent him by water for safekeeping to her Israelite relatives. I think that was the origin of the story that Moses was found in the bulrushes on the Nile.'' After 17 years as pharaoh, Ikhnaton was deposed and succeeded by the boy prince, Tutankhamen. ``I believe Ikhnaton survived and went into exile in Sinai with a few followers,'' Osman said. ``When the oppressor Pharaoh Horemheb died, Ikhnaton saw his chance to regain his throne as there was no heir. He challenged Horemheb's general, Ramses, for the throne but Ramses attacked him and forced him to flee. The flight was the Exodus, in 1333 B.C.'' ``Ikhnaton and his followers attempted to enter Canaan, the Promised Land, but were slaughtered by Ramses' successor, Seti I. This fight is recorded in the Temple of Karnak in Luxor,'' the author said. Jewish narratives are silent on any blood connection between Moses and Egypt because of memories of the oppression, Osman believes. ``However, the Talmud (the Jewish law) indicates that Moses became a king and was forced to abdicate,'' he added. Eric Uphill, an Egyptologist at London's University College, said he helped and supported Osman's research because he regarded Osman as a serious student with extensive knowledge. Osman's manuscript was based on the right sources for Egyptian history, Uphill said, but he would not comment on the conclusions without further study. ``The problem with Moses is that the historical truth about him is very unclear and lends itself to many theories, some of them haywire,'' Leperer said. Dangoor said Moses' death is a mystery that is not resolved in the Exodus accounts. ``Osman's explanation that he was killed by Seti I is very plausible,'' Dangoor said.

DOC.HEAD: 200 Sikh Widows Demand Justice for Mob Slayings
DOC.TEXT: About 200 widows of Sikhs slain by Hindu mobs six years ago wept, screamed and beat their chests outside the prime minister's home today, demanding the killers be arrested. ``We will not go until we get justice!'' cried 50-year-old Gopi Kaur, who lost 12 male relatives - including her husband and brothers - in the violence. Her outburst was supported by a religious battle cry shouted by the other women outside the residence of Prime Minister V.P. Singh. Most of them wore white, the color of mourning for Sikh and Hindu widows. More than 2,000 Sikhs were killed in New Delhi alone in anti-Sikh rioting after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was assassinated by two Sikh bodyguards Oct. 31, 1984. About 700 Sikhs were killed in similar riots across the nation. Many Sikhs, as well as human rights groups blamed the killings of Sikhs on members of Mrs. Gandhi's Congress Party assisted by hired toughs. Only 11 of the 225 people charged with murder and looting have been convicted. Three special courts have been set up in New Delhi to deal with the cases, but their progress has bogged down in legal and bureaucratic wrangles. Today's protest was sparked by the government's failure Tuesday to arrest a prominent local Congress Party leader, Sajjan Kumar. A police party that went to Kumar's house to make the arrest returned empty-handed after thousands of Kumar's supporters surrounded the house and threatened to lynch the officers. The mob wrecked two cars of the police officials and blocked traffic for several hours. In the meantime, Kumar obtained a Delhi High Court order that would grant bail in event of his arrest in connection with a murder case. ``We ... are pained that Sajjan Kumar has escaped arrest by strong-arm tactics and through ... muscle-power by indulging in violence,'' the protest organizers, the All India Sikh Conference, said in a letter to the prime minister. A copy was given to reporters. Sikhs and human rights activists have accused Kumar of personally leading death squads in the aftermath of Mrs. Gandhi's assassination. The women accused Mrs. Gandhi's son, Rajiv Gandhi, of stalling the prosecution during his term as prime minister between 1984 and 1989. ``But we derive confidence that in your regime, justice will not be denied any longer,'' the Sikhs said in their letter to Singh, who succeeded Gandhi in December 1989. Many of the Sikh victims were hacked, tortured and burned to death with blazing car tires jammed over their shoulders.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Slightly Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar recovered slightly against the yen in European trading this morning, but it was down from the previous day's levels against all major currencies. Gold was marginally higher. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 136.55 yen, down 1.10 yen from Thursday's close of 137.65 yen. It was the lowest closing level since Aug. 3, 1989, when it was 136.40 yen. Later in London, the dollar rose to 136.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5683 German marks, down from 1.574 -1.3045 Swiss francs, down from 1.313 -5.2545 French francs, down from 5.271 -1.7655 Dutch guilders, down from 1.774 -1,170 Italian lire, down from 1,174 -1.16 Canadian dollars, down from 1.164 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8855, compared with $1.877 late Thursday. The dollar opened lower in Tokyo following an overnight decline in New York. It recovered slightly as investors sold yen to take profits against the dollar and European currencies, they said. ``Investors focused on cross-trading involving the dollar, the yen and the German mark,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. She said the dollar's weakness has become a firm trend due to continuing pessimism over the U.S. economy. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $384.30 per ounce at midmorning, up from $384 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $384.25, up from $383.40 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.52 an ounce today to close at $384.34. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.81 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $4.82.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Court Expands Right to Die
DOC.TEXT: Relatives or guardians of brain-damaged people can order the removal of feeding tubes that keep them alive, the Florida Supreme Court said in a ruling hailed by ``right-to-die'' advocates. ``It reaffirms the rights of Floridians under our (state) constitution to make their own decisions about what will be done with their bodies,'' said Charlene Carres, a Tallahassee attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union. Roman Catholics, anti-abortion groups and other opponents did not immediately respond, saying they needed more time to review the ruling. The decision focused on an elderly woman who died last summer. Estelle Browning spent the last 2{ years of her life hooked up to feeding tubes that she had specified in a ``living will'' she didn't want. Mrs. Browning suffered permanent brain damage in a stroke and was left in a persistent vegetative state, unable to swallow or communicate. She was not comatose. Doris Herbert, Mrs. Browning's second cousin and only living relative, was named her guardian. Herbert sought permission to remove the tubes in 1988. The state fought the request and a trial court denied it, but a state appeals court said the Florida Constitution allowed for removal of the tubes and the issue was reviewed by the Supreme Court. ``We hold that, because Mrs. Browning was unable to exercise her constitutional right of privacy by reason of her medical condition, her guardian was authorized to exercise it for her,'' Justice Rosemary Barkett wrote. When people take ``the time and trouble'' to write ``living wills,'' express their wishes orally or appoint health-care surrogates, there's no need to go before a judge to get permission to carry out their wishes, the court ruled. Patricia Dore, a law professor at Florida State University who drafted the privacy clause added to the state constitution in 1980, said it was significant that the justices ruled there was no legal distinction between food and water supplied through tubes and other medical treatments, like respirators. Although it has no direct impact outside Florida, attorneys and advocates said other state courts could be influenced by the case. ``I think many, many state courts look to Florida for guidance on issues that affect the elderly,'' said George Felos, an attorney who represented Herbert. Florida's high court heard oral arguments in the case in January. Six months later, the U.S. Supreme Court said a Missouri couple could not order the removal of food and water keeping their 32-year-old comatose daughter alive. The daughter, Nancy Cruzan, had not left a living will. Her parents said they were certain she would prefer to die rather than live in a coma. In its split decision, the nation's high court said competent people have a right to refuse medical treatment.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Uniform Too Hot for Searing Heat
DOC.TEXT: Camouflage uniforms worn by American troops in Saudi Arabia are made for cooler climates, not searing desert heat, military and clothing industry officials say. The problem is the hot weather uniform, made entirely of cotton, doesn't have the desert camouflage pattern. The uniform worn by troops is made of the same material - half nylon and half cotton - that was criticized as hot and uncomfortable by American soldiers during the 1982 invasion of Grenada. Weather conditions are much harsher in the Saudi desert than in Grenada. Daytime temperatures have gone as high as 120 degrees since U.S. forces were sent there in August after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Jeffrey J. Weinsten, former chairman of an American Apparel Manufacturers Association committee that oversees government contracts, said the all-cotton uniform is more comfortable than the blend because ``cotton is a moisture-loving fabric that licks away perspiration.'' The blend ``is not absorbent at all,'' he said. The all-cotton uniform breathes better because it has a more open weave, but it's hard to find in the desert camouflage pattern, Weinsten said. Frank Johnson, a spokesman for the Defense Personnel Support Center in Philadelphia, said there are no hot-weather uniforms in the desert pattern because ``the powers that be said if there is a war it would probably involve the Warsaw Pact'' in Europe. ``Obviously we didn't figure on something like this breaking out in the Middle East,'' Johnson said. Johnson defended the choice of uniforms, saying the camouflage version is more durable than the cotton version. Weinsten agreed the blend fabric has greater strength and can resist desert sand better, but said comfort is more important. All-cotton desert uniforms make sense, said Philip M. Cavanaugh, director of the Quartermaster Museum at the Army Logistics Center at Fort Lee. ``It's what they should have done to begin with,'' he said. Asked why the desert camouflage pattern wasn't printed on cotton uniforms, Col. John Duff, deputy commander at the Army's research development and engineering center in Natick, Mass., where the uniform was developed, said: ``I wouldn't touch that with a 10-foot pole.'' Chemical weapons suits U.S. troops have in the Saudi desert are so heavy and unbearable that the Marines have replaced them with a lighter-weight, British-made model, a military spokesman said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Athene Seyler, Comedy Actress, Dies At Age 101
DOC.TEXT: Comedy actress Athene Seyler, whose stage, movie and radio career spanned most of this century, has died, her family reported. She was 101. She died at her home in London on Wednesday, her family said. They did not give details on funeral arrangements. Said by one theater critic to resemble ``an irritable hippopotamus'' on stage, she was recognized in the acting profession as one of the great technical experts on high comedy. She specialized in playing quirky queens and crusty dowagers with plummy voices and quivering chins. She especially favored the plays of William Congreve, Oscar Wilde, William Wycherley and Richard Sheridan. Critic James Agate once said that when it came to comedy, she could act any other English actress off the stage. Her plain looks generally ruled out romantic roles but combined with her sharp intelligence and vitality proved a considerable comic asset. In later life, she was mockingly critical of playwrights and directors alike. Of Harold Pinter's 1975 play ``No Man's Land,'' she remarked: ``I couldn't follow a word of it ... When one of the characters yawned, I said `Oh, I do so agree' rather too loudly and people (in the audience) turned and stared at me.'' She made her London stage debut in 1909, but it was not until 1920 when she played Rosalind in Shakespeare's ``As You Like It'' that her special talent for high comedy first showed. She appeared in almost 20 movies, including ``Quiet Wedding'' in 1940, ``Dear Octopus'' in 1943, ``Nicholas Nickleby'' in 1947 and ``Pickwick Papers'' in 1952. Her last major stage appearance was in 1966 at the age of 77 in a memorable revival of the comedy ``Arsenic and Old Lace'' in which she co-starred with Dame Sybil Thorndike. She continued working on radio until she was well into her late 80s. Her first husband was newspaper editor James Bury Sterndale-Bennett, by whom she had a daughter. Her second husband, actor Nicholas Hannen, died in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Drug-Sniffing Dogs End Training With a Snarl
DOC.TEXT: Ten weeks of training by drug-sniffing dogs came to a snarling conclusion when they had to be separated at their graduation. The six Labrador retrievers were sent to their handlers' cars Thursday after bearing fangs during a ceremony at the Public Service Commission's offices. The dogs get along with almost everyone except one another and will go to work this week making roadside truck inspections across the state. ``I think they were a little afraid of the cameras,'' said Keith Bissell, commission chairman. The ceremony went on without the dogs.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Praises American Troops in Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ronald Reagan today said U.S. troops in Berlin played an important role in the movements to democracy in Eastern Europe. Reagan spoke to about 1,000 American military people and dependents at Tempelhof Airport before flying to Poland, the second stop on his 10-day trip that also includes a visit to the Soviet Union. ``Nowhere have the events been more dramatic than here in Berlin,'' Reagan said to the largely military audience on the airport tarmac, in front of two old planes that flew food to West Berlin during the Soviet blockade more than four decades ago. ``What you are doing here played an important role in the events of Nov. 9,'' Reagan said, referring to the day the Berlin Wall was opened last year. As a souvenir, U.S. Ambassador Vernon Walters gave the former president one of the Berlin sector division signs that said in four languages, ``You are leaving the American sector.'' Reagan said the 7-by-10-foot sign would become part of his presidential library in Simi Valley, Calif. While in Berlin, Reagan used a hammer and chisel on the Berlin Wall, taking symbolic whacks at the old Cold War barrier, and also visited Bonn, the West German capital, where he met Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Richard von Weizsaecker.

DOC.HEAD: Action Postponed on Catholic Bishops' Letter on Women
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Roman Catholic bishops have postponed action on a divisive pastoral letter about women and plan extensive international consultations that make its fate highly uncertain. The decision Thursday by the bishops' administrative committee will mean a prolonged delay in final action on the letter, if not it's ultimate scuttling as some critics have demanded. The letter, in the works for five years, had been scheduled for action in November by the fall meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. The conference president, Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, said the letter would only be discussed then as an ``information item'' and would not be considered for action. Athough not binding, pastoral letters are circulated among Catholic churches and serve as a guide for educational efforts, preaching and the training of semarians. The letter is called ``One in Jesus Christ - A Pastoral Response to the Concerns of Women for Church and Society.'' Pilarczyk said the Vatican had suggested consultating bishops outside the United States before acting on it because of the significance of the topic and influence of the U.S. church. ``Our conference deems such a recommendation a wise one,'' Pilarczyk said. Last month, the Leadership Conference of Women Religious, comprised of 800 heads of women's religious orders, asked that the proposed letter be dropped, calling it ``intrinsically contradictory.'' Other Catholic organizations and some bishops also had criticized the declaration as seeming to uphold equality for women, yet hedging it, and continuing to defend their exclusion from ordination to the priesthood. The latest 99-page draft, released in March, says men and women are ``equal in dignity'' and women should have more equitiable roles in ``leadership, ministry, teaching and policy-making'' in the church. However, the draft reiterated the church's ban against ordaining women and defended limiting the priesthood to men as the practice of Jesus and his apostles. Leaders of the nuns' organizations said the letter's position on equality was ``undermined and contradicted'' in its internal development, especially in repeating the prohibition to women's ordination. A bishops' committee, headed by Bishop Joseph Imesch of Joliet, Ill., held hearings for several years across the country, seeking input from women about the letter. The latest revisions failed to satisfy its critics. ``Dear bishops, you embarass us,'' said liberal Catholic theologian Rosemary Radford Reuther. ``You insult our intelligence.'' She said the proposed letter criticizes sexism but ``reaffirms every aspect of the patriarchal system that is the basis of sexism.'' An independent Catholic study center, the Washington-based Center of Concern, also had urged the bishops to scrap the letter. ``It is easy to see the bind the authors are in,'' said Milwaukee Arcbbishop Rembert Weakland, a staunch advocate of a greater women's role in the church, alluding to the Vatican's position against women's ordination. He said the ``very crediblity of the document comes into question'' in reprimanding society for inequalities and calling for struggle against sexism, then upholding church policies that reflect it.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Who Backed Freedom During Cold War to Retire Within a Month
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, an outspoken advocate of religious freedom during decades of Communist control, is planning to retire within a month, the official CTK news agency says. ``The age of 91 is not normal for activities in any field, including the church,'' CTK on Thursday quoted Czechoslovakia's senior Roman Catholic clergyman as saying. Tomasek said his request to be relieved must be handled by a new papal nuncio who should assume his duties within the month, the agency said. Diplomatic relations between Czechoslovakia and Vatican resumed in April after a hiatus of 40 years. Tomasek said one of Prague's bishops should be considered to succeed him. In July 1989, four months before the peaceful revolution that ended decades of Communist rule, thousands of people attended a Mass in Prague's St. Vitus Cathedral to help the cardinal celebrate his 90th birthday. In a short address then, Tomasek stressed the importance of their religious faith to Czechoslovak believers. ``Only Christ can give an answer to the hunger of our minds for truth and to the thirst of our hearts for love,'' he said. About half of Czechoslovakia's 15 million people are Roman Catholics. Tomasek became a bishop in 1949 and was arrested two years later. He was interned during a severe Communist crackdown on religious practice, and freed in 1954. He was made a cardinal in June 1977 and archbishop of Prague that December.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Virginia and Georgia, Fog in East amd Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in in parts of the Southeast early today and a thunderstorm broke out in Minnesota. There was fog over much of the East and Midwest. Severe thunderstorms, with hail and damaging winds possible, were expected in the Great Lakes region and the Ohio Valley. Showers were also forming in Texas, Louisiana and Arkansas. A high pressure system was expected to bring sunshine to the Plains and Midwest; sunny skies were also predected for the Southeast. Cloudy skies were expected in New England. Twenty-nine cities, most of them in Utah or Colorado, broke or equaled high temperature records for the date Thursday. Levan, Utah, set a record for the month of September by reaching 100 degrees. Slightly cooler weather was expected for the West today, with rain in Northern California and Oregon and patches of frost in portions of Wyoming possible. Most of the region could expect highs in the 90s, but Arizona and Southern California were expected to have temperatures in the 100s. Highs in the 60s and 70s were predicted for the Northeast, Great Lakes and Pacific Northwest, and the 80s in the South and Midwest. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 111 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. Other reports at 5 a.m. EDT: -East: Albany, N.Y., 65 foggy; Atlanta 69 rain; Boston 66 foggy; Buffalo 67 fair; Charleston, S.C., 73 foggy; Chattanooga 70 foggy; Cincinnati 68 foggy; Cleveland 67 foggy; Detroit 68 foggy; Hatteras 76 partly cloudy; Jacksonville 69 foggy; Key West 80 partly cloudy; Knoxville 67 foggy; Macon 75 partly cloudy; Miami 80 fair; New York 68 fair; Philadelphia 67 fair; Pittsburgh 65 foggy; Portland, Maine, 60 foggy; Richmond 67 rain; Tampa 78 fair; Washington, D.C., 69 cloudy. -Central: Birmingham 71 foggy; Bismarck 51 fair; Denver 56 fair; Des Moines 66 windy; Fort Worth 74 cloudy; Indianapolis 69 foggy; Kansas City 73 partly cloudy; Louisville 71 foggy; Nashville 68 foggy; New Orleans 75 hazy; North Platte 54 fair; Oklahoma City 70 fair; Omaha 65 fair; Rapid City 46 fair; St. Louis 74 partly cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 61 thunderstorm; Sault Ste. Marie 65 thunderstorm; San Antonio 71 partly cloudy. -West: Albuquerque 68 fair; Anchorage 49 rain; Boise 62 fair; Casper 44 fair; Fairbanks 51 cloudy; Great Falls 53 fair; Honolulu 79 fair; Las Vegas 81 fair; Los Angeles 69 hazy; Medford 68 cloudy; Pendleton 57 fair; Phoenix 88 fair; Portland, Ore., 58 fair; Reno 60 fair; Salt Lake City 68 fair; San Diego 68 fair; San Francisco 61 fair; Seattle 59 fair; Spokane 51 fair. -International: Calgary 50 fair; Montreal 57 partly cloudy; Ottawa 55 partly cloudy; Regina 41 fair; Toronto 66 foggy; Winnipeg 48 cloudy; San Juan 78 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Orders Bread Rationing
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will begin rationing bread beginning Saturday, the ruling party's newspaper reported today, adding to a list of other basic food items being limited since a U.N. embargo began. The Ministry of Trade ordered all bakeries and bread shops on Saturday to observe the rationing announced earlier this month, which limits bread to three pieces per person per day, the Baath Party newspaper Al-Tharawa reported. Iraqis must present bread coupons to designated bread shops to receive their allocations, Al-Tharwa said. According to the rationing system, each Iraqi will have access to 13.2 pounds of wheat flour each month, in the form of flour or bread. Large lines have formed at bread shops since the U.N.-imposed economic embargo against Iraq and Kuwait in reaction to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraq also has imposed a rationing system for other basic food items such as rice, sugar and cooking oil, as well as soap and detergent. President Saddam Hussein also has asked Iraqis to cut back on their consumption of meat and to prepare for belt-tightening to cope with the U.N.-imposed trade embargo. The embargo prevents the import of goods as well as the export of oil, Iraq's chief source of revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Freedom Flight Picks Up Dependents In Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs to UPDATE with Britain saying 18 of its citizens to take flight.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways charter jet flew to Kuwait City today to pick up about 400 Americans scheduled to fly home from Baghdad later in the day, a U.S. Embassy official said. The Americans, trapped in Kuwait since last month's Iraqi invasion, will stop in Baghdad to receive exit visas before changing charter flights and continuing to London, the diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The flight is scheduled to take women, children and American men of Arab origin, the official said. Eighteen Britons also would be among the Westerners on board, the Foreign Office in London said. Since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait prompted U.S. and other forces to deploy in the Persian Gulf region, Iraq has held Americans and other Westerners as human shields at potential military targets. However, late last month Baghdad agreed to begin releasing mostly women and children. The U.S. Embassy official said he hoped the Boeing 747, chartered by the U.S. government, would leave Baghdad around 6 p.m. (10 a.m. EDT). However, delays have been the norm in previous flight evacuating Westerners from Kuwait and Iraq. It would be the second time in three days that a flight brought Westerners out of Iraq. On Wednesday 288 Americans, 70 Britons and 70 people of other nationalities left Iraq aboard a jumbo jet jointly chartered by the American and British governments. Officials earlier said the flight carried 300 Americans. No explanation was given for the discrepancy. A separate flight the same day took 10 ailing and elderly Italian men to Rome. The Voice of America, the U.S. government-run shortwave radio network, has been broadcasting appeals to American women and children in Kuwait to join the evacuation flight or another one planned for Saturday, the embassy official said. He did not know how many evacuees might take the Saturday flight. About 6,500 Westerners remain stranded in Iraq and Kuwait, many of them in hiding. They are believed to include about 1,500 Americans in Kuwait, according to the U.S. Embassy official in Baghdad. At least 2,500 Americans were in Kuwait at the time of the Iraqi invasion, the official said. Palestinian diplomats in Baghdad said late Thursday that an estimated 1,000 Palestinians a day who had fled after the invasion are returning to Kuwait. The diplomats did not have a total on the number of Palestinians who had returned.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Slumped 0.6 Percent in August
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales slumped 0.6 percent in August despite a huge jump in gasoline station purchases, the government said today in its first report on consumer spending since the Persian Gulf crisis eruped Aug. 2. Some analysts had said in advance that the report would be skewed by sharply higher gasoline prices that would offset falling sales elsewhere. Indeed, sales in nearly all other categories declined. Much of the increase in gasoline sales apparently represented increased prices rather than volume. The American Petroleum Institute said gasoline prices rose about 20 percent since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Commerce Department said overall sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $149.2 billion, down from $150.0 billion in July. The July sales, which rose 0.4 percent, turned out to be stronger than the 0.1 percent gain originally reported last month. But a 1.1 percent advance in June had been the first increase since last January and analysts worried whether developments in the Middle East would jack up prices and erode consumer confidence, driving sales back down. Indeed, two major consumer confidence surveys - one conducted by the Conference Board in New York and another by the University of Michigan - plummeted after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Since consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, there was concern a dropoff could help push the nation into a recession. Retail sales account for about half of overall consumer spending. The Commerce report said gasoline station sales jumped 6.4 percent in August, the largest increase since an 8.3 percent advance in August 1979. Excluding the gasoline category, retail sales tumbled even farther, down 1.1 percent. Automobile sales fell 4.3 percent, their largest drop since a 5.6 percent decrease last January. Excluding the automobile category, sales would have risen 0.4 percent. Sales of durable goods, which includes cars and other items expected to last more than three years, slid 2.6 percent after rising 0.7 percent the previous month. Besides automobiles, other components of the durable category were mixed. Sales of building materials were off 2.4 percent, while sales of furniture and other home furnishings rose 0.7 percent. Non-durable goods, which include food and gasoline, rose 0.6 percent following July's 0.3 percent gain. But other than gasoline, all other non-durable categories fell. Sales at department stores were down 0.2 percent; grocery stores, off 0.2 percent; clothing stores, down 0.9 percent; restaurants and bars, off 0.7 percent, and drug stores, down 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Search Launched; Police Defend Handling of Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 6th graf, `The dog...'.
