DOC.TEXT: Searchers began a second day of picking through swamps, bush and wooded areas this morning near the apartment of a suspect in the slayings of five college students, police said. Some objects were found during Thursday's first day of hunting, but there was no immediate word on whether they were connected to the case, said Alachua County Sheriff's Office spokesman Lt. Spencer Mann. The search party was combing 10 square miles near the residence of University of Florida freshman Edward Lewis Humphrey, one of eight suspects in the slayings. ``It's a long, slow process,'' Mann said. Searchers included Florida National Guardsmen, sailors from the Orlando Naval Training Center, military reserve officers and police from state and local agencies. Two helicopters aided searchers in Thursday's 90-degree heat, and about 10 dog teams were called in. The dog teams were looking for body parts from the five victims, but Mann said such parts might already have decayed in the three weeks since the bodies of the students were discovered. Some searchers carried metal detectors and rods for probing the ground. The work was expected to be wrapped up later today, officials said. Meanwhile, two agents with the Florida Department of Law Enforcement began what the agency calls an ``executive investigation'' aimed at learning who has been leaking information to reporters. Lie-detector tests may be used and those found to have given out unauthorized information could face disciplinary action and criminal charges, said police spokeswoman Lt. Sadie Darnell. Police say the leaks have hurt their investigation. Once again Thursday, police were secretive about their progress, and refused to comment on reports their case may have been badly compromised when investigators first interrogated Humphrey, 18, following his arrest on charges of assaulting his grandmother. A series of newspaper reports have said Humphrey was questioned in the Brevard County Jail without an attorney present, and the public defenders who finally showed up were sent away when prosecutors dropped the assault charges, only to refile them when the lawyers left. Humphrey was not brought to court until 36 hours after he was taken into custody. Humphrey, who is being treated by a doctor for manic-depressive disorder, reportedly implicated one of his multiple personalities in the slayings and told police where to look for some evidence. Humphrey remains jailed in the Aug. 30 beating of his grandmother. He also faces warrants in an October 1988 armed burglary and attempted rape in Indian River County and an Aug. 25 assault on two male university students. The mutilated bodies of Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26 in their off-campus apartment. The next morning, Christa Hoyt, 18, was found decapitated in her nearby duplex. Manuel Taboada, and Tracy Paules, both 23, were found dead Aug. 28 in another nearby apartment. All were students either at the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College.

DOC.HEAD: `Historic' Okeechobee, Everglades Plan Approved
DOC.TEXT: Sugar growers, the water district and the state of Florida have agreed to share the cost of a $120 million plan to clean up the Everglades and Lake Okeechobee. Under the plan, approved Thursday by the South Florida Water Management District, about 74,000 acres of farmland are to be bought and converted into marshes to filter phosphorus-laden agricultural runoff blamed for much of the pollution plaguing the Lake Okeechobee-Everglades system. Water flowing south from farm fields would be cleaned by running it through the marshes, where plants would absorb excess phosphorus blamed for upsetting the Everglades ecosystem. ``It's very historic that everybody came to the table and agreed to pay for this,'' said Ann Overton, a spokeswoman for the water district. ``It's a big step forward.'' Environmentalists involved in a 27-month effort to reach the accord criticized the sugar industry's $40 million share as too low. And the question of whether the federal government will now drop a pollution lawsuit against the state and the water district remained unanswered. The lawsuit, filed by Miami U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, contends water managers and the state allowed federal parks in the region to be degraded in violation of pollution laws and signed agreements. In Washington, Justice Department spokeswoman Amy Casner said the government had no immediate comment on whether the plan was enough of a step forward for the federal government to drop the lawsuit. On Tuesday, Gov. Bob Martinez worked out and approved the compromise, despite estimates that the cleanup could end up costing as much as $500 million. ``I think the majority of the industry decided that this may be as good as the deal was going to get. They'd better take it,'' said Andy Rackley, vice president of the Florida Sugar Cane League. Under the plan, the Everglades cleanup area would be quadrupled, with the cost split into equal $40 million shares for the state government, the water district and sugar growers. ``I don't think that that necessarily represents a fair contribution from agriculture. It may be, but there are too many unknowns for us to be capping any contributor,'' said Doran Jason, a member of the water district's board. Environmentalists agreed. ``You are making a statement that it is appropriate to allow an industry that is causing a number of environmental problems to pay something like 10 percent of the amount it will take to solve the problems,'' said Charles Lee, executive vice president of the Florida Audubon Society.

DOC.HEAD: Assad Expected To Send More Troops To Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 4-5 to UPDATE with conclusion of Baker-Assad talks; picks up 4th graf pvs, The additional...
DOC.TEXT: Syrian President Hafez Assad, an ally of the United States against Iraq, is likely to send another 15,000 troops to help defend Saudi Arabia, Western diplomatic sources said today. The Syrians have about 3,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia and another 1,000 in the United Arab Emirates. They are part of an international force from some two dozen countries that includes about 200,000 American soldiers. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who raised $12 billion last week from the Saudis, the United Arab Emirates and the Kuwaiti regime ousted by Iraq, met with Assad to plot further cooperation with Damascus despite U.S. accusations that Syria promotes terrorism. ``The talks were frank, clear and centered on the situation in the Gulf, the peace process in the Middle East and bilateral issues,'' Assad spokesman Jibrane Kourieh said after the 4{-hour session. He gave no other details, but the talks were believed to include Iran's growing belligerence in the standoff. The additional troops probably will be accompanied by Syrian tanks and may be transported by the Soviet Union, which also supports the U.S. attempt to reverse Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Syrians will be compensated by the Saudis and other rich Persian Gulf countries, said the sources, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Assad has long been at odds with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The crisis in the gulf gives Assad a chance to confront the Iraqi leader and gain favor with the Bush administration at the same time. Assad wants the administration to join the Soviets in calling for a Middle East peace conference with the aim of creating a Palestinian state and forcing Israel to relinquish the Golan Heights to Syria. Israel captured the territory in the 1967 Middle East war and has annexed it. Until then, attacks on villages in northern Israel from the Golan Heights were frequent. Over the last two weeks, President Bush and Baker have made a point of saying they might support an international peace conference at an appropriate time. Baker on Thursday leveled a veiled warning against Iran as he arrived here for talks with Assad and Syrian Foreign Minister Faruq al Shara. Responding to a threatened ``holy war'' against U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, Baker said the U.S. troops were defending the Saudi oil fields along with Arab Moslem nations. The threats ``obviously are of deep concern,'' Baker said as he flew here from Moscow. ``We are not indifferent to threats against our forces.'' His remarks were in response to a call by the Ayatollah Ali Khamanei, the Iranian spiritual leader, for a holy war against the U.S. troops. It raised fears of suicide raids against the Americans as well as questions about Iran's position in the economic war of attrition against Saddam Hussein. The administration, banking on Syria and Iran's long-standing hostility with Iraq, solicited the two countries to assist in the anti-Iraqi campaign. Syria, which is on Iraq's northern border, has responded with troops and played a leading role in the Arab League in condemning the Iraqi invasion. But Iran has repaired relations with Iraq, with which it fought an eight-year war until 1988, after endorsing the U.N. Security Council's call for an economic boycott. ``We are watching it closely and believe it is holding,'' Baker said of Iranian adherence to the sanctions ordered Aug. 2. Baker said interception under the sanctions of illicit cargo by sea may be expanded to aerial enforcement. Baker's visit to Damascus is the first by a secretary of state since George P. Shultz came here in June 1988 to sound out Assad on prospects for Arab-Israeli negotiations. The State Department has sharply criticized Syria's human rights record and kept it on a list of seven countries accused of sponsoring terrorism. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, which has strong ties to Syria, is suspected in the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The disaster took 280 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Arms Supplier For Trinidad Revolt Arrested Here
DOC.TEXT: Most of the arsenal used in a failed coup attempt in Trinidad by Moslem extremists was purchased at gun shows and shops throughout South Florida, says a complaint against the alleged chief supplier. Louis Haneef of Pompano Beach was arrested early Thursday during a raid on his home, said federal agents. The federal complaint against Haneef also includes a warrant for the leader of the revolt, Yasin Abu Bakr, a former Trinidad policeman who took the island nation's prime minister prisoner for six days in July before surrendering. Of the 135 weapons confiscated in Trinidad after the revolt collapsed, 105 were traced to purchases made in Florida by Haneef, said Joe Vince, assistant special agent in charge of the Miami office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. ``He was supplying the weapons that were used in the insurrection - there is no question about it,'' the agent said. The arrest shows the United States will not tolerate gun smuggling, said Miami's U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. ``We are no longer going to allow South Florida to be used as a Mecca for people to purchase weapons to be used for narcotics traffickers ... or people planning rebellions anywhere in the Caribbean or in the Americas,'' Lehtinen said. Haneef bought at least 200 assault rifles and other firearms and the ATF is seeking the missing guns, said Vince. He also purchased 250,000 rounds of ammunition, along with electronic equipment that included hand-held radios. One key question was where Haneef obtained the approximately $100,000 in $100 bills he used to buy the weapons in Dade and Broward county gun shows and weapons shops, Vince said. Trinidad officials said Bakr and many of his men had visited Libya and received training and money there, although they have found no evidence Moammar Gadhafi was behind the coup attempt. Haneef's money was drawn on a bank in the Persian Gulf nation of Bahrain, but its original source was still part of the investigation, he said. The federal complaint, along with Haneef and Bakr, names Billaal Abdullah, another leader of the revolt, and Riad Ali, both of whom are also imprisoned in Trinidad. Haneef was originally from St. Louis, and changed his name from Louis Cole when he became a Moslem, Vince said. He added that the complaint would eventually be presented to a grand jury for indictments. The men are accused of gun control and arms export violations, said Vince. The investigation began in October 1989 when a Miami police officer became suspicious of large gun purchases Haneef made at a weapons show, according to an affidavit by ATF agent Thomas Bailey. Haneef was interviewed and said the weapons were for a gun club, but the agency began surveillance. He ultimately bought about 200 weapons, including AK-47 and Ruger Mini-14 assault rifles, shotguns, M-1 carbines and large-caliber pistols. The weapons and ammunition were allegedly smuggled out of the United States in April aboard a freighter, hidden in hollowed-out wall boards, Vince said. He said investigators had obtained a warrant in hopes of placing an electronic tracer on the shipment, but it had left port before they got there. The rebellion in Trinidad broke out in July when Bakr's forces seized the Parliament House and state television, holding hostages including Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and other government leaders. They demanded Robinson's resignation, new elections and amnesty, but eventually surrendered on the sixth day of the crisis. Bakr and other revolt leaders are now in jail facing treason, murder and other charges. Vince said he did not expect Bakr to be extradited to Miami, but said the warrants would remain in force in any case.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Sending 6,00 Combat Troops to Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Britain will send an armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and about 6,000 combat troops to Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Tom King said today. The move marks the first deployment of tanks and significant numbers of ground troops by any Western country apart from the United States since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The armored brigade will more double the British military personnel in the Persian Gulf, and King stressed that force remains an option for ending the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. The defense secretary also announced that Britain would be sending another squadron of Tornado ground attack aircraft and some additional air defense aircraft. ``Our purpose in sending further forces is twofold: first to ensure that no further aggression can possibly succeed and that the defensive shield is sure for Saudi Arabia and the threatened Gulf States,'' he said. The defense secretary said that ``while we seek the implementation of the United Nations resolutions by peaceful means, other options remain available and that, one way or another, he will lose. ``Iraq's evil aggression must be reversed, and my announcement today confirms our determination to play our full part in the worldwide effort to achieve this,'' King said. The 7th Armored Brigade, based in West Germany, includes two armored regiments with 120 Challenger tanks, armored infantry battalion with Warrior armored fighting vehicles, squadron of Scimitar combat vehicles, artillery regiment and air defense battery with Javelin missiles, King said. Army units involved are Royal Scots Dragoon Guards, Queen's Royal Irish Hussars, Staffordshire Regiment, 40 Field Regiment Royal Artillery and squadron of Queen's Dragoon Guards. Defense officials indicated it would take about a month for the armored forces to reach Saudi Arabia. The announcement came after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met with senior Cabinet ministers at her 10 Downing Street office for a final decision on the British response to U.S. urgings to NATO countries to send ground troops. In addition to the Chieftain tanks, each with a crew of four and weighing nearly 150,000 pounds, the brigade is likely to include several light reconnaissance Scorpion tanks and dozsens of mechanized combat vehicles. The British tanks, military analysts say, will need a logistics chain separate from the American M1A1 Abrams tanks in Saudi Arabia as part of America's Desert Shield Operation. The shells and spares for the Abrams and the Challenger are different. Britain now has three squadrons of warplanes, 12 naval vessels and ground support units involving some 3,000 military personnel in the Gulf. The government gave no immediate indication of the cost of transporting and maintaining the brigade in Gulf region. It says the current air and naval forces cost $141 million to deploy and are costing nearly $2 million a day to keep there.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Error Due to Upside-down Measuring Rod
DOC.TEXT: A worker accidentally inserted a 2-foot metal rod upside-down in a measuring instrument while making the Hubble Space Telescope's primary mirror, causing a flaw that blurred the $1.5 billion scope's view, NASA officials said. ``This particular day, he didn't notice that the rod went in upside-down,'' said Charles Pellerin, director of astrophysics for NASA. ``So he made an ... error and never knew it.'' Pellerin spoke Thursday at a news conference at Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., where a NASA investigative team had concluded two days of meetings. The company manufactured the Hubble's primary mirror in the late 1970s and early 1980s when Hughes Danbury was a division of Perkin-Elmer Corp. There was no way the person who inserted the rod could have known it was upside-down, said Lew Allen, director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, who led the investigative team. Allen declined to idenify the person. ``It was a technical error made by people of good will who made a mistake,'' he said. The rod, made of the temperature-insensitive metal invar, was used in a measuring device that guided the polishing of the mirror, Allen said. Because it was inserted incorrectly, it caused a 1.3 millimeter spacing error that led to the mirror being manufactured with a flaw, he said. The flaw, called a spherical aberration, has blurred the view of the much-acclaimed Hubble. The orbiting observatory was supposed to take razor-sharp pictures of the outer reaches of space. The flaw will be corrected during a previously scheduled 1993 space shuttle mission to replace the Hubble's most powerful instrument, the wide-field planetary camera, said Pellerin. It will cost an extra $15 million to build the new planetary camera to make up for the flaw, Pellerin said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration originally estimated the new camera would cost up to $65 million, he said. Many tests could have been done to detect the error during the manufacturing process, but Perkin-Elmer scientists and engineers didn't do them because were under tremendous pressure to finish the project, Allen said. The pressures, including cost overruns and time constraints, distracted those working on the mirror, he said. Also, some tests that had detected the error were considered unreliable at the time, he said. ``With 20-20 hindsight, one would clearly say there was negligence ...,'' Allen said. ``But you have to take into account the situation that actually existed.'' This was the investigative team's third and final visit to Hughes Danbury, Allen said. The team will issue a final report on their findings as soon as possible, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Condemns Woman To Death In Videotape Murder
DOC.TEXT: A 21-year-old woman has been sentenced to die in the electric chair for the cold execution of a drifter bound to a tree that was videotaped and shown in court. Deidre Hunt wept, grimaced and bowed her head as Circuit Judge S. James Foxman imposed the death penalty Thursday. Hunt pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in the shooting deaths of Mark Kevin Ramsey, 19, and Bryan Chase, 18. Co-defendant Kosta Fotopoulos, her 31-year-old former boss and lover, also was charged with murder and was accused of videotaping Ramsey's killing last October. Hunt told the judge she killed Ramsey to save her own life. ``I was confronted with a decision that Kosta Fotopoulos had absolutely already made,'' she said. ``It was my decision of living by shooting Mark Kevin Ramsey or dying with Mark Kevin Ramsey. My decision was a choice to survive and I chose to live. '' The 57-second videotape, viewed last week during Hunt's six-day sentencing hearing, shows her shooting Ramsey three times in the chest, then grabbing him by the hair and delivering a final shot to the head. Ramsey believed he was being initiated into an assassins club. Prosecutors said Fotopoulos wanted him killed because he knew about a counterfeit scheme Fotopoulos was invoved in. In a videotaped confession to police when she was arrested last November, Hunt also admitted to taking part in a murder-for-hire plot in which Fotopoulos' wife, Lisa, was shot in the head. Mrs. Fotopoulos survived. In addition to the murder counts against her, Hunt was charged with attempted murder and conspiracy in that attack. Chase, the trigger man in the attack on Mrs. Fotopoulos, was shot to prevent exposure of the plot, authorities said. Hunt pleaded guilty to all charges. In addition to the death penalty, she was sentenced to six concurrent terms of life in prison. During Hunt's sentencing hearing, psychologist Clifford A. Levin testified for the defense that she was an emotionally damaged person who was threatened and controlled by Fotopoulos. Her mother and several aunts, uncles and cousins testified that she was raped at 11 by a neighbor and was rejected by her father.

DOC.HEAD: Playmates of Child Missing Since April Tell Secret: Victim Died in Silo
DOC.TEXT: The body of a 10-year-old boy was discovered in an abandoned grain silo after his frightened playmates who witnessed his accidental fall revealed the secret they had kept for months. Just last week, a nationwide mailing campaign sent a photograph of the missing boy, Ricky Rodriguez, to millions of homes, seeking clues to the boy's disappearance April 26. But Thursday, the mother of one of Ricky's playmates called police to say she learned what happened to Ricky. Ricky fell from atop a towering abandoned grain silo at the deserted Falstaff Brewing Corp. on the city's Southeast Side while bouncing with the other boys on conveyer belts atop the silos, police said. Fearing they'd be blamed for Ricky's death, the boy's friends kept the secret from Ricky's parents and their own families as police used helicopters and scuba divers to search for him. ``They were scared. They're just little boys and they thought they were going to get into trouble,'' police Detective Eileen Guest said. ``Well, everybody can stop looking,'' Ricky's father, Steve, said Thursday. ``I thought he was dead the night he disappeared. It just didn't fit his pattern (to vanish). But ... I was hoping.'' The mystery began to unravel when a sister of one of Ricky's playmates overheard a conversation in which the boy's said Ricky had fallen. She told her mother, who called police. Police interviewed each of Ricky's four playmates separately and were convinced that the boy's death had been accidental. ``We're glad the case is cleared,'' said Guest. ``It's a shame the way it concluded. But in a way, it's a relief for the family. Now they can bury their son.'' Ricky's picture recently had been featured in a nationwide ``Have You Seen Me?'' advertisement for missing children.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes to Take Up Fuel Economy Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Senate decided today to consider a bill that would require automakers to improve fuel economy dramtically. Critics said the measure would only force consumers to buy smaller cars. The move opened the way for a likely vote on the measure, probably early next week. The bill would require new cars to achieve an average 40 miles-per-gallon fuel economy by the end of the decade. A similar measure has been introduced in the House, but has yet to emerge from committee. By a vote of 68-28, the Senate agreed to proceed with the legislation and scuttled an effort by Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., to prevent the bill from being introduced. The auto industry has vigorously opposed the legislation. It claims the goal of a fleet fuel economy average of 40 mpg by the year 2001, a 40 percent increase, is not achievable without forcing consumers to buy much smaller cars. The vote was an indicator of the growing support in Congress for the legislation as the Middle East crisis and rising oil prices put renewed focus on the need for energy conservation. Supporters of the bill have argued that improving automobile fuel economy to an average of 40 mpg from today's 27.5 mpg would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day. But in floor debate, Riegle said those fuel savings are not likely to begin phasing in until 1995 and a better response to today's oil crisis would be to return to a national speed limit of 55 miles an hour. He reiterated many of the auto industry's arguments that the legislation would require the manufacture of much smaller cars, increase traffic fatalities and reduce consumer choice. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., the bill's chief sponsor, retorted that the idea was to send a message to the automakers ``that they're going to have to look at fuel economy and not just muscle cars.'' He said there is evidence that the higher fuel standards could be met without reducing car size significantly. The auto industry and its unions have waged a vigorous lobbying campaign against the measure. Riegle last week displayed 40,000 telegrams from auto workers opposed to the legislation. Meanwhile, environmentalists have maintained that improved auto fuel economy is the single best way to reduce America's dependence on foreign oil and also combat global warming through reduced emissions of carbon dioxide. ``It does not take a crystal ball to realize that if we don't start conserving now, some future president may have to consider sending our young men and woman back to the deserts of the Middle East,'' said Bryan. The bill would require automakers to boost the average mileage of new car fleets by 20 percent to about 35 mpg by 1995 and about 40 percent to about 40 mpg by the year 2001.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Proposes Legislation to Forgive Part of Latin America's Debt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today sent Congress legislation to forgive part of Latin America's debt and aides said he would follow it by seeking authority for a free-trade pact with Mexico. With the Persian Gulf situation focusing attention on world oil supplies, a free-trade pact with Mexico could help spur production in that country. Mexico has the world's eighth-largest reserves of oil. The United States already has such an agreement with Canada, under which all tariffs and other trade barriers will be lifted by the end of the century. Administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush would like to have congressional agreement to begin free-trade talks with Mexico ready when he goes to Mexico City in November. In a signing ceremony at the White House, Bush said the current attention on the Middle East does not lessen his administration's commitment to Latin America. Bush has called for an eventual free-trade zone extending from the Arctic Circle to Cape Horn. He said the legislation sent to Capitol Hill today was an important step toward that goal. The legislation submitted today would forgive about $7 billion in loans owed to the government by Latin American and Caribbean countries. Latin nations owe U.S. banks an additional $48.3 billion. The bill also seeks to make it easier for U.S. companies to invest in Latin America. He called the package ``trade, not aid.'' ``We believe these measure together will boost trade, investment and growth in our hemisphere. This legislation is good for our neighbors, it's good for the hemisphere and I believe it is very good for the United States,'' Bush said. Before the administration can begin free-trade talks with Canada, it needs legislation from Congress authorizing it. Administration sources said the free trade measure could be sent to Congress as early as next week.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Invade French Ambassador's Residence In Kuwait, Seizing Four
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with troops entering Belgian embassy, Dutch ambassador's residence invaded last week, EC protest, other comment; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops forced their way into the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait this morning, officials said. France said four of its citizens, including a diplomat, were detained, but the diplomat was later released. The Netherlands also disclosed that Iraqi troops had forced their way into its ambassador's residence in Kuwait earlier this week. It said Iraq's ambassador to the Netherlands was summoned to hear a ``sharp protest.'' Belgian officials said three Iraqi soldiers entered Belgium's diplomatic compound today and ordered the two remaining diplomats to leave the embassy, officials said. The soldiers left after the Belgian diplomats fled into the ambassador's residence, adjacent to the embassy. A Belgian Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the intrusion was ``an unacceptable act going against all international laws.'' France vigorously protested the Iraqi action, and the European Community called it ``intolerable.'' NATO chief Manfred Woerner, on an official visit to Poland, called the Iraqi incursion into the French Embassy ``another outrageous violation of international law.'' London and Washington said there had been no similar incidents at its diplomatic residences or embassies in the gulf emirate. ``The situation hasn't changed since yesterday,'' a U.S. State Department official said on condition of anonymity. West Germany's Foreign Ministry also said no incursion had taken place at its embassy in Kuwait. After Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the oil-rich nation, Baghdad ordered embassies in Kuwait closed, saying the nation was part of Iraqi territory. Iraqi troops surrounded the missions, and power and water were cut to many in an effort to force their closure, but 17 embassies have defied the Iraqi order. The staffs of more than 30 foreign missions have left since the Aug. 24 deadline, although some insist their embassies technically remain open. The French Foreign Ministry said today troops entered the residence of the French ambassador, taking the military attache and three others to an undisclosed location. The ministry said the attache was later released. It gave no details about the fate of the other three Frenchmen. The Canadian Embassy in Paris said special Iraqi forces entered the ambassador's residence before dawn. Spokesman Jacques Crete said the consul was briefly detained but later released. And the Dutch Foreign Ministry disclosed that Iraqi soldiers had forced their way into Dutch Ambassador Joop Veling's official residence in Kuwait City earlier this week. In Brussels today, the European Community demanded ``the immediate release of the abducted foreigners'' and called on Iraq to respect the 1961 Vienna Convention on the inviolability of diplomatic missions. On Thursday, the British Foreign Office summoned the Iraq ambassador to protest what it called violations of the embassies of France and The Netherlands, fellow members of the European Community. ``There has been continual harassment,'' said the spokesman. Iraqi authorities had earlier cut off water and electricity to the French Embassy in Kuwait and at one point knocked down part of the mission's wall. The ambassador's residence and the embassy are separate facilities. The French ambassador has been out of Kuwait since the invasion and a half-dozen diplomats continue to staff the French Embassy, headed by the charge d'affaires, Andre Janier. ``This is a very serious violation of the Vienna Convention,'' a French Foreign Ministry spokesman said. ``This is a new intolerable attack to international rights and the integrity of the person.'' The spokesman said the Iraqi ambassador to France was summoned immediately to hear a ``vigorous protest.'' The Persian Gulf crisis reversed 15 years of close ties between Iraq and France, which had been Baghdad's top Western arms supplier and a major trading partner. Since the crisis began France has sent the second-largest naval force to the region - after the United States - to help enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq. France has an estimated 400 nationals remaining in Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Threatens Steps to Curb Township Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela comments on unrest, picking up 4th graf pvs bgng: ```There are...'
With LaserPhoto NY15
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk said today the government may take additional steps to curb black township fighting that has claimed about 800 lives since August. De Klerk promised ``strong and comprehensive'' action, but did not elaborate. It was not immediately clear if the plan would include harsher police measures. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, who met today with de Klerk to discuss the unrest, said he expects de Klerk to announce the new policies Monday. Mandela said de Klerk no longer believes the township violence is solely a black-on-black conflict, but that ``certain faceless elements'' are behind the attacks. Mandela would not specifically name who the ANC believes is instigating the unrest, but said ``we have our own suspicions.'' Some anti-apartheid groups have alleged rogue elements of the security forces and white extremists are involved in the fighting. Witnesses in several townships say masked white men participated in recent attacks, but there has been no proof of the claims. De Klerk said growing violence threatens talks on power-sharing between whites and blacks. ``There are forces which do not wish peaceful negotiations to succeed. All those forces desiring peace must stand together to identify and counter these forces,'' de Klerk said. ``The new South Africa, which is the goal of all sincere South Africans, is being threatened by present events,'' he said. Police today said five blacks were killed and three others injured in Soweto township in two separate attacks on mini-buses used by commuters. Police said they were unsure whether the violence was linked to the factional fighting or part of a dispute among rival taxi drivers. The main combatants in the fighting are Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas and other blacks supporting the leftist ANC. Also in Soweto, demonstrators burned a delivery truck belonging the The Star, the country's largest circulation daily newspaper. Witnesses said the attackers were apparently upset by recent coverage of the fighting. Meanwhile, the South African Chamber of Business said many blacks have been staying away from their jobs during the recent unrest. Among the topics discussed by de Klerk and Mandela in Pretoria was a Thursday night rampage by youths with guns and machetes on a black commuter train that left 26 dead and more than 100 injured. Police commanders said they did not know who the attackers were, but two police officers at the scene said the youths were Zulus. A conductor said he heard the youths speaking in Zulu. About 10 black youths, most in their late teens, boarded the train in Johannesburg and began attacking passengers when it started for Soweto. Another gang of men were waiting for the train when it pulled into the next station and began shooting and stabbing the screaming passengers as they tried to flee the youths on the train. Passengers jumped from the train or tried to hide under seats as the youths stabbed and hacked people. The dead included old women and men who were unable to run from the attackers. ``They worked their way down the coaches very systematically, killing people. They were well organized and spoke to each other as they attacked people,'' said one man at the station where the train was halted. Hundreds of heavily armed police and army troops in battle gear cordoned off the area. Army patrols with assault rifles walked along railway tracks, hunting for bodies that passengers said were hurled from the train. The township fighting spread from the eastern province of Natal, where the ANC-Inkatha feud has killed about 5,000 blacks since 1986.

DOC.HEAD: $25,000 Reward Offered for Capture of Gang Members Who Shot Toddler
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jonathon is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The county Board of Supervisors offered a $25,000 reward for information leading to the capture of gang members who shot a 2-year-old boy. Jonathon Fabian was shot in the stomach on Tuesday as he played in the front yard of his home in suburban Lynwood. The boy was in critical but stable condition today at Martin Luther King Jr.-Drew Medical Center, said sheriff's Deputy Paul Archambault. His condition was expected to improve, Archambault said. Supervisor Kenneth Hahn called the shooting the ``crime of the century'' as he introduced an emergency motion Thursday to sponsor the reward money. Witnesses said three teen-age boys, one carrying a gun, ran away after two shots were fired. Because no other gang members were seen in the area, investigators speculated the shooting may have been intentional. Lynwood Mayor Robert Henning declared it was time to ``stop coddling murderers no matter how old they are.'' Street-hardened officers were among those stunned by the shooting. ``If gang members want to shoot each other, that's one thing,'' said sheriff's Detective Craig Ditsch. ``But it always bugs me when I see innocent people hurt. That feeling is just magnified when it's an innocent little boy.''

DOC.HEAD: Nebraska Sizzles in Heat Wave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with heat wave broken. Picks up 5th graf, `The warmest September ...'
DOC.TEXT: September in Nebraska hasn't sizzled like this since 1897 but relief finally came today. ``I believe the heat wave is over,'' said Steve Byrd, National Weather Service meteorologist. Some cities might hit 90 Saturday but temperatures will be mainly in the 80s, Byrd said. ``We're turning into more seasonable weather.'' Schools without air conditioning had dismissed classes early when the heat wave began Aug. 23. High school and college football games were disrupted and farm crops and livestock threatened. The state's high temperature Wednesday was 99 degrees in Chadron. North Platte hit 102 degrees Thursday afternoon, breaking its record high for a Sept. 13 of 100 set in 1895, but cool breezes helped the mercury slip to 41 overnight. ``This morning it was really quite chilly,'' said Sonia Arterburn, a waitress at Roger's Fine Food restaurant in North Platte. Moods have improved, she said, including those of her own children. ``The kids are a lot easier to live with,'' she said. The high in Omaha had averaged 92.5 degrees during the spell, said John Zapotocny, assistant professor of atmospheric sciences at Creighton University. Since Sept. 1, the average high was 92 degrees and the daily mean 80.4, he said. The warmest September on record was in 1897, when the daily mean was 75.2 degrees, the National Weather Service said. ``Unless you lived through the late 1930s, you haven't seen heat like this in your lifetime,'' Zapotocny said. Red Cross workers Saturday at the University of Nebraska-Northern Illinois football game treated 22 people for heat-related problems. Two players suffered heat exhaustion at a game last weekend between Nebraska Deaf High School and Kansas Deaf. A week earlier, eight high school football players in Raymond collapsed. Farm agents say few cattle and hogs have died, but profits could suffer because the animals don't eat as well in sweltering weather. ``The hogs are not getting as fat as fast as they normally do,'' said Arnie Stuthman, president of the Nebraska Pork Producers. The hot weather will delay Nebraska's apple harvest by about a week. Apple pickers stopped working before noon Tuesday because it was too hot to work, said Sharon Durr of Carton Orchard, near Nebraska City. How the heat wave affects the state's corn crop hasn't been assessed since Sept. 1, agriculture officials say.

DOC.HEAD: AP Board Approves 3.9 percent Rate Increase
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of The Associated Press has approved a general assessment increase of 3.9 percent for its 1,538 daily and weekly newspaper members and 5,800 broadcast members, effective Jan. 20, 1991. William J. Keating, chairman of the AP board of directors and chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer, said that the assessment increase, in percentage terms, was the lowest in three years. ``Mindful of the difficult times that confront much of the industry at this stage, the board approved a rate increase that is well below the projected inflation rate for 1990 and 1991,'' Keating said. The 3.9 percent increase will not cover all of the increases and new costs faced by AP. AP will continue to meet the growing demands of the news industry through a vigorous cost control effort and by increasing non-traditional revenue sources, Keating said. Non-traditional sources now make up 24 percent of AP's revenue. Eleven years ago that figure was 7 percent. ``Of the new money that AP needs to fund 1991 operations and continue to improve services, only 31 cents of every dollar will come from the assessment increase,'' Keating said. ``It is vital to all of us that our cooperative remain strong and able to meet the challenges in news coverage and technology,'' Keating said. ``Even as some members reduce their own activity to absorb the impact of a difficult year in the industry, demands on the AP grow as we look to AP to do things that, in a healthier time, we might not have relied on AP to do.'' The general assessment increase will be combined with another step in the phase-in of the circulation-based newspaper formula for those members that have not reached their appropriate assessment level. The 1991 assessment will also reflect any circulation changes at the member newspaper. The assessment increase applies to all basic services for both newspapers and broadcasters and to all supplemental services except for the rates for financial market tables, which are being adjusted downward in two steps in 1990 and 1991 to reflect savings achieved in producing computer-generated stock lists. AP members will receive their new weekly assessment figures by early October, Keating said.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Dallas Police Chief Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Dallas police chief Mack Vines entered an innocent plea to a perjury charge today, telling reporters he was taken aback by his abrupt firing after his indictment this week. ``I felt that we were going along well and mending bridges and building new bridges,'' Vines said before his arraignment in Dallas County Criminal Court today. ``The fact is I'm not guilty,'' Vines said. Vines, who was fired two hours after he was indicted Wednesday, was released on his own recognizance and faces a pre-trial hearing Sept. 28. State District Court Judge Joe Kendall said he would probably move the trial out of Dallas. ``Frankly, Chief, I don't believe that you can get a fair trial in this town,'' Kendall said, adding that he doesn't usually move a trial on his own, but felt obligated to because of extensive publicity over the case. The misdemeanor charge alleges that Vines lied to a panel investigating the firing of a police officer about a conversation he had with his assistant, Greg Holliday, on Aug. 2. The grand jury rejected the district attorney's recommendation that Vines be indicted on seven felony perjury counts for other statements made to the same panel. The police officer was fired after he shot an unarmed Mexican national; the dismissal was later ruled unjustified. Holliday said Vines called him late at night and tried to influence Holliday's testimony before the special panel, which he was scheduled to give the next day. Holliday told City Manager Jan Hart of the conversation and she suspended both men with pay. Holliday later was reinstated.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Strikes Down Two Gun Control Rules; Upholds Other Provisions
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court today upheld most provisions of a gun control law that had been challenged by the National Rifle Association, but struck down two record-keeping rules. The 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld regulations requiring that licensed gun dealers sell guns only from shops or a sponsored gun show. It also upheld a rule that gun dealers keep records on the sale of firearms from their personal collections as well as from their businesses. The NRA had challenged the regulations, which were issued by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to implement the Firearms Owners Protection Act of 1986. Six other gun associations, a gun show promoter and a gunsmith joined the lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Charleston, S.C. In August 1989, the district court judge, Solomon Blatt Jr., upheld all but one provision of the act. The NRA filed an appeal to overturn the remainder. The three-judge appeals panel agreed with the gun interests that the regulations went too far in requiring gun owners to record dealers' license numbers during a sale. The court also struck down a regulation requiring gun collectors to keep records of curios and relics in their possession before they get a collector's license.

DOC.HEAD: Rail Strike Paralyzes Traffic in Belgium
DOC.TEXT: A rail strike by the major unions paralyzed train traffic throughout Belgium on Friday and turned rush hour in major cities into a nightmare. Members of the Christian Democrat and Socialist union are striking for more pay. Commuters left home early Friday, but as early as 6.30 a.m. many of the main highways leading into Brussels were backed up. Train schedules will return to normal over the weekend, but more strikes are expected early next week.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Pastor Temporarily Released to Attend Mother's Deathbed
DOC.TEXT: A dissident paster imprisoned for making an illegal trip to North Korea was released Friday so he can visit his dying mother, officials said. The Rev. Moon Ik-hwan, 72, was released from a provincial prison and brought to Seoul to be with his 95-year-old mother, who is on her deathbed, the officials said. ``The release is out of humanitarian considerations,'' said one official at the Justice Ministry, who asked not to be identified in keeping with official practice. The official said Moon will be free for ``several days.'' Moon, a Presbyterian minister, was convicted of making an illegal trip to communist North Korea in 1989 and was sentenced to seven years in prison. No South Koreans can visit North Korea without prior government approval.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Leads Police to Oscar Stolen 15 Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: An Academy Award statuette that cinematographer Karl Freund won in 1937 is being returned to his family 15 years after it was stolen, police said. The Oscar was handed over to police Thursday after a businesswoman advertised it for sale in the Los Angeles Times. The unidentified woman told police she got the Oscar from a friend who owed her money. She asked $20,000 for it in her Aug. 29 ad. The statuette was stolen from the Chicago home of Freund's daughter and son-in-law in 1975. Police said a friend on the West Coast saw the ad and contacted the family. No charges were filed against the woman. ``She had no idea it was stolen,'' said police Sgt. Donald Cowen. Freund, who died in 1969, worked on such films as ``Dracula''; ``Key Largo,'' with Humphrey Bogart; and ``Camille,'' with Greta Garbo. He also was director of photography for television's ``I Love Lucy'' in the early 1950s. He won the Oscar for ``The Good Earth.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Passenger Jet Crashes; Four Killed
DOC.TEXT: An Aeroflot passenger jet crashed while preparing to land Friday in the Ural Mountains city of Sverdlovsk, killing at least four of the 124 people on board, the Tass news agency reported. Also Friday, another jet was forced to make an emergency landing in a swamp after an engine failure, Tass said. There were no injuries. Tass said engine failure also was the apparent cause of the Aeroflot crash. It said four people died and several passengers were injured when the Yak-42 went down as it approached Koltsovo airport at Sverdlovsk, 930 miles east of Moscow. It was on a flight from Volgograd. Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian federation, announced the incident to the republic's Supreme Soviet parliament. He said the plane crashed about 90 seconds before it was to touch down at the airport. Yeltsin said an investigation team was dispatched to the crash site. Tass said several of the injured were hospitalized. In the second incident, Tass said the crew of an Antonov-2 aircraft was on an aerial photography mission in the Vologda region, 200 miles northeast of Moscow, when engine failure forced it to land in a swamp. Although the single-engine aircraft nosed over, there were no injuries to the crew, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Urges Eggs Be Well-Cooked To Avoid Salmonella
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is urging that people cook their eggs well to prevent the spread of potentially fatal food contamination caused by salmonella bacteria. Cooks who use raw eggs for Caesar salads, bearnaise sauce, eggnog and ice cream risk serious food poisoning, the FDA said. The agency, in 3,500 notices sent to state and local food regulatory agencies, recommended that intact-shell eggs be redesignated as a ``potentially hazardous food'' because of increases in illnesses linked to consumption of egg products. FDA spokesman Chris Lecos said today the designation ``doesn't imply that a food is inherently unhealthful,'' only that precautions are needed in storing and cooking it. The notice advises that eggs be refrigerated at temperatures of 45 degreesfahrenheit or less and thoroughly cooked at 140 degrees fahrenheit. It says whole eggs should be cooked until the white is completely coagulated and firm and the yolk begins to thicken. Scrambled eggs need to be cooked until firm throughout. Restaurants and food service operations are told not to use raw eggs in uncooked, ready-to-eat menu items and cooks are urged to substitute pasteurized eggs and egg products for shell eggs in recipes for salads, sauces, mayonnaise and ice cream calling for raw eggs. Department of Agriculture figures show there were 6,604 illnesses and 43 deaths attributed to salmonella enteritidis bacteria between January 1985 and October last year. Eggs were implicated in 73 percent of 189 recorded outbreaks. USDA spokeswoman Margaret Webb said 56 salmonella outbreaks have been confirmed since February this year, with 22 definitely linked to eggs. She said eggs may also be implicated in other cases, which have centered in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic states. Pennsylvania has reported nine outbreaks of the illness, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea and stomach cramps and can be fatal to the elderly and young children. Ms. Webb said the USDA is trying to pinpoint infection in breeder flocks - the chickens producing commercial hens. She said one flock in Maryland, one in Alabama and four in Pennsylvania had been restricted during the current campaign. Last May, the FDA approved irradiation of poultry to control salmonella, but the industry said it had no plans to use the procedure. Cathy McCharen, vice president of the Egg Nutrition Center in Washington, said the egg industry generally supports the recommendations. ``If eggs were properly refrigerated there would be no salmonella at all,'' she said. The recommendations ``will force food handlers and restaurateurs to treat the egg with the kind of respect it deserves. That we do want to see.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
American Consul Detained Briefly in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. consul in Kuwait was detained briefly today by Iraqi troops who invaded the Canadian ambassador's residence in Kuwait City, Canadian diplomatic sources said. In addition to the American, consuls from Britain, Ireland, Australia and Canada also were detained, the sources said. They said all were released when their identity as diplomats was established. The names of the consuls were not available. According to the sources, who asked not to be identified, the consuls were meeting to discuss the evacuation this weekend of additional Westerners from Kuwait. Iraqi troops burst into ambassadors' residences or diplomatic missions of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait today, in the most serious confrontations involving diplomats in the occupied emirate since Iraq ordered the embassies closed. The Netherlands also disclosed that Iraqi troops had forced their way into its ambassador's residence in Kuwait earlier this week.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Pledged $3 Billion More For Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Facing allegations it has been too tightfisted during the Persian Gulf tensions, Japan on Friday pledged an additional $3 billion for the U.S.-led military mobilization in the region. The commitment includes $600 million in immediate emergency loans to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey to ease economic problems stemming from the trade embargo against Iraq, Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto announced. Japan will later decide how to disburse another $1.4 billion in aid to Arab nations and earmark up to $1 billion more for the gulf forces, he added. Last month, the Cabinet announced $1 billion for the troops massed in Saudi Arabia following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Japan also had pledged $22 million to help refugees in the gulf region. Japan, which receives most of its oil from the Middle East, has been rebuked by some U.S. officials who believed the nation should contribute more to pay for the forces. Japan's postwar constitution prohibits the country from sending troops outside its borders. On Wednesday, U.S. congressmen passed a resolution demanding Japan pay all expenses of American troops based in Japan. The proposal's sponsor, Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., said he thought Japan's support for the multinational effort in the gulf was inadequate. ``If they had known the magnitude of the total package of contribution measures which we have announced today, they would know how serious Japan is in trying to cooperate with the United States and other countries in keeping the peace and security in that region, even at the sacrifice of our own finances,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe. Watanabe also announced the first contingent of a 100-member medical team is scheduled to be dispatched to the gulf Tuesday. The 17 officials, doctors and nurses in the first unit will look into conditions and report back to Japan, he said. Sakamoto said President Bush expressed appreciation for Japan's ``active role in the international effort in the gulf.'' He said the loans to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey could carry 1 percent annual interest and be repayable in 30 years. U.S. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, hailed the action by Japan but said she will watch Japan to ensure the contribution is ``as good as it sounds.'' Ms. Schroeder complained that it took congressional action to get Japan to ``to provide a realistic contribution to the Middle East effort.'' The House resolution, passed 370-53, stated the United States would withdraw 5,000 troops each year from Japan until Tokyo agrees to pay the full cost of all 50,000 troops now stationed in the nation. The United States spends about $4.5 billion annually for the U.S. forces in Japan, while Japan contributes about $2.9 billion. Watanabe denied the resolution prompted the decision to expand gulf aid. Japanese press reports for several days had predicted the increase. Meanwhile, Japan has been considering legislation to allow sending non-military personnel to help U.N. peacekeeping activities. Final approval could take months.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Threatened Homes Evacuated In Northern California Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new acreage, 40 percent containment, lightning ruled out as cause, other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: About 100 people were evacuated from 50 threatened homes today as a wildfire burned out of control across 2,500 acres in Tuolumne County, officials said. The fire forced authorities to evacuate residents in the rural Mount Provo area three miles southeast of Twain Harte, said Pat Kaunert, a spokesman for the California Department of Forestry. ``This fire is potentially a real dangerous one for us,'' Kaunert said. ``The fire is burning more intensely than it should, because it is so dry.'' ``The drought has left the vegetation just crackling dry,'' he said. More than 1,300 firefighters are battling the fire, their task made all the more difficult by the steep and difficult terrain in the canyon. The blaze was 40 percent contained this morning. ``The firefighters are up against the very worst in this fire,'' Kaunert said, adding that the area is so dry that the fire is spreading rapidly even without winds. U.S. Forest Service Spokeswoman Mary Hale said the fire apparently started in a campground on the North Fork of the Tuolumne River, within the Stanislaus National Forest west of Yosemite National Park. The area is about 150 miles east of San Francisco. Since there was no lightning in the area, it is presumed the fire was caused by people, the forestry department said. Officials said they are using over 100 engines, seven air tankers, three light helicopters and 10 bulldozers to battle the fire.

DOC.HEAD: City Agrees to Provide More Stadium Seating for Disabled
DOC.TEXT: City Council members unanimously agreed to settle a lawsuit charging the city with discrimination against disabled people in building the Florida Suncoast Dome. Under Thursday's settlement, wheelchair seating would be dispersed throughout the stadium, giving users the opportunity to sit in different areas at different prices. The 43,000-seat stadium, built as part of the city's efforts to lure a major league baseball franchise, opened in February with 274 wheelchair spaces on the main concourse. The lawsuit demanded 440 spaces scattered across all levels. The settlement provides for at least 308 spaces, including spaces on all levels. The agreement must be approved by the U.S. District Court and all plaintiffs involved, but lead plaintiff George Locascio expressed his satifaction. ``I think it was a good settlement,'' Locascio said. Locascio and 13 other plaintiffs originally demanded changes that would have added $3 million to the cost of the $138 million stadium. The structural changes required by the settlement will cost $600,000 to $700,000.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Sales Drop Indicates Growing Caution, Not Panic
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales dropped 0.6 percent in August, the government said Friday. Analysts said the government's first report on Americans' spending since the Persian Gulf crisis indicated growing consumer caution - but not panic. Economists agreed the report was worrisome evidence of continuing economic weakness, but said it appeared to be worse than it really was because of the impact of the oil shock on the service station sales and the way automobile sales are counted. ``If you take out gas and autos, it was down 0.1 percent,'' said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. The Commerce Department said overall sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $149.2 billion, down from $150.0 billion in July and the largest decline since sales fell 1.0 percent in April. Auto sales fell 4.3 percent, their steepest drop since sinking 5.6 percent in January. But economists said that reflected a seasonal adjustment and that actual sales were virtually unchanged from both June and July. Excluding automobile sales, retail sales rose 0.4 percent in August. On the other hand, sales at gasoline stations jumped 6.4 percent, the largest increase since a 8.3 percent gain in August 1979. But analysts said the sharp hike reflected sharply higher prices rather than increased volume. The American Petroleum Institute said gasoline prices have risen 20 percent since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Nevertheless, sales would have fallen 1.1 percent without the service station category. ``The simple reality is that consumers are gradually pulling back in their spending out of concern over a weakening job market and unstable conditions in the Middle East,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer. ``There's no indication that will stop in the coming months,'' Jones added. ``I think the economy is slowly sinking into a recession.'' Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago, contended that consumers are ``not showing signs of panicking'' although they are ``talking one thing and doing another. ...'' Analysts are worried about the impact of Middle East developments on Americans' spending. Two major surveys - one conducted by the Conference Board in New York and another by the University of Michigan - showed that consumer confidence plummeted after the Iraq invasion. Because consumer spending represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, there was concern that a dropoff could help push the nation into a recession. Retail sales account for about half of all consumer spending. Sales of durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - slid 2.6 percent after rising 0.7 percent in the preceding month. Besides automobiles, the building material component also fell, down 2.4 percent. Sales of furniture and other home furnishings rose 0.7 percent. Non-durable goods sales rose 0.6 percent following July's 0.3 percent gain. Except for gasoline, all non-durable categories fell. Sales at department stores were down 0.2 percent; grocery stores, off 0.2 percent; clothing stores, down 0.9 percent; restaurants and bars, off 0.7 percent, and drug stores, down 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Schwarzkopf Says Some Iraqi Defectors Sent Back With Messages
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some Iraqi soldiers defecting from occupied Kuwait are being sent back home with food and water and being told to convey a message that ``things are pretty good over here,'' the U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia says. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf said he had verified ``from Americans who were there'' some reports of defectors wandering across the border and being taken into custody by Saudi Arabian troops. There were also reports of Iraqis found ``dead in the desert in Kuwait after they ran out of water.'' Saudi officers have told of hundreds of Iraqis defecting from the forces in Kuwait, sometimes arriving in armored personnel carriers or other vehicles. But the Saudis have not provided any overall number of defectors and have refused reporters' requests to see the turncoats or equipment. In an interview at his headquarters here, Schwarzkopf said he had no solid numbers but was sure some had abandoned their posts in Kuwait. ``They wander in in twos and threes looking for water and saying they don't want to fight,'' he said. ``It's my understanding that the Saudis who have been handling this problem say, `we agree, you shouldn't be fighting. Here's some food. Here's some water. Go back and tell your folks that things are pretty good over here.''' Saudi military officials were not immediately available to comment on the report of the returned defectors. ``It's not huge figures - yet,'' Schwarzkopf said of the defections. ``But I fully hope that the forces that are in Kuwait fully understand that Saddam Hussein has put them there to die.'' Some defectors, including those carrying useful military intelligence, remain in Saudi Arabia, he said. None has been shown to reporters. Schwarzkopf said information from the Iraqi forces indicated Saddam's soldiers didn't know the Aug. 2 move into Kuwait was to take over the country by force. ``They're still quite shocked by the fact that the Kuwaitis fought them,'' he said. Many thought they were going on maneuvers in Kuwait, that the Kuwaiti government had asked them to protect it, or that they were going to fight Israelis, he said. The four-star general said he could not assess the overall morale of the Iraqis. ``A lot of that depends on theirleadership, what kind of resupply they have, and we just don't have that lever of detailed intelligence,'' he said. Diplomats and Western military analysts in Baghdad several days ago reported morale problems among Iraqi troops in Kuwait because the army could not supply them with enough water and good food. They have also said some Iraqi officers were executed for opposing the invasion. Unconfirmed reports from Iraqi dissidents said as many as 120 officers had been shot by firing squad and others imprisoned.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Plan Would Hike Taxes On Lower Income Levels
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new graf 8 with Mitchell response
DOC.TEXT: A Republican deficit-reduction plan being considered by budget negotiators would raise taxes for people making less than $50,000 a year but cut them for richer Americans, congressional analysts say. The proposal would mean $4.1 billion a year in new taxes for people with annual incomes under $50,000. Those at or above $50,000 would get an $11 billion tax reduction. Disclosure of the analysis of the proposal - which includes limits on deductions for state and local income taxes, increased levies on alcoholic beverages and a cut in the capital gains tax - drew angry criticism today from GOP negotiators. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas questioned whether there is any reason to go on with negotiations when some Democrats ``continue to fax and leak and fax stuff to reporters all day long with their point of view.'' Dole said the morning news was filled with reports that ``Republicans are out there trying to favor the rich.'' ``That's the same old Democratic lie that's been out here for 20, 30, 40 years,'' Dole said. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, called the leaks part of a ``systematic strategy to take the tough components of any package and blame Republicans for those components.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, also condemnned the leaking of information from the talks. ``It is unfortunate. It has occurred on both sides. It ought to stop,'' he told the Senate. As negotiators headed toward nearby Andrews Air Force Base, Md., for another session, Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., told reporters, ``We're nowhere.'' ``It's going to be a long process,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. . Negotiators are racing to beat an Oct. 1 deadline. Unless a deficit-cutting plan is approved by then, about $100 billion of across-the-board reductions in federal programs will be triggered two weeks later. Analysts for the non-partisan staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation said the Republican proposal would produce an average 5.5 percent tax cut for the 740,000 couples and individuals with annual incomes of $200,000 and more. The 33 million people with incomes under $10,000 would pay an average 2.6 percent more. The plan is tilted in favor of those with higher incomes primarily because of the cut in taxes on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments. Analysts say nearly 80 percent of the benefits of cutting the capital gains tax would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. President Bush insists on including a capital gains cut in any deficit-reduction plan, saying it is needed for economic growth. Democratic leaders say they will not allow the cut unless overall income tax rates on the wealthy are raised to make up for the capital gains reduction. Tax provisions offered by Democratic negotiators include a 20 percent surtax on those with annual incomes above $500,000; elimination of the $51,300 limit on the amount of wages subject to the 1.45 percent Medicare tax; higher taxes on alcohol; an 11-cent-a-gallon boost in gasoline taxes and a 4 percent tax on other forms of energy. Congressional analysts said the Democratic plan would result in a $4 billion tax cut for those making less than $20,000 a year and an increase of $26.5 billion for others. A family making about $45,000 would pay 3.2 percent more; a $250,000 family would pay 6.7 percent more. Despite months of talking, the White House and congressional leaders have reached final agreement on no specific tax increase or spending reduction. They have agreed generally on the need for reducing the deficit by $50 billion in fiscal 1991 and an additional $450 billion in the following four years. The lack of agreement among the deficit negotiators prompted the House on Thursday to delay consideration of the $283 billion defense bill until next week. The delay was intended ``to give our negotiators a little opportunity,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. While the negotiations drone on, the administration is preparing for the worst. Federal workers have been notified they could be furloughed for 22 days without pay during the next 12 months, and administrators are going public with a message that government services will be pinched. At a news conference Thursday, Federal Aviation Administration chief James B. Busey said lack of agreement could cause a 30 percent reduction in domestic airline flights. Forced furloughs of FAA workers, including 17,200 air traffic controllers, would result in a 25 percent reduction in the agency's work force, Busey said. For safety reasons, that would result in a cut of 25 percent to 30 percent in flights. ``It's not a game of chicken that I'm playing,'' Busey said. ``It's a game of management.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Congressman Stratton Dies
DOC.TEXT: Samuel S. Stratton, a New York Democrat who served in the House for 30 years, has died of a heart attack. He was 73. Stratton died Thursday after being stricken at the Potomac nursing home where he had lived since last year. He announced in July 1988 that he was too ill to seek re-election. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo praised Stratton for his ``dedication and tireless leadership,'' saying he ``displayed wisdom and the unstinting willingness to serve.'' Other colleagues remembered him Friday as a champion of a strong national defense and an unflagging public servant. ``Sam was the epitome of what a congressman should be,'' said Republican Rep. Frank Horton, who succeeded Stratton as dean of the New York congressional delegation. ``He was quick to respond to the needs of his constituents and his knwledge and integrity earned him the respect of both Republicans and Democrats alike.'' A Democrat whose hawkish views broke with party tradition, Stratton favored most proposed increases in defense spending and new weapons systems, including the B-1 bomber, MX missile and neutron bomb. But he considered himself a middle-of-the-road Democrat, and had voted against an anti-busing amendment to the Constitution and supported such ``liberal'' causes as a national minimum welfare payment and economic sanctions against South Africa. Stratton's biggest congressional defeat was in never becoming chairman of the Armed Services Committee. He was passed over for the younger and less-senior Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis. Stratton was born in 1916 in Yonkers, N.Y. He graduated from the University of Rochester and earned master's degrees from Haverford College and Harvard University. He served during World War II as a naval combat intelligence officer on the staff of Gen. Douglas MacArthur. He twice was awarded the Bronze Star. Stratton was first elected to the House in 1958, the only Democrat in 42 years to be sent to Congress from what was then the 32nd congressional district. Stratton is survived by his wife, Joan, and five children.

DOC.HEAD: Constitutional Committee Rules Against Gorbachev on Rallies
DOC.TEXT: A constitutional committee overturned a decree issued by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that gave the Soviet government power over rallies in central Moscow, Tass reported Friday. The Constitutional Compliance Committee ruled that Gorbachev's decree was unconstitutional because it ``narrowed'' the powers of the Russian Republic - of which Moscow is capital - and the Moscow City Council, Tass said. Gorbachev's decree had empowered the Soviet government to decide whether rallies could be held within the Garden Ring Road, a wide boulevard that circles central Moscow. Previously, Soviet legislation gave final say over rallies to parliaments in the republics and local governing councils, Tass said. Tass did not say when the constitutional committee made its decision. Gorbachev's decree was issued in April after newly elected democratic reformers took control of the Moscow City Council. In February, the national parliament had asked the government to oversee rallies in Moscow, fearing that extremists and criminal elements would exploit the demonstrations to destabilize society. There have been several big rallies in Moscow this year drawing thousands of people shouting for the downfall of communism.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Readying Bill to Allow Lowering of Barriers with Mexico
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sent Congress a bill Friday to forgive some Latin American debt and to encourage more U.S. companies to invest there. Aides said he also was readying a bill to allow the lowering of trade barriers with Mexico. The Mexican free-trade measure could be submitted as early as Monday, wen administration trade officials testify before the House-Senate Joint Economic Committee, sources said. Bush would like to have the authority to lower trade barriers with Mexico in hand when he meets with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in Mexico City in November, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The Persian Gulf crisis, in focusing attention on world oil supplies, has added to the impetus for such an agreement with Mexico, the officials said. Mexico has the world's eighth largest oil reserves. A free-trade pact with the United States could spur oil production. The United States already has a free-trade pact with Canada and Bush has voiced the hope that some day goods and services may be traded from Alaska to Argentina without trade barriers. He repeated that goal Friday at a White House ceremony as he announced he was sending Congress a proposed ``Enterprise for the Americas Initiative Act of 1990.'' Bush called the package ``trade, not aid.'' The legislation submitted would forgive about $7 billion in loans owed to the government by Latin American and Caribbean countries. Latin nations owe U.S. banks an additional $48.3 billion. The bill also would set up a special fund within the Inter-American Development Bank to provide a variety of services to western companies wanting to invest in Latin America and the Caribbean. The U.S. government would contribute $500 million a year to the fund and would seek contributions from other countries. ``We believe these measures together will boost trade, investment and growth in our hemisphere. This legislation is good for our neighbors, it's good for the hemisphere and I believe it is very good for the United States,'' Bush said. Under the free-trade pact with Canada, tariffs, quotas and other trade barriers began to fall in January 1989 and will be removed by the turn of the century. Mexico is the United States' third largest trading partner, after Canada and Japan. The United States exported $24.97 billion in goods to Mexico last year and received $27.19 in imports, for a deficit of $2.2 billion.

Here is the text of President Bush's news conference Friday on the White House lawn: PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, I just want to say a couple of things here and I'd be glad to take just a handful of questions. First, I want to publicly acknowledge and express my appreciation for the decision by the Japanese government to make additional contributions to the effort that we're all making in the Gulf. Specifically, Japan will be providing significant economic assistance to key countries in the region that are most severely affected by the sanctions and higher energy prices. Japan is also increasing its support for the multinational forces involved in the collective defense effort. And I gave my personal thanks to Prime Minister Kaifu last night when he called me to tell me about this news. And we are grateful to the Japanese - significant contribution. And second and in a similar vein, I want to say that early this morning, Prime Minister Thatcher phoned to give me the additional good news of her country's latest contribution. She informed me that the United Kingdom would be sending a full armored brigade, along with the additional helicopters and aircraft, to Saudi Arabia. Some Americans may remember the name the ``Desert Rats,'' and that's who's - that's who will be going. As I told the Prime Minister over the phone, given all that the United Kingdom is already doing, this truly comes as the icing on the cake, a significant move by the Brits. And I also called President Mitterrand a few minutes ago to consult with him on the outrageous Iraqi break-in of the French embassy residence in Kuwait. These developments not only underscore the brutal behavior of Iraq, but also the international support that exists and is marshaled against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. I've often said that it is not the United States against Iraq, but Iraq against the world. And for our part, we will continue to do everything possible to ensure that the sanctions work as intended and to deter and if need be, defend Saudi Arabia against armed attack.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Raid Diplomatic Residences, U.S. Boards Iraqi Vessel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Iraq denying embasssy incursions. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `On the..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AHA1, NY13
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops burst into diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait today, officials said, and sources said consuls from the United States and four other countries were briefly detained. Also, Pentagon sources said a U.S. Navy frigate ship fired on and halted an Iraqi tanker today in the Gulf Oman as part of the effort to enforce trade sanctions against Iraq. The tanker was then boarded by U.S. forces, one official said. The incidents in Kuwait were the most serious confrontations involving diplomats in the occupied emirate since Iraq ordered the embassies closed. However, the official Iraqi News Agency, quoting what it called a ``responsible Iraqi source,'' denied Iraqi troops had made any incursions into what it called ``former diplomatic missions in the province of Kuwait.'' It said troops were under strict orders not to enter the compounds. Iraq annexed Kuwait six days after the Aug. 2 invasion and says since Kuwait is no longer a sovereign country, foreign nations are not entitled to diplomatic representation there. At the White House, President Bush confirmed the ship boarding incident. Asked whether it represented an escalation in the crisis, he said: ``I wouldn't put it closer to a war situation.'' It was not immediately known where the ship was heading or what its cargo was. On the raids on diplomatic compounds in Kuwait, Canadian diplomatic sources in Washington said the Iraqi troops who invaded the Canadian ambassador's residence detained the U.S. consul, along with consuls from Britain, Ireland, Australia and Canada. According to the sources, who asked not to be identified, the consuls were meeting to discuss the evacuation this weekend of additional Westerners from Kuwait. Also, the Netherlands disclosed that Iraqi troops had forced their way into its ambassador's residence in Kuwait on Wednesday. The countries involved protested vigorously, as did the European Community.
