French President Francois Mitterrand, on a visit to Czechoslovakia, called said the Iraqi move was ``an aggression, and we will respond to it.'' He called an emergency Cabinet meeting for Saturday. Meanwhile, the military noose around Iraq tightened today, with Britain announcing it would send an armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops to the Persian Gulf. It was the the first dispatch of tanks and significant numbers of ground troops by any Western country besides the United States since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and subsequent annexation of the oil-rich nation. The economic embargo on Iraq also expanded. The United Nations late Thursday set strict limits on food shipments to Iraq under a U.N. embargo. Japan today pledged $3 billion more in aid to the multinational force in the Persian Gulf and to nations hurt by the U.N. embargo, bringing that country's total contribution to about $4 billion. The United States said it welcomed the contribution. In the gulf region, the chairman of the U.S. Joint Chief of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell, warned Saddam Hussein today that he would pay dearly if he attacked Saudi Arabia. He spoke to sailors aboard the USS Blue Ridge. In Washington, the government announced that U.S. wholesale prices shot up 1.3 percent in August, the biggest surge in seven months, as the first shock wave from the Persian Gulf crisis hit the American economy. The Labor Department blamed virtually the entire increase on higher oil costs since the Middle East crisis began. The French Foreign Ministry in Paris said Iraqi troops entered the ambassador's residence this morning, taking away the military attache and three others to an unknown destination. It said the attache was later freed but the fate of the others was not known. The Canadian Embassy in Paris said special Iraqi forces also entered the residence of Canada's ambassador before dawn. Spokesman Jacques Crete said the consul was briefly detained but later released. Belgian officials said three Iraqi soldiers entered Belgium's diplomatic compound today and ordered the two remaining diplomats to leave the embassy. They said the soldiers left after the Belgian diplomats fled into the adjacent ambassador's residence. The Dutch Foreign Ministry disclosed that Iraqi soldiers had forced their way into Dutch Ambassador Joop Veling's home im Kuwait City earlier this week. The ministry spokesman did not provide further details. Britain's Foreign Office and the U.S. State Department said there had been no similar action at the British and U.S. embassies or diplomatic residences. Iraqi authorities had earlier cut off water and electricity to the French and other embassies in Kuwait in an effort to pressure foreign nations to close their missions. France, the United States and 18 other countries have refused. France was one of Baghdad's top arms supplier before the gulf crisis began, but has sent the second-largest naval force to the region - after the United States - to help enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The military buildup got a boost today with the announcment by British Defense Secretary Tom King that an armored brigade and troops would be sent to the gulf. King said another squadron of Tornado ground attack aircraft and additional air defense aircraft, would also be sent. Defense officials indicated it would take about a month for the armored forces to reach Saudi Arabia. Meanwhile, U.S. diplomatic efforts to isolate Iraq forged ahead today. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Syrian President Hafez Assad to plan further cooperation with Damascus despite a State Department report that Syria promotes terrorism. Assad was likely to send 15,000 more troops to help defend Saudi Arabia, Western diplomatic sources said today on condition of anonymity. Syria has 3,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia and 1,000 in the United Arab Emirates as part of the multinational force. Also today, an Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 chartered by the U.S. government flew to Kuwait City to pick up about 400 Americans scheduled to fly home later in the day, a U.S. Embassy official said. The Americans were to stop in Baghdad to receive exit visas before changing planes and continuing to London, the diplomat said on condition of anonymity. About 6,500 Westerners remain stranded in Iraq and Kuwait, many of them in hiding. They are believed to include about 1,500 Americans in Kuwait, according to the U.S. Embassy official in Baghdad. The Bush administration is to ask Congress today for an additional $1.8 billion to pay for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf through the end of the month, administration and congressional sources said Thursday. About 145,000 U.S. military personnel have been deployed in the region since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sent his forces into Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money. Iraq has massed an estimated 265,000 troops in or near the emirate on Saudi Arabia's northern border. In a late-night session Thursday, the U.N. Security Council voted 13-2 on the U.S.-sponsored resolution to allow shipments only to alleviate ``human suffering.'' It rejected an effort by Cuba to broaden food shipments to civilians in Iraq and Kuwait. The Security Council said humanitarian organizations must distribute whatever aid is sent, and it reserved the power to make that determination. Cuba and Yemen voted against the measure. Early today, the council's committee on sanctions approved a request by India to send a ship loaded with 11,000 tons of food to Kuwait to feed about 120,000 stranded Indian citizens. The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said the vote was in line with the strict limits set Thursday. The limits came under the U.N. Aug. 6 embargo, which cut trade with Iraq and Kuwait to medical supplies or ``in humanitarian circumstances, foodstuffs.'' Japan's announcment that t would provide more aid for the multinational forces and to gulf nations hurt by the blockade came after members of the U.S. Congress complained Japan and Germany were not enough in the crisis. Both nations are heavily dependent on Middle East oil. A government spokesman in Bonn said today West Germany will offer the United States extra help in its military operation in the Gulf, although he did not say what that aid might include.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... armed attack.
DOC.TEXT: And here I just want to reiterate what I said when I first ordered the U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia, namely, that the United States forces were sent to Saudi Arabia at the request of the Saudi government. And those same U.S. forces will depart as soon as they are no longer needed or wanted. And they will remain not one day longer than is absolutely necessary. John? Q: Mr. President, are we any closer to armed combat because of what has happened at the French embassy and also because a U.S. warship apparently has now fired across the bow of an Iraqi tanker? What do you know about that? A: I wouldn't put it closer to a war situation. I still hope that this matter can be peacefully resolved. And the way for that to happen is for Iraq to comply with the sanctions. Yes, an American vessel did, in accordance with the United Nations resolutions, in accordance with the sanctions, cause another Iraqi vessel to heave to. And it has been boarded and I expect confidently that if it indeed is not carrying any contraband, or anything that will violate the sanctions, it will be permitted to go on its way. But it did require a bit of a warning before the captain pulled over and permitted the boarding party to have a look. Yeah, Rita? Q: Mr. President, what can you tell us about the U.S. consul that was detained in the Canadian Ambassador's house? Any protest r any action about that? A: I don't have all the details about that one but again, I would lump that into the - to the - the unacceptable action category. I don't have the facts on that, I'd have - (aside) do you - Staff: They've been released, Mr. President. A: They have been released. So - but any of these incidents, all of them add up to clear violations of international law, and I think they do raise tensions, they clearly do. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, how is Ambassador Howell? And would the U.S. have to respond militarily if Iraq entered the United States compound in Kuwait City? A: That's too hypothetical, the last part of the question. But I have no reason to believe that Ambassador Howell - that Howell is not in good shape. I haven't heard anything to the contrary. Q: How long are you going to keep him there, sir? A: I have not made a determination on that. Q: Can you tell us - Q: Mr. President, gasoline prices are up dramatically and heating oil is at a record level in today's wholesale price report. Does that send - what kind of warning signals does that send to you about the overall economic situation related to the Gulf crisis?
DOC.NOTE: MORE:

DOC.HEAD: Opry's Clogging Star Dead at 61
DOC.TEXT: Ben Smathers, whose agile legs and fast feet helped spread the popularity of clog dancing during a 32-year career on the Grand Ole Opry, has died. He was 61. The leader of the Stoney Mountain Cloggers died Thursday of complications following open-heart surgery. He had been admitted to Vanderbilt Hospital on Tuesday complaining of an upset stomach and heartburn. Smathers, an Asheville, N.C., native, learned the dance as a child by watching an old man do it in the mountains of western North Carolina. A hallmark of Appalachian culture, clogging is basically keeping the beat of the music by tapping the feet. In a 1986 interview, he said the key to doing the dance well was the emotional grasp of its spirit. ``If you can't feel it in your heart, it has no meaning,'' he told The Associated Press. His eight-member Stoney Mountain Cloggers often danced on the Opry to fiddle tunes such as ``Black Mountain Rag'' and ``Old Joe Clark.'' The group had made frequent appearances with the Charlie Daniels Band, dancing to the high-powered fiddle classic ``Orange Blossom Special'' as a climax to each show. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Smathers and his group performed with Roy Rogers and Dale Evans at fairs, rodeos and other appearances. He made six low-budget movies and performed the native folk dance twice in New York's Carnegie Hall. He also appeared 300 times on network TV shows. He suffered a heart attack in 1979 and doctors told him then he would never dance again. He proved them wrong by returning to the stage in six months. ``They don't call you home 'til your work's done,'' he said about his recovery. Funeral arrangements were incomplete. Survivors include his mother, wife, three sons and three daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Condemns Iraqi Break-in at French Embassy in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs, editing throughout, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today condemned Iraq for its ``outrageous'' break-in of the French Embassy residence in Kuwait City and said the episode and the brief detaining of an American there adds up to ``clear violation of international law.'' Bush also announced that an American naval ship had fired a warning shot at an Iraqi ship so that it could be boarded. ``But it required a bit of a warning,'' Bush said. The president said he had talked with French President Francois Mitterrand earlier today ``to consult with him on the outrageous Iraqi break-in of the French Embassy residence in Kuwait.'' ``These developments not only underscore the brutal behavior of Iraq, but also the international support that exists, and is marshalled, against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.'' He had less information on reports that the U.S. consul in Kuwait was detained briefly today by Iraqi troops who invaded the Canadian ambassador's residence in Kuwait City. ``I don't have all the details on that one, but again I would lump that in to the unacceptable action category,'' he said. ``Any of these incidents, all of them, add up to clear violations of international law. They do raise tensions, they clearly do.'' Bush was asked if the United States and its allies would now seek to escalate the pressure on Iraq. ``When an escalation is required from me, Saddam Hussein will know it,'' he said. Asked what he would do if Iraq entered the U.S. compound in Kuwait City, Bush said, ``that's too hypothetical.'' He said he had ``not made a determination'' on how long to keep the U.S. embassy open in Kuwait City. It has been without electricity and water for several weeks. Bush spoke with reporters on the White House lawn as he prepared to leave Washington to spend the weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. The president said he told Mitterrand in their conversation the United States would ``do anything I could to support whatever he decides to do'' in response to the break-in at the ambassador's home. ``We'll simply wait and see what they recommend,'' he said. Asked if today's events put the United States any closer to a war with Iraq, Bush said: ``I wouldn't put it closer to a war situation. I still hope that this matter can be peacefully resolved. And the way for that to happen is for Iraq to comply with the sanctions.'' On the boarding incident in the Persian Gulf, Bush said, ``Yes, an American vessel did, in accordance with the United Nations resolutions, in accordance with the sanctions, cause another Iraqi vessel to heave-to. It has been boarded.'' ``I expect confidently that if it is not carrying any contraband or anything that will violate the sanctions, that it will be permitted to go on its way. But it required a bit of a warning before the captain pulled over and permitted the boarding party to have a look.'' Bush praised Japan for agreeing to increase its financial support for the multinational effort in the Persian Gulf confronting Iraq. And he said that British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had vowed to send a full armored brigade and helicopters. He said he thanked both leaders personally for their contribution. ``For our part, we will continue to do everything possible to ensure that the sanctions work as intended and ... if need be, defend Saudi Arabia against armed attack.'' He said U.S. forces would leave Saudi Arabia ``as soon as they are no longer needed or wanted. They will remain not one day longer than is absolutely necessary.'' Bush also said: -He expects the message he taped for the Iraqi people will be delivered to Iraqi officials in Baghdad ``after getting off to a slow start'' on Thursday when the Iraqi ambassador in Washington refused to accept a copy. -The ``sudden inflation'' represented by the 1.3 percent rise in August wholesale prices reported today by the Labor Department was ``a matter of concern, given the state of the economy.'' Still, he said, there are sufficient petroleum supplies ``and the market should not be going for higher prices.'' -The budget negotiations between the White House and Congress, under way for a week at nearby Andrews Air Force Base, were ``up and down like a roller coaster.'' He said that administration negotiators this morning felt ``they were closing the gap,'' although he had not talked to them since then. -Said he had been following some of the televised testimony of his Supreme Court nominee, David Souter, and ``my admiration for Judge Souter, my respect for him, is really higher. I really think he's conducted himself extraordinarily well.'' He said he felt questions from senators had been fair and that Souter's line of answering ``has been masterful.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... Gulf crisis?
DOC.TEXT: A: Well, I think anytime you have price inflation - sudden inflation - it is a matter of concern given the state of the economy. What it does is make me argue even more vociferously for a budget agreement. But there are - the shortages - this speculation here - we're talking about future market prices, we're talking about futures. They - that speculative atmosphere belies the reality, which is that there are sufficient petroleum products to - so that the market should not be going for higher prices. In other words, it's speculation, it's futures speculation. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, what's your reading on the budget agreement? A: Talking about - I believe you're talking about October prices that are quoted on the crude market. Yeah? Q: What's your reading on the budget negotiations as the clock ticks out? A: Well, kind of up and down like a roller coaster. This morning there was a feeling - our - Dick Darman and John Sununu, Secretary Brady felt that they were closing the gap. Last night it was a little more pessimistic. So I can't tell you. I haven't talked to our negotiators in the last two hours. Q: Is France going to take action as a result of the embassy incursion? Will the United States take action as a result of that? A: I don't know what France is going to do, but clearly, I will continue close consultation with Mr. Mitterrand, because I told him I view this as a matter that is of grave concern to - to the United States. It happens to be the French ambassador's residence, but it is a matter that we look at as - that concerns everybody. And I told him that I would do anything I could to support whatever he decides to do. And he will be back - I found him in Czechoslovakia - and he will be back, and I believe he has a Cabinet meeting tomorrow. So we'll simply wait and see what they recommend. Q: Does that include backing them militarily? Q: Mr. President - A: Yeah, Charles? Q: - (inaudible) - suggesting that the Iraqis are in fact tightening the screws in a number of areas - (inaudible) - escalation now required from you and your allies? A: Well, when an escalation is required from me, Saddam Hussein will know it. Q: What about the tape? Q: Does that - A: Oh, the tape? Haven't heard. I think it's there now. (Aside) Do we know whether the tape has arrived? Marlin Fitzwater: It should be there tonight. A: It got off to a slow start with that Eagleburger hand-off, but it should be there tonight. (Laughter.) Q: Mr. President, for two days - A: (Chuckling) It's one of the classic scenes. Q: Have you had a chance to see any of Judge Souter's testimony and do you have any kind of opinion for how it's going? A: I've seen it and I think it's been magnificent. I haven't seen it all, but I must confess - slight confession - and maybe it's because our budgeteers were out at the summit doing all the heavy lifting - I watched it for about an hour and a half yesterday and I watched it for about 20 minutes today. And my admiration for Judge Souter and respect for him is even higher. I really think he's conducted himself extraordinarily well.
DOC.NOTE: MORE:

DOC.HEAD: FBI Reports Sightings of Pilot Missing for Two Years
DOC.TEXT: The FBI joined the search for a missing insurance executive under indictment for theft, after two people reported seeing him in the Virgin Islands and another sighted him on a yacht in South Carolina. The state attorney general's office has been looking for Blan Stewart, 47, since Halloween night 1988, when his airplane disappeared near Lake Martin in central Alabama. Stewart, who lived in Huntsville, had radioed that he was having engine trouble. Repeated searches of the lake by law enforcement officers and by firms hired by Stewart's family and insurance companies never turned up the plane or a body. On Tuesday, the FBI issued a fugitive warrant for Stewart and joined the search, Agent Tom Wiseman said. In an affidavit used to obtain the warrant, the FBI quoted two unidentified sources, including one Huntsville resident, who said they saw Stewart in the Virgin Islands in late November or early December 1989. The FBI said telephone records subpoenaed by the state attorney general's office showed a collect call from the Virgin Islands to Stewart's wife's home in Huntsville in March. The call came six weeks before Sarah ``Robin'' Stewart went to court to have her husband declared dead so she could collect on $4 million in life insurance. A judge ruled, however, there was insufficient evidence to declare Stewart dead. The FBI's affidavit said a third source, who lives in Huntsville and knows Stewart and his family well, saw him on a yacht in Charleston, S.C., in early April and spoke to him by name. Mrs. Stewart's attorney, John Heacock, said, ``We've never been critical of law enforcement agencies doing their job,'' but ``we have no knowledge of any such sources.'' Don Valeska, an assistant Alabama attorney general who has helped lead the search, has said he considered the sources reliable. He said Friday there had been no new sightings and no new tips in the case since the warrant was issued. At the time of Stewart's disappearance, he was awaiting trial on charges of insurance theft involving $590,000 he collected but allegedly failed to pass on to insurance companies writing the policies. In addition, he faces first-degree theft charges in Lauderdale County, where he is accused of passing a worthless check for nearly $12,000 to a furniture plant. Insurance companies have posted a $100,000 reward for information on whether he is alive or dead.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspaper Confirms Iraqis Being Trained in Latvia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet navy captain confirmed in a report Friday that Iraqi servicemen were being trained at a naval base in Latvia, whose nationalist government has raised a strong protest. Capt. Sergei E. Sharov, an official at the Soviet Navy Training Center in Riga, the Latvian capital, confirmed the troops' presence in an interview with the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. ``At present in the garrison, along with the specialists from other countries, there are some from Iraq being trained in the ship defense equipment service,'' Sharov said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said Friday that several dozen Iraqi ``students'' were among many foreigners, including military cadets, studying in the Soviet Union. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, some of the Iraqis left the Soviet Union immediately, and none has arrived in the Soviet Union to take their place, he said at a briefing. Gerasimov said the number of Iraqi trainees was insignificant and that their contracts expire in December. The training was not taken lightly by the government of Latvia, which along with the neighboring Baltic republics of Lithuania and Estonia is seeking independence from the Soviet Union. A resolution endorsed Thursday by the presidium, or Cabinet, of the Latvian parliament protested the training of ``soldiers from the armed forces of the aggressor-state Iraq,'' and demanded the Soviet navy and the Baltic Military District ``immediately inform the Supreme Council of the Republic of Latvia about all foreign military personnel and their family members who are stationed in the territory.'' Andrejs Krastins, a vice-chairman of the Latvian parliament, said the Iraqis were studying rockets and missiles. He said Latvian authorities should cut off water, electricity and food to the base if the they didn't leave. Komsomolskaya Pravda said the report did not come as a surprise to residents of Riga, who are accustomed to seeing military specialists from the Middle East in the cafes and restaurants of the Baltic port. The Soviet Union has trained thousands of soldiers from socialist states and other nations to which it has sold military weapons. The publicity over the Iraqi trainees was the latest embarrassment for Moscow involving military ties to its longtime ally. The Soviet Union condemned Iraq following its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and has cut off arms shipments to Baghdad. But about 190 Soviet military advisers remain in Iraq, under contract to train Saddam Hussein's soldiers to use and repair their military gear. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Tuesday the Soviet Union has not reneged on the contract for fear that doing so would jeopardize the 5,800 Soviet citizens still in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... extraordinarily well.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Do you think the questioning has been fair? A: What I've seen so far, yeah. And they're - a senator has a right to ask any question he wants. And what I think has been masterful is the way Judge Souter has gone as far as he possibly can and yet has handled it with such intellect and such a, you know, knowledgeable manner that I don't think anybody gets the feeling that he is improperly avoiding things. Yeah? Q: Sen. Dole this morning said he thinks the capital gains - (off mike) - A: Listen, Sen. Dole is doing a magnificent job out there. I don't know in what context he placed that. And I think everybody in the summit knows of my commitment to it. I'm absolutely convinced that it would not even be a revenue loser, although it's scored that way, and it is something that is fundamentally important to the continued growth in the economy, a growth that, frankly, is far too slow right now. So I hope it's put into effect, but I'm not going to - kind of go beyond that. Q: Since last November - (off mike). A: Because we've got a strategy and I think it's working and I think all our people are on the same side on this issue. Fitzwater: Final question. A: Here we are. Rita, and then I've got to go. Q: Mr. President, I couldn't hear what Charles asked, but did you tell Mitterrand that you would back him with military retaliation if that's the way he wants to go? A: We didn't go into the details of the backing, but I just told him he has the full support of the United States - and he does. Q: Have you talked to Ambassador Howell about what he should do if Iraqi forces - A: I haven't talked to Howell in the last week. Last one, John, and then I really - Q: Is it different, sir, from an American - the American - embassy being invaded, however? This is - you're - A: I'm not sure I'd make that distinction. Q: Well, are you rattling at least one saber? You talk about - A: No, I'm not rattling sabers. You're trying to get me to sound like I'm rattling sabers. When I rattle a saber, the man will know it. Q: But you talked about grave concern, but you also talked about the fact that you'll pull the troops back as soon as you can. We have - we saw a mixed signal. A: Oh! No, there should be no connection between those at all. I mean, what I was trying to do was - there's been some speculation, some of it mischievous, in the Middle East, that the United States wants to remain there. And so what I want to do is just reiterate what I think I said in the meeting to the Joint Session, and that is that we want those people - all of them - out as soon as possible. And so, I - that should be separated from anything I'm saying here. I'm glad you asked - let me clarify that. Q: Are the Saudis getting anxious about having so many American troops there? A: I haven't heard that at all, and I don't think so. I know I would have heard it if - if that were the case. They are totally clued in on what our plans are. So there's no - no disquiet on that at all. Thank you all. Q: Thank you. Q: Do you expect a budget agreement this weekend? A: (We?) expected one a week ago.
DOC.HEAD: End Text
New Jersey Government Ethics Questioned in `Computergate' Case
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey state government is reeling from what some are calling ``Computergate,'' the case of a Republican computer hacker who allegedly pilfered confidential Democratic files. The files reportedly show the Democrats used state time for campaign work. It is a case that leaders of both parties declared closed in May, when the Legislature's joint ethical committee dropped its investigation and refused to release its findings. But the issue won't go away. Last week, Assembly Republican staff Executive Director John Kohler quit his $95,000-a-year job after admitting he knew former staffer Jeffrey Land had broken into Democratic computer files. Kohler had previously denied knowledge of the actions. State leaders concede that Land, who resigned in March, gathered more than 1,000 Democratic documents over 18 months. Land reportedly handed the purloined documents over to his superiors. State Attorney General Robert Del Tufo has launched an investigation to determine if criminal charges will be filed. But the legislative committee's report, leaked to The Record of Hackensack, also raised questions about the actions of the Democrats. The pilfered documents show staff members of top Democrats used state time and state computers to plot political campaign strategy. The documents reportedly include lists of campaign contributors. Critics charge that the Legislatur's decision to probe the case in private smacked of a coverup. ``This is playing out with many of the same sordid aspects of the Watergate scandal,'' said Edward McCool, executive director of New Jersey Common Cause, a government watchdog group. ``There is denial, coverup, secret meetings to decide what to do next. And there is the question of how far up it went. It seems the Legislature thinks it is above accountability.'' McCool said the computer breach ``was a break-in involving state equipment by one partisan staff of another partisan staff. Just because technology is involved makes it no less a violation. It's the same as if a door was jimmied or a window broken.'' ``Why didn't the Democrats prosecute?'' McCool said. ``Reasonably minded people can only speculate that it had to do with the nature of the information that was stolen.'' Legislative leaders deny a coverup. They initially called the ethics panel probe an internal personnel matter and said it was protected by the doctrine of separation of powers between the branches of government. Leaders from both parties have subsequently said they would cooperate with the attorney general's investigation. But Albert Porroni, executive director of the non-partisan Office of Legislative Services, told reporters that the Legislature can withhold documents having to do with legislative activity on pending bills. Democratic Assembly Speaker Joseph Doria on Monday said he was ``saddened'' by the revelations and that he is ``upset it would have to get to that level.'' But Doria also said he hadn't seen any of the stolen documents and said he doesn't have ``the time or inclination to look through 1,000 documents.'' Doria and other leaders refused further comment about what documents should be turned over to the attorney general's office. Assembly Republican Minority Leader Chuck Haytaian, who announced Kohler's resignation, said ``such conduct cannot under any circumstances be tolerated.'' Haytaian, who became minority leader in January, said in a statement: ``I remain convinced that no legislator had any such involvement or knowledge.'' On Thursday, the ethics committee reopened its investigation and announced it will call Land and Kohler to testify about their roles in the incident. Land told reporters earlier in the week that he will cooperate with the investigations. He has since refused to comment publicly on the case. Kohler said Thursday he planned to meet with the committee. Haytaian said he will call for ``clear guidelines'' to determine the responsibilities and obligations of partisan staff members. However, McCool said revamping the system ``can't be solved in the dark. This can only be solved if there is a full and public hearing of what happened.''

DOC.HEAD: Boys Clubs Make Room in Title for Girls
DOC.TEXT: Girls have been a big part of the Boys Clubs of America for some time. Now they're also part of the name. The organization has changed its title to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America. Local chapters may still call themselves Boys Clubs if they want, but 376 have already added girls to their titles. ``Since the 1860s, clubs have been keeping pace with the changing needs of America's youth,'' National Director Thomas Garth said in announcing the name change Wednesday. ``The number of girls served by clubs has doubled over the last 10 years. Today, over 30 percent of the young people in clubs are girls.'' Of the 605 chapters across the country, 552 provide services to boys and girls. The organization provides drug and alcohol prevention counseling and career programs to about 1.54 million youths nationwide. It is funded by contributions from individuals, corporations and foundations and through fund-raising events.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Says He Hasn't Made Up His Mind on Abortion Issue
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David Souter said today that he has not made up his mind on the abortion rights issue and would consider both sides if he is confirmed. Faced with repeated probes for his predisposition in the case of Roe vs. Wade, Souter broke from his pattern of not commenting and stated flatly that he didn't have a position. ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade,'' Souter told the Senate Judiciary Committee. ``I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind and I would not go on the court saying I must go one way or I must go the other way,'' he said. Souter's comments came during his second day of testimony, during which he also said he was obligated as a state official to defend limits on the separation of church and state - but he probably would have ruled for the opposite side had he been the judge. When in the New Hampshire Attorney General's office, Souter defended former Gov. Meldrim Thomson's order that flags be lowered to half staff on Good Friday. He also prosecuted two Jehovah's Witnesses for covering the state motto, ``Live Free or Die,'' on their license tags. Souter told the Senate Judiciary Committee today he was obligated to defend the state if arguments could be made, and he maintained that he could in those cases. But, he acknowledged, ``If I were sitting as a judge today, I probably would have ruled the same way'' as the one who decided the flag-lowering order was unconstitutional. As for the license plate motto, he said the state did not have ``a particularly compelling interest'' in keeping its slogan visible. The couple did not cover the numbers on the plate. But Souter said it was important for him to pursue the cases. He said part of the job of upholding the Constitution was to bring forth arguments on issues. President Bush, meanwhile, touted Souter twice today. He said on the White House lawn that his nominee's performance has been ``magnificent.'' Bush said he watched parts of the hearing Thursday and today ``and my admiration for Judge Souter - respect for him - is even higher'' than before. He said Souter had handled the panel's questions ``with such intellect and such a knowledgeable manner'' that no one could accuse him of evasion. Earlier, the president told an international gathering of appellate judges at the White House that Souter's ``strong, incisive, has an independent devotion to the Constitution that was demonstrated during 12 years of distinguished service on the trial court, the U.S. Court of Appeals and, in particular, on the Supreme Court of his state, the New Hampshire Supreme Court.'' Souter began his second day of testimony fielding questions about how far courts should go in delineating new rights, and Souter said judges needed to stick to those implied by the Constitution. A judge ``has got to guard constantly against substituting his values for the values he is sworn to uphold,'' he told Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, an anti-abortion lawmaker who quizzed the nominee about how far some judges have expanded concepts of constitutional rights. As he had the opening day, Souter preferred to speak in general terms and avoided talking about issues, like abortion, which he may have to rule on. On Thursday, committee members said they were learning about David Souter the man, but far less than some had hoped about David Souter the potential Supreme Court justice. ``I was touched by his sincerity, but I don't think I learned what's in his mind with reference to the issues that will be before the Supreme Court,'' said Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who sought unsuccessfully to extract Souter's views on the 1973 ruling that legalized abortion. As the committee's first day of hearings Thursday on President Bush's nominee, the 50-year-old bachelor took pains to describe himself as a caring and understanding man and erase his reputation as a scholarly hermit. He described the many types of cases he has handled, from volunteer work for indigents as a young lawyer fresh from Harvard to his handling of morally vexing disputes as an appeals judge. In response to senators' questions, Souter shifted between legal jargon and personal tales, the latter providing the most drama of the afternoon. Metzenbaum told the nominee of testimony he heard from people who experienced the butchery of illegal abortions before the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling. Metzenbaum then challenged Souter to discuss his personal outlook on the matter - and the nominee shot back with a story from nearly a quarter-century ago when he was a freshman adviser at Harvard. The girlfriend of one of his charges was pregnant and was planning a self-abortion, Souter said, and he agreed to counsel and console her. They spent two hours together in a small room in a dormitory, during which he advised her to do otherwise, he said. Souter, who throughout the day referred to the abortion rights position as ``the other side,'' didn't make clear whether his advice was to carry the pregnancy to term. But he said the incident etched in his mind the consequences involved. Before his confirmation hearings, Souter was counseled at length on how to handle himself. One goal was to make sure the committee didn't think he was another Robert Bork, the staunchly conservative nominee of President Reagan who was rejected by the Senate three years ago. Souter sought to portray himself as less ideological in his approach to the law. Regarding the right to privacy, he acknowledged that in some cases, such as dealings between a husband and wife, it could be considered a fundamental right even though it is never explicitly mentioned in the Constitution. However, he diligently refused to endorse specific court rulings on the issue because the Roe vs. Wade decision hinges on the concept. Souter's testimony was expected to last at least through today and the hearings were scheduled to continue next week. At the end of the hearings, the committee will vote on the nomination and give its recommendation to the full Senate for approval or rejection.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Allows Defense to Use Medical Records in Rape Case
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for a man charged with raping a woman who says she has 21 personalities are being allowed to review some of her medical records to try to prove at least one personality consented to sex. Mark A. Peterson, 29, of Oshkosh, is charged with second-degree sexual assault for allegedly having sex with the 26-year-old woman on June 11. He maintains the woman consented and he was unaware she had a mental illness. He is free on a $5,000 signature bond. Judge Robert Hawley of Winnebago County Circuit Court ruled Thursday that the defense could review the woman's medical records for the 12 months before the alleged rape. The district attorney may be allowed to strike things from the records that he fears would invade the woman's privacy, pending a review in the judge's chambers. Hawley denied a motion by Peterson's attorney, Edward Salzsieder, that a psychiatrist for the defense be allowed to examine all of the woman's medical records and psychiatric examinations and that she be available for examination by the psychiatrist. Hawley said a psychiatrist for the defense could talk to the woman's psychiatrist, listen to courtroom testimony and examine records already available. He added he would reconsider the motion, but the defense psychiatrist would have to testify as to the need to examine the woman. The judge also denied two motions by Salzsieder for dismissal of the case. One contended the statute Peterson is charged under is too vague; the other said evidence and testimony presented at the preliminary examination did not support the charge.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Endorses Decade-Old Treaties
DOC.TEXT: A Senate panel Friday endorsed a pair of U.S.-Soviet treaties more than a decade after the pacts aimed at curbing nuclear weapons testing were drafted. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee took the action on an 18-0 vote, sending the two treaties to the full Senate for ratification. The Threshold Test Ban Treaty of 1974 places a limit of 150 kilotons on the size of weapons' tests and provides detailed standards for the tests to ensure each side can accurately measure the other's explosions. The Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty of 1976, drawn up primarily to seal off possible loopholes in the TTB treaty, puts identical limits on nuclear blasts for peaceful purposes such as excavation or seismic exploration. Both treaties, which languished for years because of misgivings over U.S. ability to verify Soviet compliance, lag far behind current arms-control reality, which contemplates massive reductions in each side's nuclear arsenals. New verification protocols agreed to June 1 by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev during their Washington summit have largely cleared away the misgivings. In fact, the protocols have in some ways become more important than the treaties because they set up a new process of intrusive on-site inspections by both sides - procedures that may become a model for a sweeping strategic arms agreement.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Sonny Bono says he's thinking of taking his political act on the road - to Washington. ``If I made a move, I would decide for the Senate,'' said the former restaurateur, singer, television star and husband of Oscar-winning actress Cher. ``At this point,'' he said Thursday, ``I have to really question whether for another four years I want to just continue being mayor of Palm Springs.'' Bono said he had talked with Sen. Pete Wilson, ``about going beyond this point in politics.'' If Wilson, a Republican, wins his bid for governor, he would be in a position to choose his own Senate replacement. Bono, also a Republican, returned Wednesday from a promotional trip for his new line of chocolate chip cookies. --- ST. PAUL, Minn. (AP) - George ``Spanky'' McFarland, the former child star of ``Our Gang'' and ``Little Rascals,'' says he deserves about $100,000 from a bar that had used a logo depicting a chubby boy in a beanie. Federal Judge James Rosenbaum on Thursday ordered the saloon, now called Checker's Nightclub and formerly Spanky's Saloon, not to use the ``visage or name'' of Spanky. It's not enough for McFarland. Drawings of a round-faced kid wearing the beanie came down from the front of the building and from interior walls. Patrons no longer can buy jackets, T-shirts and hats imprinted with the Spanky's Saloon logo. Other businesses pay McFarland, 62, who lives in Fort Worth, Texas, for the right to use his name and childhood face. McFarland wants similar retroactive payments from the owner and former co-owner of the St. Paul bar. ``He's after 5 percent of their gross profits for 13 years and that's an exorbitant amount of money, even if they did something wrong,'' said Dennis Johnson, a lawyer for the bar's former owner, Michael Kalis. Kalis sold his interest in the bar to his partner, Walter Engelhardt, in 1982. Johnson and Engelhardt, who represented himself in court, contend the bar's name had little to do with its business and that the connection with McFarland was unintentional. ``If every kid with a beanie on his head is him, this country is in trouble,'' Engelhardt said last year. ``If there were actual pictures of him here, I could understand, but not when it's just some fat-faced kid.'' Rosenbaum urged attorneys to work out an agreement regarding the merchandise and took McFarland's other claims under advisement. --- SEATTLE (AP) - A leukemia victim whose search for a perfect bone marrow match inspired 50,000 people to offer theirs was recovering Friday after leaving the hospital. Allison Atlas, 20, was discharged from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center's bone marrow transplant floor Thursday, about a month after receiving marrow from her mother. She went to an apartment near the center that her family has rented since they came to the area for her treatment this summer. ``She's at day 36 (after the transplant) today and she will not be going home until she's at day 100'' or so, said the center's spokeswoman, Susan Edmonds. It will be six months to a year before it is known if her immune system has returned to normal. ``The bone marrow graft is well established and functioning appropriately,'' said Dr. David Peace, one of Miss Atlas' physicians. ``At this time, there is no evidence of recurrent disease.'' The transplant was conducted after her diseased marrow was destroyed by chemotherapy and radiation. A nationwide search for a perfectly matched marrow donor brought 50,000 would-be contributors, but none were suitable for her. Miss Atlas, from Bethesda, Md., was a student at New York University before she became ill. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Singer-songwriter Paul Anka and his wife are suing their former attorney for allegedly giving bad tax and financial advice, court documents show. The lawsuit filed Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court alleges that Albert A. Rettig cost Paul and Anne Anka hundreds of thousands of dollars in back taxes and fines and ``threatens to cause the Ankas more than $600,000 in additional damages.'' Anka's writing and recording career has spanned four decades and includes hits such as ``Lonely Boy,'' ``Puppy Love,'' ``She's a Lady,'' and ``My Way,'' made famous by Frank Sinatra. Rettig, the Anka attorney and accountant for 30 years, was fired in June. Rettig's law and accounting associates also are named in the suit. A woman who answered the phone at Rettig's Beverly Hills home said he was out of the country and could not be reached for comment. The Ankas, residents of Nevada, say that Rettig did not tell them that they would have to pay income tax if they spend more than nine months in California. In 1988, the California Franchise Tax Board, billed Anne Anka for $400,000 in state income tax because she had spent more than nine months in Carmel. Paul Anka is a Canadian citizen. The Ankas appealed following Rettig's advice and had to pay an additional $100,000, the couple claimed in the lawsuit. Court documents say the Ankas claim Rettig ignored letters from the state tax board asking that he file the taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Tribe Member Can't Challenge Relocation Procedures
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled against a Navajo Indian woman who sued to block a plan to move Navajos off Hopi reservation land in Arizona. The court said only tribal chairmen have authority to bring such lawsuits. Upholding a lower-court decision, the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Thursday ruled 3-0 that Congress, in dividing the tribal land in northeastern Arizona, authorized only chairmen to sue over relocation procedures. A similar lawsuit by a Navajo tribal chairman is pending in U.S. District Court. A 1974 federal law, aimed at ending a longstanding dispute over reservation lands, required relocation of Navajos from 900,000 acres designated as Hopi land. The Hopi reservation is an island inside the much larger Navajo reservation. The lawsuit by June R. Benally said the federal Navajo-Hopi Relocation Commission had adopted inadequate or improper procedures for relocating Navajos and awarding benefits. She sought a court order blocking further relocation and related spending until the procedures were changed. Many Navajos have criticized the commission's 1981 plan, saying it failed to give details for such services as medical care, sewage, electricity, employment and job training.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Upset Over Pared-Down Displays
DOC.TEXT: A city directive ordering teachers to curtail the traditional practice of using classroom walls as a gallery for student drawings, essays and decorations drew fire from parents. ``I think it's terrible,'' said Cindy Lawlor, who learned of the new policy through a note home from a frustrated teacher. The elementary school decorations lent cheer to the classrooms and gave children a boost, she said. ``I have three little ones and I don't have enough room on the refrigerator,'' she said. Mayor Christopher Johnson said the policy is just a matter of fire safety. ``The practice of hanging decorations in certain areas of the school has become excessive,'' he said. Johnson said some decorations were stretched over heating vents and others hung from the ceiling. The new policy says that decorations may cover no more than 20 percent of a wall. Teachers are being urged to find flame-retardant materials for wall displays, instead of the traditional construction paper. ``Unfortunately, the teachers caught wind of what was going on at the end of last year and they've kind of taken this thing and kind of blown it out of proportion,'' Johnson said. Granger Elementary School Principal Phyllis Lewis said teachers and city officials are trying to work out a compromise. ``Number 1 is the kids' safety and that's Number 1 on our minds, too,'' she said. ``Our problem is we've done so much (decorating.) It's like going cold turkey.'' ``Parents are coming in and saying, `Where did it all go?' Last year for the first day of school I had 520 teddy bears on the walls,'' Lewis said. Putting a limit on classroom wall decorations is an issue that surfaces from time to time, said Philip O'Sullivan of the Massachusetts Fire Marshal's office. The Life Safety Code guidelines of the National Fire Protection Association recommends that 80 percent of the walls be left clear. ``We've had calls in the past about excessive use of artwork and formal decorations,'' said O'Sullivan. ``It's something you do have to monitor no question. You just can't let it run rampant.''

DOC.HEAD: Daughter of McDonald's Executive Outwits Kidnapper
DOC.TEXT: The daughter of a McDonald's Corp. executive escaped from a 28-hour kidnapping ordeal and police said they arrested a friend of the family who had demanded $400,000 ransom. Sarah Zien, 26, outwitted her abductor by persuading him to take her to a drug store, where she managed to use a phone out of his presence long enough to call her parents. They in turn called police, Sgt. Bill Holmes said Thursday. J.C. ``Bob'' Aler, 55, of Point Loma, was arrested Wednesday by El Cajon police in the store parking lot while apparently looking for Zien, authorities said. He had partially disguised himself and had a pistol in his car, police said. Aler, who owns Industrial Plastics Inc. in El Cajon, was being held in county jail without bail. Zien's mother, Lois, said the family was shocked at Alar's arrest because he and his wife are social friends of theirs whom they had most recently seen two weeks ago at a dinner. Sarah Zien's ordeal began Tuesday morning as she walked from her car to the downtown San Diego photographic studio where she works. A man approached her with a note that said other members of her family had been kidnapped and would be killed if she didn't go with him, Lois Zien said. The kidnapper took Zien to an unfurnished home, where she spent the night chained to a toilet. Meanwhile, the kidnapper began making a series of phone calls to her parents' San Diego residence and demanded $400,000 ransom, Police Capt. Dick Toneck said. Zien persuaded her abductor to take her to a drug store to fill a prescription and said she needed to call her doctor. She called her parents' house instead and gave them the store's phone number. Her parents contacted police, who immediately called the store's pharmacy and alerted them to watch for Zien. When she arrived and gave clerks the prescription, they locked the doors until authorities told them Alar had been arrested. ``McDonald's Behind the Arches,'' a company history, credits Zien's father, Jim, with pioneering advertising techniques used during the early years of the corporation founded by the late Ray Kroc. Sarah Zien, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Middlebury College in Vermont, regularly takes medication for a liver ailment but doesn't need to take it every day, her mother said. ``We knew that she could hang on during this and be smart and strong, but what an experience,'' Lois Zien said.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Says He Hasn't Made Up His Mind on Abortion Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter told senators Friday he had not made up his mind about what stance he would take as a justice on possible reopening of the court's 1973 abortion-legalizing ruling. After months of refusing to even address the question, which has dominated speculation about his views, Souter said in answer to questions during the second day of his Judiciary Committee confirmation hearings: ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade. ... I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind and I would not go on the court saying I must go one way or I must go the other way.'' Abortion foes have high hopes that President Bush's nominee to replace liberal Justice William J. Brennan will provide the critical vote to overturn the decision. Abortion-rights groups have expressed fears that that might indeed happen. Also on abortion, Souter told the committee he had voted to let such operations be performed at a hospital where he served on the board of trustees. But he said his vote did not necessarily reflect his moral views on abortion. On another topic, Souter told the senators that as a judge he might go against some of the stands he took as New Hampshire's attorney general in freedom-of-religion cases. But defended his prosecution of demonstrators who opposed the building of the Seabrook nuclear reactor in New Hampshire. Meanwhile, President Bush touted his nominee at a news conference and at a White House meeting with an international gathering of judges. Bush said he had watched portions of the hearings on television, and he called his nominee's effort ``magnificent ... masterful.'' Souter was asked by Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., about his vote to allow abortions while on the Concord Hospital's board in the mid-1970s. The nominee noted that legalized abortion was ``the law of the land'' after the 1973 Supreme Court decision in Roe vs. Wade. While indicating that some trustees might have had moral scruples against abortion, he said, ``We did not believe it was appropriate to impose those views on the hospital.'' Souter attempted to distance himself from his involvement, as state attorney general, in two freedom-of-religion controversies of the 1970s. In one, he defended Gov. Meldrim Thomson's order that flags on all state government buildings be flown at half staff on Good Friday to commemorate Jesus Christ's death. In the other, he prosecuted two Jehovah's Witnesses for covering the state motto, ``Live Free or Die,'' on their automobile license plates. Noting that the flag-lowering order was struck down by a federal judge in Boston, Souter said, ``If I were sitting as a judge today, I probably would have ruled the same way'' as did the judge in that case. And he conceded that New Hampshire's interest in the license tag case was ``not particularly compelling.'' An interesting exchange occurred when Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, complained about activist judges and asked Souter about ``rights created by the courts.'' ``The Supreme Court should only act, and can only act, when it has the judicial responsibility under ... the Constitution, but the Supreme Court is left to act alone when the political branches do not act beforehand,'' Souter said. Citing the 1954 high court decision that outlawed racial segregation in America's public schools, he said, ``We had Brown vs. Board of Education ... because we had no decision from any other branch of the government, at any other level of the government, facing the undoubted constitutional problem that had to be solved.'' Souter said Congress' willingness to aggressively protect the Constitution's promise of equal protection of the law for all is welcome ``so the court is not left in the position of seeming to be the only guarantor of some of the very liberties that we must most be concerned with.'' He added: ``Judges are not the only people in our governmental structure who are sworn to uphold the Constitution and to try to make it work. The executive, the president of the United States, takes such an oath. All of you take such an oath ... you are just as much responsible for making good on the Constitution's guarantees as we are in the judiciary.'' Souter, who spent seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court before being named a federal appeals court judge by Bush last April, would become the Supreme Court's 105th justice if confirmed. The Judiciary Committee will vote on Souter's nomination after completing its hearings sometimes next week. The nomination then will go to the full Senate.

DOC.HEAD: No Takers For Springfield's Water
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to bottle and sell water from the city's reservoirs fell flat and now officials can't even give it away. This week, city officials tried to donate surplus water to the troops in Saudi Arabia but were told the military is more interested in transporting tanks. ``Everybody wants to give us water,'' said Gordon Newell, spokesman for Westover Air Force Base in Chicopee. ``One gentleman called and offered to give us 60,000 gallons.'' Looking for sources of cash for the city, Mayor Mary Hurley has been promoting a plan to bottle and sell Springfield's water, which city officials tout as pure and good-tasting. But no private companies have submitted bids for bottling water from the reservoir, prompting city officials to send the matter back to committee. Hurley, meanwhile, offered the water to the Air Force. City officials said all went well until base officials asked how the water was packaged. The answer was that it came out of the tap and base officials balked at the thought of bottling their own. Newell said water weighs 8.3 pounds per gallon and would be too much even for the huge C-5A transport planes that fly out of Westover. The 337th Military Air Lift Squadron at Westover has been activated to help with the airlift of supplies to the Middle East. ``As far as putting huge amounts of water on we would have to take priority cargo off,'' he said. ``There's plenty of water in Saudi Arabia, they have desalinization plants everywhere.'' Still, Newell said base officials appreciated the thought.

DOC.HEAD: Tape Released With Trooper Describing Woman's Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents
DOC.TEXT: Police released a taped confession by a state trooper accused of strangling a woman after a traffic stop in which he called her the name of his estranged wife and asked why she was divorcing him. Florida Highway Patrol trooper Timothy Harris, 32, allegedly stopped Lorraine Hendricks of Jacksonville on an isolated section of Interstate 95 and killed her after the two had sex on a wooded median strip March 4. In a tape made the night of his arrest in April and released Thursday, Harris told investigators Ms. Hendricks consented to sexual intercourse but became frightened when he started calling her Sandy, the name of his estranged wife. He said he went berserk and pushed her face in the sand and straddled her back while pinning her arms to her sides with his legs. ``I was trying to calm down,'' the trooper said on the tape. ``I asked her why she was divorcing me. She said she understood I was hurt, but that she wasn't the girl I thought she was.'' Moments later, detectives said, Harris crushed her throat with his bare hands, although he said he thought he had choked her with her underwear. State Attorney Bruce Colton: ``When she died, Tim, was it fast?'' Harris: ``No.'' Colton: ``Did that make it harder?'' Harris: ``I wanted to stop it.'' Colton: ``As you were doing it, you wanted to stop it?'' Harris: ``I just couldn't stop, you know.'' Defense attorneys are trying to suppress the tape, arguing Harris was coerced, and Circuit Judge L.B. Vocelle has continued the matter until Tuesday. In the same tape, Harris asked to be sent ``somewhere where I can get help'' and asked for assurances he would not get the death penalty. But Colton told Harris that he could make no promises, and Assistant State Attorney Dave Morgan said Thursday that he will ask for the death penalty when Harris stands trial next month in Bartow. Attorneys for Harris are awaiting a psychiatric report on their client before deciding whether to use an insanity defense. Hendricks was on her way to Fort Lauderdale to see her 6-year-old daughter when Harris stopped her for driving while wearing headphones, according to his taped statements. On the tape, Harris said he was going to give her a warning ticket, but they began talking about divorce and families. After the slaying, Harris said he took off the rest of her clothes and covered her body with pine needles. He said he threw her clothing and purse in a trash can at a rest stop.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Donates Video Equipment to Soldiers in Gulf
With AM-Gulf-Letters Home, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops in the Middle East will soon be able to give their families back home a vivid picture of life at the front. More than $2 million of video equipment is being donated and shipped overseas so military men and women will be able to tape and send personal messages. ``We have been truly overwhelmed by corporate response to the great need of military personnel in the Persian Gulf,'' said Chapman Cox, president of World USO, a non-profit organization serving more than 5 million American military families worldwide. The ``Better Than a Letter'' program was initiated by Montgomery Ward & Co., with help from its vendors and the World USO. The donation includes about 450 video cameras, 350 televisions, 370 video cassette recorders, 250,000 video tapes and video mailing materials. The equipment will be shipped to the Middle East within the next several weeks and military personnel will have free access to it. The program also provides postage to mail the video tapes home. Families without a VCR can arrange a private viewing of the tape at a local Montgomery Ward store. Vendors providing equipment include: Zenith, RCA, Sharp, JVC and Magnavox. Video tapes will be donated by Maxell, Scotch, 3M, BASF and TDK.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Shock Sends Wholesale Inflation Soaring; Retail Sales Sink
DOC.TEXT: Shock waves from the Persian Gulf crisis rippled through the economy in August as record increases in oil prices sent wholesale inflation surging and pushed retail sales into a nose dive. The Labor Department said wholesale prices were up 1.3 percent last month, the steepest rise in seven months. Private economists were pessimistic about future reports. ``The worst is yet to come,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. The government blamed virtually all the increase on higher oil costs that followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A 16.9 percent increase in the price of gasoline and the 62.5 percent rise in crude petroleum were the highest one-month increases recorded since the government began tracking those commodities in 1947. Also setting a one-month record was fuel oil, which soared 38.8 percent. Kerosene, diesel fuel and residual fuels also hit new highs. The fallout from the Middle East upheaval has heightened economists' fears that higher inflationary pressures could push an already weak U.S. economy into a recession. In more weak economic news, the government said industrial production dropped 0.2 percent in August. That poor showing in factory activity - the manufacturing sector's worst monthly performance since April - was also linked to higher energy prices, analysts said. Friday's data was the first hard evidence that the oil crisis has indeed had a staggering effect. While private analysts only expected inflationary pressures to worsen in coming months, the White House tried to sound a note of calm. President Bush called the big jump in wholesale inflation ``a matter of concern given the state of the economy.'' But he insisted that energy prices had been pushed higher because of unfounded market fears about possible shortages of supplies. ``The speculative atmosphere belies the reality, which is that there are sufficient petroleum products,'' Bush said. ``The market should not be going for higher prices.'' Private economists were far more discouraging. ``The economic consequences of the Iraqi event is going to be worse than we expected in terms of costs to the U.S. economy in lost growth and higher inflation,'' said the Boston Co.'s Sinai. ``The initial round is so large, it implies that the ripple-through effect in coming months will be quite sizable,'' he said. Robert Dederick of the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago said Friday's data on high wholesale inflation, coupled with weak growth, indicates the Iraqi conflict threatens to push a vulnerable U.S. economy into recession. ``It may well be the shock that broke the camel's back because the back was already bending,'' Dederick said. August's inflation outbreak is likely to become more entrenched, analysts said, filtering through to the thousands of plastic, chemical and other products made with petroleum. Oil also figures into products that must be transported long distances and shows up in utility costs as well. ``It's a component that's embedded in everything. It's not something you can hide from,'' said Peter Radford of National Westminster Bancorp. of New York. ``It's like ripples in a pool. You've just seen the wave in the middle and it's going to go all the way out through the rest of the economy.'' While wholesale inflation sped upward, a separate Commerce Department report showed that retail sales slumped 0.6 percent, with declines in nearly every category. That drop is worrisome, analysts said, because consumer spending - or the lack of it - represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The August rise in wholesale prices was the largest since a cold snap caused a 1.9 percent spurt in January. If the price of finished goods rose as much as they did in August each month, it would translate into an annual increase of 16.4 percent. So far this year, wholesale inflation has risen at an annual rate of 4.6 percent, the government said. On Tuesday, the government will provide its first look at inflation at the consumer level since the turmoil began in the Middle East. That report is expected to be equally bad, given the fact that pump prices of gasoline went up almost immediately. While energy costs overall rose 9.5 percent in August, food costs were up as well, rising 0.8 percent. Prices for goods excluding volatile food and energy items - often taken by economists as a better barometer of underlying inflationary pressures - rose 0.3 percent. In July, that so-called core rate had declined 0.1 percent for the first drop in a year.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Sends Tanks, ``Desert Rat'' Successors, To Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for AM-Gulf-Britain on News Digest.
DOC.TEXT: Britain is sending the 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the Desert Rats of World War II, to Saudi Arabia with 120 tanks and some 6,000 combat troops to bolster the multinational force, the government said Friday. And Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said a squadron of 12 CF-18 jets would be sent to fly cover for three Canadian warships en route to the gulf. The announcements came as NATO officials severely criticized Iraq after its troops raided Canadian, French and Belgian diplomatic compounds in Kuwait early Friday. The United States has been requesting additional allied support for its buildup in the gulf. British Defense Secretary Tom King said the dispatch of the armored brigade would ensure that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein understood that if U.N. sanctions fail, ``other options remain available and that, one way or another, he will lose.'' ``We wish to see this settled by peaceful means,'' King said. ``But we make it absolutely clear that should it not result in the successful removal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, then we rule out no other option, including the military option.'' King said Britain also will send another squadron of 12 Tornado ground attack aircraft to join three Royal Air Force fighter squadrons, and additional air defense aircraft. The British decision marked the first dispatch of tanks and significant ground troops by a Western country besides the United States since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. In a related development, the West German government - prevented by its constitution from deploying forces outside the NATO area - said it had given the United States a list of more than 50 merchant ships that could be used to transport American troops to the Gulf. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III this week urged NATO allies to send ground troops, even in token numbers, to symbolize shared involvement with the military buildup. British officials said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher decided with her Cabinet Friday to make a more concrete show of support. ``The deployment of any troops is obviously political in terms of value,'' said Ian Kemp, a military analyst at Jane's, the defense specialist publishers. ``But an armored brigade is militarily the most useful thing that the United Kingdom can send.'' The 7th Armored Brigade, based in West Germany, is the successor of the 7th Armored Division, which fought the Italians and then Hitler's Afrika Corp. The Desert Rats derived their nickname from the Libyan jerboa, which became their emblem. Their tanks clashed in the desert with the legendary Afrika Corp commanded by Gen. Erwin Rommel in some of the most famous battles of World War II. Under the command of Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery, the brigade fought a series of crucial battles at El Alamein and Sidi Rezegh, which led to the British recapture of the port of Tobruk in November 1942. Officials indicated the brigade will take at least a month to get to Saudi Arabia in a $47 million transport operation. It will cost about $2 million a day to keep there, doubling the pricetag of Britain's military commitment in the gulf. Opinion polls show most Britons back Mrs. Thatcher's bullish reponse to the Iraqi invasion. The British tanks will join a U.S. force of about 1,000 tanks being assembled in Opertion Desert Shield. The brigade includes two armored regiments with 120 heavily armored Challenger tanks, an armored infantry battalion with Warrior armored fighting vehicles, a squadron of Scimitar combat vehicles, an artillery regiment and an air defense battery with Javelin missiles.

DOC.HEAD: US, Australians Halt, Then Release, Iraqi Tanker
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Australian naval frigates fired warning shots Friday to halt an Iraqi tanker and inspect it for cargo prohibited under the U.N. embargo against Iraq, the Pentagon said. A joint boarding party from the two ships - the USS Brewton and the HMAS Darwin - boarded the Al-Fao and ``determined the ship contained no prohibited cargo,'' officials said. The vessel, halted in the Gulf of Oman, was allowed to proceed after five hours to the Iraqi port of Basra. President Bush, queried about the incident at an impromptu session with reporters at the White House, said the incident hadn't brought the United States nearer to war with Iraq. ``I wouldn't put it closer to a war situation. I still hope that this matter can be peacefully resolved. And the way for that to happen is for Iraq to comply with the sanctions,'' Bush said. It was the third shooting incident in the effort to put a stranglehold on Iraqi shipping and the second time an Iraqi ship had been boarded in the barricade. Earlier, the Iraqi vessel Zanoobia was boarded and diverted after it was determined to be carrying tea, a prohibited cargo. On Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded Kuwait, the U.N. Security Council authorized the dozens of warships gathered in the region to use military force to uphold its sanctions. Bush emphasized that the action was taken ``in according with the United Nations resolutions, in accordance with the sanctions.'' The president said the warning shots were fired because ``it required a bit of a warning before the captain pulled over and permitted the boarding party to have a look.'' In a statement, the Pentagon said the 41,400-ton tanker was reported to have no cargo aboard. ``After several requests to permit boarding, the Brewton fired the first warning shots from one of its .50-caliber machine guns,'' the Pentagon said. ``The Darwin fired a second set of warning shots, also from a .50-caliber machine gun, about 10 minutes later.'' The tanker's master then announced he would stop the ship and permit the boarding, the Pentagon said. ``A joint boarding party ... boarded the tanker, conducted a coordinated investigation and determined that the ship contained no prohibited cargo,'' the Pentagon statement said. The first shots in the interdiction effort were fired Aug. 18, when U.S. Navy ships attempted to halt two Iraqi tankers. Neither ship was boarded. The U.S. forces - now joined by the naval forces of several other nations - are in the Persian Gulf region to enforce the U.N.-imposed economic sanctions in the hope of forcing Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Tanks Shatter Calm of Arabian Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf to CLARIFY speaker; SUBS 14th graf to ADD name of soldier to quote.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA3,LaserColor DHA104
DOC.TEXT: The sounds of war rumbled across the Saudi Arabian desert Friday. The target: a piece of white cheesecloth 500 yards across the sand. It was the third day the Saudi government allowed U.S. forces to use live ammunition to test tanks and heavy machine guns, and the first time reporters were allowed to watch. ``On the way!'' bellowed the commanders from the 1st Tank Battalion before a shell was launched toward the targets. The ear-splitting blast from the 105mm gun shook the sand underfoot. Between blasts, the 50-caliber machine guns from another battalion thundered in the background. The practice range in the northern Saudi Arabian desert was about 10 miles inland from the coastal road the Marine units are assigned to protect. Defense Department media rules prohibit reporting exact locations or mention of specific numbers of troops and weapons. Lt. Col. Mike Kephart, commander of the tank battalion, said the live-fire tests helped build confidence and boost morale. ``Any time they fire a gun, feel the recoil of the tank, smell the gunpowder, they are motivated,'' said Kephart of Bremerton, Wash. The tests were used to calibrate the gunsights of the tanks and machine guns, which have been in storage for up to two years aboard the Marines' Mobile Prepositioning ships stationed in the western Pacific. The men, stationed at Camp Pendleton, Calif., have been in Saudi Arabia for about 10 days preparing the equipment. ``It's like hunting deer,'' said Staff Sgt. Scott Rice, 30, of Fallbrook, Calif. Kephart said there had been no problems with the equipment and that few tanks required adjustments. Marines said their older M-60 tanks lack thermal gunsights and sophisticated laser-range finders that give great accuracy through darkness, dust or smoke. But some night-vision gear compensated for the shortcomings. The Marines are formulating battle plans assuming they could face Iraq's most sophisticated, Soviet-designed T-72 tanks. ``They can easly destroy us as we can destroy them at 2,400 meters. The best tactic is to flank him and get him from the side,'' said Sgt. David Harpst of Toledo, Ohio. Reflections from the intense desert sun makes targeting difficult. And the heat makes the guns droop slightly, which can cause up to six-feet inaccuracy in shots at the maximum range of 2,000 yards. Before the first shot was fired, helicopters swept out into the range for up to 12 miles, looking for camps of nomadic Bedouins and camel herds. A local village leader rides along to explain what is happening. A few Bedouins camped near the test range the first day did not return. ``They know once we start firing to get out of there,'' Kephart said. Camels are harder to chase off. ``We're told that if we shoot one we have to eat it, so we're being very careful,'' Kephart said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Complaint Ends Morale-Boosting Show
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A variety show with women dancers that expatriates were staging as a morale booster for U.S. troops was canceled Friday after the Saudi government complained, military officials said. The Saudis said their objection was based on television coverage of the show, which Lt. Col. John Olsen, a U.S. military spokesman, said ``caused some discomfort on the part of the Saudi government and we regret that.'' The Saudis apparently found a burlesque-like dance routine in the first act of the show especially offensive. They complained to U.S. military officials after monitoring the show on CBS, which aired a brief segment showing four women dancers. ``They objected in general, but it was pretty clear that it was the women that set them off,'' said a military source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Olsen said the military decided it would not send audiences to the shows because of the Saudi objections. The episode is the latest in a series of incidents that have caused increasing cultural strains between the Americans and their Saudi hosts. Earlier in the week, the Saudi government complained to U.S. commanders about American soldiers venturing into Saudi towns carrying their weapons. Saudi officials have also been relaying complaints about women in the military driving on Saudi roads. Women are not allowed to drive here. The 90-minute show was being staged by a group of Americans, Britons and other Westerners who wanted to show their appreciation to the thousands of Americans deployed in Operation Desert Shield. At opening night Wednesday, 400 members of the 82nd Airborne were repeatedly brought to their feet by the performers and many said afterward that the show was a break from the heat, boredom and isolation of the desert. A second show was staged Wednesday night and two more on Thursday. But two planned for Friday night were effectively canceled when military officials, responding to the Saudi complaint, said they would not allow troops to attend. The troupe had planned to put on six shows next week and hoped to continue the show for several weeks to allow troops to be rotated in for entertainment while awaiting the arrival of entertainers being brought in by the USO. ``We were just trying to give the guys a break,'' one of the organizers of the show said, insisting on anonymity because of fears she would be pealized for participating. ``We were worried what might happen if the Saudis found out.'' From the outset, Saudi and American officials have predicted some cultural clashes as the 100,000-plus American troops settled in and began to interract with Saudis. After weeks of relatively few incidents the last week has become tense, with several U.S. commanders complaining privately the Saudis appear unwilling to bend their traditions. Saudi offials in turn have complained the Americans were unnecessarily engaging in activities that offended local customs. During a Thursday visit by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a Saudi official walked up to a senior American officer here and argued furiously that servicewomen be sent home or at least prohibited from driving. The officer, Gen.
