Gus Pagonis, who is in charge of the logistics and supply efforts for the U.S. deployment, could hardly get a word in as the Saudi official, who refused to identify himself afterward, insisted that driving by women be halted. ``I'm trying to hold back but I must perform my mission,'' Pagonis told the official. ``They must perform the mission.'' Saudi women appear in public draped in clothing that covers their faces, arms and legs. Western women also are advised cover their calves and arms when in public here.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Says Congress Should Control Contributions from Allies
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said Friday that the billions of dollars the United States expects to receive from its allies for the operation against Iraq must come under congressional regulations. ``We've got to make sure that we don't lose the power of the purse,'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., told reporters at a seminar on U.S. defense policy after the Cold War. He was quick to add that the administration isn't trying to usurp the Congress. However, ``there's some very sticky questions,'' he said. Expressing what has been an increasing concern on Capitol Hill, Nunn said any of the money from Saudi Arabia or allies contributed to help defray the cost of the U.S. military buildup should not be placed in accounts that only the Bush administration could control. Saudi Arabia could contribute $1 billion and the administration could spend it ``any way they want to. They could even take it and put it on the B-2 bomber,'' he said. Congress, Nunn said, should approve a statute to ensure that whatever money the United States receives must be ``subject to appropriations and the Congress has to approve that.'' ``We do not want to get a situation where we have bank accounts floating around and the executive branch basically able to spend that money,'' Nunn said. Another panelist at the seminar, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, agreed. Aspin is working on an amendment to the House version of the fiscal 1991 defense bill that would prevent the administration from using the money as it pleases. The Senate has approved its version of the defense bill, a $289 billion package for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The House began work on a $283 billion military spending plan this week, but has postponed further action because of White House and congressional negotiations on trimming $50 billion from the federal deficit. He recalled a statement made by one of the nation's founding fathers, George Mason, who said neither the executive nor the legislative branches of government should be able to combine ``the power of the sword and the power of the purse.'' The seminar was sponsored by the Progressive Policy Institute.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lottomania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of top state lottery winnings: --- - Fourteen winning tickets were sold for a $115 million Pennsylvania lottery drawn April 26, 1989. The winners included a group of 14 workers from an Ohio brick factory, several families, co-workers, and individuals. - Four winning tickets shared $69.9 million Illinois jackpot drawn April 15, 1989. Winners were sisters Linda and Barbara Lambert, Ron Miller, Maryann Dixon, and Pat and Mel Baeske. - Four winners shared the $68.6 million jackpot in the California lottery drawn Feb. 21, 1990. - Two winning tickets shared a $63.9 million Pennsylvania lottery jackpot drawn July 19, 1989. The winners were: Louis A. and Helen A. Miele, Lake Ariel, Pa.; Michael C. and Carol A. Pucillo, West Orange, N.J.; Lawrence P. Kelly, Seymour, Conn. on the first ticket and Melvyn and Rosalie Osborne; Ronald and Kelly Uhland Jr.; Tracey Osborne; and Elizabeth Johnson; all of Bridgeton, N.J. on the second ticket. - Three winning tickets shared a $61.98 million California jackpot on Oct. 29, 1988. The individual winner was Ronald Smith of Westminster. A group of 15 hospital workers in Fallbrook and a group of 25 automotive-shop workers in Sacramento held the other tickets. - Five winners shared $58.32 million drawn in the Florida lottery April 7, 1990. - Sheelah Ryan, Winter Springs, Fla., $55.16 million Florida lottery, Sept. 3, 1988. - Nine winning tickets shared a $56.34 million California jackpot Sept. 13, 1989. - Two winners shared the $52 million Illinois Lottery jackpot Feb. 24, 1990. - Two winners split $51.4 million California lottery jackpot on June 4, 1988: Shelby Carroll of Vacaville and Randy Pennington of Sacramento.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Back Bush on Gulf, Attack His Domestic Policies
DOC.TEXT: Democrats formally backed President Bush's Persian Gulf policy Friday but coupled their endorsement with a scathing attack on his domestic policies. A resolution adopted by the executive committee of the Democratic National Committee denounced ``a decade of Republican greed and debt'' and blamed the savings and loan scandal on ``hear-nothing Republican regulatory policy.'' The resolution was the principal action at the opening session of the party's two-day meeting. Another highlight was the appearance of Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia, making his first speech to a national committee meeting. Five years ago, Nunn was a founder of the Democratic Leadership Council, which was created as a conservative counterweight to the national party. Nunn's denied his appearance before the executive committee was a signal he is interested in running for president in 1992. ``I have no inclinations or plans to run for president,'' Nunn told reporters who crowded around him as he left the party meeting. The senator has stirred presidential speculation with such actions as his resignation from the all-male Burning Tree golf club and his recent declaration of support for abortion rights after decades of being in the opposition camp. Nunn said his interest in party politics began with formation of the DLC, which he described as an effort to ``get the Democratic Party back in the mainstream.'' Asked if he thought the people he'd just spoken to were now in the mainstream, Nunn replied, ``Well, I don't know everybody here.'' Nunn said he didn't think the tendency of Americans to rally around the president in a time of crisis would hurt Democratic candidates in the fall. ``I don't think it's a partisan issue,'' he said. ``I don't think the public's going to be voting in November based on the Middle East.'' Like the Democrats he addressed, Nunn was quick to praise Bush's handling of the crisis. ``I think he's done a very good job,'' said the senator. The resolution adopted by the Democrats opened with the statement that ``Today, our nation stands united in support of America's mission in the Middle East, united in opposition to Iraq's aggression. We, the Democratic Party of the United States, do here formally express our support for our armed forces and the Persian Gulf policy of our commander-in-chief.'' The praise stopped at the shore of the Persian Gulf. The next paragraph called on the nation to ``abandon Republican economic policies.'' The party voiced agreement with Bush's call for spending reductions but added that ``we insist that those reductions must not discriminate against those who benefited least from a decade of Republican greed and debt.'' It said, ``The S&L crisis is the certain result of do-nothing Republican public philosophy, hear-nothing Republican regulatory policy, and see-nothing Republican administration of justice.'' The full Democratic National Committee was scheduled to adopt the resolution at its meeting on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Economic Plan Admits Danger of Bankruptcy, Rejects Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented to the national parliament an economic reform plan Friday that proposes market-oriented policies and other measures to halt the nation's slide toward bankruptcy. But Gorbachev rejected the Russian parliament's conclusion that the solution to the economic crisis requires stripping the central government of much of its power. The Gorbachev plan refused to surrender the Kremlin's power to tax or give republics' laws superiority over national ones. Gorbachev's disagreement with the Russian parliament reduces hope of a national consensus by the Oct. 1 deadline set by the president. Industrial output has dropped to the point of ``economic depression, which worsens with every month,'' according to a copy of his plan obtained by The Associated Press. ``The international economic position of the country is catastrophic. The government's solvency is not guaranteed and foreign debt is growing rashly,'' it says. Without prompt action, ``we would be forced to choose between hyperinflation and direct seizure of cash from the population and enterprises,'' the plan says. Already, some regions of the Soviet Union are refusing to trade with each other or resorting to barter. The Soviet Union stopped paying its international bills on time months ago and has sold vast amounts of diamonds and gold in recent months to raise cash. Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov said Tuesday that imports of medicine and consumer goods could be cut by two-thirds because of lack of foreign currency. He said the nation's loan debt service has risen to $12.5 billion a year and that Western banks were refusing to lend the Soviet Union more money. Gorbachev's report is a combination of a conservative Ryzhkov plan with the more-radical 500-Day plan approved by the Russian parliament Tuesday. It accepts large parts of the Russian proposal, written by economist Stanislav Shatalin, including selling government property to the public, followed by a gradual freeing of state-set prices. But Gorbachev's proposal rejects the Russian call for the nation to become a union of sovereign states similar to the European Community. Thirteen of the 15 Soviet republics are pursuing independence or sovereignty, defined as the superiority of the republic's laws over national ones. Economist Abel Aganbegyan told a parliamentary committee session Friday that the ``sovereignty question'' should be settled under the new union treaty, which is presently under negotiation. But Russian Deputy Prime Minister Grigory Yavlinsky argued it is already too late to prevent the republics from deciding key questions such as land and housing. Aganbegyan also said it would be ``sheer madness'' to bypass the 500-Day program because it had won the approval of representatives of all the 15 republics of the Soviet Union. The Russian republic is the largest. Gorbachev's plan agrees with the Russian program in calling for distribution of housing and land, and for cutting the $105 billion budget deficit by $10 billion. Gorbachev's plan also would cut government investment, sharply reduce foreign aid and seek to sell off other nations' debts to the Soviet Union. But it waters down some critical points in the 500-Day plan, which calls for a 10 percent to 20 percent cut in the defense and KGB budgets. Gorbachev proposes ``significant reductions'' in both bugets but a recommended figure is blacked out on the copy distributed to legislators. Other items that the Russian plan foresees in its first 100 days of implementation, but which are dropped in the Gorbachev plan, include: - Ending all industrial subsidies on Jan. 1. - Selling off 50 to 60 state-owned firms to individual stock-holders. - Selling off state-owned vehicles, unfinished construction projects and construction materials. Gorbachev's plan agrees to dividing collective farms into individual plots, and permits local councils to distribute land. Gorbachev's package also would cut the artificially high exchange rate on trade from the current .60 rubles for $1 to 2 rubles for $1 on Nov. 1. The black market rate is 20 to 25 rubles for $1. Holders of foreign currency would be allowed to sell it at auction to the highest bidder starting in October.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Predicts He Will Win Presidency ... If He Runs
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa says he will win if he decides to run for president of Poland. Walesa said he will make up his mind shortly on whether to be a candidate in elections expected to be held by spring. ``My victory is rather certain,'' he said during his weekly news conference Thursday in Solidarity's home city of Gdansk. ``I am not worried about victory, but about its scale,'' Walesa said. ``The situation is hard, and if the president is elected with only 50 percent of the vote, he will have to work 48 hours a day. ... Thus he must win 80 percent.'' If his former ally and adviser, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, decides to run against him, Mazowiecki would win 35 percent of the vote, Walesa predicted. Mazowiecki has not announced whether he will be a candidate. Walesa has split with his handpicked choice for prime minister over the pace of economic and political reforms. Walesa charges that Mazowiecki's government is proceeding too slowly to remove communist holdovers from state industries and agencies, and has lost touch with society. ``The worse thing is society's non-participation and today, 60 percent of society doesn't participate in anything,'' Walesa said. He has called for early fully democratic presidential and parliamentary elections, citing the current arrangement as dated. Parliament was elected in June 1989 with the then-Communist authorities guaranteed seats for the party and its allies. Since then, a Solidarity-led government has taken power and the Communist Party has dissolved. President Wojciech Jaruzleski, the former Communist Party leader elected to a six-year term in 1989, has said he is prepared to resign at the appropriate time. Parliament is to discuss the election schedule next week. Mazowiecki has agreed with the need for speedy elections. He said Thursday that ``one should put an end to a state in which there are no elections but a permanent electoral campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk, Mandela See `Hidden Hand' Behind Violence in Black Townships
With AM-South Africa-War, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Friday that he and President F.W. de Klerk had concluded a ``hidden hand'' was orchestrating the black township fighting to undermine peace talks aimed at black-white power sharing. Five blacks were killed in Soweto on Friday and 15 others were thrown from moving trains and injured in Johannesburg, police said. On Thursday night, youths with guns and machetes killed 26 people and injured more than 100 on a train traveling from Johannesburg to Soweto. ``We are dealing with highly professional killers,'' Mandela, the African National Congress leader, said at a Johannesburg news conference after meeting with de Klerk in Pretoria. ``The government is convinced this is no longer a clash between black and black,'' he said. ``There is a hidden hand here the government intends to track down.'' Asked who he thought was responsible, Mandela said, ``We don't know ... but we have our own suspicions.'' He refused to elaborate. Almost 800 blacks have died in the townships ringing Johannesburg since fighting erupted in early August. The main combatants have been Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas and other blacks supporting Mandela's ANC. Anti-apartheid groups have alleged that police, rogue elements of the security forces and white extremists have spurred on the fighting. Witnesses in several townships have claimed that masked white men participated. But no proof has been offered. De Klerk said in a statement that unidentified groups were attempting to sabotage government efforts to end apartheid and draw up a new constitution free of racial discrimination. ``There are forces which do not wish peaceful negotiations to succeed,'' he said. ``All those forces desiring peace must stand together to identify and counter these forces.'' The president promised ``strong and comprehensive'' action, but he did not elaborate. Mandela said he expected de Klerk to announce steps Monday to curb the violence. The ANC would not oppose an increased army presence in the township as long as the troops maintain law and order, Mandela said. But he accused soldiers currently in black areas of behaving ``like an army of occupation'' and using live ammunition unnecessarily. Many black township residents see the army as a more effective and neutral force than the police. The ANC and Inkatha, the two largest black political movements, both oppose apartheid but differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. The ANC waged a 29-year guerrilla campaign against the white-led government before suspending its armed struggle last month. The ANC still supports confrontational measures such as boycotts, sanctions and strikes to pressure the government. Inkatha, led by Mangosuthu Buthelezi and made up almost entirely of Zulus, does not endorse such tactics and participates in the government's black homeland system. Inkatha favors a capitalist economy, while the ANC has an ideological preference for socialism.

DOC.HEAD: Legislator Says Some 1988 S&L Deals Should Be Renegotiated
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Banking Committee on Friday described some government sales of failed savings and loans in late 1988 as ``a giveaway'' and said many of the deals should be renegotiated. The Bush administration's top banking official said the government is considering ways to renegotiate some of the sale contracts but does not intend to break them. In a report released at Friday's hearing, investigators for the committee said outside investors in troubled thrifts received $78 in assets and government-granted benefits for every $1 of capital they put up to buy the institutions. ``These so-called deals bear all the earmarks of a giveaway - with the recipients of the government largesse being some of the fattest of the nation's financial fat cats,'' Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said at the hearing. ``We are hopeful that there can be renegotiations that rectify some of the excesses.'' Gonzalez said his committee will ``haunt'' the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency responsible for disposing of failed S&Ls ``until we have hard evidence that everything is being done to recover as many of the billions as possible.'' L. William Seidman, who heads the RTC and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told the committee that the RTC's efforts ``are to minimize costs to the government within the provisions of the contracts.'' ``We are not considering breaking the government's agreements,'' he said. M. Danny Wall, a former government official who directed the 1988 sales, defended the deals as an effort to transfer into private hands insolvent S&Ls that were draining billions of dollars from the federal insurance fund. ``Our goal was a simple one: Stem the flow of red ink with the tools and dollars at hand,'' said Wall, chairman of the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board. ``It was clear to me and my fellow board members that time was money, inasmuch as a problem institution unresolved loses more money every day, as is abundantly clear today.'' Wall was accompanied by former members of the bank board and former officials of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. Lawrence J. White, a former member of the bank board, said the deals were ``financially sound'' and cost the government $4.7 billion less than the estimated cost of liquidating the failed thrifts. The banking committee report concluded that 94 S&L deals completed in late 1988 will cost the government around $71 billion in assistance to buyers of the thrifts, including up to $4.2 billion in tax breaks. The investigators' study focused particularly on the sales of American Savings Bank FA of California and two giant Texas thrifts, Southwest Savings Association and First Gibraltar Federal Savings Bank. In the American Savings and First Gibraltar deals, the buyers were given generous tax breaks, the study said. A separate report released late Thursday by the General Accounting Office found that the rescue of American Savings will cost taxpayers $5.2 billion, three times the government's original estimate. The institution was purchased by a group led by billionaire investor Robert M. Bass. Southwest Savings was purchased in 1988 by Caroline Hunt, the daughter of legendary oil man H.L. Hunt, with the help of government subsidies projected to total $2 billion over 10 years. Despite the federal aid, the thrift failed a second time and went back to the government.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Praises Poland; Urges Political Tolerance
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan praised Poland's democratic struggle Friday but warned post-Communist leaders that difficult times may come and they must treat each other ``as opponents, not as enemies.'' Reagan, making his first visit to Poland, was interrupted by applause 10 times during a 45-minute speech to Parliament members and political leaders in Warsaw's Royal Castle. ``I have always believed that where freedom is, any friend of freedom will feel at home. And I have been waiting a long time to say to the people of Poland, `Today, on your soil, I feel at home,' '' said Reagan, who imposed strict sanctions on Poland after the Communists imposed martial law in 1981. Many current political leaders in Poland credit the sanctions with helping to pressure the government into democratic concessions. Poland was the second stop on Reagan's 10-day European trip. Earlier, he visited Berlin and chipped at the Berlin Wall. He is scheduled to leave Saturday for the Soviet Union and also plans to visit Italy. ``Even though many Americans have never met a Pole, your struggle for liberty has moved us deeply,'' said Reagan. Reagan also alluded to recent political discord in Poland between Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. ``It is natural that you will fight hard among yourselves on issues of great importance,'' he said. ``To protect the liberty you have won at such a cost, you will need a full measure of the tolerance and openness that are Poland's tradition. For you historic transition means that you must fight as opponents, not as enemies.'' Reagan planned to meet with Mazowiecki and President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the army general and former Communist Party leader who imposed martial law but last year agreed to turn over the government to Solidarity. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, are scheduled to travel to the Baltic port city of Gdansk on Saturday to see Walesa and visit the shipyard where Solidarity was born during strikes in August 1980. Before leaving Berlin Friday morning, Reagan spoke to about 1,000 U.S. military personnel and their families, praising the troops for playing an important role in the movements to democracy in Eastern Europe. As a souvenir, U.S. Ambassador Vernon Walters gave the former president one of the old Berlin sector division signs that announces, in four languages: ``You are leaving the American sector.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Strips Official of Secret Police Dissolution Duties
DOC.TEXT: An East German official in charge of disbanding the secret police was stripped of those duties Friday after lawmakers criticized him for keeping former agents on his payroll. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere relieved Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel of reponsibility for a committee investigating the dreaded security arm of the old Communist regime, a spokeswoman said. The change was the latest development in a chaotic government that will soon be out of business when West Germany assumes control of the economically reeling country on Oct. 3, the formal date of German unification. De Maiziere spokeswoman Angela Merkel said Eberhard Stief, state secretary in the ministry, would take over the role of overseeing the secret police committee. The committee last week gave the government a list of 5,000 people who once worked for the secret police unit known as the Stasi and had been assigned to various government ministries. Officials subsequently fired or suspended nearly 60 people on the list still holding government posts, most of them in Diestel's ministry. Parliament spent the better part of a 14-hour session on Thursday debating the recent allegations that the government was still rife with Stasi agents. However, a vote to demand Diestel's resignation failed after de Maiziere defended the interior minister, who also is the deputy prime minister. De Maiziere relieved Diestel of his duties in an effort to calm the political crisis, Merkel said. Diestel has become a focal point for lawmakers seeking a more aggressive purge of the old security apparatus. Merkel also said de Maiziere would authorize an investigation of his Cabinet ministers after the head of a previous committee investigating the Stasi said four ministers had worked for the secret police. Meanwhile, the man vying to be leader of a united Germany visited about 22 activists occupying the former headquarters of the Stasi. The activists, some of whom helped lead the democratic revolt against Communism last fall, are demanding public access to the files on 6 million people. They also want the files to remain in East German territory after unification. Oskar Lafontaine of the left-leaning Social Democrats is challenging West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in the Dec. 2 elections for a united German government. Lafontaine told dissidents holed up in the Stasi archives he would seek to accommodate their demands. ``I am not here for campaign reasons,'' he said. The Dec. 2 election campaign has shaped much of the debate over German unification and has helped to dismember the once-broad coalition government put together by de Maiziere. Twelve of the 22 ministers have resigned or been fired the last few weeks because of incompetence or political feuds over unification.

DOC.HEAD: Playmates Keep Dark Summer Secret: Missing Friend Fell to Death in Silo
DOC.TEXT: Five months after the disappearance of a 10-year-old boy, four young playmates revealed a dark summer secret: They saw their pal fall to his death while playing atop an abandoned 120-foot-tall grain silo. Police said Friday the fatal plunge of Ricky Rodriguez in April was accidental, but his friends kept quiet in fear they would be blamed. ``They were scared,'' said Detective Eileen Guest, a youth officer. ``They're just little boys and they thought they were going to get into trouble.'' The body was discovered Thursday in an abandoned grain silo at a deserted Falstaff Brewing Corp. plant on the city's Southeast Side. Friends said Ricky fell to his death as the five youths bounced on conveyor belts spanning the silo, police said. Investigators interviewed each of the four playmates separately and concluded the boy's death was accidental, Detective William Marley said. One friend told police he spent a terrifying summer, haunted by the fall and fears police would not believe it was accidental. ``He said he couldn't sleep, that he had been having nightmares,'' Guest said. The playmates were all about 10 years old, police said. Police scoured the boy's neighborhood after his disappearance, using helicopters and scuba divers in Lake Michigan. A picture of Ricky recently was sent to millions of homes as part of a campaign for missing children. ``We searched everywhere we could think of for this boy,'' Sgt. Robert Jones said. ``It's really sad when a 10-year-old is laying out there for all that time.'' Officers searching for the boy considered the deserted brewing plant virtually inaccessible, he said. The mystery unraveled Thursday when a sister of one of Ricky's playmates overheard a conversation in which the boy said Ricky had fallen. She told her mother, who notified police. The boys entered the silo, which had a locked door, and climbed 15 flights of stairs to get to the top, Guest said. ``The area was fenced. But these are little boys - they had no problem getting over the fence,'' she said. ``It's still unclear how they got into the building.'' Guest said the area had been abandoned for more than a decade. She said she knew of no other reports or complaints of children entering the area. On the afternoon of April 26, Ricky stopped at home and asked his father what time he should be home for dinner. It was the last time his family saw the fifth-grader. ``Well, everybody can stop looking,'' said the boy's father, Steve Rodriguez. ``I thought he was dead the night he disappeared. It just didn't fit his pattern. But ... I was hoping.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Intrusion In Foreign Embassies Violates International Law
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq trampled on a basic tenet of international law - the inviolability of foreign diplomats and embassies - when its troops forced their way into French, Canadian and Dutch diplomatic quarters in Kuwait, scholars and former diplomats said Friday. Frequently in history, the retaliation for violating diplomatic immunity has been military action. Sometimes, it has been war. ``This is an extremely serious case,'' said Grant McClanahan, a retired diplomat and author of the 1989 book ``Diplomatic Immunity: Principles, Practices and Problems.'' ``It's a very serious insult to the national dignity of the nations that suffer.'' The principle of diplomatic immunity - under which diplomats have freedom of movement and are free from arrest or taxation - is formally enshrined in the Vienna conventions of 1961 and 1963. Those conventions, to which Iraq is a signatory, specifically say that the residences of diplomats are inviolate and can be entered by local authorities only with permission from the embassy. Iraq transgressed those provisions when its troops entered the residences of the French and other ambassadors in occupied Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had already ignored international law by arbitrarily demanding the closure of diplomatic missions in Kuwait and denying permission for some Western diplomats to leave Iraq. The conventions say a nation cannot close an embassy of another country unless it first breaks relations and may not expel diplomats unless it declares them ``persona non grata.'' Iraq has done neither. Saddam has tried to muddy the legal waters by annexing Kuwait and announcing that foreign diplomats there had lost their diplomatic status. But David J. Scheffer, an international lawyer and senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, says Iraq has no legal justification for those declarations. Diplomatic law may not have precise rules on occupied countries, ``but international law itself prohibits intervening, occupying and annexing other countries,'' Scheffer said. The concept of diplomatic immunity dates back to biblical times, and became common practice from the mid-15th century, when foreign ambassadors first took up residence in the various Italian city-states. The protection of diplomats also has a ``strong basis in Islamic law,'' said Nathan Brown, director of the Middle East Studies Program at George Washington University. Mohammed recognized the importance of good relations with non-Moslem states and the Ottoman Empire respected the rights of diplomats even when relations with Europe were at their worst, he said. Historically, violations have been taken seriously. Hugo Grotius, known as the father of international law, wrote in his 1625 book ``The Law of War and Peace'' that ``Profane History is full of wars undertaken on account of the ill-treatment of ambassadors. Also in the scriptures there is mention of a war which David waged against the Ammonites on that account.'' He enumerates many instances where the Romans, and later the French and Germans, took up arms to redress wrongs done to their diplomatic corps. In more recent times, the United States has frequently used force to protect its diplomats. In 1854 troops destroyed a town in Nicaragua to avenge an insult to an American envoy. U.S. forces were dispatched to China in 1866 to punish an assault on an American consul and again during the 1900 Boxer Rebellion when the foreign legation in Beijing was under siege. American forces were sent to Chile in 1891 to protect Americans who had taken refuge at the embassy during a war there and in 1918 the Marines landed in Vladivostok to protect the American consulate during the Bolshevik-led civil war there. The worst recent violation of diplomatic immunity was in 1979, when Iranian students seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran and held 52 Americans hostage for 444 days. A botched military rescue attempt in April 1980 led to the deaths of eight American servicemen on the Iranian desert. The United States took liberties with diplomatic immunity when U.S. troops forced their way into the residence of the ambassador of Nicaragua during the U.S. invasion of Panama in December. President Bush acknowledged the mistake, calling it a ``screw-up.'' Scheffer said France and other countries whose diplomatic rights have been infringed upon are fully justified in expelling Iraqi diplomats in retaliation. But he said that under modern international law it would be difficult to equate insults to diplomats with acts of war. ``How we respond to a threat to our diplomatic premises in Kuwait is not going to be as easy to resolve as it was 100 years ago,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Named to Disability Council
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced Friday he would nominate actress Mary Ann Mobley-Collins of Beverly Hills, Calif., to be a member of the National Council on Disability. Mrs. Collins, 51, who was Miss America in 1959, would succeed Joni Tada. The position is a one-year term. Both Mrs. Collins andhusband, television personality Gary Collins, have been active in charity and volunteer work. Bush also announced he would nominate Leonard H.O. Spearman as ambassador to the African nation of Lesotho. He would succeed Robert M. Smalley. Since 1988, Spearman, 61, has been ambassador to Rwanda. He is a former president of Texas Southern University in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Australian Navies Fire Warning Shots, Board Iraqi Tanker
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Australian sailors fired warning shots Friday across the bow of an Iraqi tanker sailing toward the Persian Gulf and then boarded the vessel, American officials said. In Washington, a Pentagon source said the sailors fired Friday from an American frigate in the Gulf of Oman and that an Australian frigate helped in the operation. A U.S. Navy spokesman in the gulf said the Australian vessel had also fired a warning. President Bush, speaking about the incident at an impromptu press conference in Washington, said he didn't believe it put the United States ``closer to a war situation.'' ``I still hope that this matter can be peacefully resolved. And the way for that to happen is for Iraq to comply with the sanctions,'' he said. It was the third time during the gulf crisis that U.S. officials announced American ships had fired warning shots in an effort to enforce the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq. There have been no injuries reported in any of the incidents. The Iraqi vessel boarded Friday, the Al-Fao, was first intercepted by the frigate Burton, the Navy spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Its master said he was headed for the Iraqi port of Basra with no cargo but refused to allow the Americans to board. ``After repeated requests to allow boarding, the Burton fired the first warning shots from one of its 50-caliber machine-guns ... and requested that Al-Fao stop and permit a team to board,'' said the Navy spokesman. ``The Australians fired the second set, also from a 50-caliber machine-gun about 10 minutes later,'' he said. Al-Fao then stopped and sailors from both frigates went on board, said the spokesman. ``The team discovered no prohibited cargo aboard and Al-Fao was allowed to proceed,'' he added. He said the whole operation, which began about 4 p.m., took five hours. The Al-Fao was one of two Iraqi tankers that last month tried and failed to break a Saudi Arabian blockade on oil exports through Iraq's trans-Saudi pipeline terminal on the Red Sea. It was earlier reported anchored off Yemen with its sister ship, Al-Qadissiyah, after port authorities there denied them permission to enter. The tanker apparently was sailing home when intercepted. On Aug. 18, the U.S. Navy fired warning shots across the bows of two Iraqi vessels that defied orders to stop. But the vessels were allow to sail out of the Persian Gulf without being boarded. The United States is leading the naval buildup designed to enforce the U.N. sanctions imposed on Aug. 6. They are intended to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, which his forces invaded Aug. 2. Hundreds of ships are being chllenged in the Persian Gulf, the connecting Gulf of Oman, the Red Sea to block Iraq-bound cargo and Iraqi exports. The Navy spokesman said the U.S. Navy alone has intercepted more than 900 vessels so far. He said the number of vessels reported boarded has doubled in recent weeks to more than 40, but with little fanfare. Those actually diverted are fewer than than five. British, French, Italian and other warships have also carried out their own stop-and-search operations.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Physicist Massey to Head of National Science Foundation
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON (AP - President Bush on Friday announced he would nominate physicist Walter E. Massey, vice president for research at the University of Chicago, for a six-year term as director of the National Science Foundation. Massey, 52, would succeed Erich Bloch. Massey is a member of Bush's board of science advisers. Hanna Gray, president of the University of Chicago, said in a statement that ``the president has chosen a distinguished scientist, gifted administrator and eloquent spokesman for science to lead the National Science Foundation.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0707 to change category code to ``a''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used AM-Asbestos Settlement, a0705, of Sept. 12, which moved under a New York dateline, are asked to use the following.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on Sept. 12 that out-of-court settlements had been reached in almost all of 265 asbestos disease claims by workers at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard. Most of the 20 defendants in those cases have settled with plaintiffs, but cases are proceeding against the rest. About 200 claims are being tried together in a New York state court in Manhattan and the remainder are on trial in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn. The defendants include companies that made asbestos or products containing the material used at the shipyard.

DOC.HEAD: Vote on Fuel Economy Bill May be Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `Supporters contend ...' to UPDATE with Skinner comment. Picks up 4th graf pvs `We've just ...' DELETES now-redundant grafs 8-9, beginning `The auto ...' ^By H. JOSEF HEBERT
DOC.TEXT: The Senate cleared the way Friday for action on a bill that would require automakers to dramatically increase fuel economy. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he hoped to have a vote late next week on the bill that would require automakers to increase average fuel economy of new cars to 35 miles per gallon by 1995 and to 40 miles per gallon by 2001. Supporters contend the higher fuel economy requirements would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day once they go fully into effect, but key opponents promised to continue fighting the measure on the Senate floor. Within hours of the vote, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner blasted the legislation as ``unrealistic, irresponsible and, more important, unattainable.'' He said there's no technology to achieve the bill's goals without making cars smaller. ``It should be called the highway fatality bill,'' Skinner said at a news conference, citing a new study by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that concluded a clear link between reducing the size of cars and traffic deaths. The NHTSA study said the introduction of smaller cars over the past decade had resulted in an estimated 1,340 additional traffic deaths annually in single-car accidents. Based on those numbers, NHTSA Administrator Jerry Curry said between 600 and 1,140 additional deaths annually can be expected if automakers try to meet the 40 mile per gallon standard. Skinner said automakers had convinced him that the Senate bill's fuel economy goals can't be achieved without substantial weight reductions in cars. ``We've just had the first inning of this nine-inning game,'' Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., said after the Senate voted 68-28 to clear the way for debate. ``We hope and intend to win this fight,'' Riegle said, adding that he doubts supporters will get the needed 60 votes to cut off debate and bring it to a vote next week. A similar bill has been introduced in the House, but it has yet to be taken up by the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., is staunchly opposed to the measure. Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., sponsor of the House bill, said earlier this week she would try to push the legislation directly on the House floor in an effort to bypass Dingell's committee. But the Senate's 68-28 vote Friday to cut off efforts by Riegle to keep the measure off the Senate floor was an indication of the growing support in Congress for a measure to reduce U.S. reliance on foreign oil, a subject in the spotlight since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``It's the single most important step to reducing our dependency on OPEC oil and curbing global warming,'' the Sierra Club said of the bill sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev. In floor debate, Riegle said those fuel savings aren't likely to begin phasing in until 1995 and a better response to today's oil crisis might be to return to a national speed limit of 55 miles an hour. Later, a Riegle aide said the senator didn't necessarily support a change in the speed limit. Bryan described his bill as a message to Detroit and the automakers ``that they're going to have to look at fuel economy and not just muscle cars.'' ``It does not take a crystal ball to realize that if we don't start conserving now, some future president may have to consider sending our young men and woman back to the deserts of the Middle East,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Donation Offers Flood Military; Few Can Be Accepted
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Generosity is overwhelming the military agency responsible for shipping supplies to U.S. troops in the Middle East, an official said Friday. The military received more than 100 offers of food, magazines and other items since a donation hot line started this week. But few can be accepted now without interrupting the flow of basic and priority items such as chemical suits and medicine, said Pat Miller, spokeswoman for the Defense Logistics Agency. The hot line, which is being answered by three people, has been ringing off the cook, she said. Callers have offered videocassette recorders, Nintendo games, even fresh lobster. Many want to donate water. ``Some even collected water with the misunderstanding or thinking that we needed it,'' Ms. Miller said. But Saudi Arabia has modern desalination plants and local water supplies have been more than sufficient, she said. The calls show ``a tremendous outpouring of patriotism,'' Ms. Miller said. But they have caused some headaches too. Agency officials Friday had to explain to an angry church group why a truckload of cookies and baked goods couldn't be accepted at the military post office in New York, Ms. Miller said. ``Food items are just a really bad idea,'' she said. ``We have a way of packaging and shipping the menus that the services are requesting, according to their own feeding plan.'' Offers for electronic and recreational items are also being turned away, at least temporarily. ``I wouldn't want to stifle that. If we're still there two months down the road, some recreational items might be nice,'' Ms. Miller said. After the Armed Forces Radio Network accepted a donation of 25,000 personal stereos, the logistics agency agreed to take 30,000 pre-recorded cassette tapes offered by a record company. The agency procures items like food, fuel and medicine that are used in common by all branches of the military. In August, agency statistics show it shipped 318,000 chemical suits, 200,000 hot weather boots, 100,000 pairs of sunglasses, nearly 27,000 cans of chigger repellent, 257,000 bottles o sunscreen and 570,000 dispensers of lip balm for Operation Desert Shield. Ms. Miller suggested the best thing citizens could send to troops is a letter. The agency has been accepting donations of stationary so soldiers can write back, she said. On Wednesday, the agency took an offer of 1,000 reams of stationary from Champion International Corp., a paper company based in Stamford, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Condemns New Iraqi Moves in Kuwait, Denies `Saber Rattling'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Australian participation, subbing 8th graf, And the
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday condemned the Iraqi break-in at France's diplomatic residence in Kuwait as ``a matter of grave concern to the United States,'' and said he had pledged to do all he could to support any French response. He also said the U.S. Navy had fired warning shots and then boarded an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman as part of the effort to enforce trading sanctions against Iraq. Asked by reporters if his words and the U.S. actions were meant as a ``saber rattling'' threat to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Bush said no. ``When I rattle a saber, the man will know it,'' he promised. ``When an escalation is required from me, Saddam Hussein will know it.'' Iraqi troops also entered the Kuwait City compounds of Belgium and Canada, capturing several French citizens and briefly detaining the U.S. consul and four other Western consuls who were visiting at Canada's diplomatic residence at the time. The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad lodged a protest. The State Department withheld the name of the consul. As for the naval warning shot and boarding, Bush said of the Iraqi ship, ``It required a bit of a warning before the captain pulled ovr and permitted the boarding party to have a look.'' He added, ``I expect confidently that if it is not carrying any contraband or anything that will violate the sanctions, that it will be permitted to go on its way.'' And the ship, which also was boarded by sailors from an Australian vessel that fired warning shots, was indeed released later in the day. Bush said he had spoken by telephone to French President Francois Mitterrand after the Iraqi soldiers broke into the French compound Friday morning, an action he called ``outrageous.'' ``I just told him he has the full backing of the United States,'' Bush told reporters in a brief question-and answer session outside the White House before leaving for his weekend retreat at Camp David, Md. ``I don't know what France is going to do,'' Bush said after his conversation with Mitterrand. ``I told him that I view this as a matter of grave concern to the United States. I told him I would do anything I could to support what he decides to do.'' But Bush would not be drawn into discussing whether he was contemplating military action. ``We will continue to do everything possible to ensure that the sanctions work as intended and to deter and if need be to defend Saudi Arabia against armed attack,'' he said. He said the new incidents ``not only underscore the brutal behavior of Iraq, but also the international support that exists, and is marshalled, against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.'' Bush was asked if the heightened activity on Friday meant a war with Iraq was closer. ``I wouldn't put it closer to a war situation. I still hope that this matter can be peacefully resolved,'' through Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and release of foreign hostages, he said. ``Any of these incidents, all of them, add up to clear violations of international law. They do raise tensions, they clearly do.'' Bush said he had spoken by telephone to Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu Thursday night and thanked him for his promise of increased financial support to pay for the U.S. military effort in the gulf and to help poor countries suffering due to the U.N.-sponsored trade embargo against Iraq. He said he also talked to Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher who informed him she would dispatch ``a full armored brigade, along with additional helicopters and aircraft'' to join U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. Also Friday, Bush asked Congress for an extra $1.9 billion to pay for the military buildup in the Persian Gulf, and the White House disclosed he had warned Iraq not to back any terrorist attacks against U.S. interests. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said the U.S. charge d'affaires in Baghdad had warned the Iraqi Foreign Ministry on Thursday that ``we have cause for grave concern about any links between Iraq and various terrorist organizations, that we hold them responsible for any terrorist acts that might occur.'' He said the warning was not based on any specific threats it considers credible, but that U.S. intelligence had found ``possible links between Iraq and terrorist kinds of planning activities.'' ``We have been concerned about this and we have made that known to Saddam Hussein,'' Fitzwater said. Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said the administration's primary concern was that Iraq might use its own intelligence apparatus to undertake terrorist operations. ``The second source of concern are the many terrorist groups and radical elements that are either based in Baghdad or that receive support from Saddam Hussein's government,'' he said. Bush sent a request to Congress to increase 1990 spending to cover costs of the Persian Gulf militry action, and to provide legal mechanisms that will allow the United States to accept donations from other countries that have volunteered to help bear the costs. In addition, Bush sought congressional approval to forgive $7 billion in military debt that Egypt owes the United States. Bush said he wanted to forgive the debt in thanks for Egypt's cooperation in the U.S. strategy against Iraq. Meanwhile, an additional 300 American women and children and non-American family members left Kuwait Friday morning en route to London. They were due to arrive in Baltimore on Saturday. An additional flight was scheduled to leave Kuwait Saturday morning with the same destination, scheduled for arrival on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Member of Mercenary Squad Reported Charged With Assassination
DOC.TEXT: A French court has charged a member of a mercenary squad with assassinating the president of the Comoro Islands when his group seized power there last year. The French news agency Agence-France Presse, quoting an unidentified court source, said Jean-Paul Guerrier was ordered jailed by Judge Chantal Pedrix pending further proceedings. Ms. Pedrix has presided since April over an inquiry requested by the family of slain President Ahmed Abdallah. He was shot to death Nov. 26 at the presidential palace in Moroni, capital of the Indian Ocean island nation. Guerrier was a member of a unit of mercenaries who worked for Abdallah under the command of former French army officer Bob Denard. Denard's men briefly seized power on the islands after the assassination, but French troops forced them to leave. Denard, who took refuge in South Africa, denied responsibility for the president's killing. He is wanted in France for alleged offenses during an attempted coup in the African nation of Benin in 1977. The Comoros became independent of France in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Free Mail for Troops, Finally
With AM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Free mailing privileges have been approved for U.S. service members deployed in the Mideast, the Pentagon said Friday. The step is being taken in cooperation with the U.S. Postal Service despite the lack of action on pending congressional legislation permitting such a move, a statement said. The decision clears up a problem that arose earlier this week when the postal service said it was ready to go ahead with the privilege, but the Pentagon said it lacked congressional authorization. The free mail authorization will be funded by the postal service as an interim measure until legislation allows the appropriated funds for postage, the Pentagon said. For troops in the field, the military collects mail and transfers it to the postal service for dispersal. Service men and women will be allowed to send personal letters, postcards and recorded cassettes. They may from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Bahrain and the adjacent waters to any place within the United States, any U.S. territories or possessions or to any military post office, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Rhythm Guitarist For Creedence Clearwater Revival Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with death occurring in Scottsdale; other background
DOC.TEXT: Tom Fogerty, rhythm guitarist for the popular 1960s band Creedence Clearwater Revival, has died, a spokeswoman announced Friday. He was 48. Fogerty, older brother of Creedence lead singer John Fogerty, died here Sept. 6 of respiratory failure due to tuberculosis, said Terri Hinte, a spokeswoman for Fantasy Records. San Francisco Bay area-based Creedence, a rock 'n' roll band with eight top 10 singles and six gold albums, broke up in 1972. Their hits included ``Proud Mary,'' ``Born on the Bayou,'' and ``Bad Moon Rising.'' The Fogerty brothers and friends Doug Clifford and Stu Cook recorded under various names for nearly 10 years before scoring their first hit as Creedence, ``Suzie Q,'' in 1968. Tom Fogerty had released several solo albums in addition to his work with CCR. In the early '70s, he worked occasionally with organist Merl Saunders and Grateful Dead guitarist Jerry Garcia. In addition to John Fogerty, survivors include wife Tricia, six children and three other brothers. Services were held in Scottsdale.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Steal Computer Data on Chernobyl Victims, Erase Information
DOC.TEXT: Teen-age thieves stole computer tapes containing vital information on the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster and erased data before officials could catch them, the Tass news agency said Friday. Health data on 500,000 residents of the region surrounding Chernyobyl and information on radioactive contamination of 20,000 towns and villages was blanked out of the tapes stolen from the Research Institu press not to wipe off the data,'' Tass said. ``Their request was not heeded.'' The news agency did not say when the theft took place, how it was done, or why the unspecified number of youths involved erased the data. As for motive, police official Litsian Sobolevsky was quoted only as saying the teen-agers were after money. Technical experts were trying to salvage data from the disks, Tass said. In a related development, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov told a Moscow news conference there was no danger of another explosion at the Chernobyl plant, where a reactor caught fire and exploded on April 26, 1986. Reports in the West German news media last month quoted Soviet experts who said they feared the floor of the damaged reactor could give way under the weight of concrete slabs and release huge amounts of radioactivity. Gerasimov said a concrete block, reinforced with metal rods, had been erected after the accident to prevent the escape of radiation and to protect the environment. ``As a result of these measures, the integrity of the structure has been insured for 30 years,'' Gerasimov said. ``Nothing terrible can happen there, there can be no second explosion.'' Scientists are still studying how to carry out the final disposal of the damaged reactor, Gerasimov said. The accident at Chernobyl, in the Ukraine, left 31 dead, according to official count. Unofficial reports say 250 died. The blast spewed cesium, strontium and plutonium over a wide area of the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia, and sent a cloud of radioactive gas around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Cruzans Vow to Continue Fight to Let Daughter Die
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a comatose Missouri woman who was the subject of the Supreme Court's first decision on a person's right to die said Friday they hope a new legal effort will allow their daughter to die. ``The bottom line is we haven't stopped fighting yet because we believe in what we're doing,'' said Joe Cruzan, a sheet metal worker from Carterville, Mo. Nancy Cruzan, 33, has been in a coma-like state since she was injured in a 1983 car accident. The Supreme Court in June blocked the Cruzans' request to end their daughter's life. Cruzan and his wife, Joyce, spoke here at a law and medical symposium on the right to die. The couple asked a Missouri state court last month for permission to remove the tube that provides food and water to their brain-damaged daughter. They said three people had come forward recently with information about her wishes concerning life-sustaining medical treatment. No hearing has been held on the latest request. The Supreme Court said the Cruzans lacked ``clear and convincing'' proof that their daughter would want to die. In the 5-4 decision, the justices said states have broad power to keep patients on life-support systems when they have not made their wishes known conclusively. ``I feel like that the new witnesses coupled with the existing testimony, if that's not clear and convincing then I don't know how you're going to achieve that unless Nancy can raise up from her bed and write out something and then lay back,'' Cruzan said. He said another option was to move their daughter to another state. Nancy Cruzan can breathe on her own and at times her eyes are open and move randomly. Her body is rigid, with her hands and feet bent into claw shapes. ``Looking back, if I had to do it over again I'd probably do exactly the same thing I did then,'' her father said. ``If I knew then what I know now, I would have probably tried to take her home and do it quietly because I know that it's done.''

DOC.HEAD: Feminists Fear Souter Would Hurt Women's Rights
With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Feminist leaders said Friday the clock would be turned back 25 years on women's rights if David Souter is confirmed as a Supreme Court justice. ``If we lose this one, we'll never get it back,'' said Eleanor Smeal, president of the Feminist Majority, who is lobbying the Senate to reject the nominee. Smeal said she had read all 200 of Souter's legal opinions and believes he would work to cut off women's access to birth control and abortion. Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, said Souter revealed his opposition to abortion by calling it the ``killing of unborn children.'' ``That's the language of the right wing,'' Yard said. Souter did not use the words during the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings this week, but while New Hampshire attorney general he signed a brief that contained the language. However, during the hearings Friday, Souter said he has not made up his mind on the abortion rights issue and would consider both sides if he is confirmed. ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade,'' Souter in reference to the case that legalized abortion. ``I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind and I would not go on the court saying I must go one way or I must go the other way.'' But Yard said that Souter's repeated reference to the abortion rights position as ``the other side,'' was evidence of where he stood. Smeal and Yard, who have attended most of the hearings, said Souter's answers to questions on constitutionally protected privacy rights concerning birth control indicated he believed in the concept for married couples, but left open whether single people had the same right. Smeal said the addition of Souter to the court would create the majority needed to whittle away at a woman's right to abortion and birth control until access no longer existed. ``It would take about 10 years,'' she said. ``First would be a requirement that teen-agers get parental consent for an abortion, then spousal consent.'' She predicted the court then would restrict the time period in which an abortion could be performed and then limit the kind of facility that could do the operation. Those decisions would be followed by requirements that teen-agers get parental consent for birth control requiring a physician's prescription and later that women get their husbands' consent, Smeal said. ``The last step would be outlawing the sale of birth control to single people,'' she said. ``That would take us back to 1965.'' That year, in Griswold vs. Connecticut, a case involving the sale of contraceptives, the court for the first time recognized a constitutional right of privacy. The decision led to widespread availability of birth control for married and unmarried people. Smeal said women's ability to get out from under the burden of unwanted pregnancies have been the key to the many advances they have been able to achieve outside the home. Smeal and Yard spoke to a rally organized by NOW across the street from the Capitol. About 150 people opposing the Souter nomination attended.

DOC.HEAD: Seattle's $459 Million Bus Tunnel Ready to Open
DOC.TEXT: A $459 million bus tunnel opens Saturday after four years of ripped-up streets and traffic nightmares, offering to zip commuters through congested downtown in about one-third the time it takes on the surface. The two-lane tunnel is expected to reduce downtown bus traffic 25 percent by next fall and 40 percent by the end of the decade. Officials with Metro, the King County transit and sewage-treatment agency overseeing the project, hope the tunnel entices new riders. It will be months before Metro knows whether downtown traffic has been eased and ridership is up. Metro ordered 236 Italian-made buses at $525,000 each. Deliveries are behind schedule, however, and there are only 51 new buses, said Metro spokesman Dan Williams. The five-station tunnel opens to the public Saturday. The mostly north-south route stops at Westlake Mall, stations in the financial district and historic Pioneer Square, and surfaces at the International District near the Kingdome sports center. Commuter frustration is high in the Seattle area, which experienced explosive suburban growth in the past decade. The city has no light-rail system, though the tunnel is equipped with recessed rails. About 225,000 people use Metro's buses daily, and 84 percent of them travel to downtown Seattle, Williams said. The tunnel lies in the downtown free-bus zone, instituted years ago to ease traffic. Commuters from outside the city center must pay fares that begin at 75 cents.

DOC.HEAD: 100-Nation Meeting Urges Tighter Nuclear Export Controls
DOC.TEXT: Delegates from about 100 countries pledged to seek tighter conditions for exports of nuclear materials to countries that have not signed a treaty banning the spread of atomic weapons, diplomats said Friday. Oswaldo de Rivero, chairman of a conference reviewing compliance with the 1970 Non-Proliferation Treaty, said such a wide international call for tougher controls was unprecedented. In a separate measure prompted partly by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, delegates urged the International Atomic Energy Agency to strenthen its surveillance of nuclear installations to prevent clandestine production of atomic weapons. Iraq signed the Non-Proliferation Treaty but has tried to import components that could be used in the manufacture of nuclear bombs. The two recommendations were part of a final conference declaration that was expected to be adopted over the weekend. Delegates agreed to ask the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency to consider starting short-notice inspections. It currently inspects according to a fixed schedule. Participants also agreed to recommend to exporters of nuclear materials that they require, ``as a precondition of doing business,'' that customers have all atomic installations under the agency's surveillance, de Rivero told reporters. The move is aimed at countries that have not signed the non-proliferation treaty and are believed to have nuclear weapons capability. They include Israel, South Africa, Brazil, Argentina, India and Pakistan. The United States, Canada, Australia and Sweden have already banned nuclear exports to countries refusing full inspection. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told the conference his country plans to adopt the same restriction. In a mainly symbolic move, the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain pledged for the first time to defend non-nuclear states from attack, de Rivero said. They are the three nations with nuclear capability that also have signed the non-proliferation treaty. The move appeared aimed at addressing longtime concerns among non-nuclear states that the treaty is fundamentally unbalanced. The treaty requires states that do not possess nuclear weapons to refrain from building or acquiring them. In return, the United States, Soviet Union and Britain pledge to work toward eliminating their arsenals and provide peaceful nuclear technology to other nations. Members meet every five years to review the treaty's success. About two-thirds of the 141 member countries are attending the current session. Debate over disarmament goals was subdued this year because of superpower efforts to cut nuclear arms since 1985 and the lessening of Cold War tensions, de Rivero said. ``This produced a lot of compromises and tolerance among the parties,'' he said. Two nuclear weapon states, France and China, are not formally affected by the conference since both have not signed the treaty. However, both sent conference observers for the first time in what Western diplomats said was a sign that they might sign on. In an annex to the final declaration, France and China will join the three other nuclear states in reaffirming previous guarantees that they will never attack a non-nuclear state, de Rivero said.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Warns Against Dishes Containing Raw Eggs
DOC.TEXT: Warning! The federal government says homemade eggnog can be hazardous to your health. So can homemade mayonnaise, caesar salad and other dishes containing raw eggs. The Food and Drug Administration recommended Friday that raw eggs be classified as a ``potentially hazardous food'' and said that improperly cooked eggs raise the danger of salmonella food poisoning. Specifically, the agency urged people to stop using raw eggs for such dishes as caesar salad, homemade mayonnaise, eggnog and ice cream. The warning was contained in 3,500 notices sent to state and local food regulatory agencies. Labeling a food as ``potentially hazardous'' doesn't mean ``that a food is inherently unhealthful,'' FDA spokesman Chris Lecos said. He said other perishable but ``perfectly wholesome, nutritious'' foods such as meats, dairy products and cooked vegetables are also considered ``potentially hazardous.'' But he said the FDA, in conjunction with the Agriculture Department, is trying to halt the spread of the salmonella enteriditis bacteria, which has entered the genetic systems of some layer hens and contaminated their eggs. Agriculture Department figures show there were 6,604 illnesses and 43 deaths attributed to salmonella from January 1985 to last October. Eggs were implicated in 73 percent of 189 recorded outbreaks. The FDA notice advises that eggs be refrigerated at temperatures of 45 degrees fahrenheit or less and thoroughly cooked at 140 degrees fahrenheit. It says whole eggs should be cooked until the white is completely coagulated and firm and the yolk begins to thicken. Scrambled eggs need to be cooked until firm throughout. Restaurants and food service operations are told not to use raw eggs in uncooked, ready-to-eat menu items and cooks are urged to substitute pasteurized eggs and egg products for shell eggs in recipes for salads, sauces, mayonnaise and ice cream calling for raw eggs. Louis B. Raffel, president of the American Egg Board, said egg producers agree on the need for precautions. ``The industry's feeling is that eggs should be refrigerated and that proper handling at all levels is important to avoid any food-related diseases.'' Cathy McCharen, vice president of the Egg Nutrition Center in Washington, said the industry has been giving similar advice for the last two years. The recommendations ``will force food handlers and restaurateurs to treat the egg with the kind of respect it deserves. That we do want to see.'' USDA spokeswoman Margaret Webb said 56 salmonella outbreaks have been confirmed since February, with 22 definitely linked to eggs. She said eggs may also be implicated in other cases, which have centered in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic states. Pennsylvania has reported nine outbreaks of the illness, which can cause vomiting, diarrhea and stomach cramps and can be fatal to the elderly and young children.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebel Leader Meets U.S. Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Prince Johnson met with U.S. Ambassador Peter de Vos on Friday and discussed how to end Liberia's tribal war following President Samuel Doe's death, the U.S. Embassy said. Bursts of gunfire interrupted periods of calm in the war-ravaged capital as the rival rebel armies of Johnson and Charles Taylor raced to reach the fortified presidential mansion, Liberia's seat of government. Johnson appeared to have pushed Taylor's forces back after they had advanced from the city's eastern suburbs to within a few hundred yards of the mansion. Johnson controls the city center and areas west of the capital - including the diplomatic enclave on Mamba Point - below the clifftop executive mansion. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said Johnson and de Vos talked for 45 minutes at Johnson's request and discussed ``how to bring peace to Liberia and to provide humanitarian relief to the Liberian people.'' It was Johnson's first visit to the embassy, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. ``The U.S. government has been and continues to be in contact with all the parties in the Liberian conflict and, in this context, Field Marshal Prince Johnson came to the embassy to exchange views,'' the spokesman said. He refused to elaborate. Washington has valuable installations, including a ship-tracking station and CIA message transmission center, in this West African nation, which was founded in 1847 by freed American slaves. American administrations gave Doe's government $500 million in aid from 1980-85 despite charges of gross human rights abuses by his administration. The aid was reduced the last two years. Johnson's men massacred Doe's bodyguards and wounded Doe on Sunday. The president was reported dead the next day and his mutilated body was put on display. Since then, rebels led by Taylor and Johnson have been locked in battle. Rebels from both camps also have mercilessly sought revenge. They have hunted down and killed members of Doe's Krahn tribe just as the government troops had slaughtered civilians of the Gio and Mano tribes, which supported the rebels. The U.S. government supports the Economic Community of West African States' decision to send a 3,000-member task force to Monrovia, the U.S. Embassy spokesman said Friday. The military force was intended to end the civil war, which has killed an estimated 5,000 civilians and caused starvation. But Taylor has fought the West African force, claiming it merely wanted to prop up Doe after establishing a cease-fire. The West African soldiers, who have orders to withhold fire except in self-defense, stood by without firing a shot when Johnson attacked Doe at the force's headquarters Sunday. On Thursday, Johnson agreed to allow the West African forces to evacuate people from the executive mansion, and 1,000 mainly women and children trapped there were escorted to the port headquarters. The fate of soldiers who remained in the mansion, saying they distrusted promises of safe conduct, was not known Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan's Radar Turned on; Venus Mapping to Resume Saturday
DOC.TEXT: Engineers turned on Magellan's radar Friday for the first time in a month, preparing the sometimes unruly spacecraft to start mapping the rugged landscape of cloud-covered Venus. ``I personally am excited and jumping around,'' said Ed Sherry, technical assistant to the Magellan project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The last and only other time engineers used Magellan's radar was during a picture-making test on Aug. 16, only hours before they lost touch with the spacecraft for 14 hours. Radio contact was lost again for 17{ hours starting Aug. 21. ``I am delighted to see the blue sky that we knew was at the end of this tunnel,'' Sherry said Friday after engineers received confirmation at 8:14 a.m. PDT that they successfully turned on the radar. Magellan's radar was to remain on standby until Saturday, when it will be ordered to send radar waves through Venus' thick clouds and bounce them off the rugged surface. Magellan then will collect the reflected radar echoes and send the data to Earth, where it will be made into pictures and maps. If all goes well, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration hopes to release new pictures of Venus early next week, Sherry said. He cautioned that NASA may lose contact with Magellan again because engineers have yet to determine the cause of the earlier blackouts. But they have equipped Magellan with new computer commands that should allow them to restore contact within four to 24 hours if it is lost again, then resume mapping within two weeks. NASA's official stance is that Magellan's $744 million mapping mission won't start until late this month. But if everything works well this weekend, officials may declare retroactively that mapping began Saturday, Sherry said. ``We're not being foolhardy and rushing into a restart of operations,'' said David Okerson, a Magellan engineer. Magellan's first pictures of Venus - made during the Aug. 16 radar test - showed surprisingly violent forces shape the planet. The pictures revealed vast flows of solidified lava, volcanic cinder cones, huge meteorite impact craters, extensive ``Venusquake'' faults, numerous valleys and mountain ridges and large calderas. The calderas are volcanic craters created when the summit of a volcano collapses as lava flows out from vents on the volcano's flanks. Sherry said that during the weekend, Magellan will fly over Ishtar Terra - a continent-like highland area about the size of Australia - and a plain on Ishtar that is named Lakshmi Planum. Optical cameras can't penetrate Venus' thick clouds. Magellan's radar penetrates the clouds to make pictures 10 times more detailed than those produced by Earth-based radar or radar on the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft, which visited Venus in the mid-1980s. Magellan went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10 after a looping 948 million-mile voyage from Earth. It was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989. Magellan's primary mission will last 243 days - the time it takes for Venus to rotate once as Magellan circles the planet in a nearly polar orbit. The spacecraft should be able to map 70 percent to 90 percent of the surface during the initial mapping mission. But NASA officials have said they expect to extend Magellan's mission so the entire planet can be mapped. Magellan made its Aug. 16 pictures during two orbits around Venus. But only 1{ orbits worth of picture data were returned before contact was lost. Sherry said half the remaining picture information was radioed to Earth on Wednesday night. Engineers hoped to retrieve the remainder early Saturday. Despite 900-degree Fahrenheit surface temperatures created by a runaway ``greenhouse effect,'' Venus is the planet most like Earth in terms of size, mass, density and distance from the sun. Scientists hope to learn the extent to which Venus is shaped by forces similar to those that sculpted Earth's terrain. They are particularly interested in knowing if Venus has plate tectonics, which is the movement of giant plates of crustal rock that makes continents drift slowly across the face of the Earth. Many scientists doubt Venus has drifting plates, and believe its crustal movements are caused by ``hot spots'' in which molten material bubbles upward - the process that created the Hawaiian Islands on Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Continued High Public Interest in Gulf Coverage
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two-thirds of Americans surveyed in a poll released Friday said they are closely following events in the Persian Gulf, and a similar proportion think news media coverage of the crisis has been fair. The poll commissioned by the Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press also said some Americans seem to be tiring of the extent of coverage of the gulf crisis. The Times Mirror Center is a Washington-based public opinion research group owned by Times Mirror Co., publisher of the Los Angeles Times and other newspapers. Sixty-three percent of those surveyed from Sept. 10 to 12 said they were ``very closely'' following news about the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and the deployment of U.S. forces to the gulf area. In an August survey, the figure was 66 percent. The public also is keenly interested in several related stories, the poll said. Fifty-six percent of those surveyed said they were closely following news about rising gasoline prices, and 57 percent said they were tracking developments about Americans and other Westerners being held hostage in Kuwait and Iraq. The only major aspect of the gulf story to gain little public interest was the Helsinki summit Sept. 9 between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The poll said 26 percent of respondents closely followed news of the summit. Last June, following a Bush-Gorbachev summit in Washington, a Times Mirror Center poll said 38 percent kept a close eye on news about the meeting. Despite continued high public interest in news about the gulf crisis, the survey indicated that some have tired of the extent of coverage. Fifteen percent of respondents volunteered that there was too much news on the subject. Americans gave the news media generally high marks for coverage of the crisis. About two-thirds said the media have treated the story fairly. Ten percent said the media have been too critical of American positions, while 11 percent called coverage too supportive. A plurality of those surveyed said the views of Americans who oppose the buildup of U.S. military forces in the gulf region have not been adequately aired. Forty percent expressed that opinion, while 15 percent said critics have gotten too much coverage and 35 percent said there was too little coverage of this. When asked whether they favored using military force against Iraq in the event that U.N. economic sanctions fail to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, 63 percent said ``yes,'' 24 percent said ``no,'' and 13 percent said they didn't know. The poll said 68 percent of respondents approved of Bush's overall performance as president, a decline from a 75 percent approval rating in an August Times Mirror Center poll. The survey was conducted for the Times Mirror Center by The Gallup Organization in Lincoln, Neb., under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates. The results are based on telephone interviews with 1,244 adults. The poll's margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of Judge David H. Souter's testimony Friday before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
DOC.HEAD: ABORTION:
DOC.TEXT: ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade. ... I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind and I would not go on the court saying I must go one way or I must go the other way.''
DOC.HEAD: PAST SUPREME COURT DECISIONS:
