DOC.TEXT: ``There are decisions which we will undoubtedly discuss in the course of the next afternoon or the next day or two, some of which I would have come out differently on. Any lawyer and any judge can say that. But I don't have an alarm to raise with you at this moment.''
DOC.HEAD: SCHOOL PRAYER
DOC.TEXT: ``The fact is, the Supreme Court today I think has carried the law to the point where a period of time for silence which may be used for any meditative or non-meditative purpose that a child may want has not been declared to be a violation of (past court decisions). But I think it is probably equally clear that the use of prayer, which has, as you describe it so graphically, the kind of exclusionary effect, is by virtue of that very evidence a kind of use of prayer which under the Lemon test would have presumptive religious purpose and presumptive religious effect.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Wants to Keep Military Presence in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The government wants to keep U.S. soldiers based in the Philippines as long as they're welcome, a State Department spokesman said Friday after a congressman said U.S. negotiators likely will propose a 10-year phase out of American Philippine bases. Spokesman Richard Boucher declined to discuss U.S. negotiating positions in talks expected to open next week in Manila on the future of two of the United States' largest foreign bases. ``We will continue to support a U.S. military presence in the Philippines if we are welcome to do so by the Philippines,'' he said. ``We feel it would be premature to speculate on the outcome of the negotiations before the two sides meet.'' The talks cover an agreement that allows unlimited U.S. access to Clark Air Base, Subic Naval Base and four smaller facilities until Sept. 16, 1991. On Thursday, Rep. Stephen Solarz, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs, said he had talked with U.S. negotiators who he said are considering a 10-year phase out. ``I have the impression that this is a timetable they are comfortable with and likely to propose,'' the New York Democrat said in a telephone interview. Rep. James Leach, R-Iowa, minority leader on the Solarz subcommittee, said he had no direct knowledge of the U.S. negotiating position but agreed that a phase out is probable because of the decreased Soviet threat in Asia and Philippine sovereignty concerns. ``A gradual phase out is a likely conclusion at this point,'' Leach said. The Washington Post, citing congressional and administration sources, reported Friday that the United States will seek a phase out of the bases in the Manila talks. If U.S. negotiators seek a definite end to the bases agreement, it would be a departure from longstanding U.S. assertion that the bases are vital to U.S. and regional defense interests. The administration has said that if the bases are not wanted they will go, but has never publicly suggested it would propose a withdrawal. U.S. officials have long said the bases are critical to defense strategies in the Pacific and elsewhere and have never publicly suggested they would negotiate even a long-term withdrawal. A phase out would open the way for a commercial agreement under which the U.S. military might rent portions of the facilities if both sides feel a U.S. presence is needed into the next century, said Solarz. Richard Armitage, former assistant defense secretary who heads the U.S. negotiating team, was en route to Manila for the talks, but U.S. officials would not say exactly when he would arrive or when the negotiations will begin. Philippine officials have said they will start Monday. Recent bombings in Manila and threats against Americans have prompted the U.S. reluctance to give details about arrangements for the talks. Previous negotiations have focused primarily on the amount of aid the U.S. government gives in connection with the bases. Filipino negotiators have reportedly asked for $1 billion a year and more. The Reagan administration pledged $962 million over two years to keep the bases until September 1991, but Congress cut $96 million from the request.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Says He Hasn't Made Up His Mind on Abortion Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with Souter testimony, Kennedy, Biden comments, NARAL and Planned Parenthood opposition; testimony concluded for day, Souter will return Monday
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter said Friday he had not made up his mind about how he would vote as a justice if the court were asked to overturn its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. While refusing repeatedly to give his own views on abortion, Souter told the Senate Judiciary Committee during the second day of his confirmation hearings: ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade (the 1973 ruling). I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind and I would not go on the court saying I must go one way or I must go the other way.'' Abortion foes have high hopes that President Bush's nominee to replace liberal Justice William J. Brennan will provide the critical vote to overturn the decision. Abortion-rights groups have expressed fears that that might indeed happen, and Planned Parenthood and the National Abortion Rights Action League announced their opposition Friday to Souter's nomination. The day's most dramatic moment came when Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., pressed Souter to explain his role, as New Hampshire's attorney general, in defending the state's literacy requirement for voters. After Kennedy recited a quote attributed to Souter that the votes of illiterates ``dilute the votes of those people who can read,'' Souter responded, ``That is kind of a statement of math.'' Suggesting that Souter's response was callous, Kennedy said, ``That's something that I find is troublesome.'' Earlier, Kennedy had asked Souter whether he believed abortion is moral. Souter refused to answer, but said his view on abortion's morality ``will play absolutely no role'' in his deciding any abortion case that would come before him. Souter again refused to give his personal view after Kennedy noted that ``Sandra Day O'Connor responded to that question, judge'' during the confirmation hearings that preceded her joining the Supreme Court in 1981. Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., also expressed frustration over his inability to draw Souter out on abortion. ``No one here is seeking a commitment on anything,'' Biden said. Also on abortion, Souter told the committee he had voted to let such operations be performed at a hospital where he served on the board of trustees. But he said his vote did not necessarily reflect his moral views on abortion. On another topic, Souter told the senators that as a judge he might go against some of the stands he took as New Hampshire's attorney general in freedom-of-religion cases. But he defended his prosecution of demonstrators who opposed the building of the Seabrook nuclear reactor in New Hampshire. Meanwhile, President Bush touted his nominee at a news conference and at a White House meeting with an international gathering of judges. Bush said he had watched portions of the hearings on television, and he called his nominee's effort ``magnificent ... masterful.'' Souter will return for more questioning on Monday. He was asked by Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., about his vote to allow abortions while on the Concord Hospital's board in the mid-1970s. The nominee noted that legalized abortion was ``the law of the land'' after the 1973 Supreme Court decision in Roe vs. Wade. While indicating that some trustees might have had moral scruples against abortion, he said, ``We did not believe it was appropriate to impose those views on the hospital.'' Souter attempted to distance himself from his involvement, as state attorney general, in two freedom-of-religion controversies of the 1970s. In one, he defended Gov. Meldrim Thomson's order that flags on all state government buildings be flown at half staff on Good Friday to commemorate Jesus Christ's death. In the other, he prosecuted two Jehovah's Witnesses for covering the state motto, ``Live Free or Die,'' on theirautomobile license plates. Noting that the flag-lowering order was struck down by a federal judge in Boston, Souter said, ``If I were sitting as a judge today, I probably would have ruled the same way'' as did the judge in that case. And he conceded that New Hampshire's interest in the license tag case was ``not particularly compelling.'' An interesting exchange occurred when Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, complained about activist judges and asked Souter about ``rights created by the courts.'' ``The Supreme Court should only act, and can only act, when it has the judicial responsibility under ... the Constitution, but the Supreme Court is left to act alone when the political branches do not act beforehand,'' Souter said. Citing the 1954 high court decision that outlawed racial segregation in America's public schools, he said, ``We had Brown vs. Board of Education ... because we had no decision from any other branch of the government, at any other level of the government, facing the undoubted constitutional problem that had to be solved.'' Souter said Congress' willingness to aggressively protect the Constitution's promise of equal protection of the law for all is welcome ``so the court is not left in the position of seeming to be the only guarantor of some of the very liberties that we must most be concerned with.'' He added: ``Judges are not the only people in our governmental structure who are sworn to uphold the Constitution and to try to make it work. The executive, the president of the United States, takes such an oath. All of you take such an oath ... you are just as much responsible for making good on the Constitution's guarantees as we are in the judiciary.'' On another topic, Souter said he may have been quoted out of context when in a speech he reportedly used the phrase ``affirmative discrimination'' to describe affirmative action. ``It goes without saying that when we consider the powers of the judiciary to remedy discrimination that has gone before,'' Souter told Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., ``the appropriate response is not to say `Stop doing it.' The appropriate response is to say `Undo it.''' Souter, who spent seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court before being named a federal appeals court judge by Bush last April, would become the Supreme Court's 105th justice if confirmed. The Judiciary Committee will vote on Souter's nomination after completing its hearings sometime next week. The nomination then will go to the full Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Violent Weather Hits the Great Lakes Region; Nebraska Cools Down
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Violent weather, heavy rains, and hail pelted parts of Michigan and Indiana and a three-week heat wave in Nebraska broke Friday. Tornadoes touched down in southern Michigan but there were no reports of injuries. A employee of a dry cleaners in the Detroit suburb of Beverly Hills said she was sure it was a tornado that almost carried her off as it blasted through the building. ``The wind did pick me up. My feet actually came off the ground. It was pretty scary,'' said Brenda Reeves. ``God was looking out for me, because if the dry cleaner hadn't come back and grabbed me, I would have gone out of the door.'' There were reports of damage from thunderstorm wind gusts near Chase, Beal City, Paw Paw, Flint, and north of Mishawaka, Ind. Gusts reached 60 mph west of Flint and 65 mph at Crawfordsville, Ind. Hail hit Tuscola, Mich., and heavy rain from strong storms caused flooding of streets, small streams and low lying areas around Three Rivers, Mich. The sizzling heat wave that had gripped Nebraska since Aug. 23 broke Friday with temperatures dropping back into the seasonable 80's. The high in Omaha had averaged 92.5 degrees during the spell, said John Zapotocny, assistant professor of atmospheric sciences at Creighton University. At midday there were showers and thunderstorms over parts of Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Ohio and Michigan. Showers and thunderstorms also extended from North Carolina across South Carolina, Georgia, northwest Florida, Alabama, Tennessee, Mississippi, southeast Arkansas, Louisiana, parts of Texas and southeast New Mexico. Storms and showers also reached from the North Carolina coast across eastern Virginia, Delaware, eastern Maryland, southeast Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey. There were scattered showers in central Maine, and southeast Florida, and rain moved onto the northern coast of Oregon. Heavier rainfall Friday included 2.71 inches at Oscoda, Mich., 1.35 inches at Grand Rapids, Mich., 1.25 inches at Dover, Del., 1.09 inches at Houghton Lake, Mich., and 1 inch at Millville, N.J. Low temperature for the Lower 48 states Friday morning was 29 degrees at Truckee, Calif., West Yellowstone, Mont., and Burgess, Ind. The Big Horn Mountains of Wyoming reached 22 degrees. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 47 at Marquette, Mich., to 101 at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: First Human Gene Therapy Study Begins
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old girl received an intravenous injection Friday and made history by becoming the first patient to receive gene therapy. ``The patient is doing beautifully,'' said Dr. French Anderson, a scientist at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. ``The family now has new hope for their child,'' said another researcher, Dr. Kenneth W. Culver of the National Cancer Institutes. During the 28-minute infusion procedure, the girl - who was not identified - sat up in her bed, played and put stickers on the lab coats of her doctors. ``I'm sure this will be one of the most closely watched human beings on the face of the earth today,'' said Don Ralbovsky, a spokesman for the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., where the procedure was conducted. The therapy involves inserting curative genes into human cells. Its first therapeutic use was given final approval only hours before by the Food and Drug Administration. ``This is a small but crucial step to treating a whole array of genetic diseases,'' said Dr. R. Michael Blaese, another cancer institute researcher on the project. Success could lead to use of the procedure against cancer, hemophilia, sickle cell anemia, AIDS and other diseases in years to come. The child suffers from a rare genetic disease called ADA Deficiency, which weakens her immune system so that it cannot fight infection and disease. About 1 billion cells - approximately a small thimbleful - were mixed in a saline solution in the first infusion, which took about a half hour. Anderson said he would not expect to see results for the first several months but that within a year they should know whether the treatment is working. The National Institutes of Health has approval to treat up to 10 patients with ADA Deficiency. The afflicted children were born with a gene that does not produce the enzyme adenosine deaminase, or ADA, which is essential for an immune system to function normally This leaves them vulnerable to infections and diseases most people can fight off. The best of the current treatments for the 10 children born in North America each year suffering from the disease, is a bone marrow transplant with a donor whose tissue type matches the child's. But most of the children don't have a matched donor, and success with an unmatched donor is about 50 percent. Untreated, children with the disease die within the first two years of life. They usually don't live into their second decade even with current treatments. Weeks ago, researchers took white cells from some of the 4-year-old's blood and began growing them in tissue culture. Then they inserted a normal ADA gene into these cells with a genetically engineered virus. The virus has been disabled and is no longer infectious, but is a vehicle to get the normal gene into the cells where it produces the required enzyme. Once enough ADA-corrected cells have been grown, they are infused into the patient intravenously. The treatments will be given once a month for about two years. The experiment, first proposed by NIH in April 1987, was recommended for approval by an advisory committee July 31 and was approved by NIH last week. Another gene-therapy experiment, also approved by NIH last week and awaiting FDA clearance, would treat patients with a lethal form of skin cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis Returns, Reclaims State From Lt. Gov.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis closed the book on the Massachusetts Mutiny on Friday when he returned from a European trade mission and ended Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy's brief reign as acting governor. There was some consolation for Murphy in the aftermath of an episode that sunk her foundering race for governor. An aide said Dukakis would consider adopting some elements of her plan to restructure the state's frail budget. Dukakis said he planned to meet Saturday with assistants to discuss the state budget, which already is running at a deficit two months into the fiscal year. He refused to say what action he would take on Murphy's plans. Just a week earlier, Dukakis left Massachusetts under a cloud of rebellion, with Murphy pledging to seize control of the state's finances in his absence. Murphy, who was seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, unveiled her budget plans Sept. 7. But she could not escape charges that her tactics were designed to bolster her failing campaign. Murphy dropped out of the governor's race Monday. She said se would continue to fight for her plans, contained in executive orders she signed last week. Dukakis, whose popularity has plummeted along with his state's economy, decided not to run for re-election this year. Economic woes were on his mind when he returned from Europe. ``I will take advice from anybody and everybody who can constructively participate in this - that includes the lieutenant governor,'' he said at a news conference at Logan International Airport. Murphy said her plans would save the state about $150 million annually. She called for slashing about 1,000 jobs from the state workforce and issuing monthly budget reports detailing spending and revenues. Administration officials said they have been complying with the orders, but also indicated Murphy's plans fit within budget-cutting measures issued by Dukakis before he left to help offset shrinking tax collections. S. Stephen Rosenfeld, Dukakis' chief of staff, indicated that parts of Murphy's orders may be included in the final budget cuts. He said the eventual payroll cuts will ``go well beyond'' the reductions ordered by Murphy, although he could not specify where these cuts would occur. Rosenfeld said he did not expect Murphy would attend Saturday's budget session with the governor. Jodi D'Urso, a spokeswoman for the lieutenant governor, said Murphy was not invited.

DOC.HEAD: California Announces First Toll Roads
DOC.TEXT: California's first planned toll roads were announced Friday, marking the first time that freeway-happy motorists will face levies on anything but bridges. The roads, all privately financed under a new state-approved program, include a $1.2 billion, 40-mile highway east of San Francisco and a 10-mile segment in San Diego County near the Mexican border. Two other projects were approved for Orange County, just south of Los Angeles. All are set for completion by 1997. Gov. George Deukmejian also said two backup plans were approved, in case financing or other problems blocked the toll roads. One would replace San Francisco's earthquake-damaged Embarcadero Freeway with an underground highway, and the other would construct a high-speed train from the Los Angeles International Airport to Palmdale, in the Mohave Desert. ```While privitizing roads is not new in the country, California's approach is unique because ... the private sector selects the projects from among those already on a list of planned future state highways,'' Deukmejian said. The toll roads would all be constructed with private funds, with the state and developers negotiating the tolls before construction begins. Bob Best, the director of the state Department of Transportation, told a news conference that he expected tolls to run between 10 and 20 cents per mile. The toll roads program was part of the political compromise that led to the 9-cents-per-gallon gasoline tax increase approved by California voters in June. The planned toll roads would be: -In Orange County, an 11-mile road roughly between Anaheim Stadium and the John Wayne Airport, and 10 miles of new toll lanes on the Route 91 freeway to Riverside County. -In San Diego County, a new four-lane freeway extending 10 miles from the Otay Mesa Road near the Mexican border north to State Route 54 at an estimated cost of $400 million. -In Contra Costa County, east of San Francisco, a five- or six-lane, 40-mile road between Antioch and Interstate 680 near Sunol.

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in the Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the breakdown of the opposing forces in the Persian Gulf: ---
DOC.HEAD: UNITED STATES: Officials say more than 150,000 troops,
DOC.TEXT: including those aboard ships, are in the Persian Gulf region or on the way. Deployments could go as high as 250,000. The troops include elements of the 82nd and 101st Airborne Divisions, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment, and other units. They also include a contingent of 45,000 Marines. The American fleet in the gulf and Arabian Sea waters immediately outside it totals about 30 ships, including three aircraft carriers, a battleship armed with Tomahawk cruise missiles, more than a dozen missile cruisers, destroyers, supply ships and an undisclosed number of submarines. Two hospital ships are sailing for the gulf. Another seven ships are expected in the Mediterranean. The Pentagon has also sent 22 Stealth fighter-bombers and dozens of other aircraft. ---
DOC.HEAD: BRITAIN: Has a flotilla permanently in the gulf and has
DOC.TEXT: contributed three warships: a destroyer armed with Sea Dart missiles and two Frigates armed with Exocet and Seawolf missiles. They are accompanied in the gulf by a Royal Fleet auxiliary vessel. Soon to join them will be three Royal Fleet auxiliary ships: one supply vessel, one fleet tanker and one forward supply vessel. Three minesweepers and one support vessel are en route, but the minesweepers are expected to stay in the eastern Mediterranean. Also dispatched were two squadrons of Tornadoes and one squadron of Jaguar fighter-bombers. A squadron totals 12-16 planes. The F3 class Tornado fighter-interceptors is based in Saudi Arabia. The Jaguars are at Thumrait airbase in neighboring Oman. The second squadron of Tornadoes, which are IDS-type interdictor strike planes, are expected to arrive within the week from a base in West Germany. There are also three Nimrod maritime reconnaisance aircraft stationed in Oman. Britain has also committed an armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops to the Persian Gulf, along with another squadron of Tornado ground attack aircraft and additional air defense aircraft. ---
DOC.HEAD: FRANCE: Nine ships are either in the gulf or enroute, including
DOC.TEXT: the aircraft carrier Clemenceau with anti-tank helicopters, a guided-missile cruiser and two destroyers equipped with anti-ship Exocet missiles, two frigates and one corvette. The helicopters will be sent to Saudi Arabia. One company of 180 paratroopers has been sent to the United Arab Emirates. They are equipped for chemical warfare. ---
DOC.HEAD: GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United
DOC.TEXT: Arab Emirates, Qatar and, until Aug. 2, Kuwait): A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops based in northeast Saudi Arabia. They would be supported by Saudi Arabian forces. ---
DOC.HEAD: GREECE: Greece is sending its top frigate, the Limnos, to join
DOC.TEXT: multinational operations in the gulf. The frigate has a 180-member crew and is equipped with a Phalanx anti-missile system, ground-to-air missiles and ground-to-ground missiles. It can also carry two anti-submarine helicopters. ---
DOC.HEAD: ITALY: Two frigates and a support ship are on the way to the
DOC.TEXT: gulf, having sailed through the Suez Canal. Two corvettes are in the eastern Mediterranean off Turkey. Italy said it would send an additional warship and eight Tornado fighter-planes to the gulf region. ---
DOC.HEAD: NETHERLANDS: Has sent one air defense frigate and one standard
DOC.TEXT: frigate are expected to arrive in the Gulf of Oman or Gulf of Aqaba next week. The Dutch navy has sent six Stinger short-range missiles. ---
DOC.HEAD: SPAIN: Sending one frigate and two corvettes. The frigate will
DOC.TEXT: be based in the Gulf of Oman. The corvettes are en route to Bab El Mandeb Strait at the entrance to the Red Sea. --- Also:
DOC.HEAD: EGYPT: 4,000 ground troops sent.
MOROCCO: 1,200 ground troops sent.
SYRIA: 4,000 ground troops sent, and is planning to send 15,000
DOC.TEXT: more.
DOC.HEAD: AUSTRALIA: Two-guided missile frigates and a supply ship are en
DOC.TEXT: route.
DOC.HEAD: BELGIUM: Two minehunters and a supply ship are en route to Gulf
DOC.TEXT: of Oman.
DOC.HEAD: CANADA: Two destroyers and a supply ship are heading for the
DOC.TEXT: gulf. Sending a dozen fighter jets and a total of 450 fliers and ground crew. ---
DOC.HEAD: IRAQ FORCES:
DOC.TEXT: Army: regular 555,000, reserves 480,000. Claims militia called Popular Army, originally formed in Iran-Iraq war and partially demobilized after cease-fire, of 5 million. Tanks: 5,500, including some 500 T-72s. Heavy artillery: 3,500 Multiple Rocket Launchers: 200 Surface-to-Surface Missiles: estimated 500 Surface-to-Air Missiles: 330 launchers Combat Aircraft: 500-plus, reportedly including Soviet-supplied Su-24 long-range fighter-bombers. Navy: 1 training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, estimated eight missile attack craft, six torpedo boats.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Investigating Ship Suspected in Iraqi Supergun Project
DOC.TEXT: Authorities are investigating the cargo of an impounded, Iraqi-bound ship suspected earlier of carrying parts for a ``supergun'' that could fire chemical warheads, a prosecutor's spokeswoman said Friday. The spokeswoman also said Iraqi authorities failed in an effort to free the ship when a Dutch court refused to hear a lawsuit they had filed. The Bahamian-registered Gur Mariner was seized in the Dutch North Sea port of Vlissingen on Thursday after customs received a document identifying the destination of its cargo as Iraq. According to Dutch Radio, the ship was carrying pipe segments for use in oil drilling operations, as well as machine parts and unidentified chemicals. In April, British customs seized a consignment of Iraqi-bound pipe segments that were on a dock waiting to be picked up by the Gur Mariner. The pipes were believed parts for a 120-foot-long artillery piece supposedly being built that would be capable of lobbying shells from Iraqi territory hundreds of miles into Israel. Alleged components for the so-called supergun, believed to be capable of carrying chemical weapons, have since surfaced in several other European nations. Josine Mooijen of the Rotterdam prosecutor's office, which is investigating the case, told The Associated Press the ship's papers state its cargo ``in rather vague terms.'' She said the cargo was being investigated but refused to provide details. According to the radio report, the Gur Mariner had picked up cargo in Bremen, West Germany, and Middlesborough, Britain - where the piping was seized in April. The report said the Gur Mariner was in the Egyptian Suez Canal port of Port Said when the United Nations declared its trade embargo against Iraq. The ship then returned to Rotterdam, said the report. It added that a U.S. Navy detachment in the Mediterranean Sea had tried to chase the ship because of suspicions it sought to break the U.N. embargo imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The case came to light on Thursday, when papers submitted to Dutch customs gave the cargo's destination as Iraq. Investigators seized the ship under Dutch laws enforcing the U.N. embargo on Iraq. The prosecutor's spokeswoman also said the Iraqi government lost a lawsuit Thursday against the Gur Mariner's owners, Aza Hara Maritime Inc. of Panama, within hours of filing the case at a district court in Middelburg. Iraq demanded the ship leave Vlissingen within 48 hours without unloading its cargo and sail for a port to be specified later, said Ms. Mooijen. She said the court refused to hear the suit because the Gur Mariner's departure would violate the Dutch sanctions law. ``It was a clear-cut, textbook example'' of how that law should be applied, she said. Talal Pachachi, a spokesman for the Iraqi Embassy in The Hague, said he was unaware of the lawsuit. He refused all comment on the case. A U.S. arms designer suspected of helping Iraq develop the supergun, Canadian-born Gerald Bull, was assassinated last March in Brussels, Belgium. The case is unsolved though it is believed a hired hitmen carried out the assassination. Bull also worked on advanced howitzer systems for the U.S. Army. His technology was used by Israel, South Africa and both sides in the Iran-Iraq war.

DOC.HEAD: Conferees Approve Tighter Pollution Controls on Factories, Businesses
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators gave formal approval Friday to a compromise provision of the clean air bill that would require factories and businesses to tighen controls on smog-causing pollutants. The provisions had tentatively been approved in negotiations among staff members earlier in the week and had expected to be endorsed by the House and Senate members. The industrial smog measure is part of a much broader clean air bill that would impose tough new pollution controls on electric utilities, automobiles and factories, including reductions in sulfer dioxide and the industrial release of toxic chemicals. The agreement would require even small emitters of smog-causing pollution like dry cleaners, bakeries and furniture makers to comply with tougher controls by installing new pollution control equipment. The Senate had exempted polluters releasing less than 100 tons of pollution a year, but the House version - which was adopted by the conferees - requires compliance by polluters of as little as 25 to 50 tons a year in cities with serious smog problems. After the industrial smog section was approved, conferees agreed to proceed to a section of the massive bill that deals with new pollution controls on motor vehicles. Both the House and Senate approved clean air bills earlier this year, but the negotiations are aimed at resolving an array of differences including how much to toughen the pollution controls on cars, buses and trucks. The legislation would be the first strengthening of federal air pollution controls in 13 years.

DOC.HEAD: President Urges Dominicans to Save Gas, Stay Away from Beach
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquin Balaguer said Friday that Dominicans must ``go to the beach less'' to survive a gasoline shortage and economic crunch from the faceoff in the Persian Gulf. In another effort to solve the country's economic problems, a top Central Bank official flew to Washington for talks with the International Monetary Fund. Although there is no current agreement with the IMF, the government last month imposed unpopular austerity measures recommended by the fund. The Aug. 13 measures devalued the Dominican peso and increased prices for food and gasoline, touching off protests and strikes that left 12 people dead and 50 wounded in clashes with police. On Friday, Balaguer said Dominicans must ``tighten their belts'' to live with the recent measures and fight 70 percent inflation afflicting this Caribbean nation of 6.7 million people. ``We've got to tighten our belts and think about our country,'' Balaguer said. ``We have to use less gas, go out less, go to the beach less. We must appeal to Dominican patriotism so that we can overcome this crisis.'' Luis Toral, governor of the Central Bank, was to meet with IMF officials next week in Washington, but the country was not expected to sign an agreement immediately. The Dominican Republic is in arrears on most of its $4 billion foreign debt because it cannot make the payments. Economists say without an IMF accord, it cannot get new loans or credits to reschedule the debt. Balaguer said two weeks ago he would not sign an accord that ``imposes obligations which we cannot meet.'' The last IMF accord in 1984 led to protests that left 100 dead in three days of rioting. On Thursday, the government imposed another gasoline price increase, from about 89 cents a gallon to $1.42. It also announced 30 to 40 percent cuts in oil imports. Balaguer said he had no alternative because of the oil crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The country has no other choice but to pay for petroleum at the current prices or reduce its consumption,'' Balaguer said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Vote on Fuel Economy Bill May be Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf pvs: Skinner said to UPDATE with consumer grout comments.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate cleared the way Friday for action on a bill that would require automakers to dramatically increase fuel economy. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he hoped to have a vote late next week on the bill that would require automakers to increase average fuel economy of new cars to 35 miles per gallon by 1995 and to 40 miles per gallon by 2001. Supporters contend the higher fuel economy requirements would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day once they go fully into effect, but key opponents promised to continue fighting the measure on the Senate floor. Within hours of the vote, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner blasted the legislation as ``unrealistic, irresponsible and, more important, unattainable.'' He said there's no technology to achieve the bill's goals without making cars smaller. ``It should be called the highway fatality bill,'' Skinner said at a news conference, citing a new study by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that concluded a clear link between reducing the size of cars and traffic deaths. The NHTSA study said the introduction of smaller cars over the past decade had resulted in an estimated 1,340 additional traffic deaths annually in single-car accidents. Based on those numbers, NHTSA Administrator Jerry Curry said between 600 and 1,140 additional deaths annually can be expected if automakers try to meet the 40 mile per gallon standard. Skinner said automakers had convinced him that the Senate bill's fuel economy goals can't be achieved without substantial weight reductions in cars. Joan Claybrook, a former NHTSA administrator in the Carter adminstration and now president of Public Citizen, a consumer group, disputed claims that cars necessarily will have to be made smaller to burn less fuel. She cited a Transportation Department research vehicle built in the 1970s that achieved 43 mpg despite providing improved protection to occupants than conventional cars. ``We've just had the first inning of this nine-inning game,'' Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., said after the Senate voted 68-28 to clear the way for debate. ``We hope and intend to win this fight,'' Riegle said, adding that he doubts supporters will get the needed 60 votes to cut off debate and bring it to a vote next week. A similar bill has been introduced in the House, but it has yet to be taken up by the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., is staunchly opposed to the measure. Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., sponsor of the House bill, said earlier this week she would try to push the legislation directly on the House floor in an effort to bypass Dingell's committee. But the Senate's 68-28 vote Friday to cut off efforts by Riegle to keep the measure off the Senate floor was an indication of the growing support in Congress for a measure to reduce U.S. reliance on foreign oil, a subject in the spotlight since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``It's the single most important step to reducing our dependency on OPEC oil and curbing global warming,'' the Sierra Club said of the bill sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev. In floor debate, Riegle said those fuel savings aren't likely to begin phasing in until 1995 and a better response to today's oil crisis might be to return to a national speed limit of 55 miles an hour. Later, a Riegle aide said the senator didn't necessarily support a change in the speed limit. Bryan described his bill as a message to Detroit and the automakers ``that they're going to have to look at fuel economy and not just muscle cars.'' ``It does not take a crystal ball to realize that if we don't start conserving now, some future president may have to consider sending our young men and woman back to the deserts of the Middle East,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Says Soviets to Cut Oil Shipments
DOC.TEXT: The central Soviet government intends to completely cut off oil shipments to Poland next year and recommends that officials seek supplies from individual republics, a Polish official was quoted as saying. Polish officials, who are also contending with the loss of about 1 million tons of Iraqi oil because of the U.N. embargo, have been looking for new supply sources. ``Instead of the 13 million tons of oil which Poland has been getting annually ... the supplies proposed for 1991 will amount to zero,'' said government Minister Jerzy Osiatynski, head of the Central Planning Office of the Solidarity-led government. He was quoted in a statement carried late Thursday by the PAP news agency. He said Polish negotiators heard the news during talks held Aug. 28-31 by delegations of the two countries. ``The Soviet side suggested that in order to get any oil supplies, Poland should establish direct contact and cooperation with the republics and distributors interested in this,'' said Osiatynski in the statement. He said Polish officials followed the advice immediately but gave no indication whether Poland had succeeded in finding sellers. Poland has traditionally relied on the Soviet Union for low-cost oil for almost all its needs. In 1991, for the first time, Soviet and Polish trade was to have been conducted on a hard-currency basis with Poland paying market prices for oil. Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski, asked about the reported cutoff at a news conference Friday, said negotiations continue ``but we cannot be too optimistic'' about substantial supplies. In addition to oil cutbacks, the Soviet negotiators also said that supplies of natural gas sold to Poland will be reduced from this year's level of more than 8.2 billion cubic meters to 5.2 billion cubic meters. Deliveries of Soviet oil to Poland so far this year have been running up to 50 percent behind schedule, the government has said. Gasoline prices were increased by an average of 30 percent on Sept. 1 to curb demand and cover the added cost of supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Unsworn Clerk `Married' Hundreds
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of couples said `I do' before a court clerk who should have said `I can't.'' The clerk was not legally sworn in to administer marriages, but the weddings are legally binding anyway, Attorney General Joseph Curran said. ``I want to reassure any couple that may have been married in Howard County by the employee that the marriage is valid,'' Curran said Circuit Court Clerk C. Merritt Pumphrey said he deputized two of the three clerks who perform most of the ceremonies, but did not administer the oath to Laura Pannebecker. ``I just chose not to,'' Pumphrey said. Pumphrey said he thought he didn't need to formally deputize Pannebecker, who has conducted hundreds of weddings in the last four years, because she was authorized by an administrative judge to become a deputy clerk. Assistant Attorney General Julia Freit said that Maryland law clearly states that only deputized employees can perform weddings. ``I highly recommended that Pannebecker absolutely perform no further marriages,'' she said Thursday, adding that Pumphrey has been notified that employees conducting marriages must be formally sworn in for each four-year administrative term. Pumphrey said Friday he has not decided whether to deputize Pannebecker. She was on vacation and could not be reached for comment Friday. Couples were assured that their marriages will not be questioned. Some were mollified. ``I only live a few minutes away and I don't mind going back and doing it again,'' said Mark Cochran, 29, who was married in June. ``But in my mind, I was married on that day.'' Others in this Baltimore suburb remained angry. ``If we have to do it again it should be on Howard County's bill,'' said Jill Huston, 30, who was married in January. Curran said a 1925 Maryland Court of Appeals ruling would validate the marriages. The high court ruled that a couple's marriage was legal although the minister lacked authority from his church to conduct wedding ceremonies, concluding the union was valid because the couple believed the minister was qualified. ``It logically follows that the Court would reach the same conclusion with respect to a marriage performed by a supposed public official,'' Curran said.

DOC.HEAD: Carter's Former Pilot Freed After Years In Iranian Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Rabhan's arrival in Atlanta. Picks up 5th graf, `I look...'.
DOC.TEXT: A Savannah businessman who once worked as a pilot for former President Carter arrived in the United States on Friday after spending about a decade in prison in Iran. E. David Rabhan had been arrested during a business trip to Iran and charged with spying for the CIA, a charge both he and Carter denied. Attorney Phillips Hamilton said family members believed the 64-year-old Rabhan left Tehran late Thursday on a flight to Zurich, Switzerland. Rabhan arrived in Atlanta on Friday but he was whisked away for a private meeting with Carter, who has worked for years for his freedom. ``I look forward to being reunited with a friend,'' Carter told The Atlanta Journal. ``He's really an extraordinary person. I'm very proud of David.'' Rabhan's mother, Frances, reached in Savannah, praised Carter for his efforts to win her son's release. ``I'm not going to let him talk to you though - I'm going to keep him to myself,'' Mrs. Rabhan said in a telephone interview. ``President Carter has been like another son to me - you can't have a better friend.'' Rabhan's sister, Joan Jacobson, told The Philadelphia Inquirer that Iranian authorities had agreed Sept. 3 to allow Rabhan to leave the country. He was reportedly released from Iran's Evin Prison on Aug. 6 and issued an exit visa Thursday, hours before boarding the flight to Switzerland. The Swiss Embassy, through which the U.S. government maintains contact with Iran, would not confirm the Inquirer's report, which said Swiss authorities looked after Rabhan's interests and guaranteed he would not flee before being given a visa to leave Iran. Rabhan went to Iran in the mid-1970s to begin a business using a fish protein concentrate to make breads and snack foods. Various reports have listed his arrest date as 1981 and 1979. The exact date could not immediately be determined. ``He was a prisoner. He was never a spy. He never had any kind of connection with the CIA or with any sort of espionage or spying,'' Carter said. Rabhan was imprisoned with another American, John Pattis of Aiken, S.C., said Pattis' sister, Ellen. Pattis, a telecommunications engineer who is accused of spying, apparently remained in Evin after Rabhan's release. Rabhan's relationship with Carter dates to at least 1970, when Rabhan volunteered his services as a pilot during Carter's second campaign for governor of Georgia. After leaving the presidency, Carterdescribed Rabhan as a ``hostage,'' but neither the Reagan nor Bush administrations considered him a hostage and his plight went largely unreported. Mrs. Rabhan objected to calling her son a hostage. ``He was a prisoner, but he was not a hostage,'' she said. ``Nothing was offered for him and that made it harder (to win his release).'' According to letters he managed to get out of Iran, Rabhan was physically abused and his weight once fell by 44 pounds. He spent part of his imprisonment in solitary confinement in a windowless cell, the letters said. ``His physical condition is good,'' said Ms. Jacobson, who said she has spoken to her brother by phone. Pattis, 53, was arrested after the satellite ground communications system he was working on was bombed by Iraq in 1986 during the gulf war.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Sends Troops Into Diplomatic Residences; Britain Promises Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 29th graf pvs to UPDATE with American women and children from Kuwait arriving in London; pickup 30th graf pvs, `Hundreds of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA5, LaserColor DHA105
DOC.TEXT: Iraq turned up the heat Friday on diplomats refusing to leave embassies in occupied Kuwait, while Western nations promised more soldiers, tanks and ships for the military machine confronting Iraq. American troops fired a warning shot at an Iraqi tanker, then boarded it briefly before allowing it to proceed when they found it held no ``prohibited cargo,'' a U.S. Navy spokesman said. Americans troops fired twice before at Iraqi ships and boarded another on Sept. 4, when a tea-laden Iraqi-flagged freighter refused to divert its course. In Kuwait, Iraqi troops stormed the French ambassador's residence, seizing four citizens, including a diplomat, the French Foreign Ministry said. Troops also burst into the Belgian compound and the Canadian ambassador's residence. The consuls from the United States and four other nations were briefly detained. The incidents were the most serious confrontations involving diplomats in the emirate since Iraq ordered the embassies closed Aug 24. President Bush said the raids and brief detention of the American consul, who represents U.S. interests in Kuwait City, were a ``clear violation of international law.'' Iraq denied its soldiers entered the foreign compounds, which it referred to as ``former diplomatic missions.'' The official Iraqi News Agency said the troops were under strict orders not to enter the compounds. At least 17 embassies in Kuwait have defied an Iraqi order to close, and Baghdad has tried to make life insufferable for diplomats, in several cases surrounding the missions with troops and cutting off power and water. After the raid on the French compound, French President Francois Mitterrand called an emergency Cabinet meeting for Saturday. He said the Iraqi move ``is an aggression, and we will respond to it.'' While Iraq bore down on defiant diplomats, military pressure built on Iraq. Britain said Friday it would send an armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops to the Persian Gulf. British Defense Secretary Tom King said another squadron of Tornado ground attack aircraft and additional air defense aircraft would also be sent. The British forces mark the first dispatch of tanks and significant ground troops by any Western country besides the United States since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of oil-wealthy Kuwait. Canada on Friday committed a dozen fighter jets and a total of 450 fliers and ground crew. ``This is not a conflict between Arabs and the West, nor is it a conflict between Iraq and the United States,'' said Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. ``It is Saddam Hussein against the civilized world.'' Several other nations, including West Germany, Italy, Belgium and South Korea, pledged either money or equipment Friday to support the multinational contingent in the gulf. Japan, facing allegations it has been too tightfisted during the crisis, pledged $3 billion on top of $1 billion in non-military aid. Meanwhile, the U.N. sanctions on trade with Iraq were taking their toll on the Iraqi economy. The ruling Baath Party newspaper Al-Tharwa said that starting Saturday, Iraqis will be limited to three pieces of bread a day. Rationing of sugar, rice, cooking oil, soap and detergent began in some neighborhoods earlier this month. The 6-week-old Middle East crisis also was taking its toll on the U.S. economy. The government announced Friday that wholesale prices shot up 1.3 percent in August. The Labor Department blamed virtually the entire increase on higher oil costs since Iraq's invasion, which led to a 4 million barrel daily shortfall of oil worldwide and pushed fuel prices up by about 20 percent. Oil prices moved higher Friday, to $32 a barrel. Bush, meanwhile, asked Congress for $1.9 billion more to cover the costs of deploying the 150,000 U.S. troops in the Middle East. Operation Desert Shield is costing Washington an estimated $1 billion a month, officials have said. Iraq has massed an estimated 265,000 troops along or near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia since Saddam sent his forces into the emirate in a dispute over oil, land and money. Saudi officers have told of hundreds of Iraqis defecting from the forces in Kuwait. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, said Friday he had no solid numbers but was sure some had abandoned their posts. He said some were sent back with food and water and told to convey the message that ``things are pretty good over here.'' The raids on the diplomatic compounds in Kuwait appeared designed to intimidate diplomats who have remained in their embassies to symbolize their rejection of Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. The diplomats also are trying to provide some protection for their citizens trapped there. Iraqi soldiers forced their way into the French ambassador's residence early Friday and seized four French citizens, including the military attache. The diplomat was later released, but the whereabouts of the other three was not known. At the Canadian compound, troops entered and briefly detained the consuls from the United States, Britain, Ireland, Australia and Canada, who were meeting there. Canada issued a formal protest with Iraq. Soldiers also entered Belgium's diplomatic compound in Kuwait and ordered the two remaining diplomats to leave, officials said in Brussels. The soldiers left after the diplomats fled to the ambassador's residence nearby. A day earlier, the Dutch government announced a similar incident at its diplomatic residence in Kuwait but refused to provide details or say when the incursion occurred. About 2,200 Americans remain captive in Iraq and Kuwait, and some Western men have been transferred to strategic Iraqi installations to deter attacks by Western forces. Many Western women and children have been allowed to leave Iraq and Kuwait on chartered flights in recent weeks. An Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 chartered by the U.S. government flew 382 foreigners, most of them Americans, to London, the British Foreign Office said. They were to depart for Baltimore on Saturday. Hundreds of thousands of refugees from Arab and Asian nations have fled Iraq and Kuwait though Jordan and Turkey, straining the already tight resources of both nations. In a late-night session Thursday, the U.N. Security Council voted 13-2 on the U.S.-sponsored resolution to allow food shipments to Iraq only to alleviate ``human suffering.'' Cuba and Yemen opposed the measure, saying all food should be allowed in. Early Friday, the council's committee on sanctions approved a request by India to send a ship loaded with 11,000 tons of food to Kuwait to feed about 120,000 stranded Indian citizens. U.S. diplomatic efforts to isolate Iraq moved ahead. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Syrian President Hafez Assad. Syria, Iraq's archenemy, is likely to send 15,000 more troops to the gulf, Western diplomatic sources said Friday on condition of anonymity. Syria has 3,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia and 1,000 in the United Arab Emirates as part of the multinational force. In other developments: -The West German government - prevented by its constitution from deploying forces outside the NATO area - said it had given the United States a list of more than 50 merchant ships that could be used to transport American troops to the gulf. -The Norwegian government offered to help carry fuel and supplies to U.S. warships enforcing the economic sanctions and increase its aid to refugees fleeing the crisis to about $11 million. - Italy said it would send an additional warship and eight Tornado fighter-planes to the gulf region. Italy already has contributed five ships. - Saudi officers have told of hundreds of Iraqis defecting from the forces in Kuwait. Schwarzkopf, the U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, said Friday he had no solid numbers but was sure some had abandoned their posts. He said some were sent back with food and water and told to convey the message that ``things are pretty good over here.''

DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 19th graf, The Republicans, to CORRECT `livestock feed' to `feedstock'
DOC.HEAD: Republicans Say Leaks Are Threatening Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Angry Republican budget negotiators accused Democrats on Friday of giving reporters details of privately offered GOP tax proposals and said the disclosures were threatening deficit-reduction talks. ``We are trying to do a difficult job in cooperation with our Democratic colleagues,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said on the Senate floor. ``It is not going to work if this garbage keeps piling up day after day.'' Dole spoke as bargainers began their second week of confidential talks at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, just outside Washington. They spent much of Friday's session complaining about the leaks, said one official who asked to not be identified. ``The mood was basically ill-will,'' the official said. After a spurt of movement earlier in the week toward a package saving $50 billion next year and $500 billion through 1995, progress has slowed. ``Up and down like a roller coaster,'' was how President Bush described the talks. Republican leaders angrily took to the Senate floor Friday after some reporters obtained copies of analyses of tax proposals Democrats and Republicans have made at the negotiations. The Associated Press received the data from sources who demanded anonymity. The studies - performed by Congress' nonpartisan Joint Tax Committee - showed that GOP tax proposals would raise taxes by $4.1 billion on people who earn $50,000 a year or less. They would cut taxes by $11 billion on those with higher incomes. The analysis said the proportionately largest tax increase - 2.6 percent - would go to people who earn less than $10,000 annually. The biggest tax cut, 5.5 percent, would go to those who earn $200,000 or more a year. The Democratic plan would cut taxes by $4 billion for people earning $20,000 or less annually, and boost them by $26.8 billion by anyone else, the study said. People with incomes surpassing $200,000 yearly would shoulder the greatest burden, a 6.7 percent tax boost. Republicans complained that the disclosures of confidential proposals are designed to make the GOP look bad. ``There is a deliberate effort by some on the other side ... to cast this as Republicans for the rich and they are for everybody else,'' Dole said. ``I am not certain we ought to continue to negotiate on this basis.'' GOP lawmakers also warned that the leaks could make it harder for a budget-cutting plan to be crafted. ``We have to make some tough choices, and so occasionally somebody puts a very tough proposition on the table,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M. ``That's courage. But there won't be much courage out there if the next day that tough proposition is all over the country.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, condemned the leaks but added: ``The leaks have not all been one way.'' One of the biggest remaining disputes is over the Bush plan to slash the capital gains tax rate. The president wants to drop the maximum tax rate on sales of property from 33 percent to 15 percent, a move he says will increase government revenues by encouraging transactions. Democrats say the idea is a money-loser whose main beneficiaries would be the wealthy, and are demanding higher income tax rates on the rich in return. The Republicans have proposed a penny-a-gallon tax on all petroleum products except feedstock and limiting the deductibility of state and local income taxes to $10,000. Democrats have suggested an 11-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax increase and a 4 percent tax on other forms of energy above its current level of 9 cents. Both sides have offered to tax luxury items such as expensive cars and to increase alcohol and tobacco levies. The negotiators planned to take Saturday off and return to work Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Ethnic Albanians Die in Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Two more ethnic Albanians were killed overnight and another policeman seriously injured in rising violence in the southern Serbian province of Kosovo, police said Friday. Meanwhile, Belgrade television reported the arrest of an unspecified number of ethnic Albanian deputies to the disbanded Kosovo parliament who had taken part in an illegal meeting this month. A police statment, carried by the state news agency Tanjug, said the violence occurred when a police patrol tried to stop a car on a road near Kosovo's capital, Pristina. The occupants of the vehicle reportedly opened fire, seriously injuring one policeman. The other policeman returned fire and killed the two attackers, both members of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority, which is struggling for autonomy from Serbia. The deaths brought the number of ethnic Albanians killed the past 24 hours to four. Three policeman have been injured. Serbs dominate the security forces following Serbia's assumption of direct rule in Kosovo and the firing of thousands of ethnic Albanian policemen. Police raided an ethnic Albanian village north of Pristina in search of arms Thursday, prompting a gun battle that left two Albanians dead and two policemen wounded, according to Tanjug. More than 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes since March 1989, when Serbia severely curbed the self-rule Kosovo enjoyed under the 1974 constitution. Serbia says the measures were needed to protect the Slav minority in Kosovo, an ancient Serbian heartland, from ethnic Albanian harassment. On Thursday, Tanjug reported that Kosovo's parliament, dissolved by Serbia after it proclaimed independence in early July, met secretly Sept. 7, adopting a constitution and proclaiming a separate republic of Kosovo. It said 111 deputies attended the session. Belgrade television said police, acting on orders from Serbian authorities, on Friday detained ``a number of deputies'' who have taken part in the ``illegal'' parliamentary session, and are looking for other delegates who will face criminal charges for ``hostile activities against the state.'' The declaration has no legal validity, Serbian authorities said. They called for ``tough legal action'' against ethnic Albanian ``nationalists and separatists'' who took part in the session. Serbian authorities claim ethnic Albanians are seeking to merge Kosovo with neighboring Albania. The six Yugoslav republics are virtually independent states. According to the nation's constitution, they can declare independence from Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Dallas Police Chief Pleads Innocent to Perjury Charge
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Police Chief Mack Vines pleaded innocent to perjury Friday, telling reporters the charge was the result of a ``misunderstanding.'' Vines, who was fired after his indictment Wednesday, said he hopes to remain in law enforcement somewhere in the Dallas area. District Judge Joe Kendall said he would move the trial from Dallas because of publicity. He allowed Vines to remain free on his own recognizance. ``Frankly, Chief, I don't believe that you can get a fair trial in this town,'' Kendall said. Vines is accused of lying to a panel that investigated the firing of a police officer who shot an unarmed Mexican man to death last year. An administrative judge ordered the officer, Patrick LeMaire, reinstated this summer, but LeMaire did not return to the Dallas force. The misdemeanor perjury charge alleges that Vines lied to the panel about a conversation he had with his assistant, Greg Holliday, on Aug. 2. Holliday said Vines called him the night before he was scheduled to appear before the panel and tried to influence his testimony. Vines told the panel he had not discussed testimony before the panel with anyone. Holliday told City Manager Jan Hart about the conversation and she suspended both men with pay. Holliday later was reinstated. Vines said he was taken aback by his firing, since he thought the police department was making progress in community relations under his leadership. He had been police chief for two years. ``I felt that we were going along well and mending bridges and building new bridges,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Find Apartment Used by Irish Republican Army
DOC.TEXT: Investigators seized an apartment that was used by the outlawed Irish Republican Army in West Germany, prosecutors said Friday. The abandoned apartment was found last week, but no arrests were made, said Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the Federal Prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe. Foerster declined to say how authorities discovered the apartment had been rented by the IRA. But security officials in Hanover said investigators traced the apartment through a set of keys confiscated from an IRA suspect arrested in the Netherlands this summer. The officials, who spoke on condition they not be named, declined to identify the suspect by name or provide details, other than that he rented the apartment pretending to be an American. The IRA has carried out a series of attacks against the British military in Western Europe as part of its campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. On June 2, British Army Maj. Michael John Dillon-Lee was shot to death as he returned to his home in Dortmund, 145 miles south of Hanover.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Holds First High-Level Meeting with Israelis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met two Israeli ministers Friday in the highest-level contact between the two countries since the Soviet Union broke diplomatic relations in 1967. Gorbachev met in the Kremlin with Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai and Science Minister Yuval Neeman, the official news agency Tass said. The Israeli delegation, invited by the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry, reportedly is discussing plans to build a passenger plane with Soviet, Israeli and U.S. participation. The Israelis also reportedly had a proposal to send Israeli produce to the Moscow area. Modai belongs to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. Neeman, a nuclear scientist and longtime head of Israel's space agency, leads the ultra-rightist Tehiya Party. Shamir aide Avi Pazner said in Israel that it was the first time an Israeli minister had met a Soviet leader since ties were broken after the Middle East war. Over the last three years, the two countries have exchanged diplomatic missions and relations have improved. Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze were to meet this month during the U.N. General Assembly in New York, possibly to discuss restoration of full diplomatic relations. Jewish emigration to Israel from the Soviet Union has vastly expanded in recent years - 150,000 Soviet immigrants are expected this year alone. Soviet support for its former Arab clients, such as Iraq, has diminished. Gorbachev mentioned the plane program on Soviet television after his meeting this week with President Bush. American oil tycoon Armand Hammer is backing the program, in which Soviet-made Ilyushin-96 and Tupolev-144 aircraft would be refitted in Israel with Israeli-designed avionics and U.S.-built engines. Hammer, 92, who has close personal ties with many Soviet leaders, said the first prototype could be ready by 1995.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Guerrilla Leaders Arrive in Amman in Major Shift
DOC.TEXT: Two leftist Palestinian guerrilla leaders arrived in the capital Friday on their first official visit in 20 years to attend a conference expected to produce a declaration of support for Iraq. Their arrival marks a major shift in Jordan's ties with radical Palestinian factions, which had been banned for two decades in this moderate kingdom. One of the leaders, George Habash, heads the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the second-largest faction in the Palestine Liberation Organization. He was in Jordan briefly last week on his way to Iraq but did not meet with any officials. The other, Nayef Hawatmeh, heads the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine. That faction ranks third after Habash's and Fatah, the mainstream group headed by PLO chairman Yasser Arafat. Hawatmeh drove in Friday from Damascus, Syria, and Habash flew in from Baghdad, Iraq. They were to attend this weekend's conference of leftist organizations from throughout the Arab world, a PLO official said. The conference is expected to result in a declaration of support for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in his confrontation with U.S.-led forces in the Persian Gulf. Hawatmeh will spend a few days in Jordan before traveling to neighboring Iraq, the PLO official said without being more specific. Palestinian sources have said Habash, who spent nearly two weeks in Iraq, has moved his headquarters to Baghdad after a falling-out with his former Syrian backers. Syria, Iraq's archrival, has committed thousands of troops to the U.S.-led buildup against Iraq. Jordan has refused to provide soldiers and tried to settle the crisis with diplomacy. It is not clear if Hawatmeh, who had been cautious not to commit himself either way on the gulf issue, also has important differences with Syria. His criticism of Saddam after the annexation of Kuwait had led to a mutiny in his ranks by members who demanded unequivocal support of Iraq in line with the PLO mainstream. During their stay in Jordan, the two Marxist leaders will confer with King Hussein and other Jordanian and Palestinian leaders. Hawatmeh, 57, and Habash, 64, had not visited Jordan since the 1970 clashes between Hussein's Bedouin army and the guerrillas. One of the main causes of the showdown, widely known as ``Black September,'' was the hijacking of three airliners by Habash's guerrillas. Although they are radicals, the two guerrilla leaders have been committed to Arafat's policies to renounce terrorism and recognize Israel's right to exist. That put them more in harmony with Jordan's stand on the Arab-Israeli conflict. In addition, the refusal of Jordan to join in the military buildup against Iraq has bolstered Jordanian relations with the PLO. More than half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families. They fled their homeland after creation of the Jewish state in 1948 and the 1967 Israeli occupation of West Bank and Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Says Swap Discussed for Release of Waite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT spelling of Al-Shiraa, Thathem. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Britain's ambassador has held talks with Lebanon's leading Shiite Moslem cleric on a plan for swapping Anglican church envoy Terry Waite for a Shiite cleric held by Israel, a magazine reported Friday. Al-Shiraa magazine said the talks were held Wednesday between Ambassador David Thathem and Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah and focused on ``details of releasing the British hostage Terry Waite in return for the release of Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid.'' The story was not attributed to any source. Al-Shiraa received international attention for breaking the story of secret U.S. arms sales to Iran in 1986 in return for the release of American hostages. Its recent reports on Western captives held mainly by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon have not been accurate. Fadlallah, the reputed mentor of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, called the magazine report ``a lie.'' The British Embassy in Lebanon could not be reached for comment. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said: ``I don't even know whether the ambassador did meet him. It's possible. The ambassador is engaged on a whole series of calls there - he doesn't report them all. It sounds like pure speculation to me.'' The magazine said: ``The British ambassador asked Fadlallah to give him time to consult the British government on the offer. Thathem was given 10 days to come back with the British reply.'' It gave no other details. Helicopter-borne Israeli troops kidnapped Obeid, a Hezbollah cleric, from his southern Lebanon village of Jibsheet in 1989. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella group for the various Shiite factions holding most of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. Waite, 51, personal emissary of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, disappeared on Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his west Beirut hotel for a rendezvous with hostage holders. No group has claimed his kidnapping. Former Irish hostage Brian Keenan said shortly after his release last month that he has seen Waite. The Western captives held in Lebanon, in addition to Waite, are three other Britons, six Americans, two West Germans and an Italian. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Raid European Embassies, Seize French Citizens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with further Iraqi comment and response from French government, INSERT 2 grafs after 4th pvs, `Iraq's official...' Pickup 5th pvs, `There was...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops raided the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait on Friday, briefly detaining five Western consuls, capturing four French citizens and provoking calls for retaliation. One of the four, France's military attache, was freed after several hours. French President Francois Mitterrand called an emergency Cabinet meeting for Saturday, saying the raid ``is an aggression, and we will respond to it.'' ``We will have to decide and show very clearly our obligations,'' Mitterrand said. Iraq's official news agency denied Iraqi soldiers stormed the compounds, which it referred to as ``former diplomatic missions in the province of Kuwait.'' Since invading and annexing Kuwait in August, Iraq has referred to it as an Iraqi province. Iraq's ambassador to France, Abdul Razzak al Hachimi, accused the French in a television interview of seeking a pretext to escalate tensions. Daniel Bernard, spokesman for the French Foreign Ministry, responded to the Iraqi comments: ``It would suffice to see the state of the ambassador's residence, which was completely sacked and pillaged by Iraqi soldiers.'' There was no word on the fate of the three French civilians seized with the attache, Col. Edouard Crespin. They had been hiding in the embassy compound to avoid being taken hostage. The Canadian Embassy in Paris said special Iraqi forces entered the ambassador's residence, which is part of the compound, before dawn. The consul was briefly detained but later released, along with consuls from the United States, Ireland, Britain and Australia, according to a Canadian diplomat in Washington. The consuls had been meeting to discuss the evacuation of additional Westerners from Kuwait, said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Belgian officials said three Iraqi soldiers entered Belgium's diplomatic compound and ordered the two remaining diplomats to leave the embassy. The soldiers left after the diplomats fled into the ambassador's adjacent residence. The Belgian Foreign Ministry said the intrusion was ``an unacceptable act going against all international laws.'' The Netherlands disclosed that Iraqi troops had forced their way into its ambassador's residence in Kuwait earlier this week. It said Iraq's ambassador was summoned to hear a ``sharp protest.'' France vigorously protested the Iraqi action, and the European Community called it ``intolerable.'' French political leaders demanded retaliation, and some called for an emergency session of the U.N. Security Council. No specific moves were discussed, but there was speculation a response could entail the Iraqi Embassy in Paris, which is still operating normally. NATO chief Manfred Woerner, on an official visit to Poland, called the incursion into the French compound ``another outrageous violation of international law.'' In Brussels, the European Community called on Iraq to release the French citizens and respect the 1961 Vienna Convention on the inviolability of diplomatic missions. After Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the oil-rich nation, Baghdad ordered embassies in Kuwait closed, saying the nation was part of Iraq territory. Iraqi troops surrounded the missions, and power and water were cut to many in an effort to force their closure, but 17 embassies have defied the Iraqi order. American and British officials denied rumors their embassies had also been attacked. ``We have been in contact with the embassy and reports that troops overran the embassy are not true,'' said a State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The situation hasn't changed since yesterday. Water and electricity are cut off but they have supplies.'' The staffs of more than 30 other foreign missions have left since the Aug. 24 deadline, but some of the countries insist their embassies technically remain open. The French Foreign Ministry said troops entered the residence of the French ambassador about 7 a.m. Friday, taking Crespin and three others to an undisclosed location. Iraqi authorities had earlier cut off water and electricity to the French Embassy in Kuwait and at one point knocked down part of its wall. The ambassador's residence and the embassy are separate buildings. The French ambassador has been out of Kuwait since the invasion and a half-dozen diplomats continue to staff the French Embassy, headed by the charge d'affaires, Jean-Pierre Galtier. ``This is a very serious violation of the Vienna Convention,'' a French Foreign Ministry spokesman said. ``This is a new intolerable attack to international rights and the integrity of the person.'' The Persian Gulf crisis reversed 15 years of close ties between Iraq and France, which had been Baghdad's top Western arms supplier and a major trading partner. Since the crisis began, France has sent the second-largest naval force to the region after the United States to help enforce U.N. sanctions against Iraq. France has an estimated 400 citizens remaining in Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Police Search Swamps and Woods, Attempt to Plug Leaks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4, `Some objects...', to ADD objects found, searches ending. SUBS 8th graf, Similar searches...', to CORRECT victim to Tracy Paules sted Powell.
DOC.TEXT: Searchers waded through alligator-infested swamps and scoured dense woods in humid 90-degree heat Friday, looking for evidence in the grisly slayings of five college students. Searchers looking for body parts and other evidence concentrated on wilderness areas near the three apartments where the bodies of five students were found slain almost three weeks ago. Rusty knives, metal, paper products and clothing were among the items found. Officials said it will take lab work and analysis to determine if they are connected to the slayings. ``It's right on target,'' police Lt. Sadie Darnell said of the searches that ended Friday afternoon. Polk County authorities, meanwhile, announced that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement had taken ``body samples'' from Stephen Bates, 30, a burglary suspect jailed in Bartow. Bates is one of the two suspects publicly identified by police. Six other people also are considered suspects. Near the Williamsburg Apartments, Gainesville police and Navy searchers combed dense woods 30 yards behind the apartment where the bodies of the first two victims - Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17 - were found Aug. 26. Similar searches were going on behind the Gatorwood Apartments, about a mile away, where the bodies of Manny Taboada, 23, and Tracy Paules, 23, were found Aug. 28, and outside the apartment where Christa Hoyt, 18, was slain. At the Williamsburg site, searchers kept a close watch for a 4{-foot-long alligator that slithered away when they came near. Searchers using dogs, metal detectors and probes examined Hogtown Creek and wooded areas Thursday around the Hawaiian Village Apartment where suspect Edward Lewis Humphrey lived. Investigators already have taken blood and hair samples from him at the Brevard County Jail, where he has been held since days after the slayings on unrelated charges that he beat up his grandmother. ``We have a lot of information on Mr. Humphrey, but we have not connected him to these murders,'' Darnell said. While the search continued for evidence and suspects, two agents from the Florida Department of Law Enforcement were attempting to find the source of leaks to the news media from the 175-person task force investigating the killings. Investigators have complained that the leaks, particularly about the crime scenes and the mutilation of the bodies, have hampered their investigation. ``The damage to the investigation has not been extensive, but there has been some,'' Darnell said. Lie-detector tests may be used, and those found to have given out unauthorized information could face disciplinary action and criminal charges, Darnell said. ``We are taking this very seriously,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Elbows Out Zionism Issue, Diplomats Say
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials have suspended their effort to scrap a 1975 General Assembly resolution equating Zionism with racism because they need Arab support in the Persian Gulf, diplomats said Friday. The United States is trying to avoid aggravating Arab animosity toward Israel at a time when it needs Arab support to forge a united front against Iraq, the diplomats said on condition of anonymity. U.S. officials are not expected to raise the Zionism issue in the next session of the General Assembly, which opens Tuesday. Instead, the session is expected to be dominated by the gulf crisis. Ronald I. Spiers, undersecretary-general for General Assembly affairs, told reporters Friday that he had ``seen no sign'' of a U.S. initiative to repeal the Zionism resolution. Israel and its ally, the United States, view the measure as a symbol of U.N. antipathy toward Israel. He said that, given the Persian Gulf crisis, it is unlikely the United States would turn its attention to the Zionism resolution unless it was assured of winning broad support. Despite the diplomats' comments, a State Department official in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, insisted the U.S. administration is firmly committed to repealing the resolution as soon as possible. The official said there has been a continuing worldwide diplomatic effort to mobilize support. Yuval Rotem, spokesman for the Israeli Mission, said Friday: ``We are going to continue our utmost efforts to repeal this.''

DOC.HEAD: Martin Criticizes Simon's Reported Aid to Indebted Cooking School
DOC.TEXT: Republican challenger Lynn Martin on Friday called on Sen. Paul Simon to return any campaign contributions from trade schools, following Simon's intervention on behalf of a cooking school owing more than $150,000 in student loan refunds. The Illinois Democrat urged the Higher Education Assistance Foundation to ease up on the Culinary Institute of Washington, which at one time owed more than $500,000 to the foundation.
