Details of Simon's efforts were revealed during congressional hearings in Washington on the guaranteed student loan program. The foundation is the nation's largest student loan guarantor and is trying to stave off bankruptcy brought on by a heavy portfolio of delinquent trade school loans. After Simon intervened on the school's behalf, school owner Barkev Kibarian made two contributions worth $1,000 each to Simon's re-election campaign. Simon spokesman David Carle said the contributions were used for a fund-raiser for the senator last Nov. 8. Carle said he did not know how much was raised. Simon released a statement saying he was not pleased with his staff's conduct in the case and would consider donating the money Kibarian raised at the fund-raiser to the U.S. Treasury. Simon first wrote loan foundation Chairman Richard Hawk in March 1989, suggesting Hawk meet with Kibarian to discuss school problems turned up in an audit. Five days later, a Simon aide wrote to the school's consultant and agent, saying she had told another Simon staff member of an ``offer to host a fund-raiser'' and said the other staff member would be in touch, according to documents released in the hearings. On Nov. 3, Simon wrote Hawk, urging him to consider re-scheduling the school's payment so it would not exceed $7,000 a month. Later that month, Hawk told Simon that he would lower the payment from $20,000 a month to $15,000 but not go to $7,000.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Killed on Videotape Gets Death Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose killing of a man was videotaped received a death sentence despite her claims it was either kill or be killed. Deidre Hunt, 21, said her manipulative boss forced her to fatally gun down Mark Kevin Ramsey, 19, while the victim was tied to a tree. The videotape viewed in court showed her fire three shots, then grab Ramsey by the hair and deliver a final shot to the temple. The condemned woman bowed her head and wept when Circuit Judge S. James Foxman imposed the death penalty Thursday. The judge called the killing ``cold, calculated and premeditated.'' Hunt's former boss, Kosta Fotopoulos, 31, faces multiple murder charges and was accused of videotaping Ramsey's killing. ``I was confronted with a decision that Kosta Fotopoulos had absolutely already made,'' Hunt said Thursday. ``It was my decision of living by shooting Mark Kevin Ramsey or dying with Mark Kevin Ramsey. My decision was a choice to survive and I chose to live. '' Hunt had pleaded guilty to murder charges in the deaths of Ramsey and Bryan Chase, 18. She also was sentenced to six life prison terms for two counts of attempted murder, two counts of solicitation to murder and one count each of conspiracy to murder and armed burglary. Chase was killed after allegedly shooting Fotopoulos' wife, Lisa. Hunt, allegedly at Fotopoulos' bidding, hired Chase to kill Mrs. Fotopoulos so they could inherit her wealth along with $700,000 in life insurance. Fotopoulos allegedly shot Chase after the 18-year-old broke into the house Nov. 4 and shot Mrs. Fotopoulos in the head. Prosecutors say he was shot to prevent exposure of the plot. Mrs. Fotopoulos recovered from her wound. Hunt apologized to the victims' families Thursday and blamed Fotopoulos. ``He's evil, vicious and a professional assassin who eliminates human beings for a living and for his own personal gain,'' she said. ``He didn't just eliminate others' lives, he eliminated minds as well.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan President Announces Reconcilation Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro announced Friday that national reconciliation talks will begin next week. She said the negotiations, aimed at solving severe economic problems and relieving heavy political stress in her 5-month-old administration, will begin Thursday. ``The negotiators will be the workers, producers, business operators and central government representatives,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. Mrs. Chamorro appealed for participation by all parties. But it was not clear if the leftist Sandinistas, the country's strongest political force, would take part. In a statement Thursday, they said, ``Negotiation is a necessity for everyone so that there will be lasting peace and stability in Nicaragua, but the government has the main responsibility for creating the minimum conditions for this effort to have the results we all want.'' Mrs. Chamorro spoke Friday to thousands of students gathered in the central square of Managua, the capital, on the 134th anniversary of Nicaraguan independence. Her conservative, U.S.-backed coalition was elected to replace the Sandinista Front party administration of former president Daniel Ortega. The advent of the new government brought an end to the U.S.-funded war between the Contra rebels and the Sandinista administration. However, Mrs. Chamorro's administration has been beset by economic problems and political opposition. It has been forced to devalue the Nicaraguan currency 35 times. It has also faced two crippling general strikes led by Sandinista sympathizers.

Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter, in style and substance early in his Senate confirmation hearings, is proving what he had to: he's no Robert H. Bork. Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter, who spent many hours watching videotapes of Bork's 1987 performance, is using his appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee to distance himself from the lingering memory of Bork's defeated high court nomination. To many, Bork the Senate witness seemed a bloodless academic who talked about the ``intellectual feast'' Supreme Court service would provide. He sometimes bristled at pointed questions and ignored some softballs pitched by sympathetic senators. In contrast, many of Souter's responses Thursday were embellished with personal anecdotes. And he has won praise from two committee members for being ``a listener.'' ---= NEW YORK (AP) - An appeals court lifted a ban on publication of a book about Israel's secret service, reversing a judge's order to halt distribution at the request of Israel. And the publisher says sales will resume immediately. Israel's claim that the book endangers its intelligence agents ``has not been sufficiently supported,'' the Appellate Division of New York Supreme Court ruled unanimously Thursday. On Wednesday, Judge Michael Dontzin had issued a temporary restraining order barring publisher St. Martin's Press from distributing the book, titled ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer.'' The Israeli government filed a lawsuit claiming the book could imperil agents of the agency called Mossad by blowing their cover. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Sharon Pratt Dixon is a political unknown, but the woman who is favored to become the next mayor of the nation's capital is hardly a political novice. The probable successor to Marion Barry, Dixon scored a stunning victory Tuesday in the city's Democratic primary, her first bid for public office. ``She didn't have the kind of money in the primary to put out those television commercials, `This is Sharon Pratt Dixon, and this is who I am,''' said Julius Hobson, a longtime observer of city politics. ``But it would be a mistake to call her a political newcomer - she doesn't have a real day-to-day record, but she does have a long involvement in local and national politics,'' said Hobson. ---= PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - After 186 years of authoritarian rule, mostly out of the barrel of a gun, democracy has again been deferred on this impoverished Caribbean island. The postponement of elections has threatened to unravel the caretaker civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot and raised new doubts about whether Haiti can succeed in its march toward democracy. ``She cannot make good on her pledge to hold genuine elections, so her administration has lost its reason to exist,'' said Gerard Pierre-Charles, one of Haiti's most respected political analysts. ``We are sliding inexorably towards the temptation of a military coup.'' The independent Electoral Council, charged by the constitution with organizing free and fair balloting, said last week it was postponing the Nov. 4 elections until sometime in December for lack of funds. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - Steven Balourdos was tired of the glitz along the city's Magnificent Mile, so he did what he used to do back home in Greece. He planted tomatoes. Some of his neighbors are less than enthusiastic, but Balourdos says he's standing by his fruit. ``I feel very strongly to do what I do back home,'' Balourdos said Thursday. He emigrated from a tomato-growing region in the 1950s and runs a business on Michigan Avenue. Earlier this summer, he planted about 30 tomato plants in square granite containers on the sidewalk outside a high-rise where he runs his second-story real estate development company. Only four spindly plants remain. The rest have been ripped out by unknown foes. Planters outside other buildings on the street contain exotic flowers, neatly pruned trees and shrubs.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv17
For release Mon PMs, Sept 17 and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Parmer Holds Gramm's Washington Experience Against Him In Senate Race
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Hugh Parmer is out to turn Sen. Phil Gramm's Washington experience against him, depicting the GOP senator as part of the problem on issues ranging from the budget to the savings and loan mess. ``There is a general discontent with incumbents among voters,'' says Parmer, the campaign challenger who trails Gramm in both public opinion polls and fund raising. ``I don't think the people much like the results of what's gone on in Washington for the last few years.'' Parmer, a 51-year-old state senator who is a Fort Worth attorney and the city's former mayor, maintains Gramm is a conservative extremist who has lost touch with the values of Texans. ``Sen. Gramm's media campaign in which he basically identified himself as one of the important movers and shakers in Washington in recent years was a double-edged sword,'' Parmer said. ``It has potential to damage him, given the hostility to the guys that are in. ``They can't get the budget fixed. They can't get the savings and loan problem fixed. They can't get the trade problem fixed.'' But Parmer's approach runs the risk of drawing favorable attention to Gramm's leadership role in Congress. While budget deficits have ballooned, Gramm's name is affixed to the key law aimed at alleviating the problem, Gramm-Rudman. It mandates spending cuts if deficit targets aren't met. Gramm, a 48-year-old former economics professor, said his role in the national debate on issues such as the budget and trade matters is what the voters expect from him. ``Texans expect the man who sits in Sam Houston's seat to be a national leader,'' Gramm said in an interview. ``But they also expct him to represent the state, to get things done for Texas, and to come back home and listen to their views.'' He touts his support for a strong military, research and high technology programs and investments that advance the ``long-term future of the country.'' But Parmer says Gramm neglects programs for education, health care and aid to the elderly. Gramm bolted from the Democratic Party in 1983, resigning his U.S. House seat. He was re-elected to Congress within a month, becoming the first Republican to represent the central Texas district. Although widely disparaged by Texas' Democratic hierarchy, Gramm is one of the state's most popular politicians and is heavily favored for re-election. Gramm's campaign has raised nearly $14 million, more money than any other U.S. senator seeking re-election. And he has kept a blistering schedule of appearances, raising the GOP's profile in traditionally Democratic Texas. He said he's not just looking to win re-election, but to win with 60 percent of the vote, pulling in votes for other Republicans further down the Texas ballot. Parmer, meanwhile, has raised more than $1.5 million, among the highest totals of any Senate challenger, and is attacking on a wide array of issues. Parmer's TV ads point out Gramm's opposition to federal funding of abortions. The senator has sponsored five constitutional amendments to ban abortion, but now supports the Texas GOP's legislative plan that would allow pregnant women to obtain abortions before the fetus is 20 weeks old. Parmer says the government should leave the abortion decision up to women. Neither candidate is invulnerable on the savings and loan issue, but both are pointing fingers. As a congressman in 1980, Gramm voted to raise deposit insurance and remove geographical lending restrictions. Parmer was in the Texas Senate that deregulated state institutions in a 1983 voice vote. Gramm accepted $86,098 from thrift-related interests during the 1980s, the sixth-highest total in the Senate and fourth-highest for a member of the Senate Banking Committee, a study of campaign contributions by Common Cause found. But Gramm says that ``90 cents out of every dollar of S&L losses were not in federally chartered S&Ls but were in state-chartered S&Ls.'' ``The great bulk of the problem was under his (Parmer's) jurisdiction,'' Gramm said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Mon PMs, Sept 17
$Adv 20
For Release Thurs PMs, Sept 20 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Post-Minimalist Sculptor's Work Conveys Broad Range of Emotion
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Art lovers with a fertile imagination will have a rich field to till as they stroll through sculptor Joel Shapiro's exhibit at the Baltimore Museum of Art. Most of the 25 works are made of simple blocks of wood or bronze, and suggest human or other figures in a wide array of activity and emotion. His ability to create these impressions is what makes the exhibit, ``Joel Shapiro - Tracing the Figure'' a success, said Brenda Richardson, the museum's curator of painting and sculpture. ``Joel is more accessible. It's easier for us to get close to his work,'' said Richardson, who collaborated with the artist in designing the exhibit. The exhibit opened in August and runs through Oct. 7 at the Baltimore Museum of Art, after which it will travel to the Des Moines Art Center and the Center for Fine Arts in Miami. ``Very often when people see a minimalist exhibit, they feel hostile, shut out. Many people feel very remote from it,'' Richardson said. ``That is not the response people have to Shapiro.'' Shapiro, 48, is a New York native who calls himself a post-minimalist. Like the minimalists before him, he uses the most basic of shapes, but unlike them, he goes beyond pure abstraction and provides something more concrete to think about. ``I want the work to be loaded with emotion, loaded with reference, but not to the point where it's gratuitous,'' he said from his summer home and studio in Westport, N.Y. Therefore, Shapiro's sculptures have no faces, only the simplest representations of body parts, and no titles. Still, they succeed in conveying emotion - a tiny man kneeling in supplication; joyful kicking dancers with flailing arms; a walking figure staring at the ground apparently lost in thought. Some stimulate the imagination enough to bring several different ideas to mind. At first glance, a series of painted wood blocks clearly suggest a figure resting on its side with its left foot bent. In another moment or from another angle, the figure disappears and the blocks look more like a model of an apartment building. From one angle, a 7-foot-high bronze piece might suggest a giant bird taking off. From another it could be a strutting drum major. ``He doesn't put into it either a bird or drum major. That's precisely what he wants you to do,'' Richardson said. ``Even as you may grasp a figure, you may lose that figure, especially as you walk around it.'' Shapiro says the images people glean from his sculptures are often different from his own ideas in creating them. He accepts that as the price for displaying art in public. ``I'm open. I think I'm comfortable with people's response to the work as long as they react to it and don't walk away.'' Shapiro's roots offer little on the origins of his art. His father was a doctor, his mother a biochemist. After college, he spent two years in the Peace Corps in the late 1960s. His experience in another culture helped him get a better perspective on his own interests. ``I became an artist because that's what I did best. I chose sculpture because it was very much in the real world and not hanging on a wall.'' Shapiro's work wasn't always as tangible is the work displayed in the exhibit. Before the mid-'70s, he created more inanimate objects, such as a tiny chair, tiny homes, coffins or ladders. They implied the presence of the human form, through its absence. ``There was a point where I avoided using the figure,'' he said. ``Then there was a point where I just abandoned that limitation. I felt that by using figuration . . . I could allow more into the work. Also, it had to do with wanting the work to be more so you would have an almost one-on-one experience with it.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Thurs Sept. 20
$Adv17
For release Mon PMs, Sept. 17, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Putting a Human Face on New Civil Rights Legislation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to fix priority coding
DOC.TEXT: Alan Gersman is a middle-aged, middle-class white man who never dreamed he'd need the protections offered by federal civil rights laws. But in 1988 he lost an important computer records storage contract, and he believes it was because he is Jewish. Group Health Association stored software with Gersman's company for four years and expressed consistent satisfaction with the firm's services, court records say. But the contract was cancelled shortly after an Egyptian employee, prompted by an Iranian supervisor, asked Gersman if he were Jewish. ``It was the first time in my life when I could really identify with a black person,'' said Gersman, 51, co-owner of Computer Security International in suburban Washington. ``I'm really not used to being discriminated against.'' That was only the first shock. The next came when a federal court threw out a lawsuit he filed against GHA. The primary reason: a 1989 Supreme Court ruling that an important post-Civil War civil rights statute, while it protected against bias in hiring, did not cover on-the-job discrimination. Gersman said he found it hard to believe he had no recourse. ``That type of thing is so basic,'' he said. ``I don't know how you could have liberty and the pursuit of happiness'' without it. Gersman, now appealing his case, is one of the human faces behind the Civil Rights Act of 1990. The bill was passed by the House and Senate and is headed toward an uncertain fate this fall at the White House. The legislation is designed to reverse or supersede several restrictive Supreme Court rulings on discrimination, including the one that helped thwart Gersman's suit. The bill would also give many more discrimination victims the right to sue for punitive and compensatory damages; that route currently is open only to victims of racial bias. Civil rights advocates have fought passionately for the bill and at least one respected member of Congress - civil rights movement veteran John Lewis of Georgia - says he won't campaign for anyone who opposed it. But commercial interests and conservatives, including President Bush, contend the bill could lead to quotas and business-busting damage payments. Compromise has proven elusive through months of negotiations, but a last-minute agreement is not out of the question. Bush would much rather sign the bill than veto it and risk alienating the minority groups he has been trying to court. While blacks come to mind as the most obvious beneficiaries of stronger civil rights laws, they certainly would not be the only ones. For it is incorrect to assume, as Gersman did, that ``people have the option to do whatever they want to do... where they're qualified to do the work. Nobody thinks twice about it.'' Studies commissioned by an array of civil rights groups document job environments that are utterly hostile to women, racial minorities or certain religious groups. They also describe the many holes, actual and prospective, that victims can fall through when they try to obtain legal relief, along with writings by judges who say their hands have been tied by the Supreme Court. Carol Zabkowicz of Racine, Wisc. was one victim. She endured three years of sexual harassment so severe that her doctor ordered a two-month medical leave during her second pregnancy in order to ease stress-related gastrointestinal problems and avert a miscarriage. ``There were verbal assaults from some male employees. They called me a variety of names, they asked me to do sexual acts. There were caricatures of myself posted around the warehouse - either nude graffiti or myself engaged in sexual acts with animals or human beings,'' Zabkowicz, 35, recalled of her employment at a West Bend appliances distribution warehouse. A federal judge rejected the company's depiction of the problem as a personality clash and said Zabkowicz had been the victim of ``sustained, malicious and brutal harassment'' that was ``malevolent and outrageous.'' He also said supervisors were well aware of the harassment but did not stop it. The penalty for all of this amounted to a $2,763 check from West Bend to Zabkowicz - back pay for her two-month medical leave. There was no legal avenue to pursue damages for pain, suffering or medical and psychiatric bills, leaving Zabkowicz with what she considered a hollow victory. ``It just seems outrageous that in 1990 this stuff still goes on,'' Zabkowicz said. ``Punitive and compensatory damages would be a strong deterrent to make certain that this does not happen.'' Gary Mason, a cooler repairman at a Coca-Cola bottling plant in Lenexa, Kan., is black and therefore eligible to file for such damages under current law. But he was unable to pursue them due to the new Supreme Court restrictions on workplace protection. ``I was the first black repairman ever hired in the position I had in the cooler department,'' recalled Mason, 35. ``Naturally I started experiencing a lot of racial slurs and remarks and jokes. I was denied promotions, reprimanded for things that I didn't do. From day one, it was a bad atmosphere. The boss didn't even shake my hand.'' A federal judge said Coca-Cola officials ``apparentl said. Meanwhile, according to Mason, the harassment continues. ``I've been reprimanded for serving on jury duty,'' he said. Both Mason and Zabkowicz say they would never have gone to court if supervisors and company officials had responded to their repeated complaints. ``These things occur on their premises and they turn their back to it. That's when people are forced into the position to do something about it,'' Zabkowicz said. ``Thank goodness we do have these laws as an avenue to take. But to me, the laws aren't strong enough.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Mon PMs Sept. 17
$adv17
For Release PMs Monday, Sept. 17
DOC.HEAD: Not the Time to Cut Budget Deficits?
DOC.TEXT: With members of Congress finally working hard to achieve budget cuts, some of the very people who had urged them to do so are having second thoughts. The very idea of cuts is so politically sensitive and economically involved that some of these people speak only in whispers. But what those whispers convey is that now might not be the best time to cut anything but taxes. Events of the past several weeks have conspired to bring about this newer attitude, events such as higher oil prices, additional evidence of a decaying economy, a squeeze on household budgets and a business credit crunch. The weakening economy now worries some of these people more than continued budget overruns, in spite of their having made the latter the biggest economic issue of the past year. The latest job figures have added to the concern. New job creation has fallen abruptly. Unemployment is up, and monthly job gains in private industry so far this year have been off nearly 50 percent from the like period of 1989. Other reports show that the only parts of the economy still growing vibrantly are health care and state and local governments, and each of these presents problems of its own: inflation in health care and bureaucratic growth in government, neither of them designed for a healthy economy. But, ask the whisperers, is now the time to make cuts in government spending? Or even to hold it down? If the private sector economy is withering, what except government spending is available to give it a nudge? Besides, it is said, no matter what Congress or the White House or anyone else wants, spending isn't likely to come down when billions of dollars are being spent on the military action in the Mideast. In a announcement called ``StraightTalk,'' Conference Board economist Gail Fosler states that military and economic uncertainties, combined with high tax burdens, ``will prevent any meaningful action in slashing the deficit.'' Fosler comments that ``federal borrowing will surge over the next two years regardless of what the administration and Congress do to bring down the deficit.'' Those who say Congress shouldn't even try to make the effort aren't declaring their positions nearly as boldly. To do so would brand some of them as turncoats because all year long they have been advocating cuts. But, says one analyst of the economic scene, ``as the Gramm-Rudman deadline of Oct. 1 draws near, the weakening economy threatens to make these budget negotiations an academic excercise.'' That comment comes from John Wright of Wright Investors' Service, who adds that ``clearly, in its current fragile state, the U.S. economy can scarcely tolerate either higher taxes or across-the-board spending cuts.'' But it can hardly afford higher interest rates either, and until Congress reaches some sort of agreement those rates are likely to remain high. That much has been indicated by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Not only does he remain committed to smaller budget deficits, but he seems equally determined to forestall any drop in interest rates until Congress reaches an agreement.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday, Sept. 17.

DOC.HEAD: Adv18
DOC.NOTE: For release Tues AMs, Sept. 18, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Conservative Orrin Hatch Wins Praise for Compassion but Irks Old Backers
LaserPhoto WX10 of Sept. 14
DOC.TEXT: As one of the Senate's staunchest conservatives for a dozen years, Orrin Hatch might be expected to be among lawmakers campaigning to slash federal grants for the arts. But the Utah Republican who spent two years as a Mormon missionary is taking a pass. He shakes his head glumly at moves to curb funding for the National Endowment for the Arts on grounds that some of the money has gone to projects tainted by obscenity. ``No one is more against obscenity and pornography than I am, but I just don't believe that the Congress should impose censorship through the authorization process,'' Hatch said. ``Some of these people, if they had lived in the time of Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo, the Sistine Chapel would never have been painted,'' Hatch says of lawmakers heading the drive. ``They wouldn't allow you to hang a Reubens in the Senate.'' Hatch is scrupulously polite and soft-spoken, although sometimes an emotional side surfaces unexpectedly. When the Senate debated rights for the disabled in July, Hatch was telling how his brother-in-law suffered as a victim of polio. Suddenly, he ``just broke down.'' ``I mean I just wept, tears rolling down my cheeks,'' Hatch recalls. ``I was embarrassed because I don't like people to know that side of me that much.'' From the scourge of the liberals to patron of the arts and other issues irksome to conservatives, Hatch's political persona is undergoing a distinct change. When Hatch arrived in the Senate in 1977, he was immediately accepted as one of the fiercest conservatives to prowl the floor. Over the last two years, though, he's been at odds with old allies more than once. Despite conservative opposition, he spearheaded in 1989 a $1.75 billion-a-year package of child-care grants. He's campaigned for escalation of the battle against AIDS. And he sponsored a Justice Department program aimed at fighting ``hate crimes'' motivated by racial and religious bias. The hate crimes bill put Hatch on a collision course with Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who called it ``the flagship of the gay rights agenda.'' Hatch, 56, scoffs at the notion that he's changed: He remains a supporter of capital punishment, a critic of gun control and an opponent of a major civil rights bill on Capitol Hill whose minority-hiring provision, he says, would inevitably lead to hiring quotas. All the same, a recent poll showed many Utah voters believe he's moved in a more liberal direction. And he's finding increasing favor with lawmakers he once fought. ``He is open on some things,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. ``He has grown, and I hope we can all grow. He was superb on the hate-crimes bill.'' Lean at 6-foot-4, with every silvery hair in place and a taste for conservatively tailored dark suits and blazers, Hatch likes to tell of his humble origins as the son of a Pittsburgh metal lather. ``I grew up on the wrong side of the tracks,'' he says. ``We were poor, poor people.'' He worked as a janitor to help pay his way through Brigham Young University, where he met his wife, Elaine. They have three sons, three daughters and 10 grandchildren. He graduated from the University of Pittsburgh Law School and practiced in that city before returning to Utah. In 1976, he upset incumbent Democratic Sen. Frank Moss, in part with the help of hundreds of Hatches in rural Utah, their numbers a legacy of the heavily Mormon state's polygamous past. Moss and other Democrats, however, blamed rough-and-tumble tactics by New Right conservatives - Washington groups whose trademark was mail-order campaigns designed to rise funds and energize voters around issues such as abortion and school prayer. In the Senate, Hatch is a vocal member of the Judiciary Committee where he ranks second behind Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. But his major post is that of top Republican on the Labor Committee, where he's often at odds with Chairman Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. But frequently, Hatch and Kennedy reach a compromise, as they did on a Hatch bill opposed by some liberals that allows export of pharmaceuticals not yet approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in this country. Indeed, the Hatch record on such matters gives business little to complain about. He is a firm backer of bills to rein in court damages in product liability and medical malpractice lawsuits - major goals of the insurance industry. And he's sponsoring a bill to allow the federal government to pre-empt tough state standards governing pesticides in foods. Hatch scoffs at complaints from liberal consumer groups that his bill would allow unsafe concentrations of pesticides in foods. ``That's not based on science,'' he says. ``That's based on old wives' tales.'' Senate Republicans take little notice of strained ties between Hatch and conservative activists. They hail him as hard-working and effective. ``I'm a real admirer of Orrin Hatch,'' said Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo. ``He undertakes the toughest chores in the Senate because he is the ranking Republican on the Labor Committee,'' Danforth said. ``The issues he involves himself in are often hotly controversial and take up a good deal of the Senate's time, but he does his job with unflappable competence.'' But such testimonials leave hard-core conservatives unmoved. ``He has separated himself from us ... on social welfare legislation, on what we would call gay rights legislation, on a whole range of issues,'' said New Right pioneer Paul Weyrich. Weyrich says Hatch has been shopping for issues to help broaden his support and hopes for an appointment to the U.S. Supreme Court. Indeed, when Justice William Brennan announced his retirement, reporters were quick to corner Hatch and ask if he wanted the post. He said no. Hatch also says he's always been a champion of the underdog and that perhaps his conservative critics just haven't noticed. ``I have always been an advocate of those with disabilities, those who are downtrodden, who really can't help themselves,'' he said. ``What I have a problem with is people who can help themselves but won't.'' At the same time, he says his conservative critics should take a more careful look at his overall record. ``I wonder who they think took the lead in fighting for a lot of the changes around here,'' he said, his voice rising. ``I wonder who they think fought for fairness in the Iran-Contra hearings.'' That view is echoed by writer-activist Patrick McGuigan, author of a recent book on the battle over Robert Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court. McGuigan is an outspoken Hatch admirer, but says many would disagree. ``There are a lot of conservatives who don't know him as well as I do who think Orrin Hatch has gone around the bend,'' says McGuigan. ``They think he isn't a conservative anymore.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues AMs Sept. 18
$adv17
For Release Monday, Sept. 17, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Wall Street's Oil Obsession
DOC.TEXT: Like many other machines that make the economy go, the stock market seems to be running on oil these days. More often than not in recent trading on Wall Street, fluctuations in stock prices have looked like a virtual mirror image of the ups and downs of the oil market. Example: Last Monday, when the Dow Jones industrial average rose about 30 points in early trading as oil prices fell. The Dow's gains abruptly vanished, leaving the average with a 4-point loss for the day, immediately following an afternoon upsurge in oil prices. There is no mystery about the connection investors have been making between the two markets. When the price of oil doubles, as it did this summer from about $15 a barrel to $30-plus, it naturally tends to scramble the economic outlook in the United States and other energy-importing countries. Analysts' earnings estimates have had to be recalculated from scratch, not just in the energy business but in a broad range of other industries, ranging from the airlines and automakers to chemical manufacturing and electric utilities. With all that, however, a casual onlooker might still wonder how the fortunes of stocks in general might become so closely linked to what is happening in the market for a single commodity. Those who see a method in this mania say oil prices carry a special impact in part because of the precarious state of the economy that prevailed before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. They view higher fuel costs as the functional equivalent of a tax increase, draining off large amounts of disposable income at a time when the economy was already running low on supplies of money and credit. ``Prior to the oil shock, we were forecasting a full-scale but moderate recession,'' said Richard Hoey, chief U.S. economist at the investment banking firm of Barclays de Zoete Wedd Inc. in New York. ``In our view, the oil price shock has not precipitated a recession, but rather is likely to make the U.S. recession which had already begun more severe.'' As analysts attempt to determine the potential extent of such an economic slump, each swing up or down in the oil price yields a new result from the equation. At the same time, however, a good many observers believe the recent fixation on oil prices has gone to extremes that are typical of market psychology. Some analysts say the focus on oil provides a handy ``cover story'' while the market adjusts to a business slump that would have happened in any event. ``It is widely believed that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait significantly altered the world outlook for peace and prosperity,'' observed David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``However, the early data for August show no abrupt change in behavior. Unfortunately, the data do show that the pre-crisis pattern of steady decline in activity continued in August.'' Still other market watchers suggest that oil news has kept many people from paying as much heed as they might to other developments of lasting import. ``In the country's fixation on the Persian Gulf, it is easy to miss or ignore many other significant developments,'' said Raymond F. DeVoe Jr. at Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. Among these, he says, one holds the promise of being ``the story of the decade, or even of the postwar period'' - the political and economic upheaval in the Soviet Union. ``The Soviet Union no longer exists, either as a coherent nation or economy,'' DeVoe asserts. ``This stunning fact will dominate world affairs for decades to come after the resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Sept. 17
$Adv16
For Release Sunday, Sept. 16, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: ABSTRACT GLASNOST: Exhibit of Great Russian Painter
DOC.TEXT: One of Russia's great abstract painters of the 20th century, out of favor when ``Socialist realism'' was the only art for the Soviets, gets his biggest exhibit here on Sunday 55 years after his death. Kazimir Severinovich Malevich (pronounced mal-YAY-vitch) never went to prison, as far as anyone can ascertain today. However, the director of the Kiev Art Gallery was given a long sentence for mounting a show of his work. Malevich himself was arrested in 1930 after a trip to the West and questioned about ideologies, deviations and right and left tendencies. His friends burned some of his voluminous writings, just in case. ``He was one of the greatest and most original spokesman of the entire Russian avant-garde,'' Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev wrote in the current catalog for the exhibit ``Kazimir Malevich, 1878-1935.'' Raisa Gorbachev added a tribute of her own. And President Bush, in a letter welcoming the exhibit, wrote: ``The creative forms of Kazimir Malevich may be as complex and varied as the range of human emotions, yet they unite us in our appreciation for his talent and vision.'' Work of these avant-garde artists for decades was confined to the cellars of Soviet museums. Under Gorbachev's policies of openness and reconstruction, the Soviets brought out Malevich's work for a show in 1988. Armand Hammer, the American industrialist who has known Soviet leaders since Lenin, helped get the pictures for the National Gallery of Art. ``The Russians rarely say `nyet' to Hammer,'' explained J. Carter Brown, director the National Gallery. After the exhibition closes at the National Gallery on Nov. 4, it will go to Los Angeles as the inaugural show at the Armand Hammer Museum and Cultural Center. Malevich, the son of a sugar mill manager, produced his first finished painting in 1889, when he was 11. In the early years of the century, he learned in Moscow about the works of the great French Impressionists and post-Impressionists of the period. He painted in versions of west European styles, but always with a distinctive Russian flavor. Some of his works resemble the paintings of Fernand Leger, Piet Mondrian and even the distinctive stylings of Paul Cezanne. Malevich gradually moved away from pictures of recognizable people and objects. World War I was a time of radical art movements in Russia, each with a fanciful name. Though he was asked not to antagonize the public by introducing still another name, Malevich called his own theory ``Suprematism.'' A key painting, which has led to most comment over the years, was simply a black square. Analysts claim to see many things under the unrelieved blackness. Visitors who prefer less abstract art may get more from his earlier and later work. ``Today we have advanced into a new fourth dimension of motion,'' Malevich wrote. ``We have pulled up our consciousness by its roots from the Earth. It is now free to revolve in the infinity of space.'' Angelica Zander Rudenstine, curator of the exhibit, says that by ``Suprematism'' he meant a higher kind of painting than the representation of familiar objects. Malevich joined enthusiastically in the revolutionary movements of 1917. In the first days of the Soviet government it appointed him Commissar for the Preservation of Monuments and Antiquities, especially those in the Kremlin. But when he visited the West in 1929 with paintings for a show in Berlin, he took the precaution of leaving them behind. Many were acquired later by the Stadelijk Museum in Amsterdam and brought to Washington for the current show. Toward the end of his life, Malevich returned to painting recognizable figures. But they were flat and unrealistic, not Socialist realism at all. Some he did in a much earlier style, and put earlier dates on them. His last works were realistic portraits, including a self-portrait in which he wore clothes of the Italian Renaissance. The exhibit will be at the Armand Hammer Museum and Cultural Center in Los Angeles from Nov. 25 to Jan. 13. From Feb. 7 through March 24, it will show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv
$Adv16
For release Sunday, Sept. 16, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: One Year on, South Carolina Healing but Scars from Hugo Linger
LaserPhotos CF1,2 of Sept. 14
DOC.TEXT: One year after Hurricane Hugo smashed ashore, Charleston still bears the scars from the most destructive hurricane ever to hit the U.S. mainland. Shingles are missing from the tattered roof of St. Michael's Episcopal Church, the oldest in the city, and the spire at the top of the bell tower has yet to be replaced. The nearby Charleston County Courthouse stands empty, its roof destroyed. Masking tape still lines its windows, preparation for the storm that thundered ashore a year ago this week. But across Meeting Street, City Hall bustles with the business of government, just as it did that lightless night last Sept. 21 when Hugo crashed into South Carolina, packing winds of 135 mph. Hugo's wrath claimed 29 lives on the U.S. mainland and was felt across hundreds of miles, from fishing communities on the South Carolina coast to mill towns nestled in the North Carolina mountains. The storm caused an estimated $5.9 billion damage. A year later, the recovery - both physical and emotional - continues. But for a relatively small, poor state, a lot has been done in the past 12 months to put things back in order. ``It's a miracle we're back where we are, given the enormity of the storm that hit us and the fact that over half our state was declared a disaster area,'' Gov. Carroll Campbell said. He noted that the beaches have been repaired and the tourism industry has rebounded. The historic district, the heart of Charleston's tourist economy, was scrubbed up in quick order. Indeed, visitors would have trouble telling Charleston took the brunt of such a severe storm. ``The recovery has been phenomenal,'' said Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. ``It is almost a miracle. It's a tribute to the citizens of the community. They didn't cry or whine or get angry. Everybody got to work and pitched in.'' During the past year, the city opened a waterfront park, and a new visitor's center is nearing completion. ``The city has not only recovered, this was not a year we treaded water,'' Riley said. But the recovery among the rural poor has taken longer. The sound of hammers and the buzz of power saws still can be heard on the hard-hit barrier islands northeast of town. Following Hugo, hundreds of tons of supplies and about $3.7 million in donations flooded into Charleston. Last month, the final $1 million was distributed to relief agencies. Richard Hendry of the Trident Community Foundation said more could have been used. There was not near enough to meet requests, which totaled almost $8 million, he said. ``The needs are still being uncovered,'' Hendry said. In rural Berkeley County, about 150 people wait to have homes repaired or rebuilt, said Henry Bonner, executive director of Berkeley County Interfaith Disaster Ministries. ``No matter how much publicity we've had since the storm, it's surprising how many people hear about us by word-of-mouth for the first time,'' Bonner said. The donations of money and building supplies that followed the storm have tapered off. Now, most of the help comes from South Carolinians. ``We're finding since the emergency a lot of people have been able to get friends and relatives to help in the repairs,'' Bonner added. ``Last winter, people were struggling to get over the storm. They couldn't help each other.'' Hugo brought a building boom to the sea islands. Vacant lots remain in places where weathered bungalows once lined the beach. Much of the debris has been cleared, and new houses are going up. But a block from the ocean on Sullivans Island, weeds sprout through the floorboards of a rusted red sports car. The car sits in front of a shattered house next to the battered hulk of a pickup truck. Next door, a crew of about 20 workers labors in the hot sun on a new beach house with an ocean view. To the north, in the small shrimping hamlet of McClellanville, streets have been cleared of debris. The local shrimp fleet is again plying the Atlantic. But the rotting hulls of two shrimp boats tossed ashore by Hugo still bear mute witness to the storm's fury. It was a boom year for construction, with thousands of workers flooding the area. Officials estimate about $3 billion was pumped into the Charleston area economy for construction services and trade. Many of the physical scars have healed, but the emotional toll is more difficult to assess. The Hugo Outreach program sponsored by the state Department of Mental Health counseled more than 26,000 people during the past year. During recent weeks, an increase has been noted in requests for help, said Cathy Joyner, a counselor with the program. ``We're seeing a lot of people who have not physically recovered, and they realize they are frightened and anxious,'' she said. ``An anniversary is an opportunity to go back and re-evaluate where they were a year ago and see if they have made any progress. It will be frightening for a lot of people to see they are not where they want to be.'' Since Hugo, there have been increases in domestic abuse reports, people seeking help with drinking problems and divorce filings. Counselors say 20,000 South Carolinians could suffer long-term psychological problems. Officials hope the outreach program, which includes 50 counselors statewide, can be extended through spring. Local governments will mark the storm anniversary with a candlelight observance at City Hall. Several commercial events also will note the occasion, including a road race and a golf exposition. For some, it will be a trying time. Lynn Ziegler heads the building committee for the Sunrise Presbyterian Church on Sullivans Island. The church was destroyed in the storm, and the congregation has met in a tent since last January. A new building won't be in place until next year. Mrs. Ziegler's house on the Isle of Palms was not severely damaged, and she said she suffered from survivor's guilt. ``I had been praying for some way to help,'' said Mrs. Ziegler, who worked in relief efforts after the storm. When asked to chair the building committee, ``I felt I was unqualified. ``But then I saw this was the answer to my prayers,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Sept. 16

DOC.TEXT: As the expiration of the contract between the United Auto Workers and General Motors Corp. neared, negotiators for the two sides were keeping mum. The three-year national pact covering 300,000 workers is to expire at midnight Friday. If GM and the UAW neither reaches an agreement nor extendes the current contract, the union could call a strike. Meanwhile, more than 85 percent of the local issues between the union and GM remained unresolved Thursday, awaiting a final agreement on a national contract. GM and UAW leaders said the slow pace of loca agreements was not unusual. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Energy Secretary James Watkins said he sees no sign of price-gouging by the oil industry and characterized the surge in gasoline prices as ``not unreasonable'' considering crude oil market conditions. Watkins was asked repeatedly about gasoline costs at a hearing Thursday of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. Oil prices have risen dramatically since Iraq occupied Kuwait, and some consumer groups and politicians have raised allegations of price-gouging. Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., told Watkins that ``there will be a tremendous outrage if we see a surge in profits for the oil companies'' when they next release quarterly financial statements. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Prosecutors filed a sentencing report about financier Michael Milken that is believed to allege numerous uncharged crimes, but it was not immediately made public even though the news media wants access. An attorney for Milken said he would oppose release of the papers, filed Thursday, before the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive is sentenced on Oct. 1 for his guilty plea to six securities and tax fraud counts. The sentencing memorandum reportedly contains details about Milken's alleged conduct unearthed by the government but never made public because of the plea agreement reached in April. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Scandinavian Airlines System completed a $50 million deal that makes it the largest shareholder of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. and puts Frank Lorenzo out as Continental chairman. Lorenzo will get $30 million through the arrangement, which was finalized Thursday after being approved a day earlier by the Transportation Department, but a Continental spokesman said the money is not all coming from the SAS purchase. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Failure to reach a budget agreement could reduce domestic airline flights by up to 30 percent and cause chaos at major airports, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said. ``If it's required, we would be furloughing up to two days per person per pay period,'' Administrator James B. Busey told reporters Thursday. ``That's the worst case.'' That would cause roughly a 25 percent reduction in FAA's work force on any given day, including its force of 17,200 air traffic controllers, Busey said. --- WASHINGTON - A company stuck with four multimillion-dollar furnaces that the Bush administration first approved and then disapproved for shipment to Iraq filed a $62 million lawsuit against Saddam Hussein's government. The federal court suit filed Thursday by Consarc Corp., of Rancocas, N.J., claims that Saddam's invasion of Kuwait and Iraqi deception over how the high-temperature furnaces would be used resulted in losses for the industrial furnace builder and its sister company in Scotland. --- NEW YORK (AP) - CBS and the Tokyo Broadcasting System will combine resources and technology for worldwide newsgathering, and study the possibility of co-producing sports and entertainment programming. CBS News said Thursday that the agreement, to go into effect in April, will be the first of its kind between a U.S. network and one in Japan. It will create ``the world's largest satellite newsgathering system,'' CBS said. --- BOSTON (AP) - The quality of U.S. manufactured goods is on the rise, according to a Boston University study on manufacturing competitiveness based on a survey of company executives. The good news for manufacturers is that the improvement rate on the quality of goods has increased in the last two years. But the report also found new product development and cost as possile trouble spots on the U.S. manufacturing front. --- PAWTUCKET, R.I. (AP) - The New Kids on the Block are doing almost as well in plastic as they are in vinyl. A million of the 12\-inch fashion dolls have been sold since they were introduced a month ago, Wayne Charness, a spokesman for toymaker Hasbro Inc., said Thursday. That's platinum. By comparison, the pop group's latest album, In Step, went triple platinum last month, two months after it was released, said an official with the Record Industry Association of America. ---

The stock market fell sharply Thursday in light but steady selling attributed to fears of impending bad news on the economy. The Dow Jones average tumbled 43.07 points to 2,582.67, its biggest one-day drop since falling 76.73 points Aug. 23. The dollar sank against all its major foreign counterparts. Gold posted moderate gains. Corn and wheat futures prices fell, as did soybeans. Crude oil futures rose slightly. Precious metals were mixed. Cattle were mixed. Pork futures retreated. Treasury bonds were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Sales of New Kids Dolls Go Platinum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The New Kids on the Block are doing almost as well in plastic as they are in vinyl. A million of the 12\-inch fashion dolls have been sold since they were introduced a month ago, Wayne Charness, a spokesman for toymaker Hasbro Inc., said Thursday. That's platinum. By comparison, the pop group's latest album, In Step, went triple platinum last month, two months after it was released, said an official with the Record Industry Association of America, who asked that her name not be used. While not quite as popular as the records, ``retailers cannot keep their store shelves stocked'' with the dolls, Charness said. ``We expect whatever we get for the remainder of the year will sell out,'' said Stephen J. Sanberg, a wholesale toy distributor for H. Sanberg and Son-Sanco Toy of Foxboro, Mass. ``It's a pleasant surprise in a relatively flat toy year.'' ``It's selling well now and we expect it to continue doing well through Christmas,'' said Angela Bourdon, spokeswoman for the Toys 'R Us Inc. chain. For Hasbro, which had slow sales this year, the doll's popularity is good news. Sluggish sales in the second-quarter cut the company's profits to $8.7 million, down nearly 52 percent from the same period a year ago. Alan G. Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive, said at the time that he still expected a year-end result similar to 1989, based on anticipated sales of the New Kids dolls and others resembling members of the World Wrestling Federation. Hasbro, whose line also includes traditional favorites such as G.I. Joe and Mr. Potato Head, had net sales of about $1.41 billion last year. ``We are extremely pleased by (the New Kids dolls') first-month performance,'' Charness said. ``Early indications are that we have a real hit on our hands.'' There are two styles of New Kids dolls, one in concert clothes that comes with a tape and retails for about $18, and one in street clothes that sells for about $15. Charness said dolls usually attract girls aged 4 to 10, but the New Kids also have been selling to young teen-agers up to age 15. ``The older girls are using them as a kind of three-dimensional poster,'' he said. It's been five years since a major toy company made a doll based on a pop group. A Michael Jackson doll, launched by LJN Toys Ltd. of New York, was on the market for less than a year, but did ``exceptionally well for a short period of time,'' a spokesman said. Other New Kids products marketed by various companies include a book, beach towels, watches, T-shirts, lunch boxes and a TV cartoon show. Charness said there are plans at Hasbro for New Kids in 1991 ``that we think will extend the longevity of the doll,'' but he would not identify the plans. An unidentified toy industry source told The Providence Journal-Bulletin that a soft, stuffed New Kids doll will be introduced next year.

DOC.HEAD: As National Talks Go, So Go Local Negotiations
With PM-Auto Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Local union bargainers with contracts of their own to negotiate are closely watching progress in national talks between the United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. as tonight's contract expirations draw near. As of Thursday, tentative agreements still hadn't been reached in about 85 percent of more than 100 GM-UAW local contracts. A GM official, who declined to be identified, said company executives were satisfied with that level and that such a pace was normal. Local contracts, like the national GM-UAW agreement, expire at midnight. Main issues facing national negotiators include job security and wage increases. Issues in local talks var widely from plant to plant, including matters such as location of break areas, availability of emergency health care and plant safety. Larger economic and non-economic issues affecting all auto workers are reserved for the national contract. There are 155 GM facilities with UAW-represented employees, the vast majority of which are parts plants. Fourteen of the locals have ``living agreements'' with no expiration dates. Seventeen UAW locals had reached tentative local agreements by Thursday, the company official said. The remaining 124 locals have yet to reach agreements. Leaders of some union locals may have taken the advice of UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich, who said last week that it may be a good idea to keep at least one local issue open as national negotiations neared the deadline. ``We're meeting every day and things are moving along, but a lot of bearing has to do with national negotiations and progress there,'' said Dave Kimmel, president of UAW Local 1714 at GM's metal stamping plant in Lordstown, Ohio. ``When that gets through, then the process locally will speed up.'' Bargainers for GM and UAW Local 276 at the automaker's car assembly plant in Arlington, Texas, reached a local agreement last month, well ahead of the deadline, said local President Dave Perdue. Four years ago, the local renegotiated its contract with GM so there wasn't too much work to do this time, he said. ``It was a fine-tuning sort of thing,'' Perdue said. Labor relations at parts and component plants have become increasingly important as the huge automaker relies more on the ``just-in-time'' parts system, which delivers components to assembly plants sometimes just a few hours before they're needed on assembly lines. Because of that, a walkout at a parts plant over a local issue can quickly stop assembly plant production. If such a strike were prolonged, idling assembly plants, other parts plants could be affected. GM learned the potential effects of such a strike last month when UAW Local 659 in Flint struck a fuel-tank factory for six days. By the time the dust settled, seven assembly plants had shut down and portions of more than a dozen other parts plants were idled. Wall Street analysts have speculated the strike by about 2,800 Local 659 members will create a $50 million dent in GM's third-quarter earnings because of lost assembly plant production.

DOC.HEAD: Car Sales Edge Up While Truck Sales Lag
With PM-Auto Talks, Bjt
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Light-truck sales lagged as Middle East tensions boosted gas prices, but a rise in car purchases brought overall sales of North American-made vehicles up 2.4 percent in early September. The 10 major companies making cars in the United States said average daily sales crept up to 31,065 in the Sept. 1-10 period from an average of 30,333 a day in early September 1989. Car sales rose 6.7 percent while truck sales dropped 4.6 percent for the period. Car sales by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. were virtually flat, edging up just 0.8 percent, while sales of cars made by Japanese companies in North America jumped 81.9 percent. A 6.8-percent slide in light-truck sales overwhelmed the car-sales increase for an overall 2.2 percent decline for the Big Three in the 10-day period. Rising gas prices were just one concern of consumers, who also worried about the economy in general and their jobs, GM spokesman Terry Sullivan said. But automotive analyst Maryann Keller of Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney in New York blamed the dent in truck sales on gas price increases after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``These are the gas guzzlers of this decade,'' Keller said. ``Gasoline is suddenly more expensive and they look at a truck and they see a healthy 14 miles a gallon, and they say `There might be a place where I might spend my money more efficiently.''' For the year through Sept. 10, North American-made cars and light trucks sold at a rate of 36,460 a day, down 4.5 percent from a 38,194-a-day average through Sept. 10 last year. Car sales were down 5.6 percent and light truck sales were down 2.8 percent for the year. Chrysler said its combined early September car and truck sales dropped 16.4 percent from the year before, with car sales down 15.9 percent and light truck sales - including popular minivan models - 17 percent behind last year's. Chrysler reported overall vehicle sales for the year down 15 percent. Ford said its early September sales of cars and trucks ran 3.7 percent ahead of last year's pace, with a 10.2-percent gain in truck sales overcoming a 0.6 drop in car sales. For the year, Ford said its car and truck sales were down 9 percent. GM said its early September truck sales lagged 13.8 percent while car sales rose 6.4 percent, for an overall 1.1-percent drop in vehicle sales for the period. For the year, GM car and truck sales were down 4.6 percent from last year.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Still Worried Over Possible Securities Levy
DOC.TEXT: Capitol Hill staffers say a suggested tax on securities transactions appears to be foundering, but opponents are still mounting a massive lobbying effort just in case. ``I think rumors of the demise of it are probably premature, but I haven't heard any great clamoring out there for it. I have not talked to anyone who thinks its a good idea, but it's not dead,'' a lobbyist, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Thursday. However, several congressional staffers - who did not want to be identified during the sensitive budget negotiations - said the tax's chances look weak, at best. ``The transaction tax is, I think, dead,'' said a House staffer familiar with the budget discussions. ``If there's any life to it, it's wheezing on the floor.'' ``The last I heard, it was not dead but it seemed to be reeling,'' said a staffer on another House committee. Securities firms have run newspaper ads against a rumored transaction tax on the sale of stocks, bonds, futures contracts and other financial products. Opponents say the tax would hurt everyone, not just Wall Street, because the tax would eventually be passed on to customers and make it harder for companies and local governments to raise money through bonds and other securities. There have been published reports since July that the Bush administration was considering a stock trading excise tax between .15 percent and .5 percent as a means of closing the budget gap. Officials believe that the deficit will likely exceed $250 billion - a record - in the upcoming fiscal year unless something is done. Without a budget agreement by Oct. 1, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will shrink the $1.2 trillion budget by $100 billion, an amount that would disrupt most federal programs and agencies. But since securities and futures exchanges, pension and mutual fund groups and local politicians in New York and Chicago rose up to oppose the proposed securities tax, little has been heard about it around Congress. ``In broad terms, I've heard no mention of that kind of tax being proposed by anyone in these discussions,'' said a Senate aide close to the negotiations who spoke on condition he not be identified. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that a broadly based .5 percent tax on all securities except Treasury securities would raise about $12 billion a year to start. But opponents say those numbers will never be reached because the tax would make trading more expensive, driving business overseas and leaving fewer transactions to tax. They also say the increased costs to high volume traders like insurance companies and pension funds would be passed on to customers, pensioners or - in the case of public employee pension funds - taxpayers. Even the Congressional Research Service, in a report issued in July, noted that a half penny tax on transactions could cut trading volume in the stock market by 7.9 percent and reduce stock market prices by as much as 7.7 percent. Numerous groups spearheded by the Securities Industry Association and the Public Securities Association have written Congress and the White House arguing against a securities tax. New York City officials have also been vocal in their opposition to the tax, saying it would hurt the city's securities industry and the local economy.

DOC.HEAD: Garfield, Beware: Cat Food Makers Encouraging Slimmer Felines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report; also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS1 sent Sept. 13.
DOC.TEXT: Watch out, fat cats. Pet food manufacturers are competing for the right to reduce your ranks. And the new battleground is the supermarket, rather than specialty pet stores. Starting this month, Heinz Pet Products Co. is distributing a diet cat food to grocery stores nationwide. The company says Lean Entrees, its new 9-Lives product, is the first national line of 95 percent fat-free canned cat food. The company, a subsidiary of Pittsburgh-based H.J. Heinz Co., is hoping for greater sales in the supermarkets than it could achieve in specialty stores, and is targeting owners who fear their felines are putting on pounds. ``We've got our fingers crossed,'' said Ed Johnson, general manager of cat food marketing for Heinz Pet Products, which moved its headquarters last year to this northern Kentucky city from Long Beach, Calif. It may be a while before results are clear. Diet pet food is too new to have made any measurable market impact, said William Leach, an industry analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. ``Diet pet food just seems kind of ridiculous to me,'' he added. ``There are so many people starving in the world, and pet owners are worried about their pets getting fat.'' The entry of reduced-fat, reduced-calorie products into the cat food market is a carryover from the human interest in those concerns, said Patrick Farrell, a spokesman for Ralston Purina Co. of St. Louis. His company came out several months ago with Cat Chow Mature, a reduced-fat, reduced-calorie, dry cat food sold in supermarkets. It's marketed for older, more sedentary cats. ``It's an area that's become popular recently. More and more consumers are taking an interest, and you're seeing more products coming out in response to that,'' he said. ``The big thing right now in consumer human food is fat, low-fat. I think that trend is carrying forward into pet food,'' Johnson said. Fat cats are a growing problem. Heinz estimates that 20 percent of the nation's cats are overweight. Like obese humans, they have a greater risk of heart ailments or other fatal maladies. Heinz says ``health and fitness'' pet foods have been sold mostly in specialty pet stores and veterinary clinics. Those businesses account for about 20 percent of the $5.9 billion U.S. market for cat and dog food, says Heinz, which produces cat and dog food. Lean Entrees results from a year of development, Johnson said. He declined to reveal what the company's sales projections are or how much it cost to develop the product. Nationwide television advertisements promoting the product will begin next month. Competitors also are trying to claw their way into the market. Ralston Purina has its Cat Chow Mature. For the past three years, it's also sold Pro Plan cat food, a line of products including a ``light formula'' intended for aging fat cats. ``We don't discuss sales figures, but it's meeting our expectations,'' Farrell said. Lean Entrees features five popular flavors from the 9-Lives line: liver and beef, beef and seafood, chicken and seafood stew, chicken and liver entree, and ocean fish and shrimp stew. A can will cost 39 cents, a few pennies more than 9-Lives' regular variety.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Says Gasoline Price Hikes `Not Unreasonable'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices have jumped an average 20 percent in the six weeks since Iraq invaded Kuwait, but Energy Secretary James Watkins calls the rise ``not unreasonable'' and discounts suggestions that oil companies are gouging consumers. Watkins was asked repeatedly about gasoline costs during a Thursday hearing of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., told Watkins the public is awaiting release of quarterly statistics on oil company profits and predicted ``there will be a tremendous outrage if we see a surge in profits.'' The secretary said his department would keep an eye on the profit reports. But he spoke out against legislation, introduced earlier in the week, that would prohibit ``unreasonable'' price increases for petroleum products. He said such a law would amount to price control and require a ``massive bureaucracy'' to ensure adequate monitoring. Since Iraq overran Kuwait Aug. 2, gasoline prices have risen about 20 percent at the pump while crude oil prices have jumped about 55 percent, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Watkins acknowledged that initial increases at the pump were greater than the early rises in oil prices. However, he said, retail increases in recent weeks have ``lagged about 4 cents a gallon'' behind hikes on the spot crude oil market. Americans on average are paying 22 cents a gallon more for unleaded gasoline today than before Aug. 2, while the spot price for crude is 26 cents a gallon higher, according to government and industry officials. Watkins told the Senate panel that the pricing of gasoline ``is working very well and is rather typical of the supply and demand situation.'' The secretary said he considered the recent price hikes ``not unreasonable.'' A group of senators said Wednesday they would try to push through in the coming weeks legislation that would strengthen federal laws against price gouging by oil companies. ``The laws of gravity and economics clearly don't seem to apply to gas prices. What goes up stays up,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn. ``They charge what they can get away with.'' The bill sponsored by Lieberman and other senators would prohibit ``unreasonable'' price increases in petroleum products, including gasoline and heating oil, and would make ``profiteering'' a criminal offense punishable by a maximum five-year jail sentence and $500,000 fine. Watkins said his department would watch for ``unscrupulous'' business people taking advantage of oil shortages but said he didn't want to ``assume that everyone in America is a crook.''

DOC.HEAD: Inflation at 10.6 Percent; Highest since 1982
DOC.TEXT: Retail prices in Britain were up 10.6 percent in August compared to levels a year earlier, the highest rate of inflation since 1982, the government reported Friday. Higher prices for gasoline, heating oil, food and beer pushed the index up 1.0 percent between July and August, the Central Statistical Office said. The last time inflation was in double figures was in March 1982 when the rate was 10.4 percent. Excluding mortgages and local taxes, the rate of increase was 7.9 percent in August, up from 7.0 percent in July, the government said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Takeover of Appliance Maker
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy court judge has approved the $650 million takeover of Allegheny International Inc. by the New York investment firm Japonica Partners. Judge Joseph Cosetti gave his assent Thursday at a hearing after the appliance maker reported the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had authorized the transfer of a radioactive waste dump to the partnership. The NRC approval was one of the last steps necessary before the court could approve the acquisition. Allegheny International, which makes Sunbeam and Oster products, said the change in control will take place during the week of Sept. 24. When the takeover becomes effective, the company will emerge from federal bankruptcy protection after 2{ years. The radioactive site is in Newburgh Heights, Ohio. It was used by a former Allegheny International subsidiary as a waste dump.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Launches New Film Venture With Japanese Funding
DOC.TEXT: A $100 million joint venture between Walt Disney Studios and a Japanese-backed company to produce motion pictures was created in response to complaints of foreign investment in Hollywood. The four-year deal announced Thursday calls for Disney and Interscope Communications to contribute equal sums of no less than $50 million each to a production and marketing fund. The effort should yield about seven pictures, said Robert Cort, Interscope's chairman and president. Interscope's contributions will be funded by Nomura Babcock & Brown, the giant U.S.-Japanese investment enterprise. Founded in March 1988, Nomura was founded by Nomura Securities Co., Japan's largest securities firm, and Babcock & Brown, a San Francisco-based investment banker. Nomura will sell partnership interests to its customers in Japan in order to provide all of Interscope's funds for the enterprise. ``We've found in Japan an enormous interest in the whole U.S. communications industry,'' said Richard Koffey, managing director of Babcock & Brown. ``The Disney name is extremely well-known and respected in Japan.'' Koffey said the deal's balanced structure - with Disney and Interscope sharing costs and revenues - was in response to complaints over Japanese investment in Hollywood. Under the agreement, the Interscope-Nomura partnership may elect to co-finance the films that Interscope produces for Disney. Some of the initial projects will be selected from the 16 movies Interscope now has in development with Disney. Disney and Interscope have already collaborated on several films, including ``Three Men and a Baby'' with Ted Danson, ``Cocktail'' with Tom Cruise and Bette Midler's ``Outrageous Fortune.'' Interscope is an independent supplier of motion pictures, television shows and videocassettes. Interscope's other productions include ``Bird on a Wire,'' ``Revenge of the Nerds'' and ``Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure.''

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Moves Closer To Siberian Oil Deal
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Corp. has moved closer to a joint Soviet oil venture with the signing of a protocol to study development of oil and gas fields in western Siberia. The protocol with the Soviet Union's state gas business office was the most recent in a series of protocols resulting from discussions that began in July 1989, Amoco said Thursday. It provides an opportunity for Amoco, following the completion of a preliminary study, to conduct a detailed study of the technical and economic feasability of developing several oil and gas fields in western Siberia in cooperation with Soviet organizations. The protocol also lists many of the guiding principles that would be incorporated into an eventual joint venture agreement, Amoco said. Amoco believes the oil and gas potential of the fields is significant, according to Robert L. Blanton, president of Amoco Eurasia Petroleum Co., an Amoco subsidiary. Several other oil companies also are pursuing joint ventures to produce oil and gas in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Government Tries to Recover on Medicare Payments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This was part of PM-Washington in Brief on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The federal government is trying to recover as much as $600 million in Medicare payments for claims that should have been paid by private insurance companies or other payers. Louis Sullivan, Health and Human Services secretary, announced the program Thursday. The funds are expected to be recovered in fiscal years 1991-1993. The program will identify cases in which Medicare was charged incorrectly for health care services to beneficiaries who work or to spouses whose claims should have been paid by employment-related plans.

Stock prices declined broadly today as the market absorbed new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 11.14 to 2,571.53 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 7 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 199 up, 745 down and 429 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 19.02 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Labor Department reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp rises in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possible fallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pressures. In that kind of climate, few market participants can see much reason for optimism about the outlook for corporate profits and dividends. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Philip Morris, down ] at 44{; General Electric, down } at 59|; Bristol-Myers Squibb, down ] at 59}, and International Business Machines, down ] at 104|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.00 to 174.16. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off .39 at 321.62. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 43.07 points to 2,582.67, for its biggest one-day drop since it tumbled 76.73 points on Aug. 23. Declining issues outnumbered advances by nearly 5 to 2 on the NYSE, with 421 up, 1,005 down and 512 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 123.37 million shares, against 129.89 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Asahi Breweries Investing in Australian Brewer
DOC.TEXT: Asahi Breweries Ltd. said Friday it has proposed to buy a nearly 20 percent equity stake in Elders IXL Ltd., Australia's largest brewer, for 110 billion yen, or about $809 million. The investment would be made late in October under a basic agreement with Harlin Holding Pty Ltd. of Australia, Elder's biggest shareholder, Asahi officials said. If the deal is completed, Asahi would be the second biggest shareholder in Elders after Harlin, which currently has a 56 percent stake, the Asahi officials said. Peter Bartels, chief executive of Elders IXL, said in a statement from Melbourne, ``We would welcome the opportunity presented by this transaction for both organizations to enlarge their presence internationally.'' He said Elders planned to discuss the proposal from Harlin with its its advisers and that it board would meet to consider the matter. The Elders group, comprising three affiliated breweries, has a 3.5 percent share of the world's beer market. Its wholly-owned Carlton and United Breweries subsidiary has a 48 percent share in the Australian beer market. Its main brand is Fosters. Elders has about 10 percent of the British beer market through its Courage Ltd. unit, and its jointly-owned Molson Breweries in Canada holds 52 percent of the Canadian beer market, according to industry estimates. Asahi has a 25 percent share in Japan's beer market, up from 10 percent four years ago before its 1987 introduction of dry beer. Dry beer is considered less sweet than regular beer and it has proven very popular in Japan, prompting other brewers to produce their versions of dry beer.

Stock prices showed a broad loss today as the market absorbed new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 17.57 to 2,565.10 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 273 up, 919 down and 485 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 44.35 million shares at mdimorning.
