The Labor Department reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp rises in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possible fallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pressures. In that kind of climate, few market participants can see much reason for optimism about the outlook for corporate profits and dividends. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Philip Morris, down \ at 44|; General Electric, down | at 59}; Digital Equipment, down 2~ at 56], and International Business Machines, down { at 104{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.24 to 173.92. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.00 at 321.01.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 373.72 down 2.46 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Shot Up 1.3 Percent in August
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with analysts' comments, industrial production report; editing thruout. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices shot up 1.3 percent in August, the biggest surge in seven months, as the first shock wave from the Persian Gulf crisis hit the American economy, the government said today. The Labor Department blamed virtually the entire increase on higher oil costs that followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The fallout from the Persian Gulf turmoil has heightened economists' fears that higher inflationary pressures could push an already weak U.S. economy into a recession. In another report today, the government said retail sales slumped 0.6 percent in August despite a huge jump in the amount of money people spent on gasoline. Sales at gasoline stations climbed 6.4 percent in August, the largest increase since an 8.3 percent advance in August 1979, the Commerce Department said. But sales in nearly every other category dropped to cause the downturn in consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Retail sales account for half of consumer spending. Another worrisome government report issued today showed industrial production dropped 0.2 percent in August, which economists linked to higher energy prices and their effect on factory activity. It was the manufacturing sector's worst monthly performance since a similar decline in April. The August rise in wholesale prices, the largest since a cold snap caused a 1.9 percent spurt in January, would translate into an annual increase of 16.4 percent if prices rose that much each month, the government said. That is far above the 3 percent advance in the Producer Price Index from January through July. While prices settled down after the January increase, analysts were worried that this inflation outbreak could become more entrenched, filtering through to the thousands of products made with petroleum or that must be transported long distances. Eventually, wages that are linked to the cost of living could rise as well, analysts said. ``The initial round is so large, it implies that the ripple-through effect in coming months will be quite sizable ... The worst is yet to come,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. ``The first shot of oil and energy inflation suggest a wave of inflation in the U.S. economy that will be in high single digits for three to six months. In turn, it will squeeze purchasing power enough to produce a substantial recession,'' Sinai said. Robert Dederick of the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago said today's data on high wholesale inflation, coupled with weak growth, indicates that the Iraqi conflict threatens to push a vulnerable U.S. economy into recession. ``It may well be the shock that broke the camel's back because the back was already bending,'' Dederick said. Today's report on wholesale prices will be followed next Tuesday by the government's first look at inflation at the consumer level since the upheaval in the Middle East. That report is expected to be equally bad, given the fact that pump prices of gasoline went up almost immediately. In August, energy costs overall rose 9.5 percent, the government said today. Gasoline jumped 16.9 percent while fuel oil skyrocketed 38.8 percent. Natural gas was down 9.4 percent, today's report said. Inflation at earlier stages of the production process was up sharply, too, largely due to the gulf crisis, the Labor Department said. Crude goods jumped 9.3 percent, their steepest monthly increase in 17 years. Intermediate goods jumped 1.3 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be clothing for finished goods, cloth for intermediate and cotton for crude. Food prices overall were up 0.8 percent after remaining unchanged in July. Fresh fruit prices fell 6.3 percent after jumping 14 percent in July. Egg prices, which had declined by 18.3 percent in July, soared 25.8 percent in August, the government said. Costs were up for rice, pasta, beef, coffee and cooking oils. Prices were down for bakery products, pork, young chickens and dairy products. Prices for goods excluding volatile food and energy items - often taken by economists as a better barometer of underlying inflationary pressures - rose 0.3 percent. In July, this so-called core rate had declined 0.1 percent for the first drop in a year. Passenger car prices were up 0.8 percent after having declined 0.5 percent in July, the government said. Clothing prices were mixed, with a 0.3 percent rise for women's apparel but a 0.2 percent decline for girls', children's and infants' clothing. There was no change in the cost of men's and boys' apparel. Footwear fell 0.3 percent. Tobacco prices increased 0.9 percent and were 13.2 percent higher than they were a year ago. The various changes put the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 119.2 in August. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $119.20 last month, up from $113.40 a year earlier. The overall weakness of the nation's economy - it grew at an anemic 1.5 percent annual rate during the first half of the year - probably kept wholesale inflation relatively low before the Middle East erupted, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Government Announces Offshore Oil Project
DOC.TEXT: Canada's largest offshore oil drilling project has been approved, and construction is expected to begin almost immediately, the nation's federal energy minister announced today. The formal go-ahead for the $5.2 billion ($4.5 billion U.S.) Hibernia oil project off Newfoundland's coast was announced by federal Energy Minister Jake Epp as a major advancement for the economically troubled Atlantic province. ``Hibernia will bring jobs and economic diversification to Newfoundland and all of Canada,'' he said. ``The development of the Hibernia oil field will diversify Canada's sources of oil supply. The opening up of this new frontier will put Canadians at the leading edge of offshore development technologies.'' The project is a collaboration between the federal government, the province and a consortium of four oil companies led by Mobil Oil Canada. Ottawa will contribute $2.7 billion ($2.3 billion U.S.) to the project in cash and loan guarantees. The rest will come from the operating companies and Newfoundland, which will help out with tax breaks during contruction. The consortium estimates up to $3.1 billion ($2.7 billion U.S.) of the total capital construction costs will go to Canadian companies. Production is expected to start in 1996 and last about 20 years. The companies estimate the Hibernia field has recoverable oil reserves of 525 million to 650 million barrels. The peak output will be about 110,000 barrels a day. Epp was joined in the announcement by International Trade Minister John Crosbie, Premier Clyde Wells, provincial Energy Minister Rex Gibbons and several other officials. The announcement ends weeks of speculation about the agreement. The underwater oil reserve was discovered a decade ago about 190 miles southeast of St. John's. Years of negotiations followed over issues such as the split in development costs and amount of benefits to go to Newfoundland. A tentative agreement was reached in 1988. Since then, three deadlines for a formal go-ahead have passed. Mobil's redesign last year of the topside sections of the Hibernia production platform - which will house production facilities and living quarters above the water - contributed to the delay. Also, the federal government promised the consortium - which includes Gulf Canada Resources, Chevron Canada Resources and Petro-Canada - $2.7 billion ($2.3 billion U.S.) Canadian in cash and loan guarantees. But a bill authorizing Ottawa's contribution was pulled in late June after the collapse of a constitutional accord that stirred controversy across Canada over recognition of Quebec's French Canadians as a distinct society. Wells cancelled a vote on the accord in the Newfoundland legislature, and Conservative Parliament members from Quebec are believed to have threatened to vote against the bill in retaliation for Wells's action. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's absence from the announcement today has fueled speculation that tensions are still high.

DOC.HEAD: Globex Launch Date Pushed Back Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Partners in . . . to CORRECT launch date to first quarter sted spring; Pickup 3rd graf, `The latest . . .
DOC.TEXT: Investors eager to do their futures and options trading at night will have to wait a little longer. Partners in Globex, a proposed 24-hour electronic system for trading financial futures and options, said Thursday they have pushed back the planned start-up date from November to the first quarter of 1991. The latest obstacle involves modifications to accommodate products offered by the Chicago Board of Trade, according to a statement issued jointly by the Board of Trade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters Holdings PLC, a British company that is supplying technology for the system. The Board of Trade joined the venture in May after abandoning plans to develop a competing system. The parties also have yet to iron out a firm agreement on sharing the operation of the system, which is subject to approval by the Board of Trade's directors and members, according to the two-paragraph statement. When the Merc and Reuters announced their Globex plans in September 1987, they projected a launch date in the first quarter of 1989. The parties said they have been pleased with the results of testing Globex's functions. Globex would operate during the hours that the exchanges' trading floors are closed. It would theoretically enable participating brokers around the world to get orders filled at any time, either through the traditional open-outcry method when the trading floors are open or through blind order-matching by the Globex computer when the floors are closed.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to note bargaining resumed and include newspaper report on sourcing. Picks up 4th graf pvs, UAW Vice President . . .; ADDS 2 grafs with CAW-Ford situation in Canada.
DOC.TEXT: A virtual news blackout on national contract negotiations between the United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. continued as bargainers faced a contract expiration tonight. Bargaining resumed this morning, company and union officials said. There was no all-night session Thursday. There was speculation Thursday night that the silence indicated negotiators were making slow but steady progress toward a new three-year agreement covering more than 300,000 workers at the world's largest automaker. The current pact expires at midnight. Major issues yet to be resolved included job security, wages and pensions, according to a UAW official who declined to be identified. Tentative agreements have been reached on a variety of mostly non-economic issues including health and safety and attendance policy. The Detroit Free Press reported in today's edition that GM and the union have agreed tentatively to a contract provision involving UAW leaders in decisions about where auto components or entire vehicles are made. The newspaper, quoting unidentified union officials, said there were no references to specific goals for increasing the use of GM facilities and UAW workers in manufacturing parts for the huge automaker. The ``sourcing'' issue has been emotional for UAW members, who have complained the company has turned its back on unionized American workers in favor of non-union, sometimes overseas, factories. UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich, head of the union's bargaining effort with GM, made a brief appearance Thursday night in a hallway of the GM Building, where the negotiators are working. He was dogged by reporters and television camera crews. He declined to say anything about the talks. ``Everybody is curious,'' Dave Perdue, president of UAW Local 276 at GM's Arlington, Texas, assembly plant, said Thursday. ``They're hungry for information. ``The lack of information, the lack of strike rhetoric - that tells me I should anticipate a settlement.'' In addition to the national contract, more than 100 GM-UAW local contracts covering specific working conditions on a plant-by-plant basis remained unresolved Thursday. Those contracts also expire at midnight, as do UAW contracts with Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. But the Ford and Chrysler talks have been put on hold pending the outcome of negotiations between the union and GM. In all, more than 450,000 active workers are covered by the three contracts. In a recorded telephone message for UAW members, Yokich said Thursday that more work remains for negotiators who began working on the new contract in late July. ``The deadline is quickly approaching and we must see more movement by the corporation if we are to reach tentative agreement prior to the deadline,'' he said. ``I urge you to stay in close touch with your local officers about our plans as we approach midnight on Friday.'' As the deadline drew near, there was increasing speculation that if an agreement wasn't reached before midnight, then bargainers would extend the current contract through the weekend. ``We've got very little information here as far as national negotiations,'' said Jerry Gorski, financial secretary of UAW Local 634 in Buffalo, N.Y. ``Whatever they've got they're keeping it under their hats. ``I imagine they'll probably have an extension.'' Any strike called by the UAW wouldn't have any significant effects until Monday. Most GM plants are scheduled to close for the weekend. The UAW has called a meeting of its GM bargaining council for Monday in Dearborn, a suburb of Detroit, for local presidents and bargaining committee heads. That announcement prompted speculation that negotiators were closer to a settlement than a strike. Another union official said the meeting could be used to brief union leaders on a strike, but it more likely would be used to discuss a tentative settlement. UAW locals nationwide put the finishing touches on strike plans Thursday. Mike O'Brien, president of UAW Local 95 at GM's Janesville, Wis., truck and bus plant, said his members were prepared for a strike. Picket line assignments have been made and signs will be ready by the deadline. Meantime in Canada, bargaining continued today between officials of the Canadian Auto Workers and Ford's Canadian subsidiary over a contract covering about 12,800 workers. Like the UAW-GM contract, the CAW-Ford agreement expires at midnight. The rhetoric in the Toronto talks has been much higher than in the U.S. negotiations. CAW President Bob White said the two sides remain far apart.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed After Steep Losses
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as the corn and wheat markets sought direction after posting steep losses in the previous session. The soybean market also closed lower Thursday despite a late rally that appeared to generate some followthrough buying this morning. Corn and wheat futures were narrowly mixed early in today's session. Prices fell sharply in those markets Thursday in response to unexepectedly large government forecasts for this year's U.S. corn and wheat production. Analysts said some of this morning's selling pressure stemmed from a National Weather Service 30-day forecast for normal temperatures and normal to below-normal precipitation in the Midwest and Southern Plains. Those conditions would be ideal for corn and soybean harvesting and winter wheat planting. In early trading, wheat futures were 1} cents lower to \ cent higher with September at $2.60 a bushel; corn was { cent lower to \ cent higher with September at $2.33 a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent higher with December at $1.14} a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to } cent higher with September at $6.22\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent lower to .10 cent higher with October at 78.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .20 cent higher with September at 88.40 cents a pound; live hogs were .12 cent lower to .48 cent higher with October at 51.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .38 cent to .97 cent higher with February at 53.97 cents a pound. Cattle futures ended mixed Thursday; pork futures fell.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Hit Above $32 Following Seizure of French Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures moved above $32 per barrel today on news that Iraqi troops stormed the French Embassy in Kuwait this morning, seizing a diplomat and three other citizens. ``It was the first time Bagdad's occupying forces have seized anybody in a raid on the diplomatic community,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``The market's trading up on that story pretty much alone.'' After opening higher and climbing to $32.10 per barrel, light sweet crude was trading late in the morning up 73 cents at $31.80 per barrel for October contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months were mostly higher. Crude's all-time high on the exchange, $32.35 per barrel, has been matched once during the Persian Gulf crisis, on Aug. 23. Traders thought crude might be heading toward a record high as the Mideast tensions increase. As crude moved up today, gasoline and home heating oil futures were also on the rise. Unleaded gasoline was up .64 cent at 94 cents per gallon for October delivery, while heating oil was up 1.62 cents to 85.10 cents per gallon for October delivery in late morning trading. Later contract months for gasoline and heating oil were higher. Natural gas was up slightly, rising to $1.543 from $1.540 per 1,000 cubic feet. Trader Ed Kevelson with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said heating oil was outperforming gasoline on the Merc because there was an abundance of gasoline available on the cash market. Later contract months for gasoline were moving up farther than October, showing it nonetheless remains strong, Kevelson said. Kevelson said the rise in crude prices was partially attributable to indications that the Saudis might be cutting back on their production of sweet crude. Sweet crude, with a low sulfur content, is best suited to U.S. refineries. ``You're setting up for possible sweet crude shortages in the future,'' Kevelson said.

DOC.HEAD: U995
DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for light sweet crude was $31.62 per barrel at 12 p.m. Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Wall Street Journal To Be Printed in Thailand
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Company Inc., a leading American publisher, plans to begin printing the Asian Wall Street Journal in Thailand within the next few months, it was announced Friday. The Journal will be printed for distribution in Thailand and some other countries in the Southeast Asian region by The Nation Publishing Group. A news release from the Thai group, which publishes the English-language daily The Nation and several magazines, said a contract was signed Friday between the two companies. ``This marks the first time that Thailand will be printing a foreign aily newspaper through a satellite linkup, setting the stage for Bangkok to become the new publishing center in the region,'' the release said. The Journal is currently being printed in Tokyo, Singapore and Hong Kong, where the newspaper has its headquarters. It is distributed mainly in Asia. The government banned the newspaper for five days last November for printing a story that it said insulted the Buddhist supreme patriarch. It reinstated the paper after its editor said he regretted any offense caused. Dow Jones also owns the Wall Street Journal, Barron's, the Far Eastern Economic Review and a number of other publications. It has a 4 percent equity in The Nation Publishing Group.

DOC.HEAD: Iberia Given Cabinet OK to Buy Lufthansa's Viva Air Shares
DOC.TEXT: The cabinet Friday authorized state-owned Iberia Airlines to buy the 48 percent stake in charter airline Viva Air currently held by West Germany's Lufthansa. The government said in a news release that the purchase by Iberia will raise the flag carrier's control of shares in Vuelos Internacionales de Vacaciones SA (Viva Air) to 96 percent. The purchase of Lufthansa's stake for the equivalent of about $8.4 million will permit Iberia to transform Viva Air from a tourist charter carrier to a company with regular international flights to England, Germany and France, the release said. Iberia and Lufthansa founded Viva Air in February 1988. Its original nominal share capital totaled about $17.5 million. Each airline took a 48 percent stake. Other founding partners Infoleasing SA and West German tour operator A. Paukner are expected to retain their 2 percent interests. The move is in step with other Iberia efforts to expand its European and intercontinental service. Last July, an Iberia-led consortium agreed to buy 85 percent of Argentina's state carrier Aerolineas Argentinas for $130 million in cash, $130 million in 10 installments and the retirement of $2 billion of Argentine foreign debt. Aerolineas ownership transfer is set for Oct. 8, although it may be delayed. Lufthans officials last spring told Iberia they wanted to sell their Viva Air stake because of concerns tourist travel to Spain was declining and they wanted to focus on their expanding interests in Central Europe. The Spanish Tourism Secretariat reported last Aug. 27 that 27.8 million tourists visited Spain through the first seven months of the year, down 2.6 percent from the same period a year earlier. Iberia President Miguel Aguilo said Wednesday that Iberia planned to have Viva Air's future flights cover travel on ``non-trunk'' international routes. Aguilo said those were between smaller Spanish cities and major European cities and between smaller European cities and major Spanish cities - flights not always profitable for Iberia. Viva Air owns five Boeing 737-300 aircraft, leases two DC-9 aircraft from Iberia and employs 145 people. In its first full year of operations last year, Viva Air reported a profit of the equivalent of about $1.65 million on revenue of $75.2 million. Last year Viva Air carried 808,603 passengers and logged 14,809 flight hours.

Stock prices lost more ground today as the market absorbed new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 17.08 to 2,565.59 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 320 up, 961 down and 502 unchanged. The Labor Department reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp rises in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possible fallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pnking official said the government is considering ways to renegotiate some of the sale contracts but does not intend to break them. In a report released at the hearing, investigators for the banking committee said outside investors in troubled thrifts received $78 in assets and government-granted benefits for every $1 of capital they put up to buy the institutions. ``These so-called deals bear all the earmarks of a giveaway - with the recipients of the government largesse being some of the fattest of the nation's financial fat cats,'' Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said at a hearing. ``We are hopeful that there can be renegotiations that rectify some of the excesses.'' Gonzalez said his committee will ``haunt'' the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency responsible for disposing of failed S&Ls, ``until we have hard evidence that everything is being done to recover as many of the billions as possible.'' L. William Seidman, who heads the RTC and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told the committee that the RTC's efforts ``are to minimize costs to the government within the provisions of the contracts.'' ``We are not considering breaking the government's agreements,'' he said. The committee report concluded that 94 S&L deals completed in late 1988 will cost the government around $71 billion in assistance to buyers of the thrifts, including up to $4.2 billion in tax breaks. The investigators' study focused particularly on the sales of American Savings Bank FA of California and two giant Texas thrifts, Southwest Savings Association and First Gibraltar Federal Savings Bank. In the American Savings and First Gibraltar deals, the buyers were given generous tax breaks, the study said. A separate report released late Thursday by the General Accounting Office found that the rescue of American Savings will cost taxpayers $5.2 billion, three times the government's original estimate. The institution was purchased by a group led by billionaire investor Robert M. Bass. Southwest Savings was purchased in 1988 by Caroline Hunt, the daughter of legendary oilman H.L. Hunt, with the help of government subsidies projected to total $2 billion over 10 years. Despite the federal aid, the thrift failed a second time and went back to the government. M. Danny Wall, the former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, also was expected to testify at the hearing. Wall, who presided over the 1988 sales, has defended them as a crash effort by the government to transfer into private hands insolvent S&Ls that were draining billions of dollars from the federal insurance fund. But critics have charged that in its mad rush to complete the S&L sales in late 1988, the government entered into contracts that virtually assure the buyers a profit from generous government subsidies that will end up costing taxpayers more in the long run. Unless the Bush administration renegotiates some of the sales, critics say, it would further swell the cost to taxpayers of the S&L bailout, already estimated at $500 billion. ``There is an obligation to renegotiate some of these deals,'' Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said Tuesday. Metzenbaum, who chairs a Senate Judiciary subcommittee, said he would press the administration to renegotiate several of the 1988 deals. Metzenbaum was completing a series of hearings on one of the most controversial 1988 deals: the sale of what is now known as Bluebonnet Savings Bank to James M. Fail, an Arizona insurance executive. Fail put up only $1,000 of his own money and borrowed another $70 million to complete a transaction that investigators said qualified him for at least $1.85 billion in government subsidies. The deal will cost taxpayers up to $3 billion, Metzenbaum says. The investigation by the House Banking Committee is one of several conducted recently on the 1988 sales, which were made by the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The Resolution Trust Corp. is scheduled to complete its own study soon into whether the government would be better off by exercising contract options allowing the government to get out of some of the guarantees made in the 1988 deals. According to a recent FDIC report, the 1988 sales of around 200 failed S&Ls cost taxpayers $4.6 billion in 1989. The FDIC's estimate, which is the first official accounting of the cost, does ot include tax breaks given to buyers of the thrifts.

DOC.HEAD: Utility Unveils New Organization
DOC.TEXT: Arizona Public Service Co., following up on a mid-year announcement that it hoped to cut capital expenditures and trim its budget, says it will eliminate 675 full-time positions. APS President Mark De Michele said Thursday that one goal for the state's largest utility was ``to reduce our pending rate-increase request before the Arizona Corporation Commission and work toward a period of price stability.'' De Michele said he could not provide specifics on the size of the reduction. APS executives said the cuts are needed to keep rates at a reasonable level and match competition in the utility industry. In January, APS filed a $271 million rate proposal, seeking increases of 6.8 percent in 1991, 1992 and 1993. The request has been amended to 6.5 percent per year, or $259 million. A sluggish economy that has resulted in a slowdown of customer growth also is a major factor in the cost-cutting effort. The utility has roughly 591,000 residential and commercial customers. This is the third time APS has eliminated positions to try to cut costs. It has cut 1,548 jobs since 1988, generating $63 million in savings. De Michele said that, in addition to the 13 percent cut in the company's full-time, non-nuclear workforce of 4,908, APS will eliminate another 450 jobs by not filling vacant positions. The targeted jobs include those of 300 unionized employees, 315 clerical-professional positions and about 60 managers and supervisors; they do not include about 400 jobs eliminated since Jan. 1, when the company had nearly 5,800 full-time employees and decided to adopt an early-retirement program. The reductions do not affect either employees or contract workers at the Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station, the only nuclear facility in the state, said APS spokesman Wayne Kaplan. About 2,840 people are on the Palo Verde workforce, Kaplan said. The statement withheld details of the company's revised filing and stability plans and said the reorganization would take until the end of the year to complete. Under the plan, employees holding jobs targeted for elimination first will be offered positions within the company. A voluntary severance plan will follow. Layoffs then will go into effect, APS executives said.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan To Open Stock Market to Foreign Investors
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan will open its stock market to foreign institutional investors in a bid to curb speculation by local investors, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Friday. Chang Chang-pang, commission chairman, said his agency wants to allow foreign banks, insurance companies and fund management agencies to invest in Taiwan's stocks, beneficiary certificates, government and corporate bonds. ``We believe the participation of foreign institutional investors would help curb speculation and stabilize the market,'' he said. Under the proposal, total foreign investment in the market would be limited to $2.5 billion of the total $130 billion invested in the market, Chang said. He said all transactions should be made through designated agents or representatives in Taiwan. Each foreign institutional investor, who can invest between $5 million and $50 million in Taiwan stocks, can purchase up to 5 percent of the shares in a listed Taiwan stock, he said. However, combined foreign investment should not exceed 10 percent of any individual stock, he added. The commission's proposal will be submitted to the Cabinet for final approval, he said. The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted index jumped more than 150 percent from the opening session in 1989 to 12,495.34 on Feb. 10 this year before plunging to as low as 3,135.56 on Aug. 24. On Friday, worries about oil price hikes sent the weighted index down 39.64 points, or 1.14 percent, to close at 3,480.47.

DOC.HEAD: Pichler Now Kroger's Chairman and CEO
DOC.TEXT: Kroger Co. veteran executive Lyle Everingham on Friday relinquished the title of board chairman to Joseph Pichler, the company said. Kroger announced at its May 17 stockholders meeting that Pichler, 50, was moving up from president to succeed Everingham in June as chief executive officer. Everingham, 64, who is retiring, now has passed the chairman's title to Pichler as well. Everingham, who began with Kroger as a store clerk in Adrian, Mich., in 1946, will remain as a member of the company's board of directors. He also will continue to serve as chairman of the executive committee until he retires in January. Pichler became Kroger's president and chief operating officer in October 1986. He joined the Dillon Cos. Inc., of Hutchinson, Kan., in 1980 as executive vice president and came to Kroger when Dillon became part of the company in January 1983. Kroger, based in Cincinnati, operates supermarkets, food processing plants and convenience stores. It employs about 170,000 people in 32 states.

DOC.HEAD: CBOT Turns Down Plan to Repay Stotler Debt
DOC.TEXT: Customers of the failed Stotler & Co. may have to wait up to six months to receive payments after the Chicago Board of Trade turned down a plan to pay off $930,000 of the company's debt. Stotler's court-appointed bankruptcy trustee, Ronald Peterson, said Thursday that he proposed a plan for the Board of Trade to cover the debt while he battles a challenge to the payment in bankruptcy court. The Chicago-based futures brokerage firm filed for bankruptcy liquidation on Aug. 24, after financial problems surfaced in mid-July. Peterson said he believes there is more than enough money to pay what is still owed to customers, an amount estimated at $2.3 million. He said he proposed the plan because Stotler's debts ``created a black eye in terms of people's confidence in the marketplace, and it would be great publicity to do this.'' But Board of Trade officials turned down the plan, saying that other steps in the legal process should be used. ``There appears to be plenty of funds to pay out to customers,'' said Frederick Grede, vice president of the Board of Trade. ``The trustee has to get a legal order from the bankruptcy judge to pay those funds out.''

DOC.NOTE: $adv 17
For Release Monday, Sept. 17
DOC.HEAD: Thrift Regulators' Junk Bond Sales Ripple Market, But Don't Swamp It
DOC.TEXT: The Resolution Trust Corp. has been selling an estimated $50 million to $75 million worth of junk bonds weekly, chipping away at its $2.9 billion portfolio from failed savings and loans. For the most part, the weak junk market has been able to absorb the selling without plunging further than it has already on fears of a sluggish economy. ``There are still buyers in today's market willing to invest in what they see has value,'' said Joseph Bencivenga, head of high-yield, or junk bond, research at Salomon Brothers Inc. A number of reasons are offered for the bond market's resilience to the RTC sales, but many point to the decision by the thrift bailout agency to unload the securities slowly. ``The RTC has done a good job of metering the flow. In the beginning people were afraid they would dump hundreds of millions a day,'' Bencivenga said. During a slightly busier than normal week, the RTC sold about $70 million worth of bonds Tuesday and offered $40 million more Wednesday, market observers said. The RTC has been able to avoid a great shock to a market that handles $100 million to $200 million worth of bonds daily. When the government announced it would sell assets from failed thrifts, including high-yield bonds, many feared the bond sales would further depress the market. Junk prices have slumped for most of the past year since investors became skittish after the highly leveraged retail empire of Campeau Corp. began to come apart. Junk bonds pay higher interest than investment-grade bonds to compensate for the increased risk that the company issuing the bonds won't be able to make payments on them. ``I think the sales have hurt the market, but everyone has long since discounted the sales,'' tempering the damage, said Paul Getman, an economist at Regional Financial Associates Inc. in West Chester, Pa. ``When it first got wind that the RTC was going to be seizing thrifts with large junk portfolios the market really fell apart.'' Despite the depressed market, the RTC cannot wait for better days. The agency is in business to get rid of the bonds and other assets from failed thrifts and apparently wants to do it before the market gets worse. The value of many of the RTC's bonds is depressed, but if the economy continues to slow and consumers spend less, the companies that issued the bonds may have less money to pay interest and principal. That would push the market value of the bonds down even further. Thrift regulators last week blocked Columbia Savings & Loan from selling $3 billion of its junk bonds to a group of investors primarily from Canada and Hong Kong. Regulators apparently feared the deal could leave the government holding the bonds if their market value declines further. Under the deal, the investor group, called Gordon America LP, would pay $300 million up front and give Columbia a 10-year note paying 10.5 percent interest for the remaining $2.7 billion. Gordon America had an escape route that apparently left regulators concerned the government would wind up getting the bonds at a price even lower than they are now. If the value of the bonds fell 10 percent below the purchase price, the buyers could have walked away from the deal, losing their down payment but avoiding further losses. The bonds would then go back to Beverly Hills, Calif.-based Columbia and, if it were seized by regulators, to the government. Regulators say they would support an all-cash deal in which Columbia gets rid of the bonds for good.
DOC.NOTE: End adv Monday, Sept. 17

DOC.HEAD: On 30th Anniversary, OPEC Official Predicts Group's Survival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subroto is cq as full name.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC marked its 30th anniversary Friday with its top official predicting the oil-producing organization would survive the Persian Gulf crisis that has badly tarnished its image. ``A world without OPEC is unthinkable for as long as oil continues to provide the prime source of energy,'' said Subroto, secretary-general of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. ``OPEC will stay around. We have survived crises before. ... Surely, we'll survive this also. All disputes ultimately get resolved,'' he said in an anniversary message carried by the group's OPECNA news agency. OPEC was created by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Iran, Iraq and Kuwait on Sept. 14, 1960, in Baghdad, Iraq, in an effort to give them more muscle to push up crude prices. It has since grown to 13 nations. Throughout its history, the cartel has had to deal with a string of crises, including Iraq's 1980 invasion of neighbor Iran. This time, the oil producer moved against another neighbor, occupying tiny Kuwait and creating more turmoil for the cartel. In his statement, Subroto said the group's objectives remain sound. They include coordinating oil policies of member nations, steadying the world market, ensuring a constant flow of oil revenues to members and maintaining an adequate supply of crude for consumers. ``Everyone is for a stable oil market,'' he said. ``No one wants violent fluctuations in prices.'' He said the producing nations do not want a repeat of the 1980s when prices went on a roller-coaster ride that carried them to almost $40 a barrel before plunging to a little more than $10. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, crude prices have soared. Light sweet crude, the benchmark American grade, has been trading at about $31 a barrel. A basket of crudes monitored by OPEC surged last week to $28.84 a barrel, well above its target price of $21 dollars that was set shortly before the Iraqi strike. Subroto, who previously was Indonesia's oil minister, said the cartel was in a position to meet the crude requirements of consuming nations well into the next century. ``No one should think otherwise because of the temporary difficulties we face today,'' he said. OPEC President Sadek Boussena, who is the Algerian oil minister, said producers and consumers can learn from the group's experience ``that what is needed is good will, not ill will; trust, not suspicion; and cooperation, not confrontation.'' In addition to the five founding members, the group includes Qatar, Indonesia, Libya, the United Arab Emirates, Algeria, Nigeria, Ecuador and Gabon.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.HEAD: British Shares Fall
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the London Stock Exchange fell sharply on Friday. With the tensions in the Middle East and Friday's release of an unexpectedly high 10.6 percent August inflation rate in Britain, caution would prevail in the market for the near future, traders said. The Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 33.3 points, or 1.56 percent, at 2,093.8. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index closed down 23.3 points at 1,609.6, while the Financial Times 500-share index closed down 15.67 at 1,125.83. Volume Friday was 418 million shares, up from Thursday's 335.4 million shares traded.
Here are the major business events and economic events scheduled for the coming week (some dates are tentative; times are EDT):
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. - United Mine Workers convention begins weeklong run.

WASHINGTON - Business inventories for July will be released at 10 a.m. by the Commerce Department. WASHINGTON - The United Shareholders Association will hold its annual meeting. DETROIT - Chevrolet previews 1991 models.
DOC.HEAD: TUESDAY, Sept. 18
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON - Merchandise trade for July will be released at 8:30 a.m. by the Commerce Department; Consumer prices for August, 8:30 a.m., Labor Department. DETROIT - Ford previews 1991 models. SAN FRANCISCO - Next Inc. computer company introduces improvements to its workstation and new software. ROCHESTER - Kodak will unveil a new photo system.

WASHINGTON - Housing starts for August will be released at 8:30 a.m. by the Commerce Department. HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. - Chrysler 1991 model preview. RICHMOND, Va. - Philip Morris due in court to answer a charge that it has violated the state's new public smoking law at its plant.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala. - USX Corp. and two United Steelworkers union officers are scheduled to be sentenced for conspiring to provide the union leaders with pensions while negotiating a new contract.
Nothing scheduled.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Agriculture Still A Dangerous Job
DOC.TEXT: Keith Adams was helping his father unload corn on their Iowa farm one day, but he climbed into the wagon and was sucked into the grain as if it were quicksand. He suffocated. Keith was 11. His mother, Marilyn Adams of Earlham, Iowa, soon discovered her son's tragedy was no freak accident. Many others had been pulled into flowing grain in wagons and bins and suffocated. Mrs. Adams decided to design decals warning, ``Flowing grain traps and suffocates victims in seconds,'' and ``Never play in or on this wagon.'' She also broadened the scope of her crusade and formed Farm Safety for JUST KIDS. The group produces literature and video tapes on farm safety and arranges workshops and school presentations. Farming is one of the nation's most dangerous occupations, and the families of victims of farm tragedies are using their stories to warn others and to improve agriculture's safety record. ``Farmers are beginning to change their behavior and attitude,'' said Mrs. Adams. ``Mom has a reason now to tell Dad that Johnny is not going with him to do something today. Keeping kids alive is a top priority.'' Farming, the nation's deadliest job in 1988, improved to second place behind mining in 1989 with 42 deaths per 100,000 workers. But the death rate for all industry is nine per 100,000, and the agriculture statistics do not include 200 to 300 deaths of youngsters, said Larry Williams, a farm safety expert with Country Companies Insurance Group. In addition to 1,300 farm deaths, 130,000 disabling injuries occurred last year. Country Companies estimates the loss at $3.6 billion. Ralph Wier, 63, was hurrying to finish his farm chores so he could go to the bank, but his tractor overturned and crushed him to death. Delight Wier lost her husband in 1987. Her 3-year-old son caught his leg in a wagon auger in 1958 and died. Her 12-year-old daughter fell on an electric fence in 1970 and died. Mrs. Wier, who lives near Lacon, now writes magazine columns and books and stresses safety to other farm families. She and son, Jon, also practice what they preach on their 1,000-acre Marshall County farm. ``We have seat belts and rollbars on our tractors and slow-moving vehicle signs on all machinery that goes on the highway,'' said Mrs. Wier, who has taken implement safety courses and learned CPR. ``Accidents happen when farmers are under stress, so I insist they take breaks,'' she said. ``I don't think it'sa favor to take food to them in the field. They should stop and come in the house and rest.'' The best rule for farm children is to avoid the dangers, from mowers to slurry pits. Various reasons for the dangers exist. Experts cite the vast array of heavy machinery and large animals, the fatigue associated with long hours of work during planting and harvest seasons, the constant exposure of living at the workplace, and the long distance to hospitals. ``Children seem to be attracted to farm equipment because of its size and power,'' said Williams, adding that they also want to help their parents. Children are most often injured while riding on machinery with an adult. Farmers are most often killed when their tractors roll over and pin them. Solutions can be as simple and inexpensive as not allowing extra riders on implements, or as costly as the $400 to $1,500 to add seat belts and rollbars to an older tractor, said Bob Aherin, a University of Illinois farm safety specialist. He said farmers also are encouraged to attend safety workshops now offered in rural communities, to read and follow instructions in equipment manuals, to wear protective clothing, and to know their limitations. Aherin said a bill in Congress would provide $320 million over five years to improve farm safety. The measure would pay for research on health and safety issues, rehabilitation programs for injured farmers, training for rescue workers, education on farm safety, and a national data collection system on accidents.

Stock prices declined broadly again today as the market absorbed new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 24.75 to 2,557.92 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 334 up, 1,094 down and 451 unchanged. The Labor Department reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp rises in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possible fallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pressures. In that kind of climate, few market participants can see much reason for optimism about the outlook for corporate profits and dividends. Brokers also noted that stocks had to contend with rising oil prices in the commodity markets today. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included General Motors, down { at 37}; General Electric, down 1[ at 59\; Digital Equipment, down 4 at 55\, and International Business Machines, down 1[ at 103~. Depressed bank stocks also remained on the defensive. Chemical Banking fell } to 20[; Citicorp [ to 17\, and Manufacturers Hanover ] to 25\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.64 to 173.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.44 at 320.57. Volume on the Big Board came to 97.08 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: British Inflation Worst Among Major Industrialized Nations
DOC.TEXT: A dry summer and the Middle East crisis have driven Britain's annual inflation rate up to 10.6 percent, the highest rate in more than eight years, the government reported Friday. The latest inflation rate is 0.3 percentage points higher than the financial markets had expected, and is at its highest level since February 1982, when it stood at 11 percent. The figure is also higher than the rate Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher inherited in 1979 from a Labor Party government she had chastised for loosing control of the economy. ``After 11 years in power the government that promised us stable prices has delivered us an inflation rate of 10.6 percent,'' said lawmaker John Smith, the Labor Party's spokesman on Treasury matters. But Norman Lamont, the Treasury's chief secretary, said on British television: ``We will be content at the election to be judged on our record. Our record over the lifetime of this government is very much better than what we inherited, and you must not forget that.'' The government blamed the surging inflation on higher oil prices caused by the Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, as well as a jump in food prices caused by drought. Britain has by far the highest inflation rate among the major industrialized nations. Italy's 6.2 percent rate is second. The government's forecast that high interest rates would moderate inflation by the end of the year now looks doubtful, and time is running out for Mrs. Thatcher's government to find a solution before an election is required in mid-1992. Inflation has risen steadily even though economic growth has declined since Mrs. Thatcher won her third consecutive five-year term in June 1987. The government's chosen cure has become as painful as inflation. With interest rates at 15 percent for a year, the number of house repossessions has doubled since the second half of 1989. The problems started when the government lowered interest rates in 1988 to prevent a recession after the October 1987 stock market crash. This year's inflation outlook will remain clouded by the Mideast crisis, although economists say the world's economies are better prepared to handle oil shocks than they were in the 1970s. The current problems contrast with the mid-1980s, when Britain was enjoying a sustained economic boom and Mrs. Thatcher was credited with curing Britain's economic disease. Inflation, which had crested at 21.9 percent during a recession in May 1980, had dropped to a 20-year low of 2.4 percent in July 1986. Now the socialist Labor Party considers itself justified in criticizing the government's economic policies. Labor had been widely blamed for soaring inflation, high interest rates and militant unionism in the 1970s. In August 1975, under a Labor government, inflation peaked at 26.9 percent. On Friday, Labor spokesman Smith blamed the current rise in inflation on the goernment's ``massively incompetent economic mismanagement.'' Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major conceded in radio interviews that Britain's inflation was a ``good deal higher than we would wish to see it'' but maintained that inflation was not ``out of control.'' Although some economists and businessmen fear continued high interest rates will tip Britain into a recession, Major reiterated his commitment to holding interest rates high until he feels inflation is defeated. Major declined to say when inflation might peak and when interest rates might come down.

DOC.HEAD: Operations at Kuwaiti-Owned U.S. Companies Return To Normal
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Six weeks after the government froze Kuwait's U.S. assets to prevent Iraq from seizing them, Kuwaiti-owned companies in this country say operations are back to normal thanks to exemptions granted by the Treasury Department. Customers and suppliers of Santa Fe International in Alhambra, Calif., initially expressed concern about dealing with the Kuwaiti-owned oil drilling company following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, said Vice President John Mika. ``They wanted assurance that they were not violating any freeze order by continuing their relationship with us,'' he said. But the Treasury ``cooperated quite well with us'' in granting the exemption, which allows the company to continue writing checks, making payroll and otherwise operate normally, he said. At Georgetown Industries, a Kuwaiti-owned steel company in Charlotte, N.C., ``our business is very much business as usual,'' said President Roger Regelbrugge. ``We have no other restrictions than that we are not supposed to transfer assets to the government of Kuwait or to Iraq,'' he said. The Hilton Hotels Corp., whose Atlanta Hotel & Tower is owned by the Kuwaiti government, also has had no problems, said spokeswoman Kendra Silverman. Estimates of Kuwait's U.S. investments vary widely - from under $10 billion to more than $50 billion - because of the nation's policy of secrecy. One investment industry source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Kuwait bars its investment managers from speaking publicly about its assets. ``A great deal of it is going to be unknown,'' said Scott Rogers, a Mideast economist at the economic research firm DRI-McGraw-Hill. Kuwait's overall foreign assets last year totaled an estimated $124 billion, according to DRI-McGraw-Hill. Much of that is in Europe, and includes such high-profile investments as a 14 percent stake in Daimler-Benz AG, the German auto, electronics and aerospace giant. Santa Fe International, which state-owned Kuwait Petroleum Corp. bought for $2.5 billion in 1981, is believed to be the Mideast nation's largest single U.S. holding. Among Kuwait's other U.S. assets are stakes in several hotels, a bank holdingcompany, a real estate investment company and undeveloped land, along with stock and bond holdings in various U.S. companies. Other known Kuwaiti government assets in the United States, according to the New York-based newsletter MidEast Report and other sources, include: - Occidental Geothermal Inc. of Los Angeles, which Kuwait Petroleum Corp. bought for $350 million in 1984. - About 12 percent of Corporate Property Investors, which owns real estate in New York as well as a number of shopping malls nationwide. - An undetermined stake in First American Bankshares Inc., a bank holding company in Washington, D.C. - Forty-five percent of the Phoenecian resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., which was controlled by scandal-plagued Lincoln Savings and Loan until the federal government took over Lincoln's share. - Forty-five percent of the Crescent hotel in Phoenix. In addition, private Kuwaiti investors - not subject to the asset freeze - hold an undertermined stake in Investcorp, which owns the Saks Fifth Avenue department stores and other properties. MidEast Report estimates Kuwait's U.S. assets at $50 billion. Not even the Treasury Department, charged with enforcing the asset freeze, has a complete accounting of Kuwait's U.S. investments. The department began a list after Iraq's invasion, but had not finished it as of Friday, a spokeswoman said. The Treasury would not disclose which companies have been granted exemptions. The spokeswoman, who asked not to be identified, said the exemptions were designed ``to allow the Kuwati government to conduct its normal business in the smoothest way possible while assuring that no benefits accrue to Iraq.'' The department also has issued general exemptions for categories of companies, such as telephone and foreign exchange companies, that meet certain conditions. According to one measure by the Commerce Department, Kuwait's direct investments in U.S. companies totaled $4.2 billion last year. That figure does not account for investments made through intermediaries such as Kuwaiti companies not based in Kuwait. Nor does it include investments in companies that result in less than 10 percent of the voting stock, nor Kuwait's ``portfolio'' accounts of stocks, bonds and other investments being managed by U.S. investment houses. David T. Mizrahi, editor of MidEast Report, estimates 25 percent of Kuwait's U.S. assets are held in portfolio accounts at firms including J.P. Morgan & Co., Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc. and Citicorp. By a broader measure last taken in 1988, the value of all U.S. companies in which Kuwait held at least 10 percent control totaled $10 billion. But since that Commerce Department figure includes the full value of those companies no matter what the size of Kuwait's stake, most likely overstates Kuwait's investment. Former Treasury Secretary G. William Miller helps manage Kuwait's U.S. assets, MidEast Report says. Among Kuwait's U.S. investment groups is the Wafra Investment Advisory Group of New York, which invests Kuwaiti pension funds. Much of Kuwait's assets worldwide are managed by the Kuwaiti Investment Office in London.

DOC.HEAD: Telefonica Takes 6 Percent Stake in AT&T's Main European Unit
DOC.TEXT: Spain's Telefonica SA said Friday it had reached an agreement to take a 6 percent stake in American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s main European holding company in exchange for its 20 percent share in a Spanish microchip company. In a joint statement, state-controlled Telefonica said it was swapping its 20 percent share in AT&T Microelectronica SA for 6 percent of Netherlands-based AT&T Network Systems International BV, or AT&T-NSI. AT&T-NSI will now own 100 percent of AT&T Microelectronica, which in 1985 built a $200 million custom microchip factory just north of Madrid. Telefonica President Candido Velazquez called the accord ``an important step in the growing process of internationalization of Telefonica, permitting us to directly participate in a European project like ATT-NSI.'' AT&T President Robert Allen said the agreement ``permits us to widen our European perspectives and strengthen our position as a global company.'' The U.S. company owned a 65 percent stake in its ATT-NSI European unit. Italy's state-controlled STET owns 15 percent and the Netherlands' N.V. Philips Gloeilampen fabrieken owns another 15 percent. ATT-NSI produces software and hardware products for most of Europe's public telecommunications networks. Earlier Friday, AT&T Network Systems Espana presented a new, $100 million factory, which will provide 250,000 telephone lines to Telefonica through 1990 and 300,000 lines in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Auto Talks
DOC.TEXT: Here with brief descriptions are some of the issues being discussed in national contract talks between the United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. as bargaining entered the final hours Friday.

The overriding issue in the negotiations. The union wants employment guarantees for a large number of its members while GM wants flexibility to reduce its size. There are about 300,000 active UAW-covered workers at GM plants nationwide.

The union and GM have refused to release details of proposals. But an early GM offer reportedly involved a 2 percent increase in base wages in the first year and 2 percent lump-sum payments in each of the next two.

Automakers have said they desperately need to cut health-care costs and the union said it will not stand for a reduction in benefits. Ways to cut costs include more movement to managed health-care systems, such as health maintenance organizations, and more active monitoring of claims.

A large group of UAW members have pushed their leadership to demand cost-of-living protection keyed to the inflation rate. UAW and company officials have conceded that could cost billions of dollars. More likely is a lump-sum increase for retirees.
GM and the UAW have agreed to an entirely new program that says workers with more than 16 unexcused absences a year would be disciplined.
Agreement has been reached on a long-term GM commitment to help workers seek counseling for substance abuse and other problems.
GM has agreed to boost payments to a legal assistance program for UAW workers until the fund reaches $10 million. Then the automaker can scale back contributions.
Both sides have agreed that at least one employee in each plant will have the full-time job of monitoring quality.

A pilot program was agreed to under which a child-care center would be established to replace the current referral service. Chrysler Corp. is building such a center at its Huntsville, Ala., parts plant.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Down
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.13 percent this week, down from 10.19 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.26 percent, down from 8.29 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Grains Lower, Beans Advance
DOC.TEXT: Corn and wheat futures prices extended their losses Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade while most soybean futures advanced, all in a continuing reaction to a recent government crop report. The Agriculture Department report released Wednesday contained projections for 1990 U.S. corn and wheat production that were higher than the market expected. The USDA also predicted the nation's soybean stockpile would continue to dwindle due to strong world demand for soybean meal and a smaller harvest next spring in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer after the United States. ``People are getting bullish on the meal, and meal exerts a lot of influence over soybeans,'' said Joel Karlin, grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Karlin said wheat futures also were pressured by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's pledge to oppose an increase in crop set-aside acreage as a means of stemming a slide in wheat prices. Yeutter told a farmers group in Chicago that taking more crop acreage out of production would ultimately make the United States less competitive in the world market. At the close, wheat futures were 2} cents to 4\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.57 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2 cents lower with September at $2.32} a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent higher with September at $1.07 a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to 4 cents higher with September at $6.24{ a bushel.

Stock prices fell again today as the market absorbed new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 23.02 to 2,559.65 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 399 up, 1,055 down and 464 unchanged. The Labor Department reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp rises in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possible fallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pressures. In that kind of climate, few market participants can see much reason for optimism about the outlook for corporate profits and dividends. Brokers also noted that stocks had to contend with rising oil prices in the commodity markets today. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included General Motors, down { at 37}; General Electric, down 1 at 59]; Digital Equipment, down 3] at 55~, and International Business Machines, down 1[ at 103~. Depressed bank stocks also remained on the defensive. Chemical Banking fell | to 20\; Citicorp [ to 17\, and Manufacturers Hanover \ to 25]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.36 to 173.80. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.01 at 321.00. Volume on the Big Board came to 113.34 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Falling Output Another Indication of a Lethargic Economy
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production fell 0.2 percent in August, its worst performance in four months, the government said Friday in a report analysts said was another indication the manufacturing economy remains locked in lethargy. ``The industrial side is clearly signalling a slumping economy,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York government securities dealer. It was the government's first report on factory activity since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. But the manufacturing economy had been sluggish long before that, growing a meager 1.5 percent over the last year, the Federal Reserve said. In a companion report, the central bank said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities - which usually moves in tandem with industrial production - fell 0.4 percentage point to 83.1 percent. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. ``It's consistent with the other data, for example, the manufacturing employment figures, ... the National Association of Purchasing Management index,'' said Evalina Tainer, senior domestic economist with the First National Bank of Chicago. ``It continues to show the manufacturing sector is quite sluggish.'' The Labor Department reported last week that 45,000 factory jobs were lost in August. It was the 16th time in 17 months that manufacturing jobs declined. The monthly survey by the purchasing executives last week showed the manufacturing sector had slowed in August for the second straight month. Their index was down to 47.0 percent. When the index registers below 50 percent, it indicates the economy is weakening. In fact, economist Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers and Richard W. Rahn, chief economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said in separate statements the economy may have slipped into a recession in August. Only utilities posted a gain in production, up 1.2 percent. But Richards noted the advance was due to electric power and ``may have been little more than a seasonal factor'' during the airconditioning season. None of the other major components showed a gain. The manufacturing sector was off 0.1 percent, including a 0.2 percent drop in output of durable goods, items expected to last more than three years. Non-durable output was unchanged, while mining production plunged 2.3 percent. The Fed said its industrial production index in August stood at 109.8 percent of its 1987 base, down from 110.0 percent in July. In its capacity utilization report, the Fed said the operating rate at factories producing durable goods fell 0.4 percentage point to 81.4 percent, while the rate at plants making non-durable goods slipped 0.2 percentage point to 83.8 percent. The operating rate at mines fell from 89.7 percent in July to 87.8 in August, while it gained 1 percentage point to 86.9 percent at utilities.
The stock market declined broadly today in the face of rising oil prices and negative economic news. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 19.55 at 2,563.12.

Stock prices fell today, faced with new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Labor Department reported this morning that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp rises in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possiblefallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pressures. In that kind of climate, few market participants can see much reason for optimism about the outlook for corporate profits and dividends. Brokers also noted that stocks had to contend with rising oil prices in the commodity markets.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: commodity markets.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 18.56 to 2,564.11, extending its loss for the week to 55.44 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 451 up, 1,005 down and 479 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 133.39 million shares, against 123.37 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index fell 1.01 to 174.15.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: With AM-Auto Talks, Bjt
DOC.HEAD: Sketches of Main Auto Negotiators
DOC.TEXT: Here are thumbnail sketches of the top four management and labor leaders involved in national contract negotiations between General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union.

NAME: Robert Stempel. POSITION: Chairman and chief executive officer. AGE: 57. BACKGROUND: Stempel took over the world's largest corporation on Aug. 1, and is GM's first engineer-trained chairman. He joined the automaker's Oldsmobile Division in 1958 and held various design and engineering positions in that division until 1973 when he was appointed special assistant to GM President Edward N. Cole. The following year he moved to the Chevrolet Division where he served in a variety of engineering divisions. After a two-year stint in GM's Pontiac Division, Stempel headed overseas where he was appointed managing director of Adam Opel AG of West Germany in 1980. He returned to the United States as Chevrolet's general manager in 1982. He was promoted to head the Buick-Oldsmobile Cadillac Group before becoming an executive vice president in 1986. The following year, he became GM's 17th president, a post he held until he succeeded retired GM Chairman Roger B. Smith.

NAME: Alfred S. Warren Jr. POSITION: Vice president of industrial relations. AGE: 64. BACKGROUND: Warren, born in Aliquippa, Pa., took his current position on Sept. 1, 1980, and is the veteran among this year's top negotiators. He joined GM in 1959 as assistant personnel director at Chevrolet's Tonawanda engine plant in Buffalo, N.Y., and was promoted to several plant manager positions. He was transferred to the company's personnel administration staff in October 1973. Warren is a champion of joint company-union programs and worked closely with retired UAW Vice President Donald Ephlin in implementing a variety of joint programs in GM.

NAME: Owen Bieber. POSITION: President. AGE: 60. BACKGROUND: Bieber, a native of North Dorr, Mich., joined the UAW in 1948 while working at McInerney Spring and Wire Co. in Grand Rapids, Mich. He rose through the ranks through Local 687 before being appointed to the international union's staff in 1961. He served as an assistant director and director in Region 1D in southwest lower Michigan. He was elected as a UAW vice president in 1980 and was appointed head of the union's GM Department, a post he held before being elected president of the one million-member union in 1983.

NAME: Stephen P. Yokich. POSITION: Vice president and director of the UAW GM Department. AGE: 54. BACKGROUND: Yokich, whose grandfathers were active in UAW matters, began working as a tool-and-die maker in Oak Park, Mich. His first union job was shop chairman in UAW Local 155. He was appointed to the UAW staff by former union president Walter Reuther. He held a series of international union offices, including vice president of the Agricultural Implement Department and the Ford Department before being named to his current position in June 1989. Yokich is regarded as a tough negotiator and a likely successor to UAW President Owen Bieber.

DOC.NOTE: $adv 15
$adv 16
For Release Weekend Editions Sept. 15-16
DOC.HEAD: Extended Trading Hours, Rumors and a Sad-Damn Recession
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't the biggest headline of the week, but the New York Stock Exchange's approval of extended trading hours provided an entry for the history books. The board of the world's best-known stock market put its stamp on the first stages of a plan that could lead to round-the-clock trading within five to 10 years. Approved were two after-hours trading sessions that will allow big market players to execute trades after the NYSE's closing bell at 4 p.m. Eastern time. Up to now, such business has been flowing overseas; hence the motivation for the exchange's unprecedented move. It was a small step - the sessions will only last about an hour and are aimed at big stock traders, not individuals - but the late sessions are nevertheless a giant leap for the tradition-bound Big Board. The sessions won't require the services of the so-called ``specialists'' who manage trading on the floor of the exchange during regular business hours. The post-close sessions propose to match buyers and sellers electronically, as they are in London. The new ``crossing sessions'' won't radically alter Wall Street life as the world knows it. Individual stocks will trade at their closing prices. But later stages of the plan call for stock auctions several times a night, and then 24-hour trading before the year 2000.
DOC.HEAD: MARKETS: Rumors Haunt the Pits
DOC.TEXT: Six weeks into the Persian Gulf crisis, rumors were supplanting headlines as the currency of the financial markets. Oil futures trading, in particular, caromed from rumor to rumor. The impact was most apparent Monday, when lower oil prices were suddenly pushed higher on reports of Iraqi troop movement toward Jordan. Officials at the New York Mercantile Exchange, seeming more suspicious than usual about the circulation of false reports, said they would investigate to determine whether any gossip was being spread to influence prices. Meanwhile, oil appeared to be establishing a base at $30 per barrel, evidence to some experts that the rumor mill was helping support that floor. Stocks, for their part, started to pay more attention to the economy. A 43-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average Thursday was blamed on fears of rising inflation.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Fears Are Panning Out
DOC.TEXT: Inflation worries were confirmed by the wholesale price report issued Friday, which showed a big 1.3 percent jump in August. The Labor Department blamed the increase on Gulf-inspired oil price hikes. Most other economic newswas bad as well. The government said retail sales slumped 0.6 percent last month despite a jump in spending at gasoline stations. The combination of sluggish growth and increased inflation revived fears of ``stagflation,'' the old bugaboo that haunted the economy in the 1970s. One market economist, Roger Brinner of DRI McGraw-Hill, said it was up to the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates and spare the economy from a ``Sad-damn recession,'' coining a reference to the man behind Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
DOC.HEAD: BANKS: Reaching a Crisis Point
DOC.TEXT: A recession could wipe out bank deposit insurance funds and require a bailout along the lines of the savings and loan rescue, Congress was told. Reports on the banking sector from the General Accounting Office and Congressional Budget Office were the bleakest seen to date. Even Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan agreed the situation was grim, but he warned Congress against hasty action that could precipitate a crisis. Still, lawmakers readied bills to raise bank insurance premiums and limit coverage on deposits.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: A Merger Battle Erupts
DOC.TEXT: Aon Corp. launched a $840 million bid for the insurer Corroon & Black Corp., setting up Wall Street's first big merger contest in months. The new bid competes with a stock swap Corroon had already arranged with Willis Faber PLC of London. Corroon said it would study the new proposal. American Airlines said it would go to court to reverse a government decision allowing United Airlines landing priorities at Chicago's O'Hare airport. The move heightened the feud between the two carriers over evening landing schedules at the nation's busiest airport. Coca-Cola was proclaimed the strongest brand name in the world by a consulting firm. Sony and Mercedes-Benz were runners-up. Testifying to the importance of imagery, retailer K mart Corp. unveiled a new red logo to counter its reputation as blue-light discounter. And the RCA division of Thomson Consumer Electronics announced it was bringing back Nipper the dog, of ear to the gramophone fame, for a new round of television commercials. The hound will be joined by little Nipper, an even cuter pup.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: The Pros and Cons of Sentencing Milken
DOC.TEXT: Fallen financial star Michael Milken was back in the headlines as his sentencing on six felonies neared. Government prosecutors, who had doggedly pursued the junk-bond king for four years before his guilty pleas in April, planned to lay open their full case against him to influence his sentencing Oct. 1. They planned to allege additional crimes to persuade the judge not to go easy on the financier. Milken was not without his supporters, though. Scores of letters were filed with the Manhattan court testifying to Milken's otherwise upstanding character. Among his advocates were Time Warner Inc. Chairman Steven J. Ross; Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum Corp.; and former ``Let's Make a Deal'' host Monty Hall.
DOC.HEAD: DEALMAKERS: Have Pizza, Will Litigate
DOC.TEXT: Houston attorney Reid McInvale said he was only trying to be a good Samaritan when he had pizza delivered to hungry help in local emergency rooms. But some Texans thought the personal injury litigator had raised the art of ambulance chasing to a new level of - no pun intended - bad taste. McInvale dispatched pizzas to two public health hospitals for several nights - with business cards attached. The attorney insisted he wasn't trying to solicit business, but local prosecutors looked askance at the practice and asked him to cease and desist. Texas Bar authorities reckoned it was their first-ever ethics question involving pizza pies.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Sept. 15-16

DOC.HEAD: Tucker Named Head of Saatchi's US Operations
DOC.TEXT: The troubled advertising giant Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC said Friday that Martin Tucker has been named president and chief executive of its holdings in the United States. Tucker, formerly the U.S. operation's general counsel, replaces W. Jonathan T. Hirst, who is resigning to pursue ``other career interests,'' Saatchi said.
