Robert Louis-Dreyfus, the chief executive of the London-based parent company, said Hirst, 41, had told him several months ago that he wanted to pursue other interests once he had completed the sale of the Saatchi consulting business, and that that task ``was now virtually done.'' Hirst had been with Saatchi for eight years, including two as head of its U.S. operations. Efforts to reach the three Saatchi executives were unavailing. London-based Saatchi got its start as an advertising company but grew rapidly over the past decade, branching out into management consulting in an effort to offer its advertising and marketing clients more services. But the results from consulting have been poor and the company decided to sell its consulting businesses. Some of them have been sold for only a fraction of what Saatchi paid for them, however. For the first half of this year, Saatchi reported it lost about $13.4 million, mainly reflecting losses on the sale of two consulting businesses. A week ago the company said its balance sheet was too weak to pay a regular dividend. Louis-Dreyfus said Tucker, 67, brings ``many years of experience in the advertising business, both as a lawyer and executive'' to the new post as president and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Holdings (USA) Inc. ``His appointment underscores our company's decision to concentrate on its core communications business,'' Louis-Dreyfus said. He said Hirst will remain as a consultant to the company to complete the previously announced sale of Gartner Group Inc. and to assist Tucker in transition. Gartner is being sold to an investor group for $55 million in cash and $15 million in notes and other obligations. But Saatchi paid $86 million for Gartner only two years ago. ``Jonathan Hirst has made many outsanding contributions to the company during the past eight years, not the least of which was the sale of the consulting group companies in the difficult business and financing conditions of the past year. We wish him well for the future,'' Louis-Dreyfus said. Saatchi operates the giant ad agencies Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. In addition, it owns the ad agencies Campbell-Mithun-Esty, McCaffrey & McCall, AC&R and Conill Advertising. It owns public relations and design firms, a direct marketing agency and several smaller management consulting firms.

DOC.HEAD: Manpower Agrees to Sell British Units
DOC.TEXT: Manpower PLC has agreed to sell five British subsidiaries for $200 million in the last step in a restructuring of the temporary-help giant, Manpower Chairman Mitchell Fromstein said Friday. Fromstein said the company had agreed to sell the five non-related British subsidiaries for $200 million to a group that includes managers there in a leveraged buyout. The executives from Brook Street Bureau, the largest of the five British companies being sold, have formed Brook Opportunities Ltd. to make the acquisition, he said. The other four companies are Blue Arrow Personnel Services, Extrastaff, DP Support Services and IPS Group. The companies, all in the temporary and permanent placement business, together brought in 15 percent to 20 percent of Manpower's total sales, Fromstein said. ``It's quite a relief,'' Fromstein said. ``It's a relief because the market is weak today. So we've had to work very hard to get this thing done. We are satisfied with it.'' Fromstein said the sale, which is expected to close Oct. 4, would allow Manpower to pay down debt. The next steps include incorporating Manpower as a U.S. company, he said. The deal calls for Manpower to receive $200 million in cash plus 15 percent of the voting share capital of the acquiring company. After the sale, Manpower will buy an additional $4 million in variable nonvoting preference shares of the new company. The sale is part of a planned divestiture of companies that made up the Blue Arrow Group before it acquired Manpower in 1987. Fromstein subsequently took control of Blue Arrow and moved Manpower's headquarters from London to the Milwaukee suburb of Glendale. At the time, the company said it would sell non-Manpower subsidiaries to retire long-term debt. The leveraged buyout announced Friday will include an equity investment of about $80 million. The remainder of the purchase price will be borrowed from banks. In June, Manpower sold a group of six non-Manpower subsidiaries in the U.S. for $46 million in cash.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 173.94 Friday, down 3.41, or 1.92 percent, from a week ago and down 23.34, or 11.83 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 163.94 Friday, down 3.25, or 1.94 percent, from a week ago and down 21.17, or 11.44 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 137.89 Friday, down 2.22, or 1.58 percent, from a week ago and down 30.42, or 18.07 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Breeden to Meet with Japanese, British Stock Regulators
DOC.TEXT: Securities regulators from Britain and Japan will meet with Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden in Virginia next week, the SEC announced Friday. The first trilateral meeting between securities regulators in the three nations is slated for Sept. 18 and 19 in Airlie, Va., outside Washington. John Redwood, undersecretary for corporate affairs of Britain's Department of Trade and Industry; David Walker, chairman of the Securities and Investments Board for the United Kingdom and Nobuhiko Matsuno, director-general of Japan's Securities Bureau of the Ministry of Finance, will discuss investor protection, market access disclosure principles and other topics with Breeden.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher in New York; Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished modestly higher against most major foreign currencies in U.S. trading Friday after news of a flareup in the Middle East conflict abruptly reversed a dollar slide. Gold prices gained. Initially, the dollar moved lower as trading opened in New York, continuing a trend based on a bearish U.S. economic outlook. Government reports released early in the session confirmed that deteriorating economic conditions are being accompanied by rising inflation. The Labor Department reported that the producer price index jumped 1.3 percent in August, due mostly to steep oil price increases. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. The figures didn't surprise financial markets but they added to a pile of pessimistic economic data. It is widely expected that the Federal Reserve Board will modify its monetary policy to revive growth. If the central bank pushes down interest rates, demand for dollars and dollar-based investments would decline. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan told a congressional committee Thursday the central bank would be inclined to ease policy if White House and congressional negotiators reach a credible agreement on cutting the budget deficit. Speculation about imminent Fed action intensified Friday when word circulated that a deficit accord could come over the weekend or early next week. But currency traders put aside their economic concerns when news broke that U.S. and Australian Navy ships had fired warning shots, halted and then boarded an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman. That news, plus earlier information about Iraqi troops breaking into the French Embassy residence in Kuwait City, spurred dollar purchases. Investors and speculators typically turn to dollars at times of international turmoil. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the dollar periodically has been bid up sharply. Robert Gruber, senior corporate trader at Chemical Bank, said U.S. trading was hectic and volatile before settling down, as it usually does on Fridays. He said once it became apparent that an actual shooting war wasn't breaking out in the Mideast, the dollar buying subsided. On foreign exchange markets abroad, the dollar lost ground against the Japanese yen and German mark but weakened vs, the British pound, as it did in New York. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 136.55 Japanese yen from 137.65 yen at Thursday's close. It was the lowest closing level since Aug. 3, 1989, when it was 136.40 yen. Later, in London, the dollar fell to 136.65 yen. But in New York the dollar ended dealings at 136.45 yen, up from 136.25 yen late Thursday. The British pound rose to $1.8980 from $1.8770 late Thursday. The pound climbed in New York also, ending the session at $1.8930 compared to $1.8825 late Thursday. Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late quotes Thursday, included: 1.5695 German marks, up from 1.5680; 1.2990 Swiss francs, down from 1.3025; 5.2565 French francs, up from 5.2520; 1,171.75 Italian lire, up from 1,170.00; and 1.16505 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16175. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's levels were: 1.5625 German marks, down from 1.5740; 1.2910 Swiss francs, down from 1.3130; 5.2305 French francs, down from 5.2710; 1.7605 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7740; 1,166.00 Italian lire, down from 1,174.00; and 1.1648 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1640. Gold prices posted minor increases. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for September delivery rose $2.20 to settle at $385.10. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $385.75 an ounce, $1.75 higher than Thursday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $385.25 a troy ounce from $384 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $385.00 from $383.40 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.52 to close at a bid of $384.34 an ounce. Silver prices moved lower. The metal fell on New York's Comex with the contract for September delivery closing at $4.750 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's settlement of $4.773. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $4.79 dollars a troy ounce from $4.82 late Thursday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices kept falling Friday, weighed down by new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 18.56 to 2,564.11, extending its loss for the week to 55.44 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 472 up, 1,008 down and 470 unchanged. The Labor Department reported that the producer price index of finished goods jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of sharp increases in energy prices. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped 0.6 percent. Neither of those figures came as a drastic surprise to Wall Street analysts, who have been busy since midsummer trying to estimate the possible fallout from the showdown in the Middle East and a doubling of world oil prices. Nevertheless, analysts said, the data served to reinforce fears of ``stagflation,'' a combination of sluggish growth and increased inflationary pressures. In that kind of climate, few market participants can see much reason for optimism about the outlook for corporate profits and dividends. Brokers also noted that stocks had to contend with rising oil prices in the commodity markets. Crude oil for October delivery climbed 69 cents a barrel to $31.76 on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid resurgent worries about the continuing showdown in the Persian Gulf. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included General Motors, down } at 37{; General Electric, down ~ at 59{; Digital Equipment, down 2~ at 56], and International Business Machines, down | at 104]. Bank stocks, which had a rocky weak amid persistent credit-crunch worries, turned in a mixed showing. Chemical Banking fell | to 20\, and Citicorp slipped [ to 17\, while J.P. Morgan rose { to 32| and BankAmerica was unchanged at 21}. Energy issues also finished mixed. Exxon gained | to 51]; Texaco added [ to 64{; Atlantic Richfield rose 1[ to 139~; Mobil dropped [ to 65{, and Chevron was down [ at 75~. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 133.39 million shares, against 123.37 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 159.71 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $17.05 billion, or 0.56 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.01 to 174.15. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.28 to 374.60, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 1.82 at 316.83. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 1.76 to 374.42. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 321.45, down .56.

DOC.HEAD: Vote on Fuel Economy Bill May be Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, Supporters contend, to UPDATE with Skinner comment. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `We've just. DELETES now-redundant grafs 8-9, The auto. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate cleared the way Friday for action on a bill that would require automakers to dramatically increase fuel economy. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he hoped to have a vote late next week on the bill that would require automakers to increase average fuel economy of new cars to 35 miles per gallon by 1995 and to 40 miles per gallon by 2001. Supporters contend the higher fuel economy requirements would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day once they go fully into effect, but key opponents promised to continue fighting the measure on the Senate floor. Within hours of the vote, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner blasted the legislation as ``unrealistic, irresponsible and, more important, unattainable.'' He said there's no technology to achieve the bill's goals without making cars smaller. ``It should be called the highway fatality bill,'' Skinner said at a news conference, citing a new study by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that concluded a clear link between reducing the size of cars and traffic deaths. The NHTSA study said the introduction of smaller cars over the past decade had resulted in an estimated 1,340 additional traffic deaths annually in single-car accidents. Based on those numbers, NHTSA Administrator Jerry Curry said between 600 and 1,140 additional deaths annually can be expected if automakers try to meet the 40 mile per gallon standard. Skinner said automakers had convinced him that the Senate bill's fuel economy goals can't be achieved without substantial weight reductions in cars. ``We've just had the first inning of this nine-inning game,'' Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., said after the Senate voted 68-28 to clear the way for debate. ``We hope and intend to win this fight,'' Riegle said, adding that he doubts supporters will get the needed 60 votes to cut off debate and bring it to a vote next week. A similar bill has been introduced in the House, but it has yet to be taken up by the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., is staunchly opposed to the measure. Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., sponsor of the House bill, said earlier this week she would try to push the legislation directly on the House floor in an effort to bypass Dingell's committee. But the Senate's 68-28 vote Friday to cut off efforts by Riegle to keep the measure off the Senate floor was an indication of the growing support in Congress for a measure to reduce U.S. reliance on foreign oil, a subject in the spotlight since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``It's the single most important step to reducing our dependency on OPEC oil and curbing global warming,'' the Sierra Club said of the bill sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev. In floor debate, Riegle said those fuel savings aren't likely to begin phasing in until 1995 and a better response to today's oil crisis might be to return to a national speed limit of 55 miles an hour. Later, a Riegle aide said the senator didn't necessarily support a change in the speed limit. Bryan described his bill as a message to Detroit and the automakers ``that they're going to have to look at fuel economy and not just muscle cars.'' ``It does not take a crystal ball to realize that if we don't start conserving now, some future president may have to consider sending our young men and woman back to the deserts of the Middle East,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Consolidates Merchandise Groups
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. announced the resignations of two retailing executives Friday in a further realignment of the merchandise division's management as part of efforts to reduce expenses. Under the realignment, officers in charge of the company's six merchandise categories will now report directly to retail President Laurence E. Cudmore. The changes follow a management shake-up last month in which Sears' board put Chairman Edward A. Brennan directly in charge of the Sears Merchandise Group, the nation's largest retailer. Brennan took the helm from Michael Bozic, formerly chairman and chief executive of the merchandise division. Bozic was reassigned to a new position as president of the group and assumed reponsibility for logistics and the group's catalog. ``We are eliminating a layer of management and consolidating certain corporate and merchandise group staff areas,'' Brennan said in a news release. Under the realignment, Matthew A. Howard, formerly senior vice president in charge of hard merchandise lines, will become senior vice president of marketing, replacing Thomas E. Morris, who resigned. Eric D. Saunders, formerly senior vice president of soft lines, will become vice president of the home fashions group, succeeding Jerry A. Hand, who also resigned. The company said Morris and Hand resigned to pursue other interests. Sears is seeking to cut costs to offset declining profits from its retail division. The company plans to review costs at all levels of management, Cudmore has said. An effort Sears began last year to preserve market share by revamping its merchandise strategy still hasn't borne fruit, according to retail analysts. Sears' double-pronged program involving the introduction of more national brands, from General Electric appliances to Pirelli tires, and a switch to an everyday low pricing policy appears to be sparking little buying enthusiasm among customers, analysts say.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Weekend Editions Sept 15-16
DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Portents: Neither Fair Nor Foul
DOC.TEXT: After the summer slide Wall Street has been through, many an investor might be tempted to go scavenging for ``bargains'' in the stock market. But even though stock prices have been marked down sharply, Wall Street analysts remain leery of pronouncing them cheap just yet. By most traditional measures, stocks are now well below the extremes of valuation they reached at past peaks. Most analysts agree that atmosphere of restrain lessens the chances of anything resembling a repeat of the crash of 1987, when the market lost more than a third of its value in a span of less than two months. At the same time, they say, readings on most of the gauges they monitor still stand well above the levels that showed up at market bottoms in the past. ``The world equity markets toward the end of August were very close to panic point, oversold extreme, selling climax or whatever you want to call it,'' said Barton Biggs at Morgan Stanley & Co. Still, Biggs added, measures of things like investor sentiment and market momentum ``are not yet at bear-market bottom extremes, and it will probably take at least a few more months for them to get there.'' One of the most common standards applied to market values is price-earnings ratios - a simple computation of how much investors are willing to pay for stocks in relation to the current annual earnings of the company or companies involved. P-E multiples for the various market averages and indexes recently have hovered in the 12.5 to 15 range - well below the readings of 20 or more that have been attained in past periods of exuberance, but still far from the single-digit lows of the 1970s and early 1980s. Similarly, dividend yields for stocks overall, in the area of 3.8 percent to 3.9 percent, are ``in the normal range and neutral,'' as described by Norman Fosback in the investment advisory letter Market Logic. A similar picture emerges from a comparison of stock prices among the issues in Standard & Poor's industrial index versus the corresponding companies' book value, or theoretical worth if those enterprises were to be liquidated and the proceeds distributed to shareholders. By the reckoning of Michael Metz and Norman Weinger at Oppenheimer & Co., the S&P industrials recently traded at around 250 percent of book value, down from 285 percent in August 1987. ``Whether the market is now cheap or dear depends to some extent on one's perspective and on comparisons with other assets, including debt instruments,'' Metz and Weinger report. ``Valuations still aren't bargains by historical standards. Mitigating this consideration, however, is the fact that the book value of many companies is now more conservatively stated due to the huge writeoffs of obsolete and underperforming assets in recent years.'' However attractive stocks' prices may have become, investors showed little appetite for them in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 55.44 to 2,564.11. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 3.36 to 174.15; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 5.96 to 374.42, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 2.32 at 321.45. Volume on the Big Board averaged 123.92 million shares a day, against 115.74 million the week before. Market barometers at neutral levels provide a little something for everyone, since forecasters can use them to support either a bullish or a bearish case. They can also be cited as a reason to sit tight. Concludes Standard & Poor's Corp. in its weekly publication ``The Outlook'': ``Although we'd maintain sound long-term holdings, conditions remain too unstable to justify bargain-hunting at this time.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Sept. 15-16

DOC.HEAD: Oil Crisis Gives Natural Gas Industry Some Extra Momentum
DOC.TEXT: As America feels increasing pangs from the latest oil crisis, the natural gas industry sees an opportunity to grow. Increased use of natural gas ``will keep us from sending the money over to Saddam Hussein and other Arabs,'' contended Robert A. Hefner III, a leading gas explorer from Oklahoma City. Supporters say natural gas is cheaper and cleaner, with a plentiful supply in North America that's free of supply disruptions caused by Mideast political strife. More than 90 percent of the gas used in this country is produced domestically, with most of the rest from Canada. While oil prices have shot up in chaotic trading since Iraq invaded Kuwait, pushing up the cost of gasoline and home heating oil, natural gas has moved up only in a predictable response to the coming cold season. With oil trading above $30 per barrel, the cost of an equivalant amount of natural gas, 6,000 cubic feet, is about $9. Natural gas now has about 24 percent of the energy market, and the American Gas Association has its sights set on a 28 percent market share by the year 2010. Uncertainty from the Iraqi invasion has prompted gas producers to push themselves even harder lately through advertising and lobbying. The AGA says some 20 new pipeline projects that now await regulatory approval could quickly cut the need for foreign oil by bringing more gas into three regions: the Northeast, Florida and California. The industry says demand for gas in those areas is greater than the current infrastructure can support. ``We could replace roughly 160,000 barrels a day within 60 days,'' said Michael German, senior vice president with AGA. ``We could displace 480,000 barrels a day within a year. We could displace 1.3 million barrels a day within five years.'' Energy Secretary James Watkins told the Senate Energy Committee on Thursday that the government would seek faster ways to cut through the red tape. Watkins, however, offered more modest figures for the amount of oil that could be replaced. He put the figure at 55,000 barrels per day by 1991, 300,000 barrels by 1992 and 600,000 barrels by 1994. There is also strong opposition to some proposed pipelines by local groups, who claim construction of the underground lines would damage the environment. Some are also afraid of leaks and accidents, although the industry claims transporting natural gas is safer than moving other kinds of fuel. Automobiles present another frontier for natural gas. It can power cars more cleanly and at about 70 cents per gallon, the industry says, compared to prices of more than $1.25 lately for a gallon of gasoline. But its limited use keeps startup costs high. At present, natural gas is being tried mostly by motor fleets in the United States, although some people envision the day when consumers will drive natural gas cars that are filled up overnight by machines set up in the garage. Hefner views natural gas as the logical successor to oil, the same way oil replaced coal as the fuel driving the nation this century. He would like to speed things along by imposing a $1 per gallon tax on gasoline to force consumers to pay the entire cost of their fuel. As he sees it, the government is propping up a dying oil industry though such multibillion-dollar acts as the deployment of troops to the Persian Gulf and the storage of crude in the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve. ``If the oil companies or the producers had to pay the bill to ensure the free flow of oil, they couldn't pay the bill,'' Hefner said. The AGA, however, is not ready to endorse a gasoline tax, although its members would benefit. ``It at least targets oil, which is an imported product,'' German said.

DOC.HEAD: Approves $1 Billion in New Loans
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank will loan Argentina $1 billion in coming months to aid the country's economic and social restructuring, a bank official said Friday. World Bank first vice president Moeen Qureshi said the loans will help finance reforming Argentina's state sector, reorder government relations with provinces and develop programs in the housing, health and public education. ``We hope that in the next six months we can bring forward at least some of these programs,'' Qureshi said. He did not specify precisely how the $1 billion would be spent or when. President Carlos Menem's 14-month-old government is selling state companies, paring public employment, curtailing subsidies, hiking public service rates and shutting down money-losing public banks. The government already has eliminated price and currency exchange controls, partially deregulated the oil industry, increased foreign currency reserves, narrowed the fiscal deficit and proposed to reform the tax code and make the Central Bank independent of the government. ``I think the turnaround they have made in the fiscal area is quite impressive,'' Qureshi said. In the process, however, social services have declined markedly. Schools operate sporadically because of boycotts by teachers demanding higher pay. Public hospitals barely have enough funds for food, let alone medicine. The austerity measures also have contributed to recession. Real wages have shrunk and tens of thousands of people have been thrown out of work, and are unlikely to find jobs in the private sector. Apart from the new $1 billion loan, Qureshi said the bank has approved $4.4 billion in loans to Argentina since 1961, and Argentina has repaid $1 billion. Another $1 billion has been approved but not disbursed, he said, and Argentina is in the process of repaying $2.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Advances on Mideast Tension
DOC.TEXT: The gold market remains sensitive to developments in the Middle East but to a lesser extent than in the early days of the conflict, analysts said Friday after gold posted modest gains amid unsettling news from the region. On other commodity markets Friday, crude oil futures rose; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $2.20 to $2.30 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September at $385.10 a troy ounce; silver was 2.3 cents to 3 cents lower with September at $4.75 a troy ounce. Gold rallied strongly at midday on news that American troops fired a warning shot at an Iraqi tanker and then boarded it briefly in the first instance of U.S. forces boarding an Iraqi ship. But the gains were quickly scaled back despite higher crude oil and lower stock prices, two factors that have tended to support gold during the 6-week-old conflict. Higher oil prices suggest the U.S. inflation level could rise, prompting investors to buy gold as an inflation hedge. ``To a certain degree, gold is divorcing itself from the action in crude,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in New York. Analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities said gold had responded ``very tepidly'' to Friday's 69 cents-a-barrel jump in crude oil prices. The Labor Department's report of a 1.3 percent rise in wholesale prices last month provided little support to inflation-sensitive gold, the analysts said, because the number was within expectations. Savaiko said gold is near the top of its recent trading range, which runs from about $370 to $390 an ounce, and some traders are reluctant to buy until the market shows it has enough strength to go above $390. He said gold also may have been held back by weakness in silver prices, a function of abundant supplies, and by selling linked to the expiration of October gold options. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil settled 30 cents to 69 cents higher with October at $31.76 a barrel; heating oil was .74 cent lower to .74 cent higher with October at 82.79 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 3 cents lower to .25 cent higher with October at 90.36 cents a gallon. Corn and wheat futures extended their losses on the Chicago Board of Trade while most soybean futures advanced, mostly in a continuing reaction to Wednesday's government crop report. The Agriculture Department report contained higher than expected estimates of 1990 U.S. corn and wheat production and predicted the nation's soybean stockpile would continue to dwindle. Joel Karlin, grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said wheat futures also were pressured by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's pledge to oppose an increase in crop set-aside acreage as a means of stemming a slide in wheat prices. Yeutter told a farmers group in Chicago that taking more crop acreage out of production would ultimately make the United States less competitive in the world market. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents to 4\ cents lower with September at $2.57 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1} cents lower with September at $2.32} a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent higher with September at $1.07 a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to 3{ cents higher with September at $6.24{ a bushel. Pork futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, boosted by higher than expected cash hog prices. Cattle futures ended mixed. Live cattle settled .23 cent lower to .35 cent higher with October at 78.62 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .13 cent to .55 cent higher with September at 88.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent to 1.25 cents higher with October at 51.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.43 cents to 1.65 cents higher with February at 54.65 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Wins Auction for Integrated Resources Unit; Expands Into Real Estate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf and ADDS 2 grafs with Icahn comment; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Carl Icahn, usually associated with bidding wars in takeover battles, won a bid of a different sort in an auction for a division of Integrated Resources Inc. Icahn won an auction in U.S. Bankruptcy Court here for American Property Investors, a real estate holding company of Integrated Resources. The takeover strategist bid $44 million for the company, topping a $43.5 million offer by investor Meshulam Riklis and other bidders. The purchase of American Property Investors represents an expansion into the real estate business for Icahn. He has other real estate properties, including Bayswater Realty, taken over in 1979 after a proxy fight, but heretofore has been more involved in corporate investment and takeover bids than real estate. ``We want to get into the real estate business in a large way,'' Icahn said in a telephone interview Friday. ``There might be a lot of good investments at this point. Everyone is selling and it might be a good time to buy.'' American Property Investors is the general partner and 10 percent owner of American Real Estate Partners L.P., which owns some 300 real estate properties. By buying the general partner, Icahn would have control over its properties. However, if he were to sell the assets, the lion's share of the proceeds - 90 percent - would go to other partners. The winning bid does not necessarily seal the deal. Icahn must still provide details of how he will finance the purchase, and Bankruptcy Court Judge Howard Buschman will consider objections to the sale by another losing bidder, Oppenheimer & Bigelow Income Fund I. However, Integrated Chairman Stephen Weinroth said in an interview Friday that Buschman told the parties ``he hasn't seen any compelling theories to hold up the transaction.'' The proceeds from the sale will go to Integrated, which is undergoing reorganization after filing for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in February. Integrated sought bankruptcy court protection after some of its creditors balked at restructuring more than $1.6 billion in debt. The company had tried to build a financial services empire with about $800 million in junk-bond financing provided by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., but was unable to meet the high interest payments due on the debt. Integrated's filing for bankruptcy court protection came within hours of Drexel's parent seeking the same protection. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, is best known for his takeover attempts, which included unsuccessful runs at Texaco Inc. and USX Corp. In May, he lost a ballot at the USX annual meeting calling on the steel and energy conglomerate to spin off its U.S. Steel subsidiary. But Icahn did not indicate he was getting out of investing in companies. ``I think there are some good corporate investments still,'' he said Friday, but added, ``I think there are some very good real estate investments.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped dollar sign in 3rd graf
DOC.HEAD: Diplomat Seizures in Kuwait Send Oil Prices Higher
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures bobbed up above $32 a barrel Friday, finishing a week of closes over $30, after Iraqi troops in Kuwait raided the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium and briefly seized several consuls. At one point, light sweet crude hit $32.20 a barrel, just 15 cents shy of its all-time high of $32.35 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders were also responding to news that pipeline capacity was being cut back in the North Sea and possibly in the Soviet Union. Crude settled 69 cents higher at $31.76 per barrel for October delivery, with other delivery months up across the board. Friday marked oil's seventh straight close above $30 per barrel. ``Some people are still anticipating a pull back,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``But it still looks like we are forming a base.'' Unleaded gasoline and home heating oil closed lower for near months, which trader Ed Kevelson of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. attributed to adequate supplies of those products on the cash market. Gasoline fell 3 cents to 90.36 cents per gallon for October delivery, while heating oil fell .69 cent to 82.79 cents per gallon for October delivery. Prices were higher for more distant months. Natural gas for October fell to $1.52 per 1,000 cubic feet, from $1.54 on Thursday. Other natural gas prices were mixed. The oil markets intially shot up Friday morning on news that Iraqi troops had stormed into the French ambassador's home in Kuwait, capturing the French military attache and three other French citizens. ``It was the first time Bagdad's occupying forces have seized anybody in a raid on the diplomatic community,'' said Brian Tagler, a Shearson broker. The military attache was later released, and although the fates of the other Frenchmen were not immediately known, the markets were calmed when President Bush said the tense situation did not appear to be moving any closer to armed conflict. Later in the day, crude moved back up on news that a Soviet pipeline might cut its capacity, Hittle said. Earlier, prices had been buoyed by news that a North Sea pipeline was cutting capacity by 15 percent. Kevelson said the rise in crude prices was also attributable in part to indications that the Saudis might be cutting back on their production of sweet crude. Sweet crude, with a low sulfur content, is best suited to U.S. refineries. ``You're stetting up for possible sweet crude shortages in the future,'' Kevelson said. Oil's record high of $32.35 on the Merc was set Aug. 2, 1983, and matched during the latest Persian Gulf crisis on Aug. 23.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Slide
DOC.TEXT: Treasury bond prices fell Friday as the market digested a mixture of good and bad news on interest rates and the economy, sending a key rate above 9 percent. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 19-32 point, or $5.94 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which moves inversely to the price, rose to 9.02 percent from 8.96 percent late Thursday. The 30-year, or ``long bond'' rate is an important economic indicator used to calculate some mortgage rates. In a report on inflation, which is the greatest concern of bondholders, the government said its producer price index rose 1.3 percent last month, a steep jump but in line with Wall Street's expectations. In other economic reports for August, the Federal Reserve said industrial production fell 0.2 percent and retail sales declined 0.6 percent. Both figures were poorer than economists expected, but are good for bonds, since signs of increasing economic trouble could prompt the Fed to ease interest rates. Lower rates benefit fixed-return investments such as bonds. Gib Clark, chief trader at Daiwa Securities Inc. in New York, said the bond market expects Fed easing is imminent. Meanwhile, signs of increasing tension in the Mideast sent oil prices higher. Crude for October delivery rose 69 cents a barrel to $31.76 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Increasing oil prices are a worry to bond investors because of their effect on inflation. Another negative for bonds was the rise in interest rates abroad, which makes U.S. investments less attractive, Clark said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell 1-32 point to 3-32 point, intermediate maturities lost \ point to ] point, and long-term issues fell as much as 19-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 2.71 to 1,142.95. Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 7.58 percent as the discount remained at 7.35 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.63 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.26 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.70 percent as the discount rose 2 basis points to 7.20 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7} percent, down from 7~ percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell [ point to 89 25-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.59 percent from 7.58 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Heileman Official Charged With Taking Kickbacks
DOC.TEXT: Two men were indicted for allegedly defrauding the G. Heileman Brewing Co. of hundreds of thousands of dollars in payments to a nonprofit sports marketing group in Chicago. The federal indictment names Joseph Monreal, 46, a former director of advertising and special events in Hispanic markets for Heileman, and Carlos Quintanilla, 32, a former executive director of now-defunct Operation Search. Monreal was accused of taking $135,090 in kickbacks from payments to affiliate the La Crosse, Wis.-based brewery with sporting events and other activities run by Operation Search between September 1983 and June 1987. Monreal was charged with three counts of mail fraud and interstate transportation of money taken by fraud, while Quintanilla was named in four counts. Both men pleaded innocent Thursday in U.S. District Court in Chicago. A third person involved in the alleged scheme was mentioned but not named in the indictment, which was returned by a grand jury last week. Monreal is a former president of the Milwaukee Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. He was named Hispanic Person of the Year in 1985 by the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce of Wisconsin. According to the indictment, Operation Search received $341,204 from Heileman after Monreal, Quintanilla and the third person created and submitted false and inflated requests for funding from the brewing company. It also charges that $10,090 was paid to each of two other agencies after the defendants forged signatures of officials of those agencies. According to the indictment, the defendants arranged for Heileman to sponsor a city softball competition that never took place and the purchase of $70,000 worth of baseball uniforms and equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Company's Attempt to Block Hearing
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday refused to grant an Italian company's request to block a Chicago Board of Trade hearing on the company's alleged manipulation of the soybean futures market. U.S. District Judge James Zagel's decision allows the Board of Trade to go ahead with a disciplinary hearing Monday on whether to ban the Ferruzzi Group from trading on the exchange. The company is accused of trying to corner the soybean futures market in July 1989. Ferruzzi said in asking the court to block the hearing that the exchange had a financial stake in finding the company at fault. A $30 million lawsuit filed by Ferruzzi seeking damages against the Board of Trade is still peding. That suit accuses the exchange of manipulating the market and conspiring to force prices lower when it issued an order forcing Ferruzzi to liquidate most of its soybean holdings. The Board of Trade could decide to fine Ferruzzi instead of banning the firm from trading on the exchange, said spokesman Mark Proust.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS information on American Airlines also raising fares in lede; EDITS to conform.
DOC.HEAD: USAir, American Raise Air Fares
DOC.TEXT: USAir and American Airlines on Friday announced a 4.2 percent fare increase for domestic flights effective Oct. 1, blaming the increase in higher fuel prices from the Persian Gulf crisis. With the announcements, the airlines join a growing group of carriers to impose a second increase in fares since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Delta Air Lines on Thursday announced a 4.2 percent increase, while Pan American World Airways and Alaska Air have also announced fare hikes, most to take effect Oct. 1. The increase comes on top of a 5.3 percent increase that nearly all domestic airlines imposed Aug. 30, due to higher jet fuel costs. USAir said the cost of jet fuel has periodically risen more than 30 cents per gallon above the average price of 58.5 cents per gallon in the second quarter of this year. Each 1 cent increase in fuel costs translates to $13 million in annual costs for the carrier, the company said.

Retail sales dropped 0.6 percent in August, the government said. Analysts said the first report on Americans' spending since the Persian Gulf crisis indicated growing consumer caution - but not panic. The Commerce Department said Friday that overall sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $149.2 billion, down from $150.0 billion in July and the largest decline since sales fell 1.0 percent in April. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Industrial production fell 0.2 percent in August, its worst performance in four months, the government said in a report analysts said was another indication the manufacturing economy remains locked in lethargy. The manufacturing economy had been sluggish long before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, growing a meager 1.5 percent over the last year, the Federal Reserve said Friday. --- WASHINTON (AP) - President Bush sent Congress a bill to forgive some Latin American debt and to encourage more U.S. companies to invest there. Aides said he also was readying a bill to allow the lowering of trade barriers with Mexico. The Mexican free-trade measure could be submitted as early as Monday, when administration trade officials testify before the House-Senate Joint Economic Committee, sources said Friday. Bush would like to have the authority to lower trade barriers with Mexico in hand when he meets with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in Mexico City in November. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A United Airlines workers group announced they were ending an agreement with an investment partnership to acquire the carrier's parent, UAL Corp. But in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, the worker group, United Employment Acquisition Corp., said it was still interested in acquiring the Chicago-based airline. The disclosure, which came after the markets had closed Friday, ended an agreement between UEAC and Condor Partners LP in April to help UEAC, a company formed by United's unions, acquire UAL. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate cleared the way for action on a bill that would require automakers to dramatically increase fuel economy. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Friday he hoped to have a vote late next week on the bill that would require automakers to increase average fuel economy of new cars to 35 miles per gallon by 1995 and to 40 mpg by 2001. Supporters contend the higher fuel economy requirements would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day once they are fully in effect, but key opponents promised to continue fighting the measure on the Senate floor. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The chairman of the House Banking Committee described some government sales of failed savings and loans in late 1988 as ``a giveaway'' and said many of the deals should be renegotiated. The Bush administration's top banking official said Friday that the government is considering ways to renegotiate some of the sale contracts but does not intend to break them. Investigators for the committee said in a report that outside investors in troubled thrifts received $78 in assets and government-granted benefits for every $1 of capital they put up to buy the institutions. --- LONDON (AP) - A dry summer and the Middle East crisis have driven Britain's annual inflation rate up to 10.6 percent, the highest rate in more than eight years, the government reported. The latest inflation rate, reported Friday, is 0.3 percentage points higher than the financial markets had expected, and is at its highest level since February 1982, when it stood at 11 percent. --- MOSCOW (AP) - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented to the national parliament an economic reform plan that proposes market-oriented policies and other measures to halt the nation's slide toward bankruptcy. But Gorbachev on Friday rejected the Russian parliament's conclusion that the solution to the economic crisis requires stripping the central government of much of its power. The Gorbachev plan refused to surrender the Kremlin's power to tax or give republics' laws superiority over national ones. Gorbachev's disagreement with the Russian parliament reduces hope of a national consensus by the Oct. 1 deadline set by the president. --- BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) - The World Bank will loan Argentina $1 billion in coming months to aid the country's economic and social restructuring, a bank official said. World Bank first vice president Moeen Qureshi said Friday the loans will help finance reforming Argentina's state sector, reorder government relations with provinces and develop programs in the housing, health and public education. ---

Stock prices kept falling Friday, weighed down by new signs of stepped-up inflation and weak consumer spending. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 18.56 to 2,564.11, extending its loss for the week to 55.44 points. The dollar finished modestly higher against most major foreign currencies. Treasury bond prices fell. Gold prices posted modest gains; crude oil futures rose; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Asks Bankruptcy Judge To Negate Union Back Pay Claim
DOC.TEXT: Striking bus drivers shouldn't benefit from a bankruptcy they caused, Greyhound Lines Inc. claimed Friday in asking a bankruptcy judge to move the union to the bottom of its list of creditors. In a complaint filed as part of its bankruptcy case, Greyhound attacked a multimillion-dollar claim for back pay sought by members of the Amalgamated Transit Union who went on strike March 2. Greyhound does not believe it will have to pay the strikers anything. But the carrier said Friday that if it does end up paying, the union members should have to get in line after the other creditors. ``The strike has injured the creditors of Greyhound and to that effect - because the tactics used by the union were violence, which is illegal - those tactics should not be able to benefit the union members ahead of the creditors,'' said Rosemary M. Collyer, an attorney for the company. The union has attempted to devalue Greyhound to the point it could buy the only nationwide intercity bus company, said Collyer, former general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board. The ATU will oppose Greyhound's complaint as it presses ahead with efforts to collect the back pay. ATU general counsel Earle Putnam said the back pay has been accumulating at between $2 million and $3 million a week since May 27, five days after the drivers offered to return to work. Greyhound has been operating with replacement drivers and union members who crossed the picket line. The company said that even if it loses, the back pay probably would not come to more than $8 million, based on a study of recent NLRB awards. Greyhound's complaint, filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Corpus Christi, is a move to erase the largest uncertainty it now faces. The company, which hopes to emerge from bankruptcy by mid-1991, has until Oct. 2 to file a reorganization plan, but has asked for an extension until Nov. 19. The size of the potential back pay claim has made devising a reorganization plan more difficult, so Greyhound's latest move attempts to negate and minimize it. An administrative law judge on Nov. 19 plans to hear testimony on an NLRB unfair labor practices charge that says Greyhound improperly hired replacements after the 6,300 bus drivers went on strike. If Greyhound loses that case, it could be liable for the back pay. Greyhound filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors on June 4, after failing to meet debt payments. Company spokesman George Gravley said the strike has cost Greyhound more than $50 million. Friday's filing by Greyhound accused the union of plotting to get in line ahead of other creditors. ``That's ludicrous on its face,'' Putnam said. Greyhound's complaint, and other documents compiled by the company, claim the union planned as early as last fall to drive the company into bankruptcy. ``Between Nov. 2, 1989 and March 1, 1990, the union ... planned and advocated a violent strike. ... to achieve the acquisition of Greyhound by the union. ... (or) to drive Greyhound into bankruptcy in order to obtain increased pay and other benefits ... at the expense of other creditors.'' The company has compiled a ``white paper'' and videotape on strike violence, using information uncovered in gathering evidence for a $30 million racketeering lawsuit filed in Florida against the union and some of its leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Reportedly Planning Pullout From Project With AT&T
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with AT&T spokesman denying that Philips stake was sold to Spain's telephone network, and to ADD material from f0153, BC-Spain-AT&T-Telefonica.
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch electronics giant N.V. Philips refused to comment Friday on a report that it was pulling out of a multimillion-dollar telecommunications project with AT&T. Het Financieele Dagblad, an authoritative Dutch business newspaper, said Philips is planning to sell its 15 percent stake in AT&T Network Systems International, which develops and manufactures public telephone exchanges. A Philips spokesman refused to comment on the report, saying the company would make an announcement only if and when it saw fit. An American Telephone & Telegraph Co. spokesman in the United States, Tom Harris, also said he had no comment on the report. The newspaper added that Philips would limit itself after the pullout to making only industrial telecommunications equipment, including corporate switchboards. Philips' share in the project with AT&T was estimated by the newspaper at $100 million. That would place the total worth of the joint venture at $666 million. The report said AT&T would absorb 9 percent of Philips' share, while 6 percent would be taken over by Telefonica SA, a Spanish telecommunications company. But Harris, the AT&T spokesman, said that report was incorrect. Though Telefonica announced Friday it was buying a 6 percent stake in AT&T Network Systems International, he said that stake came out of AT&T's share in the venture. After the Telefonica transaction, AT&T will own 59 percent of the venture, down from 65 percent, Harris said. Italy's state-controlled STET owns the other 15 percent. AT&T NSI, the U.S. company's main European operation, produces software and hardware products for most of Europe's public telecommunications networks. At a special shareholders meeting in July, Philips announced it was beginning a major restructuring to streamline its operations. The announcement followed unexpectedly low first-quarter profit of $3.4 million, down from $126 million in the first quarter last year. Philips President Jan Timmer warned at the meeting to expect more than $1 billion in losses and up to 10,000 layoffs. Timmer was appointed last May in a widely publicized boardroom reshuffle and is reputed to be a ruthless cost-cutter. Philips, which began as a small light bulb factory, has grown to be one of the world's biggest manufacturers of consumer electronics, computers and other appliances, but has been facing fierce competition from Japanese companies. Meanwhile Friday, Telefonica said it had reached an agreement to take the 6 percent stake in AT&T NSI in exchange for its 20 percent share in a Spanish microchip company. In a joint statement, state-controlled Telefonica said it was swapping its 20 percent share in AT&T Microelectronica SA for the stake in Netherlands-based AT&T NSI. AT&T NSI will now own 100 percent of AT&T Microelectronica, which in 1985 built a $200 million custom microchip factory just north of Madrid. Telefonica President Candido Velazquez called the accord ``an important step in the growing process of internationalization of Telefonica, permitting us to directly participate in a European project like ATT NSI.'' AT&T President Robert Allen said the agreement ``permits us to widen our European perspectives and strengthen our position as a global company.'' Earlier Friday, AT&T Network Systems Espana presented a new, $100 million factory, which will provide 250,000 telephone lines to Telefonica through 1990 and 300,000 lines in 1991.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollars are Canadian unless otherwise noted
DOC.HEAD: Canadian Government Announces Oil Project
DOC.TEXT: Work on the Hibernia oil project off Newfoundland will start almost immediately, now that a formal deal has been struck to build the $5.2 billion ($4.5 billion U.S.) project, federal Energy Minister Jake Epp said Friday. ``This day has been a long time coming but few will have reason to doubt that it has been well worth the wait,'' Epp told a news conference. ``Today, a major milestone has been reached. Hibernia will bring jobs and economic diversification to Newfoundland and all of Canada.'' Companies estimate the Hibernia field has recoverable oil reserves of 525 million to 650 million barrels. Peak output will be about 110,000 barrels a day. The deal involving Ottawa, the province and a consortium of four companies led by Mobil Oil Canada is to be signed when the House of Commons resumes Sept. 24. A bill authorizing Ottawa's contribution of $2.7 billion ($2.3 billion U.S.) for Canada's largest oil project cannot be passed until then. The rest of the costs will be covered by the consortium and Newfoundland, which will also provide tax breaks during six years of construction. The project will create up to 6,000 jobs during contruction and about 1,100 during production. Mobil kicked off the project Friday by announcing the St. John's-based company Nodeco will construct the gigantic concrete underwater base that will hold up the rig platform about 190 miles southeast of St. John's. About $3 billion ($2.6 billion) worth of construction work will go to Canadian firms. Epp insisted the project - slated to start production in 1996 and last about 20 years - will be profitable, although some oil analysts doubt that claim. A senior Energy Department offical said Ottawa and Newfoundland each stand to make about $3.7 billion ($3.1 billion U.S.) if the price of oil averages $30 U.S. in current dollars over the life of production.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS details of Condor in 4th graf, The disclosure; ADDS two grafs of United Airlines reax in new 6-7th grafs.
DOC.HEAD: UAL Employees Split with Investor Group in Airline Acquisition
DOC.TEXT: A United Airlines workers group announced Friday they were ending an agreement with an investment partnership to acquire the carrier's parent, UAL Corp. But in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the worker group, United Employment Acquisition Corp., said it was still interested in acquiring the Chicago-based airline. ``In light of current market conditions and in order to maximize the flexibility of UEAC to pursue any appropriate transaction for the acquisition of UAL, UEAC and Condor Partners L.P. entered into the termination agreement dated as of Sept. 13, 1990,'' the filing stated. The disclosure, which came after the markets closed Friday, ended an agreement between UEAC and Condor, an affiliate of Coniston Partners, to help UEAC, a company formed by United's unions, acquire UAL. Coniston Partners is the largest shareholder of UAL. Last October, news of the collapse of an employee-management leveraged buyout of UAL prompted a 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. Officials at United Airlines refused to comment on Friday's announcement by the employee group. A representative at Coniston Partners called the move a ``non-event'' and a ``tactical move.'' They refused to comment further.

DOC.HEAD: Business Editors
DOC.TEXT: The FFF financial wire AMs report is now complete. Further updates to AM-Post Talks and AM-Auto Talks will appear on general news wires only.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
